For mains which were all price at £6.95, there was the sea bass fillet with crushed new potatoes and minted pesto, a rib eye steak served with shallot sauce and a Scottish salmon with sautéed spinach and lobster sauce.
We all had a great time soaking in the atmosphere and vibe. It can indeed be quite a romantic place. The food may not be outstanding but is decent and with those prices, reflects a good value. An unassuming place that might not reside in your memories for long but will be thought of fondly if this happens to be part of your local eaterie.

OK I know I'm going against the grain here but bear with me.  I went a couple of weeks ago for the first time with Lucy who raves about it so I had high expectations. A major bonus was the fact that due to volcanic activity (what else?), mutual friend's flight was seriously delayed so we arrived about 45mins after we had the table booked for.  There was no problem with this, despite the fact that it is nearly always fully-booked so that was great. Lucy noted that the prices had gone up since the last time she'd been, so while still cheap (7.45, specials of the day around 9 or 10 pounds), not as cheap as they used to be.  My starter was great, my steak was cooked to perfection but not of the highest quality as I was still chewing it over literally 10 minutes after Lucy and friend had finished. Not a good look! The sticky toffee pudding (a passion of mine) was a little dry and not as sticky as it should have been.
I thought I'd give it another go for boyfriend's birthday meal as everyone else seems to think it's amazing so I wondered if I'd gone on an off-night. 
Not so, sadly.  The maitre d' sat us, a waiter brought over some wine (complementary wine! How thoughtful!) but it wasn't ours and turned out to be the first of many errors of the evening.  After some time, the maitre d' took our order without writing it down (why do people do this? I've been a waitress and could NEVER remember orders without writing them down - it turns out that this guy couldn't either) so when the starters came, I got the soup I'd ordered, boyfriend got something he didn't.  It was replaced quickly though and we had complementary bread and butter to keep us going which is a plus. 
My soup was a disappointment though. French onion is another passion of mine but I make it far better than what I was given - watery, thin, with little flavour.  Boyfriend's poached pear with blue cheese was lovely though. 
Some 45 minutes after we had had our starter, I asked where our main courses were and they arrived soon after. I think 45 minutes is a very long time between courses and we were filling up on bread.
Anyway, for main I had pork belly which I'd expected to be a slice of meat layered with fat and with a nice chunk of crackling on top. Again, not so. It was a huge lump of tasty pork, not a scrap of crackling to be seen and not enough jus to counteract the dryness of the meat.  I ended up drinking so much water with it (I can't leave meat, an animal has died for this so I'm not wasting any of it!) that by the end of the meal I was absolutely full to bursting. So much meat and you only get vegetables / chips etc if you order them (1.95 on top) which presented another problem. I ordered a side salad (mixed leaves, 4 slices of cucumber with only the slightest hint of dressing, 1.95 seems very steep for that) while boyfriend ordered chips and a vegetable selection which it seems the maitre d' forgot.  When we reminded him, we were shortly presented a plate of beans, new potatoes and the oddest carrots which looked like they had been boiled, then left in a low oven for many hours so that all the water had been removed from them. Wrinkled, dehydrated and burnt around the edges. Very strange and not nice to eat! 
By the end of all that, I wasn't hungry for dessert which is just as well as it took another 20 minutes to get the bill.  
Not bad in that the whole thing was 35.00 for 2 people with a glass of wine and a beer but I wonder if we're all mistaking good value for cheap?
Let me know if I'm wrong, but I'm not charmed by Le Mercury.

Intimate, romantic, and delicious.  All the elements that define French cuisine.  Affordable is the one missing element Le Mercury adds to the formula.  I love the friendly waiters and will be back whenever I celebrate with my special one!

Wow! Now this is a rare find - gourmet quality for mainstream prices! I almost don't want to review this place so that people don't flood it, but I want them to continue doing their beautiful thing!
 We went here after a week in Dijon, where we were sickened by the high prices for relatively little quality. Coming back to London to find this awesome little place was such a contrast.
 We started off by only wanting main and perhaps dessert, but ended up having wine and all three courses! Every single course was amazing. I recommend this as one of my favourite places in Angel!

I love this place with absolutely all of my heart. Although the food probably only warrants a 4-star rating, I love this place enough to rate it a 5-star. Honest, unpretentious French food at ridiculous prices, a fantastic atmosphere, and decent wine - and on Upper St.

Hello new favourite restaurant!
 Seriously, is there nothing this place doesn't offer? When someone suggests a French restaurant, you immediately think it's going to be pricey, but this couldn't be further from the truth. All of the mains are under £7, desserts under £3.
 So what did we have? Well we shared a starter of Crayfish and Lobster ravioli which was yummy. really nice. I think we were both a bit annoyed that we didn't order one each.
 But the mains were ace too - it's not a huge selection, but it's a good one. I had duck breast on garlic mash with cabbage. It had a great sauce, although I can't remember what was in it. The mash was really too garlicky for my taste, but the duck was perfect. Yummy yummy yummy. We didn't get a side of veg with our meals, but we did spie roasted potatoes and green beans on a nother table and were instantly jealous. My friend's mushroom rissotto was yummy too. Dessert was a mascarpone cheesecake. YUMMY!
 There was nothing bad about this place, it's a gorgeous little find. We booked ahead, and we might have been lucky but it's not a bad idea. The service isn't the best, but my friends and i were catching up so we didn't really mind that they didn't take our order for a while - in fact I think they were waiting for us to shut up! In the meantime we ate all of the bread that they gave us. Freshest bread eve. The place is open very late (1am on weekdays, 2am on weekends) so you could even pop in after going to the cinema. It's a little further up Upper Street than the main drag, but that's a good thing. If I was just looking for somewhere to grab a bite to eat, I wouldn't have walked up this far. I'm so pleased I did!
 So one starter, one dessert and two very yummy mains, plus a couple of glasses of wine costs us £26. Very impressed indeed.
 Do come here! On a date, with friends, whatever. Just come here. We were in such a mood for all things French that we've booked the Eurostar to Paris next month! Doesn't get much better
Friendly service and delicious food.  And don't be put off if you walk in and it seems full, there are tables upstairs.  Will be back next time in the area for sure!

I love the simplicity of the prices of this place.  All appetizers, entrees and desserts are a set price.  Whether you get the duck or beef it is the same.  It is not Michelin star but the food is really good and the price is right.  French food and candle lights, just don't screw it up by saying something dumb and it is the recipe for a really good romantic date.

Whilest the French food here is amazing, their roasts weren't so hot. I had the beef roast and it was...meh. Not bad. Not good. Rather mediocre. If you're  coming to a french restaurant, don't eat the British food. Common sense I should have had then but now consider a learned lesson in my culinary adventures.

Reasonable quality food, hence the price.  If the credit crunch is hitting you hard then this a good place to take that special someone without having to spend too much.  It is pretty much always busy, maybe I am being too harsh on the food quality rating but I have been to many french restaurants and have had better, because I've paid more.  The starter was the best out of the three dishes, it was the mussels in white wine (not as fresh, but they were only £3.95).  The salmon was tasty with the lobster sauce but I was let down by the food's temperature, as if it had been left on the side for a bit before serving it.  Other than that, decent candle lit place with many tables cramped in a small-ish area but you will be surprised when you realize it is actually a three storey building.

Le Mercury is a great cheap and chic French restaurant situated on Upper Street. The prices really are unbelievable with starters beginning at just £3.95, mains at £6.50 and deserts at £2.95.
The crab and lobster ravioli or the calamari are two of my favourite starters although it is is difficult to choose from such a wide selection
It has a romantic feel and is certainly an ideal place for a date with food that is impressive but prices that won't break the bank. From the outside the dimmed lighting and minimalistic decor gives the impression of Le Mercury being an expensive snooty restaurant but it certainly is not.
Another great thing about Le Mercury is the very fast service- an added bonus when you're feeling hungry and watch the other diners tucking into their delicious meals.

This French restaurant has a wonderful philosophy of quick service, excellent food and at very reasonable rates. Its no wonder that its always packed - but you don't have to wait long for a table. The steak was the best I've had in a while, soft and tender with a shallot sauce. At only 6.50 pounds, it was an absolute bargain! Starters are also very good, and around 4 pounds each. A bottle of wine is pretty reasonable at 10.50 as well. 
The restaurant gives the atmosphere of an intimate high end eatery, and the dim lighting and soft candles save it from looking like a bistro. This is a perfect place to go for a pre-theater or cinema meal, as the fast service won't keep you waiting long for a great meal. The Creme Brulee is still a simple favorite that is on the menu. Have with an espresso for the perfect meal!

Le Mercury is a real gem. It's not very fancy, but it has loads of atmosphere with the lighting provided by candles in wine bottles and street lights coming through the windows. Things can get packed in pretty tight, so it's best to make a booking (even on a Monday night at 8pm we wouldn't have been able to get a table if we hadn't already reserved one).
 The food is quite good, even if the menu isn't terribly extensive. My sea bass was fantastic, nice a crispy on the outside but really moist on the inside. Their desserts are really nice too, but don't expect anything on the lighter side. But the portions are perfect, just enough to leave you feeling satisfied without feeling stuffed. And things are relatively cheap with three courses costing only about £15 (excluding drinks).
 It's a really good late night spot as well; they're open til 2, and they won't rush you if you want to sit around and chat after your meal. It can get a bit noisy in there, but still a good place to bring friends.

Adequate French restaurant in Angel. There are many to choose from but if you want something cheap then this is ok. You do get what you pay for though.
 On the standard menu starters are £3.95, mains £6.95 and desert £2.95. There are always specials as well with prices going up to £10. Salmon was nice, steak was gross.
 Service was prompt but disinterested & I wouldn't return. I did in fact leave without leaving a tip because our waiter gave a bit of a mad serial killer impression.
Great food and service is also good... decor a little drab these days.. still a favourite of mine though

I really like this restaurant. My boss put me on to it a couple of years back, and I have been numerous times since.
 The combination of good value with high quality food and a nice location / layout really make this worth going to.
 The menu is always varied and changes frequently. As I said, the great value makes it even better. You don't get massive portions, but more than enough to do the job. There is always a specials menu (no, not just the leftovers) which has some stunning dishes. Haven't had a bad dish yet!
 There are a few French restaurants in Angel, this being my second favourite. A very close second, mind

My favourite little restaurant in Islington. I almost want to be selfish and pretend I hate it so that it doesn't get any busier! But in the spirit of paying it forward - GO TO THE MERCURY!! 
It does get very busy so make sure you ring ahead.
Anyway, the food is unbelievably delicious, which is exacerbated by the excellent prices and good sized portions. I cannot say enough to recommend this restaurant. The candle light and the warm atmosphere all add that little extra special something.
I remember the lamb main course being particularly yummy, but the menu keeps changing and I haven't had a bad experience yet.

I went here with a french person and apparently it is incredibly authentic. The food was lovely (steak cooked to perfection) as was the wine. No problems with the service.
 It's in a very busy area so you will be lucky to find a seat, I definately recommend booking in advance.

I'm just going to second what everyone else is saying.  This place is cheap, and the food is good.  I'm not expecting food cooked to level of a good Parisian bistro, but for how much you have to pay, this place is amazing.  Gets super packed though, so make reservations at least a few days in advance.

Very unpretentious little place along Upper street. We casually popped in one evening. We had to wait a while, as the place was full and apparently, you are advised to make reservations. Considering the price level, my expecations were low, but I was positively overwhelmed. They keep a simple menu, reproduced in high volume, which is probably the recipe for success. Its not a top class French restaurant, but it is extremely good value for money.

Reasonable priced, quick service, nice atmosphere, decent food.  Within their price range, I cannot expect anything better.  All the tables have candles, the windows are lined with plants and other decorations.  The food wasn't anything amazing but you can tell some care went into the preparation and it surpassed expectations

I sit down and am promptly ignored until Meg comes in. The vibe is very French bistro and a bit like Lucien in NYC which used to be our favourite place for a mildly celebratory dinner so that's good. The restaurant is crowded but unlike a crowded NYC restaurant you aren't putting your elbows in your neighbour's soup.
 Tiny paper napkins and diner-standard flatware/glasses are all that's on the table. Meg arrives, we get the menus, and order drinks. We get glasses of tap water, which are never refilled, and a bottle of chenin blanc which turns out to be a 2008 from Long Beach winery in South Africa. This is a little sweet, but very nice - I like it a lot. The bread is pretty plain-jane white bread, but it has poppy seeds on the outside which make it better than expected.
 Meg has Tian au Crabe which is described on the menu as Tian of crab and avocado emulsion. What is a tian? We don't know which seems as good a reason as any to order it. It turns out to be something like crab salad. Meg seems to enjoy it.
 I have Chevre Chaud, grilled goat's cheese with fresh leaf salad and basil pesto. This is quite good although I think rather too heavy on the goat cheese and not heavy enough on the pesto as it's a little dry. The salad is nothing special and in fact I was hoping for more leaves. Weirdly, I guess, I'm asking for them to have more of the cheap ingredients in this dish.
 For mains, Meg gets Supreme de Poulet Roti - roast breast of chicken, garlic mash, green peppercorn. She seems to like it. I have Filet de Loup de Mer - sea bass with cauliflower puree, raisins, and chili lemon zest. Everything individually is good but they don't seem to go together that well.
 And that's it. We're tired, Meg seems to be coming down with something, so we skip out after just over an hour for under 40GBP. A great deal, convenient, decent food. We'll definitely be back.

Had passed this place a lot and never got around to calling in until one night when 6 of us decided to go for food and every where was absolutely packed out around here. With empty grumbling bellys we made it to a really busy looking La Mercury and luckily were able to get a table upstairs. We couldn't believe how cheap the food was, we got a set meal and the food was stunning. We were all well impressed and would definately head back soon.

You really can't fault Le Mercury for what it is. All starters are the same low price. All entrees are the same low price. And yes, all desserts are same low price as well. It's incredibly cheap, yet still tasty. Probably the best value for money you can find in the area. It does get quite crowded though, so call ahead and make a reservation. And also be prepared for it to be a tad noisy on the weekends, but certainly not overwhelming.

This is a friendly and inexpensive French eatrie perched on the corner of Upper St and Almeida street.In my opinion it has carved a good niche for itself in a market where there are hordes of over-priced and over-rated restaurants. The management has particularly laid back attitude towards customers and the food is inexpensive. Starters cost around 3.95 and main course around 6.45. A starter of gnocchi with butternut squash was light and delicious,the steak and chips was cooked just to right level and the banana shortcake with strawberries completed the meal nicely. It has pictures of Paris all over the walls and lit by candle light stuck in arty bottles.

Cannot recommend this place enough! Food... delicious. The staff was SO kind and helpful, it was clear they wanted us to enjoy ourselves and our food. We weren't sure what we wanted to order so they helped us each make decisions based on what we have liked in the past. I loved the butter chicken, two in our group got vegetarian dishes and loved them as well. The portions were also the perfect size, not too much and not too little.
As a side note, you should read the fine print on the menu, it had us cracking up. Start with reading the details under Garlic Naan.

Anurag was super excited about this place, having seen it on Andrew Zimmerman. I honestly really wanted to like this place. The place is very small and cramped, and the service was pretty poor. Even in the tiny place, the server didn't make eye contact and we had to flag him down several times. When the server did make his way to us, he was very bent on overselling dishes to us and had us over order, honestly. 
The food was very average. Other than the kaddu poori, which made me think about home (which was something we grew up eating), everything else was sub par. The naan/ roti was too hard and the Kadhai chicken was not great The daal was also very bland.
I don't know if we came at an off time, but our experience was sub par and I won't recommend it/ come back again.

I'm not going to lie, British food proper isn't much to write home about, but they've been smart enough to bring the best that the Empire had to offer back to London, and Punjab is a case in point. We were there pretty early (maybe 6ish?) on a random Tuesday, and had no issues getting a table for two as walk-ins, but they were steadily busy so your mileage may vary. 
Service was proper; friendly enough and efficient, and both our beverages and our food came out remarkably quickly. Additionally, we had no issues getting the check when we were ready to depart, which is a change of pace from most of continental Europe.
My colleague's Butter Chicken was excellent; flavorful and a touch spicy (or perhaps I've been eating bland German food for too long). Definitely a solid choice. However, we both agreed that the Pudina Ghosht (a mint lamb curry) was the real winner of the meal. I don't think I've ever had a mint curry before, and I'd order it again in a heartbeat. Spicy and packed with herbal flavors, but without the sometimes overpowering richness that comes from some of the more common curries (at least those that are common in the US). Absolutely fantastic!
One tip: the meals don't generally come with rice or naan, so make sure to order a side of them if you want them!

This place was amazing. This place was mentioned by guy fieti on a tv show, I'm glad I stopped by. Excellent service, amazing food, great prices. I suggest getting the garlic naan with whatever you order. Don't be afraid of the spicy dishes, they are manageable. I will come back here next time I'm in London.

Pujab has a separate menu for vegans and vegetarians to leverage when ordering. I ordered the gobi aloo with roti and really liked my dish overall. The cauliflower and potatoes were cooked and flavored very well. My only gripe is that I asked for my food to be cooked extra spicy and I felt like my entree was not spicy at all--huge let down. They brought some little peppers over so that I could eat them with my dish but I prefer spice to be cooked into my meal. I recommend they spice dishes they way their customers ask going forward.

Walk-ins seated via party size with larger parties seated first
Owner is out front, very charming
Service is fast, quick turnaround so the line goes fast
Extremely effecient service - they didn't get it wrong, it was probably you. ;)
Light takes on the heavy items were used to in the US.
Meats cooked very well-being even white meats came out tender
Nice sized portions. We were able to finish without being overly full
Interesting mix between friendly and brusquely efficient
Delicious flavors
Highly recommend
Wish we could've stayed for dessert
This place was much better than the other Indian restaurant we visited.   The chicken curry, curried lamb, and naan very very flavorful.  The service was impeccable.  On my list for when we return!

I LOVE Indian food and eat it almost weekly, so was excited to try some tikka masala in England. Came here since it seemed to be authentic and at a good price.
The service was great. Very prompt and accommodating. We started with samosas with a great dipping sauce.
We followed with the chicken tikka masala, mixed grill and garlic naan. I asked for the chicken tikka masala a touch under "Indian spicy" which is how I normally order it in the US (a 10 Indian spicy usually knocks me out haha!) Not sure if they assumed we couldn't handle their spice level because we are not Indian and from the US, but it was not spicy AT ALL. My boyfriends mixed grill was good, but he also requested a side of spicy tikka masala sauce and it was again not spicy at all. They quickly gave him a spicier sauce, madras, which was better, but still not nearly the spice we are used too.
To be clear, the food at its core is good!! However, we have found at many different types of restaurants in London that the spice level is just not what we are used to in the US. If you are an American craving spice, would just recommend asking for a much higher spice level here and really most places in London.

Punjab has created this Indian food Monster in me. I recently stop by their location in Covent Garden while on a trip in London and Oh my Gosh! 
It is a bit in the upper price but well worth for the quality of the ingredients, efficient service and definitely the location. 
We had the Lam Biryani £14.50 ($19), Saag Paneer £7.95 ($11), Chicken Tikka Masala £11.75 ($15.50), and Tandoori Lamb Seek Kebab £12 ($16) and obviously a serious overload of Naan bread £2.50 ($4)! 
Every dish was excellent, perfect mild spice to it. Creamy Saag Paneer and Tikka Masala. 
All these dishes just went perfectly with each other. 
And what would Indian food be without Raita?? It was so creamy, and fresh! 
Hopefully it is not too far away my next trip to UK so I can definitely touch heaven again!! 
Cheers!

Punjab is located on Neal St at Convert Garden area.  It's one of oldest Indian restaurant in London.  
We came here for lunch and arrived 5 mins before they opened.  However, there were few groups of people waiting in line.
We ordered more than enough for our last day lunch in London coz we really enjoyed authentic Indian cuisine in London.  
Samosas - It was just ok and taste didn't like fresh made. 
Naan - We liked it the sliced garlic on naan. 
Gobi Aloo - Cauliflower and potatoes lightly spiced and sautéed, it's good.
Chicken tandoori - Roasted chicken marinated in fresh yogurt and tandoori masala.  Chicken quite tender and moist, so delicious. 
King Prawn Bhuna - Jumbo prawns curry was excellent and just made us fell in love with curry.....
Overall, decent service and very reasonable price.  I would recommend to visitors (like us) and like to try causal Indian food.

The restaurant was recommended by a friend and when we arrived it was packed. Fortunately, we were able to find a table for 2. I looked for recommended items on the menu and ended up ordering the butter chicken-a Punjabi speciality. Well, when it arrived I took my first bite and  it was insanely spicy. To the managers credit he saw the face I made after that first bit and asked me if anything was wrong. I told him it was very very spicy. He then had the waiter bring me some yogurt to calm the spices down. if you love spice this is your dish. If not, stay away from it.

Good service, food is satisfying. I really wish they had traditional chai. The place is very conjugated. 
Serviceman are attentive but at times I feel rushed by them

Showed up without a reservation on a Thursday night.  Only had to wait a few minutes for a table for one, despite being a small line.  Ordered the Chicken Madras, garlic naan, and a Cobra beer.  Food was out in minutes.  Too hot to eat!  Chicken was spicy, and the naan awesome.  Both of those combined with a beer...AWESOME!  If you are seeing a show, and need a quick place to eat, this is it.   All around awesome!
Excellent vegan options. They offer a separate vegan menu from which I ordered gobi aloo with rice and samosa. Delicious!

Located in beautiful Covent Garden (aka the theatre district of London), Punjab remains true to its authenticity. Open since 1945, It's apparently the oldest North Indian restaurant in London. The decor inside is traditional with purple as it's predominant color. The seating is a bit cramped in here, as tables are quite close to each other. The food here is great. My family and I got the mango lassi, saag paneer, naan, tandoori chicken, lamb madras, and chicken madras. 
The mango lassi was creamy and fragrant. But, I still think it doesn't even compare to the mango lassi in Singapore, which was mind blowing. The saag paneer was less creamy compared to one I usually eat in Houston at Naseeb. But, I did appreciate the spinach flavor that's more predominant at Punjab. The tandoori chicken had a nice grilled flavor and was moist. It went well with their naan bread. Now, the best dish on their menu by far was their lamb or chicken madras. Strong curry flavor and spicy as hell! Thank goodness we had enough rice to calm the spice. I would definitely recommend eating this. 
I can't wait to come back to this restaurant whenever I visit London again. It would be a wonderful dinner choice before a theatre show close by. I'm sad I missed the Harry Potter and the Cursed Child play that was currently playing nearby when we were there.

The was the ONLY restaurant that was a repeat from our previous London trip.  We have been daydreaming about coming back since our first London trip 9 years ago. Reasonable price with fast and friendly service.  I wish I can have the naan bread and the chicken tika marsala again right now. I also appreciate how it's bright light inside so I can see and take pictures of my food.  The couple next to us both ordered a sizzling plate and it smelled great too! Will definitely come back if I'm lucky to visit London again.

Decent, best way to describe it. Service was good. But was initially a bit spotty. The food was average. Just average. Disappointed as I was told London was the place to eat Indian food. I am also fairly picky about my Indian cuisine and was so surprised at how average my food tasted. Oh well.
Amazing food and service- loved the EVERYTHING and worth any wait there is- right near covent garden- wow!

One of the best if not the best Indian meal
I have had. The shrimp tandoori were out of this world. #londonturist

I came here because of a recommendation from a friend in Los Angeles and thought my tastebuds were in for Nirvana.  The line out the door was a good sign, but sadly my hopes of finding Nirvana at Punjab was not so. I came here a couple times during my last trip to London hoping things would get better.  I did meet some nice people who shared a few of their dishes with me so I was able to taste more than I would have by myself - that's always nice!  There are some good things, but mostly I left with a poor taste in my mouth and bitterness in my heart. 
The service was consistently fair to middlen. Anytime someone comes to take your full order without suggesting appetizers or beverages it makes me feel like they want you in and out as fast as possible. Is this a fast-food joint?  No?  Then let me try to enjoy the experience you have to offer. 
I asked the server for suggestions since every chef has their specialty, but I didn't get any. "Whatever you feel like" doesn't sit well with me.
On my second and third visits I ordered different appetizers.  Each were very hot, tasty, fresh and perfectly seasoned with dipping sauce that add the right amount of "kick-ass" to your tastebuds.  The stuffed eggplant didn't seem to be stuffed with much of anything (it was cut down the middle and roasted), but I could eat roasted eggplant any day of the week and be perfectly content. 
The chicken Korma was like puréed baby food without any of the flavor or spices you might expect. No cashews, raisins, or any other seasonings you'd normally latch onto to please your palate.  Such a disappointing dish. They wouldn't let me order it "spicy."  I was also told that people have nut allergies, so I guess I can't have nuts at Punjab either!  I realize there are different styles of cooking, especially when it comes to south Asian cuisine, but I didn't enjoy the bland nature of this dish which I generally love and call "my favorite" at other restaurants. 
Here is what upset me the most and left bitterness in my heart:  I had already experienced different dishes throughout my stay in London at Punjab with a variety of meats, but on my last night I ordered a different chicken dish (my cardiologist would like this).  When I tasted the dish my tastebuds said "baa baa baa" and not "cluck cluck cluck."  It was lamb, again. I love lamb so I ate it anyhow and didn't complain, but as I was leaving the restaurant one of the owners said, "I saw that you ordered chicken, but I switched it to lamb because lamb is better."  I don't mind a prefix menu if that's what I'm ordering, but intentionally changing my order and NOT telling me is WRONG. If you want me to try something different, then give me a taste and don't force your opinions on me.  I was consistently asking the servers for suggestions and they wouldn't give me any!  I already had plenty of lamb at Punjab and wasn't in the mood for more, but I ate it, again. 
How would you feel if you ordered a cucumber sandwich and the chef said, "I saw you ordered a cucumber sandwich, but what you really wanted was a BLT so I changed it...oh, and you're still paying me for it."  
I'm generous with two stars.

As tourist at London, we wanted to taste authentic Indian cuisine since all my good friends told me that the Indian food in London is better than that of native food at India. When we stopped at Trafalgar Square which is 10 minuets walk to the restaurant, it's time to try this one. The lamb biryani was very good, chicken tikka masala was good too, less tasteful than I expected, curry lamb was tender and tasty. Decent quality and portion. The service was fast and courteous, environment was casual.

Some might erroneously call me unadventurous for never straying from my order of chicken tikka masala at an Indian restaurant. Others might correctly recognize that I simply wanted to honor "a true British national dish" (shout out to you, former British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook) in one of the world's most multicultural cities.
Dishoom is definitely the more popular Indian restaurant in London, but I didn't want to risk having to wait for a table. Punjab fit the bill perfectly. We were promptly seated and ordered chicken tikka masala, butter chicken, garlic naan, and rice. The garlic naan was so good that it has now ruined all other kinds of naan for me. Both of our curry dishes included succulent, juicy chicken. While the butter chicken was extremely flavorful, I wish we would've gotten a vegetable dish instead because it started tasting a little repetitive. 
If you're torn between Punjab and the Dishoom in Covent Garden a few blocks from Leicester Square (even if you're already in line for Dishoom), don't hesitate to give Punjab a try. The decor here looks a bit traditional and outdated compared to Dishoom's trendy atmosphere, but you can't go wrong with the curry at Punjab.

This was reputed to be the best Indian food in London but I don't think it is. Interesting photography on the wall - enough to give it one more star. It was good but not great. It's in the West End and a fun location. I'm waiting for a truly great Indian food in England. Any suggestions?

I LOVE Indian food and was excited to try this restaurant. I always order Chicken Tikka Masala at new places so that I can find out how it ranks to my favorite places. The dish was not very good so unfortunately I will not be back!

Must try Gazar Halwa!
For an Indian and especially Punjabi, this is definitely a historic place. First Indian restaurant in London. Authentic old era building feeling and beautiful neighborhood. In SOHO close to oxford st, and many other London attractions
No long wait times even on Saturday. Welcoming staff and interior with history. Nice clean and good presentation. Good music and not loud.
Probably not good for kids as space is little congested.
Ordered Chana masala, dal makhani, tandoori roti and gazar halwa
Ratings
Chana Masala 4.5 I hope it was slightly less tangy. Good balance of spices
Dal Makhani 4 Spices delicately balanced but I felt some Masala was missing maybe because couldn't taste ginger and garlic.
Tandoor Roti 4 was not crispy
Gazar Halwa 5 SUPER DELICIOUS
Service 5
Overall 4
They accept AmEX (not a big deal but important for business travelers)

We arrived for dinner about 5:30 pm on a Saturday after taking in a 2:30 show in West End. The place was already busy but we were seated promptly. It filled up shortly after we arrived. We selected Punjab because it was highly rated on Yelp and once again Yelp was right!!
I don't eat a lot of Indian food, but this is the best I can remember. Our amazing appetizer was Kandu Puru, the pumpkin bread. Our courses were Acharri Murgha (chicken curry) and Methi Gosht (lamb curry). Both were exceptionally prepared, tender meats and truly delicious sauces. We accompanied it with cheers naan which was also delicious. My favorite of the dishes was the chicken curry. The menu states "has to be experienced once in a lifetime" and I'm glad I experienced it!
Service was fast and extremely friendly and attentive. Highly recommend!!

We were looking to go to Dishoom, but the darned place always had a 90 minute wait, and I wasn't planning on standing in a line outside in the cold weather (yes, that's what they make you do in many of the  UK restaurants!), so we came here. 
Even though we were here at 9:30P on a Thursday night there was still a 10-15 min wait. The service was generally very friendly, especially the hosts. 
The food was a bit of a hit/miss. Excellent butter chicken and Chole, and pretty good tandoori chicken. Very mediocre lamb biryani. Lots of meat but the flavor wasn't particularly good. Chicken tikka masala was okay and the naan was ok.

Our experience was not a bad one... but when you're eating Indian in London man do you have a lot of competition so at this point the food needs to be damn good in order to have a high rating. The service was very good and the wait was not too long on a Saturday evening- maybe 15 minutes. 
Samosas were alright (I feel bitchy saying meh), and the prawn puri and king prawn bunha were also ok. They were slightly disappointing from flavour and temperature. Keep in mind that I've become snobbish when it comes to Indian food in London at this point. I did, however, love the cheesy naan. It's a very subtle light cheese inside the naan and adds a beautiful creamy and fluffiness. It's a nice Indian restaurant in a very good location but you can find much better (and much worse) elsewhere.

Had a wonderful meal here on a stopover in London. It was recommended by a friend and I'm so glad we stopped in! Very easy location and excellent staff who were very attentive but laid back to let you eat as well. Kid friendly too!
The pakora were crispy and wonderful. My husband had a chicken dish that came in a sizzling fajita like platter that was pretty awesome and I had the chole which was just enough spice and super flavourful. It wasn't spicy to cover up blandness but just enhanced all the ingredients. 
We overheard another couple talking about gluten-free options and they were being more than accommodating which is great to hear. Reasonably priced too, we defintely will consider visiting again next time we are in London.
Great food and service.  Their menu has some bold font items that are specialties.  They are awesome!  Affordable food. Popular and a good location. Happy we made this stop!!!

The food is delicious especially their bullet Naan 
I enjoyed the malai kofta more than the paneer entree! While The Samosas were good!

My family and I were in London for the first time in March. Did you know the national dish of England is Chicken Tikka Masala? It's a long story, but google it sometime. So, we had to order just that with some curry as well. They were fantastic as were the appetizers and side sauces. They even served us a complimentary sparkly dessert custard! Everything was delicious and the staff were so nice. Quick services too!
Amazing cuisine and even better service. Chicken Tikka Masala and Acharri Ghost was fantastic. Make sure you get the Bullet Naan if you're into spice. Santana is the best!

Punjab was great! There was a line to get in and we were seated very quickly. Good selection of traditional Indian food and beers. We had the Paneer Pakora to start which we didn't love but it was still nice, think pakora generally goes better with a lighter batter. The aloo gobi was amazing, perfectly spicy and lots of flavour! The Tikka Masala tased awesome but not as creamy as usually get more like a tomato curry than creamy tikka masala. Overall the service was great and really enjoyed our food!
I had thd samosa and chicken curry.  It was delicious along witn indian beer.  Servers were very friendly Prices are fair. The restaurant itself could use some updating, thus not a 5 star review.

Awesome. We tried another restaurant that had super long lines. We happened to be walking by some locals who said that line is ridiculous. Especially since the food is better. We walked with them and were very happy we did.

Ok I first have to say that this review is 1 year old lol. That alone should tell you how much I loved this restaurant, I still think about it all the time! I went to this restaurant last year when visiting London and out of my whole trip my absolute favorite meal was eaten here!!! Their butter chicken!!! It was so delicious I cannot speak highly enough about it! Peshwari naan did not disappoint either. And the mango lassi! Everything was so amazing I seriously enjoyed it so much!! If I am ever in London again this is a MUST go. Service and decor were great as well. Love this restaurant so much and wish they had one in California!
Tried to get into dishoom but was 2.5 hr wait.  This was a great 2nd choice.  Just 10min wait, food was great as was the service.

This review is a bit dated but ended up coming here again for my second trip.  The inside is very clean and gives a sense of coziness. You can easily tell that many locals come to this location and for good reason. The staff are very pleasant and the food was okay but just what I needed. I wished it had a bit more spice to the Chicken Tikka and Jalfrezi but that's possibly due to me comparing what I eat back home in Los Angeles. Overall, it was a pleasant experience.

Walked over to Punjab absolutely starving after trying to check out another restaurant in the area and I'm so glad we did. Walked in and we were warmly greeted by the team at the door and also saw there was a great variation of ethnicities as far as diners which is a good indication that this was going to be a great experience. 
One of the guys came over, took my friend's jacket and placed it on the chair - truly gentleman move right there and asked if we needed some suggestions for a great meal. We asked for time to review the menu, made our selections and anxiously anticipated our food to come. Out first, they bring you a gratuitous aperitif - a thin and crispy flatbread with four salsas/salads - mango puree, onion/tomato/cucumber diced salad, this delish apple/mint chutney mix and some type of spicy pickles I think (forgot to try that though). 
We ordered an app of ground lamb and lentils formed into patties and OMG - this is patty heaven! The rest of the meal consisted of saag paneer And chicken tika masala - all absolutely divine! My soul says too bad I dont live here but my waistline is grateful! Excellent job all around!

We came to this restaurant after reading Yelp reviews. Arrived at about 6:30pm, one party ahead of us. Despite seeing several open tables we were told to wait, and took about 20 minutes to seat the 3 of us. The ambience was good, and the food aroma was inviting. We ordered buttered chicken which consisted of two medium sized pieces of chicken that was covered with the yellow spiced curry, but dry on the inside. We also ordered the goat tandoori which came in 4 kebabs, well seasoned but very salty. Also ordered buttered naan and sweet naan, both just okay. The service was definitely a low light, had to ask for water 3 times, and they never came by to refill. The bill came quickly though, and surprised to find they already added tip. Overall not impressed with the food, bad service, definitely not recommended and would not come back.

I knew while I was in London that I had to eat some Indian food. After spending a full day at Warner Brothers Studio we went to Yelp for suggestions. Punjab had the highest stars with the most reviews, most places had under 50. We arrived around 7:30-8p on a Monday night and the restaurant was fairly crowded. We put our names in and waited about 10 minutes before being seated. Our waiter was friendly and personable, he made suggestions that we gladly took. 
We ordered:  Tikka Masala, butter chicken, saag paneer, gobi aloo, and acharri gosht lamb, cheese naan and rice. We definitely ordered too much food. My friend also ordered samosas as an appetizer for herself. 
Samosas: my friend loved them, they were hearty and the pastry they were cooked in had just the right amount of flaky texture to it. She wasn't a fan of the mint chutney she ordered with them and I tasted it and was also underwhelmed. 
Tikka masala: delicious. The chicken was juicy and tender and the sauce was rich and creamy. I wish it had a little bit more spice 
Butter chicken: the sauce was AMAZING. I couldn't stop dipping the naan in it. It was the right amount of spice and so flavorful. The chicken also was cooked wonderfully and fell off the bone. 
Lamb dish: delicious. Flavorful and juicy. I only had a small amount of this but my friend was in love. 
Saag paneer: was good, not great. Would probably pass on this dish if I came again. 
Gobi aloo: my boyfriend loved it. I didn't try any. He said it was the best he's had. 
Cheese naan: cheese and bread are the perfect pairing. This didn't disappoint. 
The flavors of the food and the service definitely makes me want to visit this restaurant again if I'm ever in London. It's the oldest Indian food restaurant in the city!
Great food and ambiance in a very busy street with lots of choices. Recommend stopping here first
Awesome atmosphere. Quick wait outside. They keep things moving. Very clean, and great attention to detail. Food was excellent. Highly recommend

Had lunch with my husband at Punjab today...
Ambiance was nice enough and the restaurant was about 1/3 full on a Wednesday afternoon at 2pm.
Service isn't friendly AT ALL ... not sure why? 
Food was pretty good but the biggest problem was that the spice level was pretty intense. If my mouth hadn't been on fire the whole time I was eating I surely would have enjoyed the chole, the bhindi, and the aloo gobi much more. The rice and naan were good (no spice obviously).
Prices are quite reasonable.
Overall I just wish the food wasn't so spicy! If we could somehow get mild food we'd definitely return.

Simply amazing. Cannot say enough good things about quite possibly the best meal, and hands down the best Indian cuisine I have ever tasted.
We ordered off the vegetarian menu. The paneer and dhal lentils were to die for. Our group left nothing to spare - it was all so good.
Our servers were attentive and hospitable (amazing!) and our group was even able to chat with the owner before we were seated, and as we were leaving. A very nice man with a lot to be proud of! 
I will remember this meal forever. Thank you Punjab!

What a great place! We are visiting from Los Angeles, and saw results on Yelp. We knew we had to have curry at some point during our trip, and we weren't disappointed. 
Even without reservations, we were quickly ushered to a table and food came our perfectly -- savory, flavorful, and delicious! We ordered the pumpkin on bread, butter chicken (savory as it should be , not sweet), methi gosht (might not be spelling this correctly!), bullet naan (garlic and chilis! Heaven!!), aloo paratha, and butter naan. This was enough for dinner and some leftovers for tomorrow :) Besides that, the owner and staff are wonderful -- friendly and good-natured. 
Definitely recommend this place!
Really delicious authentic Indian food. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys this type of cuisine. And I will visit any time I'm in London.
Excellent Indian food in London.  One of our children does not like Indian food. But even she greatly enjoyed the lentils, samosas, and other items. We had a blast at this nice restaurant.

Overpriced. Below average food. The taste is blended.
Not very attentive service, server seemed annoyed after couple questions about the menu from us.
Seems a lot of people come here for pre show dinner only, most of them finished meal really fast.
One positive star is their interior design is quite nice.

Punjab has been highly recommended by so many travel articles including Condé Nast Traveler. So naturally I had to try this place out! My sister and I absolutely loved their delicious, fragrant dishes. My favorite dishes were their Chicken Tikka Masala and Grandad's Kali Daal! These dishes were so powerful in flavor. You won't be disappointed with these two! Service was excellent. Would recommend this place to anyone visiting London! Can't wait to come back!
We loved Punjab!! The food was excellent and service was fast and very friendly. We had the Acharri Gosht and loved it!

Had the itch for some Indian food, after searching for a few in the London area, I found this. I made my way from the hotel which was a quick 10 minutes via Uber, arrived and was quickly seated.
The waiter took my order, I ordered a plate that I will do it some justice and won't even attempt to name it because I asked the waiter for something he would recommend and I believe it was curry lamb. I told me what the name of the plate was but I'll be honest, it flew past my head, all I know is that the plate came with naan, some rice, and the lamb in some orange curry sauce.
I loved it, the food was really good, the service quick and the cost wasn't too bad, for dessert I had some mango kulfi which was also delicious.

My wife and I have a tradition where we go to the Punjab before going to see a West End show. We get here at 6, and we leave with plenty of time to get to the theatre before curtain up.
The food is always great, and the staff are extremely welcoming. It's no wonder this in the the UK's oldest North Indian restaurant.

After walking around London by myself for hours, I stopped in at Punjab for lunch. The staff was polite and prompt, and the food was delicious. I got the acharri gosht (lamb curry) with garlic naan. The naan was thinner than what I'm used to, but whatever. The location is nice too--lots of shops nearby and close to the British Museum.

This was a really great restaurant. They only take a handful of reservations ahead of time, but when I called they said that 50% of their tables are available for walk ins. We arrived on a Thursday and got in within a few mins. The food was sooooooo yummy. Loved the vegetable kofta and chicken tikka masala. The dal was very good too and the garlic naan made things really complete. The service was attentive and kept things going. Would highly recommend coming here for quality Indian eats!
Holy smoke this place crazy good. Top notch INDIAN right in the middle of the theatre district. You gotta go!

Fab Punjabi food I loved the food and service and hospitality my first visit to London from California 
Great owner, his name is Amrit , fantastic personal touch

The food was amazing! Excellent customer service. 
Authentic Quality.  Really enjoyed the environment.

I saw this restaurant on one of Guy Fieri's show and have been wanting to visit for a while. It was such a pleasant experience! The staff was great and attentive but not over the top. The food speaks for itself! The chicken tikka masala was so flavorful and the chicken was so tender. The samosas were crispy on the outside and jam packed with goodness inside - a bit on the spicy side, so be careful if you're not into spicy food. The lamb shami kebab was on point! The accompanying sauce was minty and citrusy all at once and really brought out the flavors of the lamb patties. 
I'll be dreaming of this place for years to come!

AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS FOOD! I happened to come across this place whilst on a walking tour of London and I'm very glad I did as it did not disappoint! The chicken tikka masala has moist, tender cuts of chicken in a delicious and not overly greasy curry sauce. The garlic naan was in fact coated with just the right amount of garlic flavoring and was not burnt or overly crisp. The mango lassi which I also tried was also delicious and not too sweet. Every item I tried was on point! Also, the staff was friendly and attentive! I would definitely come back the next time I'm in London!

This was such a delicious meal! We popped in on our way to see Matilda. We had the bullet naan (pretty spicy), chicken biryani, samosas, and a fried fish appetizer that I can't remember the name of. Yum!

Really delicious Punjabi Indian food in London! On my one week trip to London this past week we looked for Indian food since we heard that it's your best bet at good food in London (otherwise notorious for having shitty food).
The restaurant itself was packed on a Friday night around 8pm, but luckily there was barely any wait (10 min or so). I ordered the Lamb Madras since it was the only item under lamb labeled "hot/spicy". It was SUCH tender lamb - I was actually surprised but it may be the most tender lamb I've had at any Indian restaurant. The sauce was spicy enough, 7/10 on my spicy level scale (I love spicy food for reference). The curry flavor was really yummy, packed with just enough spices for that kick. My friend ordered one of their tandoori chicken dishes and I was equally surprised by how juicy the chicken pieces were (they didn't come with bone, so that's even more surprising). They poured a shot of (alcohol) on her chicken tandoori sizzling plate and lit it up with a match - the fire was HUGE so be wary of your hair! The mango lassi drink was perfect and not too sweet. The only letdown was the appetizer - we ordered the prawn puri and it came with SUCH tiny shrimp (def not prawn....). Skip that appetizer!
Overall - food was delicious, portions a bit small for the price (approx 20 pounds per person) as we had no leftovers. I'm usually almost always left with leftovers at Indian restaurants in the States...
If I'm back in London I'll be sure to visit Punjab again :)

For the prices we expected high quality. If not from the food at least from the service. However, our main waiter was rude and made us feel like he might spit in our food. The samosas were greasy and lacking flavor, the paneer pakora had been sitting in it's old greese and then reheated. Then the main course arrived and the rice was soggy, which is a sure sign of a bad Indian restaurant.  The kitchen should never have allowed it to come out. We had a Dahl and chickpea curry.  The chickpea curry was good but the dahl was barley editable. Had this been a 20 pound meal we still would have been disappointed but at 60 pounds it was offensive.

What I Ordered: Chicken Tikka Masala, Saag Paneer, Samosas and Naan
Flavor: This was probably the best Chicken Tikka Masala I've ever had.  I've heard this is one of, if not the first place to serve the dish so if you come here, definitely get that.
Service:  Pretty attentive.
Atmosphere: Nice traditional old school Indian restaurant decor and music.
Price: Good for the quality.
Location: Great location.  In walking distance from the West End and Picadilly Circus.  So a nice pre-show meal if you plan on seeing any plays.
Other Comments:  I would definitely come back here.

I went here on my only night free in London based on other yelp reviews, and was not disappointed. I do not normally seek out Indian food on my trips, but the reviews were fantastic and again it did not disappoint. I wish I could tell you what me and my guest ordered, but we ordered a lamb curry dish and a chicken curry dish based on the suggestion of the waiter or manager. We had naan bread, and white rice, and the local beers Again, I wish I could say more about the dishes other than the spices were perfect, medium was just right, and the atmosphere was fantastic. It felt very much like a local, cozy place to eat for locals. I would highly recommend to anyone..

If I could I would give them 20 stars.
The food the service is great here.
Nothing goes wrong feel free to order whatever you like. The spicy naan was my favorite. Chicken beryani was outstanding.
I would go back again when I am back in London.

This is the first Indian restaurant in London's history. The menu is quite extensive and there are some unique items that aren't found in majority of restaurants. The food was quite good, but after going to Dishoom a few nights before I felt this restaurant was a bit of a let down based on the standards of Dishoom. The owners and staff were very helpful and took time to talk to us.

This is an awesome place to get Indian food when you're in London. Very home style cooking. Usually not too long a wait to get a table. Not a fancy place. The naan wasn't great but the food is very good. Good stop if you're in the area.

I came to London from Germany looking for good Indian food-- this place was the best. The food was near authentic and their chai tea was so good.
We had chicken vindaloo and the shrimp curry-- with some rice and naan. Amazing!

Food: Meh. Ordered chicken tikka masala, chicken curry, naan, garlic naan, and basmatic rice. So, I thought chicken ticken masala was tandoori chicken in a tomato cream sauce. Well, this was very dry chicken breast that was never tandoori chicken in a pretty good tomato cream sauce. Like I said, meh. But basmatic rice and naan was really good.
Service: Good. But who cares if the food is meh.
Atmosphere: Clean, classy, formal.
Visited on 20 June 2017.

Great food! The chicken tikka Masala is different than I've had at other places. But it's a great difference. It was so tasty. Probably the best I have ever had! Service was also great. One thing both my wife and I noticed is that the staff here is so very nice, warm and welcoming. They even saw a homeless woman outside wearing a brown shawl and went out to offer her some food! I mean come on! Talk about paying it forward! Not only does your establishment deserve an award in customer service and quality and taste of your food, but throw in a humanitarian award in there as well for helping out someone in need! I give all of the staff here my highest respect! That's for making me, my wife and my sleeping son (lol) feel so very welcome in a place that is truly amazing! We were so very fortunate to have stopped by to eat here. Thanks again!

Very cute cozy restaurant in Covent Garden area. Service was good and the food was yummy. I had my go to dish (chicken tikka masala). It was good but needed a touch more yogurt. Chicken was very tender and cooked perfectly. My local Indian restaurant make the curry a bit more flavorful so I am used to that. Overall great restaurant

Very good Indian restaurant! Good service, nice atmosphere and fine food.
If you're looking for a great place to have an Indian meal in London it's hard to beat.

I came to London with a group of friends, one of which frequently visits London for work.  I have to admit, I was beyond confused when the first place he wanted to take us was an Indian restaurant.  I did not realize that England's Indian food was so highly regarded! He insisted that Punjab was the best place for us to go.  
I was definitely overwhelmed by the menu.  It is quite extensive!  I had tried Indian food a few times before, but I am certainly no expert.  My friend and I decided to split an order of the Butter Chicken (it sounded simple for us beginners) with sides of Cheese Naan and white rice.  Our friend recommended the Chicken Tika Masala, but we decided to play it safe.
It actually turns out that we should have listened to my friend.  Although the Butter Chicken was good, it was actually much richer and spicier than the Chicken Tika Masala that we tried!  The Chicken Tika Marsala was mild, unique and delicious.  I will definitely be ordering it during my next meal at an Indian restaurant.
Our Butter Chicken WAS enjoyable.  It was very tender and went perfectly over our side of white rice.  However, my favorite part of the meal was the Cheese Naan.  I could have eaten a stack of it!  Naan is an oven-baked flatbread served with Indian food (I did not know this).  The Cheese Naan has a white cheese baked inside the flatbread.  It was AMAZING and I loved it.  I'm actually craving an order as I write about it.
The restaurant was casual, but nice.  I loved the Indian decorations and bold colors.  The service was also wonderful.  The next time I am in London, I will be sure to stop at Punjab for some Chicken Tika Masala and endless orders of Cheese Naan.

I wasn't going to leave London without eating Chicken Tikka Masala (it was invented here, or so I'd heard) and made a special trip to Punjab based on the reviews. 
In fact my wife and I almost didn't eat here because when arriving and asking for a table for 2, the host barked "go outside and wait til I see what I have" which was a little off putting, since it was a cold December night and we had no idea how long we'd be expected to stand out there. We also arrived at the same moment as a drunken group of 8 who the same host basically told to hit the bricks as they couldn't be accommodated.  
As we were walking away I heard him calling for the table of 2 so we scurried back and they seated us a few minutes later. 
The upstairs dining room was much quieter than the downstairs. At first it was eerily quiet but eventually they turned on some Indian music that improved the the atmosphere a bit. 
Whoever wrote the menu has a good sense of humor. I appreciated that when reading some of the descriptions. 
After 2 entrees, 2 naan breads, 2 drinks, and the service charge, the total came to £44. Great food, unmemorable service, pricier than your typical takeout. Overall a good choice if you only have limited time in London and you can get in the door.

We absolutely loved our experience at Punjab. I have a wheat/gluten allergy and they were very attentive to ensuring no wheat exposure. The food was delicious (we had a chicken curry and a lamb dish). The service was stellar--we were welcomed warmly and had the opportunity to speak briefly with the owner as we were leaving. I'd highly recommend Punjab if you're in London.

You're in London.  You have to get Indian food.  I don't really think it's an option.
I saw this restaurant on one of those shows on Travel Channel or it was on Food Network or something but I had it bookmarked.
It's in Covent Gardens so expect it to be pricey for sure.
I did not have a reservation but I was by myself and I was there relatively early for a Saturday night so I figured I would chance it and just walk over to the restaurant after going to Laduree to pick up macaroons for my trip home.
I was seated upstairs at a table.  The servers were nice and attentive.  The food gets delivered via dumbwaiter up and down the stairs for the most part.
I order butter chicken, garlic naan and some rice.  It was the perfect amount of food but man was it expensive.  It was basically one airline breast of chicken and one piece of naan with a plate of rice and it was over 40 GBP.  Was it good food?  YES.  It was really good.  I would imagine if I was there with a group of people and we order a bunch of things we could share, but I have to question how would you share one piece of chicken?
Overall, I'll definitely be back again if given the chance since it was really good, but it would probably depend on what else i spent money on during that trip
No complaints! Arrived around 8 pm and was seated in a few minutes. The food is delicious and spicy! Portions are a good, filling size. Would highly recommend.

Good food , good service 
Slightly overpriced for what it is but an enjoyable experience overall!
Great Indian food in London -  kids liked it, great flavors - super casual and busy but not overly so.

Found this place on Yelp and decided to go in for lunch with my mother who said she does not like Indian Food. I told her give it a chance. I ordered for her. We had Cobra Beer to drink and Paneer Pakora to start (the sauce with the paneer was great!) For our mains we had Chicken Tikka Masala and Pudina Gosht (lamb). The mildness of the Tikka Masala with the spicy Pudina Gosht was great complements to one another. The meat in both dishes was tender and the seasonings were spot on. To go with our mains we had Pilau Rice and Garlic Naan. Both were excellent. If we weren't so full we would have ordered more!
The only thing I can say is the service is a bit brusk on cheeriness but fast response times and there wasn't much of a wait between ordering and receiving food.
We came in around 2pm on a Thursday and one side was full. By the time we started eating our side had every table occupied as well. The decor of the restaurant is also great with old photographs decorating the walls.
Can't wait to return on my next visit to London!

My friend took me to Punjab for good Indian food and he wasn't kidding. The service was quick and we ordered a LOT. We shared chicken tikka masala, paneer, and lamb curry. We each got garlic naan bread and I got basmati rice and he got white rice. I also ordered the cucumber salad. Our selection was so good- the curries were flavorful and rich! My salad was sort of sad, I was expecting larger chunks of vegetables, but it did its purpose in cleanses my palate after eating some curry and naan. Overall, Punjab is definitely a place I recommend and would come back to!
Good Indian food, but the owner earned the fifth star with his personal service.

After a lengthy visit at the British Museum, we hungered for some hardy Indian food. Punjab definitely fulfilled this desire. Here is my take on the service, atmosphere, and most importantly, the food.
Appetizers:
We ordered samosas, a favorite of ours, to start the meal.
Rating: 3/5
The samosas were decent, but lacked the complexity(in terms of spices) that is necessary for a good samosa.
Entrees:
I ordered the chicken tikka special; boneless chicken pieces with  Tandoori 
Seasoning and onions flambéed in Brandy at the table side. Quite delicious pairing with mint yogurt sauce that comes on the side. My only complaint is that the chicken was mildly dry and some of the onions were burnt to blackness. The sauce helped overcome the dryness.
Rating 4/5
My son ordered the Methi Murga; pieces of chicken submerged in mildly spicy tomato sauce with onions. He said that the chicken was very good but the sauce was a bit soupy and needed more onions. 
Rating 4.5/5
Desert:
I ordered Gulab jamun; it had a pleasing doughy texture although I felt the liquid it was bathing in was overly sweet and overwhelmed the more subtle flavors.
Rating 3/5
My son ordered mango lassi; mangoes submerged in a sweet syrup. He said it tasted wonderful, with the syrup covering the tartness of the mango but not overwhelming the flavor.
Rating 5/5
Recommendation: If you are in the area Punjab is a great place to dine.
Just landed in London and needed some good food. And we found it here. I think we had butter chicken and naan...basic. But it was really good.

Fantastic, liked it more than the highly recommended Dishoom, which we also loved.  But Punjab felt a little more comforting, it was busy for sure but we were early and were seated right away.  The food was standout delicious.  From simple items like garlic naan and tikka, with highlights being all the curries and stews we tried.  We found them each to be unique, and we had all veggie items.  Highly recommend.

I have to disappointingly give 3 stars the Punjab. I specifically dragged my friend here for dinner because I wanted to go to the oldest Punjabi restaurant in the U.K.  The food here is pretty good. We both loved the apps we got (lamb shish and the pumpkin app). My paneer makhani was fine, but I wish it was spicy. Her chicken tikka speciality was a bit smaller than expected. Sugar and mango lassi's were also good. I was not too thrilled that you have to also buy rice. We ended up buying one naan and one basmati. And if we had wanted water we would have paid. 
But here's where the bigger problem comes. We had no problems with the waiter who seated us and gave us our check. But the waiter who took our orders and brought our food out was a big problem. He's a young guy, probably the youngest there, but that's no excuse for being OFFENSIVE. Let me preface this by saying both my friend and I are American and speak English perfectly without accents (which btw our rude waiter had an accent when he spoke in English) AND YET despite this, he chose to continually say "arigato" and "xie xie" to my friend, thinking he was cute or funny? I don't know but it's completely unacceptable. It made both of us extremely uncomfortable and he never stopped doing it. Not to mention when he brought my rice out he referred to it as "arroz" instead of rice. And he did all of this clearly KNOWING we speak English (better than him for that matter). For these reasons, I'm disappointed that Punjab isn't a place I can recommend to anyone who isn't white or south Asian since our abilities to speak English were questioned while here.
All I can say is outstanding!  I went there two times during a five night vacation in London and once again during a trip there the following year.  This is the best Indian food I've ever had.

Another fantastic meal at Punjab
Been eating here for 40 years whenever I'm in town 
Food and service always exceptional 
Try the Acharri Gohst with garlic naan
Superb !!!

One of the best Indian Restaurants that we have been to.  And the best dinner in London on this trip.  We were promptly seated.  The decor evokes a feeling of old India.  We felt comfortable in our very casual attire.  We ordered Garlic Nan, one of the Chicken curries (ACHARRI MURGHA) Gobi aloo, and some basmati rice.  The waiter suggested some Papadam with a selection of chutney and other sauces. 
We really liked everything served.  And it was served promptly with heated plates.  Some of the items that came with the Papadam were foreign but tasty.  The Curry was spicy but the heat only lasts a few minutes and was the perfect level for us.  Everything was just good good good.
You even get lollipops with your check.  Next time we are on London we will come back.

Tuesday night, this place was fit to burst. We actually came here after failing to get into Dishoom (another Indian joint) as they had over an hour's queue. Punjab also had a queue but that one was significantly shorter. 
We came here as a group of 5 people but were soon seated in a cushy corner table. The food was amazing, though some were spicy and the staff were super friendly, evoking images of a close knitted family and even posing for pictures with us and at one point, patiently explaining some of Punjab's background with us as they found us standing by a large map on the wall. 
We were advised to order a variety of dishes and share (which worked out fab for me as I love trying out new foods!!) The menu was expansive but the waiter was patiently and enthusiastically guiding us through it and in the end, we opted for the bold text dishes (which were chef recommendations). Our food arrived promptly and we tucked in. I did admit that I wanted to order more, mainly because it was so good, everyone was fighting for every last morsel! 
I would definitely be coming back to this long standing establishment, with its genuinely friendly service. It honestly felt like I was in their family home, being treated to home cooked food!! If you want genuine North Indian food then go here! It is also the UK's oldest North Indian restaurant!

Overall, I was disappointed in my experience at Punjab, which has been recognized throughout the world as " The Oldest North Indian Restaurant in London." To be honest, I was saddened by my chicken tikka massala (which, to be honest, tasted more like an American chili than the classic dish I expected - waaaaaaaaaay too much cumin in this recipe). The atmosphere was fine, but nothing special, and the food was a bit overpriced for the quality. All in all, this was a rather lackluster experience with food that was average, at best. While Punjab may be the oldest Indian restaurant in London, it's certainly not the best - by far.

Felt like we needed to have Indian for dinner!! There was a little bit of wait to get in but it wasn't too bad. 
Ordered the butter chicken and naan for myself! I felt the naan was a little dry and the butter chicken and lacking a bit of a kick that you usually get with the spices. 
Service wasn't too bad. Our only complaint was one of the waiters had knocked down my friend's full bottle of beer and didn't replace it. We had to ask him to do it. 
I think I had high expectations based on other reviews I had seen. So I found Punjab to be average.

Wanted a nice feed for our last night in London and could not fault a thing. One of the best service we have ever experienced, the staff were so friendly and on the ball... so attentive & quick! The food was amazing, butter chicken was to die for. Would definitely return!

My coworkers and I spent a Saturday in London. I am huge fan of Indian food so it was a must for me. We searched Yelp for recommendations based on our location. The first spot, which I won't name, was more of an fusion restaurant with a limited menu. I knew it wasn't what I wanted because it didn't even smell like an Indian restaurant. Where was the aroma from the spices??? Fortunately, was able to convince my coworkers to look for another restaurant when we came across Punjab. I knew we were in the right spot the moment we walked in the door. We didn't order anything out the ordinary. We shared some chicken masala, Korma chicken, the chickpea dish (I don't believe it was called chana masala here), aloo gobi, rice and garlic naan. Everything was delicious and flavorful!!! One of my coworkers had dietary restrictions so we requested to speak to the manager. He was very attentive and accommodating in fulfilling his needs.  We ordered a bottle of Indian red wine called India Grover's LA Reserve.  It was excellent!! My coworkers told me they were glad I suggested finding another restaurant. I'd definitely go back and highly recommend the Punjab restaurant if you're looking for great  Indian food.

My first Indian food experience ever. From NYC where the food is significantly better than London in many categories. We were pleasantly surprised vy this outstanding establishment. The owner greeted all the guests at the door and the customer service was excellent! Food was very good. Highly recommend.

Had a wonderful dinner here my last trip through London. The best Indian food I've had in years, combined with wonderful service. 
It's quite busy here on a Friday night, so be ready to be cozy.

Best service! I was so glad we found this establishment which not only have a great staff and amazing food, but so much history behind it. Everything we had was amazing. Definitely the spot I will be visiting when I'm back in The area.
Nice people but slow service, but incredibly delicious food. It's not necessarily cheap, but you get a good amount of food.

This is the best place I've eaten in all of London.  It's not a trending setup but if you want food that is freaking great, just come here and stop messing around with everything else.  I love the Punjab Restaurant.
Best Indian food I ever had. From the service to food, everything was perfect! Many thanks to staff for providing exceptional service. Cheers!

The wifi password is "butterchicken" - how awesome is that - I had to laugh a little when the waiter told me
That said - in hindsight maybe I should have ordered that - can't go wrong with butter or chicken. The chicken tikka masala however was excellent so either or I'm sure both are good. 
I'll be honest - I found this spot after getting an hour and 45 minute wait at Dishoom - no thanks, nothing is worth almost a 2 hour wait. I found Punjab which is just a few streets down and I'm glad I did. No wait at all and seemingly more authentic. 
Of course I had to get the chicken tikka masala - the chicken was some of the best I've had at an Indian restaurant - super moist and tender - excellent. The curry base was great as well - it was a little on the lighter side - was hoping for more spices and robust flavor. 
It wasn't on the menu but I got mixed vegetables in a tomato based curry which was also very good. The dishes don't come with rice or naan so I ordered a white rice and garlic naan - the rice was just plain rice, should have ordered the one with the seeds. 
The garlic naan was good but not as good as the bullet naan which I added later on because of the pictures. It's not as spicy as you would think (bullet naan). The samosa was delicious - crunchy outside and soft pillowy potato mash inside. 
 I also got a masala chai tea - very good and spicy. One of the better meals I've had in London - great Punjab food! Portions are good, prices are on par for the city - total came out to about £43 for 2 ppl - appetizers, main courses, drinks.

Great tasting food.  I had chicken tikka masala and sag paneer.  Lots of cheese in the paneer.  Food was spiced just right.  A bit expensive. They charge for rice aide dish.  Same dishes were $30 in NYC vs 30 pounds in U.K. .  I would highly recommend.  Line was fast less than 10 mins to be seated on a Friday night.  Lighting was awful.  Not a romantic place to take a date.

The curry here was stellar.  Get the Chicken Tikka Masala with some rice and naan.  This place has been around for several decades and has a history of their delicious Chicken Tikka Masala.  It's in Covent Gardens, so it can get very crowded with tourists.  Don't come during peak hours and you will have an easy time finding seats and ordering.  Staff was very professional, but expect a gratuity tacked onto your bill.

It's pretty good given the touristy crowd and location. Good food and attentive service.
I had the khari ghost, which was good, but I did expect more of a kick to it. The lamb was also not completely tender.
My friend got the butter chicken, a London staple, but I didn't get to try it.
The garlic naan wasn't the best I've had. It has thin slices of garlic on top. I almost prefer it when it's finer pieces.
Mango lassi was fine, but not very sweet. I think it's a good option if you're around central London. I liked the attentive service, but I'm not sure if I'd queue up for it. There's always a line out the door.

Nice, authentic, home made flavors and feel to the food. Service was great and the ambience was cozy while feeling a bit dated, which is likely intentional. Overall, good experience and I would dine here again.

Similar to some other reviewers here, I also wanted to go to Dishoom but the wait was so long and we really wanted Indian food so we yelped and found this place. I'm glad we did! 
The service was a bit rocky at first. "What you want? ... No you wait. Let me finish writing."  Uhhhh, what??  But then the waiter came back and was okay again. He served naan and garlic naan, both deliciously buttery and soft. We almost wished we saved the naan to eat with our meal instead but gobbled it up quickly. I loved my chicken Tikka special- the spices marinated in the meat perfecto with an abundance amount of sauce to mix with the rice. My husbands butter chicken was a little bit dry but he said the flavor was bold and spicy, just the way he expected it. 
We didn't have room for dessert unfortunately but a mango lassi was quite enough for me to leave happily and satisfied.

The food here is reallllly good. I had a little bit of everything because I was dining with a large group. They have several spicy dishes that are actually spicy enough to taste the difference. They have 4 or 5 different kinds of Naan. We were kind of loud due to the size of our party but the way waitstaff was as very understanding and patient with my group.
Excellent meal, great service, and only a 20 minute wait on a Friday night.

I came to Punjab with a few friends for dinner and had not only a great experience but some phenomenal indian food.  We came on a Friday night and weren't sure how long the wait would be, but they were able to seat us within 5 minutes of arriving.  We started out with Samosas which were delicious and not at all greasy.   For our main course we shared chicken tikka, butter chicken, along with two standouts the bullett naan (spread with chopped fresh chilli and garlic) and the saag paneer which was beautifully spiced, not oily and tasted like fresh spinach.
