Not only is the food good, but the service is also on point.  Our waiter was attentive and food arrived fast, hot and as ordered. 
A+

This was our best meal in London! We were seated right away, service was fast and accurate, and most importantly the food was delicious. Chicken was slow cooked and fell apart. The menu has tons of options - so there's something for everyone. Great place!

A few of my friends and I came to London for the day on our way back from Glasgow. We had been craving Indian and decided we would on our last night. With the help of Yelp we came across Punjab. It was the best Indian I have ever had, I am very loyal to one family owned one in my home town but this exceeded all expectations. The food was delicious, staff was friendly and helpful. We had ordered butter chicken, tandoori chicken and chicken tikka. No food was left! 
I would recommend making a reservation, we were lucky at 6 to get a table. Leaving though we saw the line out the door and along the restaurant! 
We met briefly with the owner who was extremely generous, he is part of the fourth generation running this restaurant. I know my next trip to London I will be making an other appearance! Thank you Punjab!
Delicious classic, light Indian dishes. Owner was so friendly and accommodating. We loved the carrot cake!

Definitely get the chicken tikka masala! So good! Don't order the buttered chicken if you aren't expecting a slight kick. We were seated immediately upon arrival (party of 2), and the staff was very attentive and kind. The fried lentil and lamb appetizer is delicious, but be warned -- there isn't much of it. So don't order to split if you're hungry! Portion sizes of the entrees are larger than one might come to expect in London. 
Decor was interesting and cool -- one might call it slightly dated, but when the food is that good, who cares? 
The restaurant is easy to find and within walking distance of an excellent ice cream place!

Solid and reliable spot for northern Indian cuisine - I always swing by at least once when I visit London. Both lentil dishes (yellow and black) are to die for. Love the methi gosht. Acharri and karahi dishes are also really good here.
I get the feeling this place tones down the spiciness, so if you're a regular Indian eater and like spicy, make sure to ask staff to bump it up a bit. For example, the biryani dishes are not nearly spicy enough in their "standard" forms. Same with the jalfrezi - the basic flavor is very good, but could definitely use a bump up on the spiciness. That said, once you request spicy, it really does get spicy!
Also, one of the better gajar halwa I've had. If you're a fan, make sure you save room. Even if you're not (and you don't hate carrots as a dessert), give it a try.
Go at lunch to avoid the queues.

Wonderful food.  The owner was incredibly friendly.  I especially loved how friendly they were to my kids who have nut allergies.  We rarely eat Indian food because of their allergies,  but they really enjoyed it!

One of the best north Indian restaurants outside of India! We ordered vegetarian curries - paneer  tikka masala, the best Channa Masala I ever had, naan and biryani. Everything was so delicious. Great service too. Will definitely return when I go back to London.

We went to Punjab because there was a wait at another Indian restaurant. We were seated promptly, but the table was a little small for our family. We ordered naan and I got chicken korma. There is only one circle of naan per serving, would have preferred more per serving. My chicken korma was excellent and just the right spice amount. Went well with rice. I enjoyed my food. My biggest complaint is that they charge you for your water, which comes in fancy bottles. Overall, a nice Indian restaurant that is centrally located.

We went on a working lunch here today. For a Tuesday it was surprisingly busy (I see Indian/Punjabi food as a night time meal really). We went based on Yelp reviews, obviously, and we weren't disappointed. 
It announces itself as the UK's Oldest North Indian Restaurant and the photos and articles around the room provide you with its history. The decor isn't anything to shout out about but it's simple and comfortable which I liked.
The waiter was slightly abrupt but in a comical way. He provided us with the wifi password via the menu (butterchicken) and helped with the food recommendations - I'm glad he did! 
We started with popadoms, pretty standard, but the chutneys which accompanied them were unisual particularly the greeny grain looking one (not sure if the name - sorry) which was tangy yet delightful.
We then shard the Samosa's - crispy not soggy pastry (which does happen) on the outside, and the inside was almost creamy, stuffed with meat and potatoes with fantastic flavours running through.
Now to the dish I was prompted to try, the Archarri Margha, I truly enjoyed this! You could tell that the ingredients were fresh and that they take pride in their special dishes and you could really taste tang!
It was first Punjabi food experience, it won't be my last!
To note: the prices are really decent especially for a restaurant in Covent Garden.

SERVICE:
The customer service here has some serious room for improvement. Between the moments I stepped in the restaurant to the moment I stepped out, each interaction with the staff felt very impersonal and unfriendly. If I say "Thank you" to a waiter, he would just stare at me and walk away. When it was time for me to pay, the person who inserted my credit card didn't even say a word. He just took the card, printed out a receipt, let me sign it, and walked away. Not a single eye contact. Wow. On top of all that, I'm required to give a "10 percent optional service" fee.
PRICE:
My total amounted to 14.25 GBP for Butter Chicken with rice. That's about $23.63 USD for those living in the states. People say that this place is cheap but I think it's expensive. I have been to other Indian restaurants where my total is about 11 GBP for the same or more portion of food. 
FOOD:
I ordered the Butter Chicken and rice. The Butter Chicken included two pieces of chicken still on the bone. The gravy was good and had a slight spiciness to it. It goes well with rice or naan (not included in the price). 
If the customer service was better, I would have given this place a 3 out of 5 stars.

*Very rude behaviour*
Apparently there's a rule that the order should exceed 15 pounds per person.
We were a party of four visiting - one of us wasn't too hungry and our order fell short initially. The waiter first pointed the rule out to us with a rude "can't be done."
After finding out about the rule, we told the waiter that we'll order dessert in the end to cover the difference. Yet again the waiter in his border line accusatory tone said "what if you don't?"
My Rating is not because of the rule - the restaurant is entitled to keep it. However, I do think the waiters could do a much better job of explaining it to customers understanding that they're not thieves trying to trick them.

My hubby really wanted Indian food in London, and our first choice was Dishoom, but when we got there we saw it was closed for renovations (we probably should've checked the website in advance...), so we quickly scrambled and found Punjab. There was a 20 minute wait, and the little wait area is so tiny and crowded. We moved around as people came and went (it was raining outside, duh, so couldn't wait there), after the time passed we were seated at a table upstairs. The restaurant is huge and it was packed. 
My hubby really wanted to try some stuff he doesn't see on menus in the US, and he did, I can't remember what it was that he ordered though (something very spicy), but he really liked it! We also ordered samosas, naan, chicken tikka masala, some veggies, and rice since it did not come with the meat dishes, weird. The food was good! The flavors were very authentic and tasty, the naan was delicious! The service was ok, I kept having to ask for water, which seems to be on par for London (I had to basically beg for refills everywhere!) but overall this place was pretty good! We definitely left quite full!

BEST indian food in London for sure (Coming from someone that grew up in India!) Flavors were authentic,the laccha parantha was on point and the service was friendly. The naan is one of the best I have had here in London. The quality of the food is as good or even better than dishoom and the setting is more authentic. I'm so glad to have found this place and will be a regular patron moving forward.

We went here for a dinner, on a weekday night. we expected a long wait, but were seated in 5 - 10 minutes. The service was prompt and courteous. We started off with vegetable samosas. 
For main course, we ordered the butter chicken and baigan as gravies, with rice and naan. It was one of the best Indian food I have had outside India. The butter chicken reminded me of food in local dhabas in Punjab :') we absolutely loved our dinner here!

We wanted to dine at another Indian restaurant but they had an hour and a half wait on a Saturday night. We walked to Punjab hoping to get dinner. We were fortunate to get a table for four.
Ambiance: bare minimum, no great wall decorations. It is a series of small rooms.
Service was good but they tried very hard to rush us through dinner. We fought them off. Manager was nice to take pics of the foursome outside.
Food: was good, northern Indian. Our vegan friend ordered sweet and spicy pumpkin and a lentel dish, tarka dall. We also tried the prawn puri, spicy shrimp on a crispy puri. Very tasty. We also ordered 2 butter chicken entrees, a Punjab specialty. Delicious, tasty and very enjoyable.
Overall, a nice experience.

London is known as a mecca for delicious Indian food. You're more likely to find a place selling tikka masala than the traditional English fish and chips while visiting. Because of this, I knew I had to try some good Indian food when I went to London. I knew it would be the best Indian food I can get without actually being in India. While doing research about where to eat, my sister and I stumbled upon Punjab. Punjab is known as one of the best Indian restaurants London has to offer. On any given night, you will have to wait up to an hour to get seated. 
My sister and I arrived at a good time. A bit before 7pm, and with hardly any line. Since we were only a party of 2, we were seated in about 25 minutes. The restaurant is much larger than it looks on the outside. When you first walk in you think there is only one room for dining, but then you see that there is another room, and even more seating upstairs. My sister and I were directed to the upstairs seating. The ambiance of the restaurant is very homey. Punjab isn't trying to be fashionable, and it isn't trying to be the best in London. This is just some good Indian food without all the hoopla. 
When we sat down, we knew we wanted to get something to drink. After looking at the drinks menu we decided to get the India Grover's Sauvignon Blanc. We thought it would be interesting to try some Indian wine. The wine was wonderful and refreshing. When I came time to order appetizers, I knew I had to get samosas. I can't have an Indian meal without trying the samosas. The samosas offered at Punjab were some of the best I've had. We also split some garlic naan. I garlic naan was just as good as the samosas. For my meal I got the chicken tikka masala. Chicken tikka masala is my go to Indian dish, and it was renowned in London. I just had to get it. The chicken tikka masala was outstanding. I loved the tomato based sauce that the chicken comes in. My sister got the karahi paneer and thought it was great. There were no complaints from her about any of the dishes. The entire meal was absolutely perfection.
The service was also really great. All the waiters and employees were very nice, and courteous. I also appreciate that we were only waiting outside for 25 minutes when it was very cold outside. My only issue with Punjab is that I don't live in London and I can't visit as often as I wish I could. Punjab is a restaurant I would recommend to people visiting London.
Good if you're feeling some Indian. Portions are on the smaller side, but the flavour is definitely there. Can be a line but it moves quick. Clothing can smell of spices after.

Dined here for dinner during our recent trip to London. We actually initially tried to go to Dishoom down the street, but they had a 90 minute wait. When we asked the hostess at Dishoom about other good Indian restaurants in the area, she directed us to Punjab. 
We had some papadams and samosas for appetizer. My wife had the chicken tikka masala, and I had the lamb roganjosh. All simply fantastic. 
The following day, we trekked out to the famed Brick Lane for some more Indian food, but honestly, Punjab blows away the Indian food on Brick Lane. We will definitely make a return trip to this restaurant on our next trip to London.

So recently I've become an Indian food lover. London has a plethora of Indian food restaurants located on every corner. I wanted to find a good one for our first night in London. I looked at reviews online and I found Punjab. Upon entering it looked pretty busy for a Wednesday night they have it set up with almost a fine dining appeal. We were seated right away, which is always a plus in my book. I ordered the Strongbow cider to drink, which I was told was London's signature cider but I had never tried it before. To eat I ordered the garlic naan, the dahl, and the chicken tikka masala. Everything came out pretty quickly and it was all very good and I devoured it down but the stand out for me was the garlic naan I think it was the best I ever had. The service was friendly and attentive. I'd recommend this place to every fellow Indian food lover to try out.

The amritsari fish is ok. It's like fried fish with a lot of seasoning in the coating. The dipping sauce is very good though. Then we had butter chicken,  lamb madrus, and acharri gosht. They all taste good but similar. All dishes tend to be a bit salty. Lamb madrus is the best as the meat is most tender and the dish is most spicy. The garlic naan is perfect. The cheese naan tastes good but a bit oily. The service is pretty good in general.

Ok... my favorite food is now Indian food. Indian food made from  this Pakistani family at this restaurant. WOW! That's enough said... spicy deliciousness that made my 10 year old ask for more and more.

You must try it 
the fooooooood is so good
You must try it 
the fooooooood is so good
You must try it 
the fooooooood is so good
But it's very spicy be careful

Visiting London for a couple of weeks and I found this place on Yelp. I love, love, love Indian food, so I put it on my list early on to stop at. When I got there the line was pretty big and I wasn't too sure how quickly it was going to move. I easily put in a takeaway order and my food was ready in 10 minutes. The owner of the establishment was incredibly nice and even threw a couple of jokes my way even though it seemed like a mad house inside. I wouldn't normally think of this, but this place really splurges on the takeaway packaging. The containers were sealed really well and the bag was sturdy and leakproof, in case the containers didn't work. The only reason why I mention this is because this made it really easy to go through the Underground on a Saturday night without getting curry all over the place.
I ordered the Kadu Sabji-their signature pumpkin curry (because I'm American and Americans love all things pumpkin this time of year), plain rice, and garlic naan. The food was PERFECTION. The curry was nicely spiced and had whole chunks of pumpkin in it that were perfectly tender. The garlic naan was also something to write home about. Very soft and chewy. Though, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone expecting to get a kiss afterwards; I suppose unless you both eat it then it cancels out. The meal is definitely enough for 2, which means I have some left over to enjoy tomorrow!
Go here, seriously.

I admit I had some reluctance to come here as opposed to the newer, more modern Indian restaurants which are more trendy in London these days.  But I have no regrets, it was delicious.  Of course, we ordered the Butter Chicken and Tikka Masala.   Both were so delicious, I ate past the point of fullness.

Delicious food with large menu and Attentive and friendly staff. My boyfriend has a nut allergy so they gave us a menu with all of the allergies and dietary restriction labeled which was very convenient. Must visit!
You never fail me Punjab...everything I eat when I go is perfect and fantastic...always worth the wait.  See you next time!

I'm so glad we found this Covent Garden gem! This restaurant is in a tiny house, complete with a dumbwaiter for serving up the good to second floor (unique for us Americans).
Walking up it looked like a club with a short line outside, but we got seated quickly and the service and food were fantastic. My husband was weary of Indian food but he was impressed with the chicken tikka masala, you can never go wrong there.
I had the mutter paneer since I going for a milder dish. It was amazing! Make sure you get the Pilau cumin rice, best rice I've ever had anywhere. We miss Punjab, Indian food is terrible in Texas. :(

the BEST Indian food ever!  my nephew and niece and I agree, it was the most delicious and memorable Indian food- not only was the food extraordinary but the owner Amrit gave that special touch to make us feel like guests.  All the staff were great. 
Any Americans who go to London MUST stop by lovely Covent Gardens and go to this restaurant-  it will be memorable.

Good food for sure. We were 2 of us, and since we were not very hungry we ordered 2 Sweet Lassi, 1 Methi Gosht and 2 Bullet Naan. 
The portion size was good. Bullet Naan was quiet delicious.
Definitely recommended.

Delicious meal...pumpkin puri appetizer, cheese Naan, Italian wine...when advising me about the Butter Chicken being bone in vs. Tiki Marsala boneless, waiter in error ordered the Tiki, they ended up providing me some of both to make up it for delicious and great service!  I'll be back for sure!

We have heard a lot of good things regarding England and Indian food. My wife and I decided that we had to have it at least once during our UK vacation. Just by chance, right before our trip we saw a Food Network program that had a special on food in London. One of the places that they pointed out was Punjabi. We randomly ran into Punjabi while walking around, remembered it for the program, and decided to eat there. 
The food at Punjabi was really good and surprisingly cheap. At the end of the meal we were surprised at how low our bill was.
We had the Samosas (a must get), the chicken tikka masala, and the saag paneer. All items were great. We shared a mango lassi as well (yum!). 
Recommended place to eat. We went on the later side and it wasn't TOO busy but I've heard if you good at prime dinner time it can be a bit crowded.

No matter how frazzled or worn out you are once you sit down at the Punjab, read the menu here and you'll be in good spirits before you even order food. Such a witty little menu. 
This place gets backed for dinner  - we went for lunch and got seated immediately. They were taking reservations the entire time we were there. Go at lunch.
I ordered the chicken tikka masala since it's the most famous dish in London, and I purposefully chose this place when doing research. The reviews weren't wrong! 
This was the best Indian food I've ever had! The chicken was so smokey, the sauce so creamy and everything in between so flavorful. I'm obsessed and want some now. 
Get the samosas, the sweet lassi, plain naan and rice and you'll be all set.

Really wanted to love this place, and although the food is good, it just doesn't justify the prices to me- I've been able to get some food that's just as nice or better for so much cheaper in London. Seating is very crowded, but I actually like that. Be prepared to wait if you have a big group or go on a weekend.
Indian cuisine lover, easily some of the best I have ever had. Great staff who clearly take pride in their food. Would give them 10000000 stars if I could

Great service--exceptional.  We were there early (around 5:30) and they told us we could only have a table if we were done by 7:30.  This was blunt but to the point and I'd rather them say that then tell us no.  The service was great--within moments of asking, we had everything we needed.  
We had the Daal, Malai Kofta, and one of the signature dishes (all from the vegetarian menu).  They were all solid.  Everything was on the spicy side (rather than creamy and sweet) and it was good.  Prices were reasonable.

Punjab was the start of my incredible Indian food adventures in London, and I'm so happy we got to try it! My friend and I came in sans reservation on Sunday around 7:30 PM, and it was totally fine. There were other diners in the restaurant, but it wasn't too full.
We ordered the garlic chicken, butter chicken, garlic naan, and mango lassis, and everything was AMAZING. I did prefer the garlic chicken over the butter chicken, but both were great, and the naan was perfect for sopping up all the delicious sauce. Mango lassis were nothing inventive but still delicious and refreshing. 
Punjab's staff was also super helpful--giving us recommendations on things to do before we returned to our apartment later that evening and even chasing us out the restaurant to make sure we were headed in the right direction.
If you're looking for authentic and delicious Indian food, don't miss it! :)
Was the only tikka masala I tried when in London, and judging by the taste and quality and I'm positive it's the only tikka masala you need to try when there. Also, impeccably fast service.

You absolutely have to make room on your busy itinerary for some Punjab! Honestly, prior to my trip to London, I never preferred to eat Indian food. However, Punjab has changed it all! In particular, their Chicken Tikka Masala! You cannot leave London without trying their Chicken Tikka Masala. The sauce is absolutely delicious with its creamy and flavorful texture. It isn't too spicy either if you regularly cannot handle heat.  To go with this, I actually preferred the spiced rice over the naan. I believe it's seasoned with cumin and maybe some turmeric. I am more of a rice than a bread person though. 
The only downside of this place is the service. They know they are the best so service isn't all too friendly and attentive. They also slap on an "Optional" service fee. We didn't bother asking them to remove it, considering how long it took to place our order and to get our bill. Nonetheless, this place is still worth check out!

Definitely the best Indian I had in London, and I hit no less than a dozen places.  The paneer makhani, my favorite, was top knotch.  
You really can't go wrong here.  Definitely a great lunch choice.

We came here on a recent trip to London. My family is Indian and we had heard about all the great Indian restaurants in London and had received a recommendation for this restaurant from a friend. We ordered the butter chicken, saag aloo, daal, and paneer tikka masala. Everything was delicious and very authentic. One of the best meals we had on our vacation.
A bit overrated thought it was decent Indian food.  Dishoom is way better go there instead.  Chicken Tikka Masala was kind of bland.

Amazing Indian food!! So authentic in their cooking it was like my Indian friend was cooking for me in her home! I loved stopping here for a late dinner with friends, they had quick service and were able to accommodate a vegan diet. I got a menu for people with allergies, and ordered a chickpea dish with a side of rice. It was delicious! They warned me that the food I ordered is spicy, but it was perfect. We had our own dishes with naan to share, it was a perfect meal! Definitely come here if you're looking for Indian food in London.

Was recommended a trendy Indian restaurant which had a massive wait. Found Punjab on yelp and was absolutely delighted. 
Wait was less than they said, service was spot on, atmosphere was great and food was fantastic!
My Boyfriend and me loved the delicious vegetarian meal. Thanks a lot as well for the polite service. We are coming back

We are recent connoisseurs of Indian cuisine and this place is very very good. Service was quick the food was delicious ....what else can we ask for.   Just make sure you get there early because by the time we left there was a queue of about 20 people out front door.

excellent food, impeccable service & the atmosphere was great. fresh ingredients, wonderful masala chai tea and mango ice cream to finish the meal. we're here in town one more day and we'll be coming back again tomorrow
Really delicious meal from start to finish!! Generous portions. Vegan and gluten free options available. Ask for an allergy menu if you have dietary requirements.

Fantastic Indian cuisine, with excellent range of appetizers, entrees, and desserts. Can get rather busy, but it's a local treasure and well worth the wait. 10/10 for an all around great find, in a charming city.

Food: incredible. You really do need to add this to your London to-do list if only here for a few days. Came with my parents, international Indian fans and they were very impressed. But not with the service! We spent probably an hour here and it took us 20 minutes to eat. The other 40 was twenty waiting for a beer out of a bottle (I mention this because I can open a beer bottle in 10 seconds flat!) (they brought beer WITH food) and twenty waiting on the check. Then verbally suggested a 20% tip. Not too classy. But the food!!! Lamb and chicken cooked to PERFECTION!

A true gem among so many wonderful places for curry in London. Yes, it is in a location that attracts tourists but be discouraged by that. It is truly delicious Northern Indian cuisine.  
I love the Jalfrezi and Punjabi Samosa. Chana Masala is amazing as well. Delicious -- fresh and so nicely balanced that it is fun to try to discern the individual spices even though it all blends so well.
I've been going for many years and the staff are always the same and that says so much. Everyone is kind and the service is amazing. A long time family business. The owner seems always to be there and making sure the service and food are perfect. And it is.

Taste: 3
Creativity/Authenticity: 3
Atmosphere: 3.5
Service: 2
Bang for your buck: 3
Let me start by saying when in London which claims to have the best indian food your not gonna find it here. I'm free Los Angeles and we'll punjab is about the same as LA; Los Angeles might be better!! First our waiter was very rude, service Def needs work. As far as the food goes nothing special the condiments tasted like pre package jar sauces, their chicken masala just another indian dish nothing that a place that claims to be the first indian restaurant in London should taste like. If you want indian food you can probally find another place that has just as good food if not better i suggest for the price of punjab you go eat at dishoom way better service, better food but make a reservation. Good luck
Tried three Indian restaurants on our 8 day vacation to London and we all really enjoyed this restaurant the most.  Good food, good service, good location.

I definitely agree with others - don't wait for Dishoom.  Come here and you can eat very well.  We actually wanted something more home style and lighter than the creamy sauces you'd find at typical Indian restaurants.  We asked for the dishes to be prepared with as little oil as possible, but maximum flavor (spices, etc.) and they delivered!  The food was delicious, vibrantly spiced, and not too heavy.

This restaurant deserves to have been in business for as long as it has been. With so many restaurants to choose from in London, Punjab consistently offers delicious food, quality ingredients and friendly staff. Locals know about it and hopefully tourists get to appreciate this much-loved restaurant.

Tried their house specialty chicken , the stew lacked depth in flavor that Indian cuisine is famous for. The base was pretty much tomatoes with chili powder. I was expecting to taste aromas of roasted seeds layered with other species . And the chicken kabob was surprisingly bland! It came in a flaming hot skillet drizzled with a believe some kind of alcohol. 
delicious was mango lasi drink.  service was very nice
Must try curry chicken & butter chicken! Delicious !

Good food, decent service and ambiance. 
We stumbled upon Punjab during a recent visit to London. We were on the hunt for Indian food, saw a line out the door and figured it would be an hour wait. Don't be deterred by the line outside, it moves very quickly and we were seated within 15 minutes. However the first thing we were told before we sat down was that we had to be out by 8 o'clock, which was about an hour-and-a-half away. That was fine, but a little strange we were being rushed before we had even ordered. The atmosphere was also very basic inside, it's definitely more on the casual side. 
We decided to order  a good variety of starters and main plates because we quite enjoy Indian cuisine. We ordered Samosas and papadom with mango chutney to start. The chutney was delicious. We then followed that with chicken tikka masala, vegetable curry, chicken korma and peshwari naan bread. The portions were decently sized, not overwhelmingly big. The food was all good and the naan bread was fantastic. 
My only issue with Punjab was that we felt rushed the whole time we were there. It felt like they were just waiting to take our plates away and hurry us along so they could seat the next group of people. I noticed they did that with all of the tables in the restaurant, which took away from the experience as a whole. Overall this was a good restaurant.

Came here for dinner. Had the samosas, garlic naan, butter chicken, chicken tikka masala and cumin rice. Everything was delicious and flavorful except the butter chicken. The butter chicken was a little pink by the bone. 
There was no wait. Staff was attentive and nice. Service was quick. Would definitely recommend this place!

We originally wanted to go to Dishoom, but being closed for construction we quickly searched up another place and found here. I'm so glad we found it! There was barely any wait and we were seated quickly. The servers were helpful and friendly. The food here is great. The only disappointment I had was not being able to try the dish that lit up on fire. Which every other table seemed to have got instead.. 
This was one of the best and cheapest places we ate in London on our trip.

Came here with my boyfriend when we were visiting London, we both loved it. I got the Chicken Tikka Masala with naan and aloo gobi, everything was fresh. I wish they opened up a restaurant in the states!

Probably the best Indian food in Central London. Curries are very good and prepared fresh. Things to try:
- Daal Tarka
- Paneer Makhani
- chana masala
Chapati felt like home made.
Drinks: mango lassi had good flavor.

This is a London institution and behaves as such. Waiters are plentiful and efficient, some friendly others appeared stressed. Bottles of beer and pints of lager abound as do young Americans.  Food is fine, portion sizes not too big.

A classic Indian restaurant in the heart of London, specializing in the north, specifically the Punjab. Don't expect modern interpretation of Indian food, fusion or anything like that - expect a typical British Indian restaurant, done just right. I've visited the place many times before when in London, mainly owing to its central location, and it never disappoints. Prices are very reasonable too, despite the prime location.

Nice location for this wonderful Indian eatery, there is not much room so its a bit of a shuffle game dealing with the space. We had a reservation and they were very friendly and accommodating. Some of our party was late for a reservation and they adjusted for us. The food was quite good, this is a northern indian place with reasonable prices.

My family and I visited this restaurant while on vacation to London last week. It's an easy walk from Tottenham Court Road tube station and was easy to find. 
Once seated we checked out their menu and settled on a few dishes for us to share. We ordered the Punjabi Samosa, Acharri Murgha, Tarka Daal, and Methi Gosht to name a few and the meal was delicious. We ordered a mixture of chicken, vegetarian, and lamb dishes. All the dishes had their own unique flavor, spice, and aroma. The staff were all attentive and saw to our every need. 
We all agreed that we would recommend this restaurant to anyone who was looking to have a great Indian meal while in London.

Service and ambiance are nice. We arrived when they first opened and the restaurant had an overwhelmingly strong scent of cleaning solution. Not sure if it always smells like that.
We liked everything we tried and the spices in the dishes really stood out in comparison to some of the other places we have tried. The dishes also had a nice smoky flavor.
CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA £9.50 No standard recipe exists for this classic dish, however our 1973 formula continues to withstand the test of time, Chicken Tikka served in tandoori masala & tomato based sauce
BUTTER CHICKEN £9.75 The godfather of all punjabi dishes, succulent chicken on the bone served in a creamy
BUTTER NAAN £2.35 Simple but sumptuous flatbread expertly baked against the walls of the tandoor

Today was my third meal here. I've enjoyed each one. Amidst the hustle of Covent Garden, this little place would be easy to overlook. Please don't.  Just about everything here has been consistently good, and everyone I've eaten here with has loved it. Despite a minor mix up today with my food being delivered to the adjacent table, service is good if a tiny bit unhurried, and food quality is excellent. A few highlights:
Onion pakora - little fritters of gram flour (believe it's chickpea flour) mixed with onions and spice and fried to a delicious crunch
Hariyali chicken - mentioned by at least one other reviewer, it's a bit showy when it comes sizzling to your table, and it tastes great. Skewered chicken coated in yogurt, coriander, mint, garlic, ginger and chile and cooked in the tandoor. This is my favorite! No sauce, FYI, but some grilled onions underneath are great
Bullet naan - naan with garlic and green chiles - not overpoweringly flavored, but really nice alongside the other dishes - I liked the little bit of extra spice this added to my meal
One I won't order again- the mixed vegetable curry - I should've inquired more about this one, as it just wasn't "green" enough for me, having lots of potatoes, carrots, and peas in it. Oh well, I'll stick with my okra or saag dishes next time
Do check this little place out. They take Amex, too, for those who care.

3.5 stars for me.  The food was good, but nothing special that would make me want to come again.  Had the Chicken Tikka Masala, samosa, vegetable curry.  Garlic naan was blah. I dont know why this restaurant was so busy, but there was definitely a crowd.

Punjab is a fantastic restaurant with the most amazing staff! I highly recommend this restaurant for the authentic cuisine and the family atmosphere. Amrit and Angelo certainly understand the meaning of fine dining and great customer service. Thank you for a fantastic meal!

Well beyond its Use-by date.  Decor is tired.... threadbare dirty carpets and worn furniture.  Food was also a huge disappointment. I love Indian cuisine .... but you can walk down any suburban UK high street and get better than this. Having visited India several times, with a name like Punjab, I had especially high expectations of the tandoori dishes...again a huge disappointment as the meats had none of the smoky charcoal flavor one expects from genuine tandoor cooking. Moreover the "curry" dishes had no depth of flavor and all seemed to have been microwave reheated as they were delivered to our table within less than 2 mins of ordering. This place is trading off a long past reputation.

*Be aware of the £15 minimum per person purchase, our neighbors were kicked out for wanting to order apps only, see below*
We ordered the vegetable biryani with vegetable curry, chicken madrasa, bullet naan and a beer. The rice and chicken madrasa was very flavorful, spicy and worth the order. The bullet naan wasn't anything special, the cilantro and chillies didn't add much flavor. 
*Food was delicious, however, the lead waiter was pretty rude to other guests (we were there at 3:30 pm: he asked a couple to leave for only waiting to order appetizers, and a father wanted to sit next to the window with his daughter but he wouldn't let them).
Nice ambience and service. Seated quickly. Food was good but for London standards was just 'ok'. Lacking salt all around and I'm not one who likes a lot of it.

I've always wanted to visit this restaurant since it is supposed to be the oldest North Indian restaurant in London. 
We ordered the vegetable pakora for an appetizer, but found some hair in it. Not good. The mango lassis were good but not great. 
We ordered the malai kofta with vegetable biriyani and Naan (bullet and garlic). The naans came way after the kofta was almost gone - not good again. 
With some many other Indian options like Dishoom and Gymkhana around, I will not be back.

Pricey, but the best Indian food I've ever had, and my home is close to Fremont, California. Make sure to get a nice cobra beer with your meal :). We had a paneer dish, but the butter chicken and lamb korma were sooo money. I wish the sides of rice and naan were included though..

The Resturant is nice and clean & the waiters are attentive .
I ordered the samosas , nothing to spectacular but it was perfectly cooked not oily or over cooked 
For the main course I ordered the lamb chop curry , & tikka Masala  , white rice  and garlic nan bread.
I was warned by the waiter that  my lamb chop curry would be spicy,  which I love . However , the curry sauce wasn't as spicy enough  to me . They gave  a nice portion of pieces of lamb chops with the bone. I enjoyed my meal very much but wish it was spicer.
The tikka masala was very well prepared the sauce was so good and fresh . 
The garlic nan bread was so good and hot and perfect to use to dip up the sauce from your plate 
 
I didn't order any drinks just seltzer( sparkling )  water

Excellent service and excellent food! This place was very authentic (according to an Indian friend who I spoke to after going here) and reasonably priced. Everything is a la carte, however, which I wasn't aware of so it took a little while to get everything ordered that I needed for a full meal. Nonetheless, the food is hearty and the spice level is right on point. I'm someone who enjoys fiery foods and felt that their spice level was adequate. Great place!

Great food! We'd been looking for a really good Indian restaurant and Punjab did not disappoint. Staff was friendly and courteous, and the food was outstanding! A few other tourists (like us) but also a good number of locals -- always a good sign. After a full day of sightseeing we were exhausted. We didn't feel rushed at all and somehow managed to finish everything. We'll definitely be making another stop at Punjab the next time we visit London!

The most amazing Indian food I have ever had, period. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu and I'm totally addicted to their curry! The service is amazing! I have a food allergy and the staff went out of their way to make sure there was no cross contamination. I would eat here every day if I could!
This place was incredible! By far the best meal we had while in London. The Chicken Tikka Masala with rice and a spicy naan is a must try. Definitely plan on coming back when we return.

Excellent. Food was exceptional and owner sat us down and gave us a little history and food recommendations. We had some great chicken, lamb and vegi dishes.  Seems very popular and you may want to make reservations.

Loved this place!  Best Indian food I have ever had. The flavors were incredible. Loved the tandoori chicken and cumin rice. I'm a light weight when it comes to eating spicy food and I was able to eat many things on the menu. The servers were so friendly and helpful and very fast. The restaurant has a great environment.

We were originally going to try Dishoom but the line was so long, so we opted to grab takeaway from Punjab.  One of the best Indian meals I've had!  Note that if you grab for takeaway, you get a discount (as with most places in London).  While we were waiting for our food, I ordered a mango lassi which was perfect and not overly sweet.
The garlic naan was buttery and had excellent flavor and giant pieces of garlic (which is a plus to me).  The chicken tikka masala had so much flavor, and the lamb korma was very creamy.  I think this place had the hands-down best tikka masala I had.  The prices are going to be a little steeper than what I'm used to in America, but we had leftovers that were still great the next day.  Service was excellent for us while we were waiting for our food, and they made sure to provide us with all the utensils that we needed.

I loved the food. And the wine is more than what I'm use to. My boyfriend and I shared the chicken tikka masala because we thought it would be too much for the both of us. Know that you need to add an order or rice and vegetables because it's not included with the main dish. We also added cheese naan, which I also loved! Lastly we ordered a milky dessert with bread in it and I also thought that was delicious! I would definitely return here for more meals. Service was extremely professional and friendly and quick.
One of our friends was on her way, and the staff didn't give us a table until she arrived. This is not the hospitality I would expect from any decent restaurant.

What a great find for Indian food!  On a busy Saturday night, the staff at Punjab were welcoming and highly efficient. After just a 15 minute wait, we were shown to a table upstairs where our drink orders were taken shortly after being seated. I had the house red wine, Borsao Garnacha 2014, which lived up to the fruity, full flavor as described on the menu!  Yum!
The vegetable samosas were great as an appetizer with a slightly different sauce than what I've had before, not too sweet, not hot, but flavorful - almost like a barbecue sauce. 
I had the chicken tikka masala and my husband had the Achari Murgha. My dish was tender and flavorful, definitely stood out among the many tikka masalas I've had!  The Achari Murgha was spicy and full of flavor, a completely different set of flavor than either of us had tried before. Both dishes were excellent and were well complemented by the garlic naan. 
We were impressed by the setting, the great food but especially by the service and care taken by the staff. We were greeted by the owner and he took time to speak with us on our way out, too, showing real interest and pleasure in our experience at his restaurant.

I arrived here on a Saturday evening for dinner. I was alone and it just took them 3 mins to find a place for me but even for large parties reservation didn't seem to be required.
The service was quick and courteous. I have ordered an Achcari lamb, which I loved -- it had the right amount of spices and it took no time to arrive -- but I think it can still be improved. 
I will go to this place again!
Amazing curries - definitely try their specialties. Very rich and complex in flavor and the ingredients tasted fresh. Great service and a pleasant dining experience overall.

We went here for dinner while visiting London and LOVED it!  We got an assortment of dishes that were all great. The service was excellent. The owner was talking to us while we were waiting for a table. My son remarked on how he likes spicy foods so the owner sent over a sample of the Chicken Madras sauce for him to try. This evidently is the spiciest thing on the menu. My son thought it was the best thing he ever tasted!!! We'll crave this yummy place now that we're back in the States!

It was my first time eating Indian food (as a well as my super picky husband). This place was awesome! We had the chicken tikka misala and tandoori vegetables! They were delicious. The cheese naan was also amazing. We are both hoping that we can find something that is close to this at home!

On our nightly wander looking for a place to eat dinner while on vacation my husband and I were planning to hit up Dishoom; however, the line was very, very long and we were very, very hungry. We checked out the map of the area and found Punjab was a quick walk from where we were and, since we were in the mood for Indian, it seemed a good choice. Let me say, I know nothing about Indian food and I have only ever had it twice in my life prior to this, but if I lived in London this would be a go-to, hands down. The food was absolutely delicious and largely sized, the staff actually provided a carafe of water for our table, the drinks were well priced and large, and the staff was friendly, too! I had the Chicken Tikka Masala and I wish I could find something this delicious close to home. My husband ordered one of their spicy dishes and it was definitely spicy (he tried denying this, but the color of his lips told the real story). We also had a flavored naan and the plain rice, both of which were delicious and helped stuff us. We also had no clue that this place was included in a Guy Fieri show, but luckily it wasn't super crowded when we went. Overall, go here. It's delicious, it's filling, it's just what you need if you're looking for Indian food in the Covent Garden neighborhood.

recommended by my indian friend as the "BEST indian food outside of india" that she's had, Punjab was one of the first restaurants i tried after landing in London
we were pretty underwhelmed by the food 2.5 stars.. but maybe because I didn't order the famed chicken tikka masala
--grandad's daal: BLAND
--lamb korma: this dish was ok
--acharri chicken: too tomatoe-y for my taste
--Garlic naan: pungent but pretty good
--we got one order of Flavored and another order of unflavored rice for the 3 of us
a reasonably priced meal for london
Bill includes a suggested 10% tip
NOTE: the 15 pound minimum order per person is flexible & they only print that on the menu so people don't order solely appetizers

The best parts were the service and the naan. It's a bit of a tourist trap, but almost everything in central London is to some extent, so I can't fault it for that- plus I'm no local either.
After years living in Singapore within a 10-minute walk to Little India for my weekly Indian fix, this was my first taste of classic British style Indian food. I had to try a chicken tikka... and it was ok. I've now been there, done that. Meh. The black dal (Grandad's dal) was ok. And so was the lamb korma. All around average. 
So far in London I preferred Dishoom more, however it is a much more modern restaurant. I opted to take the in-laws here, to Punjab, as I knew it was more traditional restaurant (quiet, good service). Not a bad place at all, but with all the Indian places in London, I'll try somewhere new next time for something more authentic, unusual or innovative.

We arrived with a large group of energetic children for dinner and were seated promptly and courteously. Traveling with children can be met with annoyance. I'm allergic to dairy and my server was incredibly conscientious and helpful in every way, assisting me to find the best dishes to accommodate, and setting the dishes I ordered carefully aside so as to avoid intermixing. Nirag was who helped us. He rushed the food out to help with the children and in every way was so attentive. For the flavors of the food, everything we tried was fantastic!
Great time with the kids. Good was great as always but I forgot how good the service is. Awesome.

We came here on a Wednesday evening for dinner. For a party of 6, the wait time wasn't bad at all - probably only 5 minutes? Anyway, we were seated pretty quickly, which was nice. One thing to note is the seating arrangement felt pretty cramped - separate tables were really close to each other, which made things a bit more uncomfortable.
Since I'm not an expert on Indian food, I let my friends pick our dishes since we were going family style. I think we went with a Chicken Tikka Masala (apparently a classic), Acharri Murgha, Karahi Paneer, and another paneer dish that I've forgotten. For sides, we ordered 3 garlic naans and 3 butter naans. The food took a while to come out, but when it did it all came out at once. Maybe for that reason the dishes weren't as hot as I would've liked them to be, but it was still warm enough.
I'm not the biggest fan of cheese, so the paneer dishes weren't my favorite. I did, however, enjoy the Chicken Tikka Masala! And the other chicken dish was alright, too. The garlic naan was pretty tasty, but it was a bit too oily for my liking. Overall, I thought the meal and experience were just ok - nothing special, but then again maybe that's just because I'm not a huge fan of Indian food to begin with.

Although I am no great expert on food, I think I can tell the difference between meals that come from a can, or a box, and those that come from the hands of a staff that knows what it's doing. The staff at Punjab knows what it's doing. The tikka masala is complex, as is the khorma. By complex I mean that I could taste the separate ingredients working together. My son, who has eaten a lot of Indian cuisine, says it was the best tikka masala he had ever had. Plus the service is relaxed. No one rushed us. This place is well worth a return trip.

Excellent food and great service!
We were seated right away and were informed that they needed the table at 7.30 and would we still like to sit. There was ample amount of time to eat so we sat down and looked at the menu. We ordered poppadoms, achari murgha, methi gosht, punjabi chole, rice, and pashwari naan. 
Everything was very yummy and in particular the chole was very tasty. I wish there was a little more heat in the lamb and chicken dish, but I'm sure I can ask for this next time I'm there.
The servers were very attentive. Will defo be back!

The food was pretty good, portions not huge and glasses were a bit dirty. Overall it was a good experience, but the waiters were a bit too pushy with drinks and food, continuously suggesting to get double of everything and more of this more of that. If you're in central and craving Indian this is good place

This was my first time in London and my first time having Indian food, and I have got to say, it was delicious! When I get back to New York I have to search for a spot like this. Really cool atmosphere and awesome food. if I'm ever back in London, I will be back at Punjab! Get the butter chicken!

One of the best indian food I have ever had. It is no wonder that my colleague recommended Indian food when I told him about my trip to London. I am sold. Bread was warm, every dish we had was tasty, five of us shared our food and we wipe down each plate clean. The server was super friendly and professional, he gave us suggestions since it was our first time there. I saw someone there wearing a really cool sheep t shirt and actually went up to him to ask him where he got the shirt from. Too bad it was from a local market, and I didn't have enough time to go.

If I were to pick between Dishoom and Punjab, I think I would pick Panjab. The wait time never exceeds 20 minutes no matter what group size. All dishes are pretty solid, from Lamb Korma, to Acharri Murgha, to Chicken Tikka Masala (just to name a few that I've tried). The Mango Lassi was good. But the mango juice was a bit watered down? I think I'm just used to a more nectar like consistency for mango juices. 
Special shoutout for the Chicken Madras though. The waiter warned me that it's very spicy and I didn't think too much of it. But seriously, never have I ever tasted such a spicy curry, let alone food. I was literally sweating buckets from this. My friends sampled my dish and felt the burn immediately. I think I felt it 1/3 of the way in. I wouldn't say it's a numbing kind of spicy, but more like a slow burn. Nonetheless, I thoroughly enjoyed the dish. But the strange thing is, I ordered the Lamb Madras a few months later and it wasn't half as spicy as the Chicken Madras? I already ensured my waiter that I can handle my spices... But I guess you really have to emphasize that you want it SPICY SPICY. 
I also like how the waiters throw in freebies every once in a while. My Panjabi friend asked for a Panjab specific bread called bhature, but was told that it's not on the menu. Around 15 minutes later our waiter brought out a basket of bhature specially made for her, free of charge! There was another occasion where I got a plate of papadam accompanied with various chutneys and pickled vegetables, free of charge once again! How awesome is that?! 
Overall great food, fantastic service, and reasonable price. I don't think my expectations for curry will be the same after eating at Punjab. Highly recommend this place!

My first time in London, and my first time eating authentic Indian food and what a terrific experience.  The service is great. The servers stand nearby and are waiting to serve you with a smile. The wait was short and the wine was delicious!  I wish California restaurants had the same service.  Bravo!!! One more thing, the manager Agnelo, surprised us with a sparkling desert. What a great guy.  Cheers Agnelo!
This place was very good. I came here with my family on our way to the British Museum

Amazing! Recommend sticking with the items in bold on the menu. We got papadum to start. The main dishes were chicken tikka special (when it comes out they light it on fire on the table!), chicken tandoori and butter chicken. Sides were malai kofta, saag paneer, rice, garlic naan and cheese naan. Everything we had was delicious. 
We also celebrated my parents 30th anniversary. The waiters all signed a card and brought out a nice ice cream dessert with a candle in it. The owner came by at the end to wish them well and see how we enjoyed dinner. We'll be back again :)

Manager is up front rushing everyone in and tells you quite bluntly that he has a table but you must be out by a certain time. 
The idea behind it is that he must rotate the tables 2-3 times for dinner, and it shows. Wether the food is good or bad is irrelevant, you can't enjoy it when waiters are staring you down for you to leave! As soon as you put your fork down, they are at your table to clean up. We refused to tell them that we were done, 5 times in less than 7 minutes, just to let our food go down to your stomach,
We were seated in the back room, which has 4 long tables, canteen style. There is a thick carpet in the room and dust accumulates on the black side boards on the walls .. disgusting. 
This place has a lot of potential, but when managed as it is, is just plain sad.
Save your money and go eat somewhere else, there are better places in London.

The ultimate gem of Punjabi food. 
How did miss this! All these years in London wasted!
Unbelievably good. 
Friendly staff with a great sense of humour.
Super fast service and no reservations. You won't have to wait long to be seated.
Trust me, you don't need to reserve here, just walk in anytime.
You might not realise how big this place is until you actually get in and explore it yourself. There are multiple floors and no matter where you sit, you'll have someone around to serve you. 
They serve traditional Punjabi food and some non Punjabi dishes too. 
Unfortunately I was so hungry and seduced by the look of the dishes served in front of me that I forgot to take pictures of them, which I usually do to post to Yelp. And when I started having them, I was in trance, so wasn't aware of much going on. 
One thing I noticed is that this place is filled with tourists and foreigners. Well that explains it. This restaurant is more famous than many others, search the web for "Oldest Punjabi restaurant in London" and you'll know. 
I will be eating here many more times. 
They have a wide variety of things on the menu, Punjabi Chicken/Mutton dishes are fabulous, but so are the vegetarian ones, so I hope to try out everything on their menu in the coming few years. 
I so regret the time I spent in London, not knowing this place existed. 
Don't repeat my mistake.

The food is good, but not that perfect.
The place a little bit small there is no personal space you can share the conversation with the next table.
Try the chicken masala and chicken butter. And the vegetable and lamb biryani.
And at last don't forget to try the cheese naan.
The best Indian food I've EVER had!!! If you're visiting London, you must go!!!

Punjab what can I say. Good quality food but Shitty service. We were forgotten(4 tables who arrived after us received their food before us wtf). They also charged our table for an additional naan.....that we never ate)... I never ever write bad reviews but after tonight's dinner I have to. I was so hungry and sad that the staff forgot about our table that I started to tear. Bye punjAb. I'll go to dishoom

Same as others had reviewed, we originally went to Dishoom down the street, but had a 40 minute wait at 10pm. Came here and were blown away by the flavors.  Great service accompanied fantastic food. I highly recommend!

Food is okay. Butter chicken ... Meh ... It's alright . And then . Well . Food quality is alright ! It's just the staff Is the reason I downgraded this review from a 4 to a 2. To begin with, in 5 mins , the same waiter asked 3 times : are u ready to order . ( as if I am in his way if I don't ) And when I asked for recommendation and asking what the indian dishes were ( I was searching on my phone earlier ) , and then he fucking took my phone and then did some tapping ( hard!) and then satisfied himself with what he found as a " bangai" food pic and then threw my iPhone 6s on the table ! Basically he has used my phone without my permission and Hey ! Throwing it back ! That was raging !! And then when we ordered , me and my friend said one only even after he said it s too small for both of us, and we said no, and when he confirmed the order , he just was like : 2 naan yeh ? I was like ONE !!!!! And then he asked what we want to drink and we don't feel like ordering any beverages but just tap water . He shot this look of " order so little !" At us ( at this point , it is pretty subjective ) . Anyways . Got through the end ... And then once they quickly cleared the table , there stood the dessert menu and when we said no , next thing on table was the bill, even we didn't ask for it. We didn't touch the bill for like 2 mins cuz me and my mate were chatting . This staff interrupted and was like : everything alright ? There are people waiting outside . We were very upset by the service . Probably won't go again .  This kind of fast food restaurant is not what we look for and customer service still trumps commercialized food ! Even fast food allows u to sit for awhile. And besides , had better Indian food around the area .

Great Indian restaurant with a very differentiated menu, for every kinda of taste! Excellent quality-price considering that it is settled in the heart of London. Friendly place, excellent both for a dinner with friends or a more serious occasion.

Very good food! Actually best food I had in London! 
Service was excellent! Very friendly and polite!

My first taste of authentic Indian food was at Punjab and it certainly didn't disappoint! Holy moly, the food amazing and the service was friendly. I ordered the lamb curry (which was extra spicy) and the white rice as well as the chicken tikka and a side of naan bread. Everything was delicious. I dream of the day I get back to London and go over to Covent Garden to get my Indian food fix on.

The service was friendly, and the food was delicious. The portions are perfect, had plenty of food. It was very congested inside, very tiny tables with barely any room to walk around, which is probably because so many people are enjoying the great food.

Great service and food. The cheese Naan is a must.
No reservation was needed, came in and was sat right away.

This two-story restaurant is good, and apparently very established. It is not my favorite by a long shot (try Indian Express in West Kensington), but I would go there again if I was in the area. Service was sufficient, but not as refined as some of the Indian restaurants I've been to recently.
The portions were generous, and the Acharri Ghost (lamb) had delicious flavor without being too hot, although the lamb itself was just a bit tough. The Chicken Tikka Masala was good as well. I really liked the Grandad's Kali Dall, and I ladled it over my Pilau Rice to form a great concoction. I have no idea if this is the proper way to eat it, but it worked nicely and nobody kicked me out.
Long story short, this place can leave you walking away happy, but I can't guarantee that you'll fall in love.
I always visit the Punjab whenever I go to London. Did is always good and service outstanding. The Methi Lamb is my personal favourite. I would not go anywhere else in central London.
Excellent food, amazing service, authentic and reliable quality food.

This restaurant was recommended by many on a recent trip. It was good but for sure did not live up to the hype. Service was excellent but food lacked spices and depth. If you like blander food this is the spot for you.

Good food with decent service. You won't be sorry you came but there's probably some better Indian in london , they did have air conditioning during the heat wave in london while we were there. 
If you're nearby its worth the eat.

So so so good! Cool looking space, very clean and seems like they have two waiters per table, so you are well taken care of. Very reasonable prices if not on the cheaper side for the high quality. I will for sure be back!

We wanted to go to Homeslice around the corner but the wait was too long and so decided to go here instead since there was sort of a small queue and we always passed by it wanting to try it out. The food is good. The daal Makhani tastes like my moms and that almost brought tears to my eyes :') the service is O-Kay at best and the ambience is also a bit strange. Overall good food, but I don't know if I'll go back again!

Decent food. Rude and curt staff. Didn't check in one between ordering food and drinks and when I asked for the bill. When I asked for the bill, the waiter finally asked if I wanted I refill on my drink which I had finished 20 minutes earlier. There are better places in London with less entitled staff.

Sometimes it's easy to forget what a great Indian meal is when there is so much mediocre out there. Glad to say that after tonight I have been reminded again. Their no reservation system works because their service is so efficient, so even though it was Friday and they were rammed, we didn't wait too long. Food was very tasty, chicken succulent, sauces just right without relying on over spicing and naan supper fresh. A great curry house in the centre of theatre district - but given that it's been going since 1946 you probably don't need me to tell you that.

Very friendly welcome and attentive service for my family of 5 children under 13yrs old on a busy Friday night at 8:30pm. So thankful!!! Great depth of flavor in every dish we tried - butter chicken, tikka masala, black lentil dal, samosas, mango lassis, even the cheese naan. A bit too spicy for my kids after growing accustomed to our favorite Indian in blandly spiced Germany. Easy to get to from Tube station nearby.

We came here based on the reviews and proximity to our hotel.
I enjoyed the food here but not sure if it's the best Indian curry I've ever had. I know there's many types of curries from different regions but I guess Punjab is not my favorite. It's a little too tomatoe-y for my taste.
I've never been to an Indian restaurant where I had to pay extra for white rice. The rice usually comes with the curry. And not only that but when we got the bill, the rice was 3 pounds so that's about $5 USD for just white rice. We ordered two. If we had known, I would have gotten more naan instead. Some of the naan were cheaper than white rice.
The service was ok. Nothing great.
The place seemed pretty touristy. No one at the nearby tables were English. They were either Japanese, American or Swedish (?).

We ordered the butter chicken along with chicken marsala accompanied by rice and naan, of course. I really enjoyed the butter chicken, it had flavor but I definitely wouldn't consider it "spicy." I will admit that I don't have the most refined Indian pallette in the world but the chicken marsala sauce tasted much like the sauce in a can of SpaghettiOs if we're being honest. 
The service from the staff was excellent. They seated us immediately and made sure we were always looked after. 
The meal was relatively costly for what I expected, about £35 for the two of us.
Came here cus I saw it on TV. I have 0 regrets! Service great and the food so so tasty! Id love to go back! And i will!

This had the best chicken tikka masala that i've ever had. Real good service in a nice part of town. Excellent. Wife had the muhtar paneer, which was also very good. The samosas leave something to be desired, but other than that, its brilliant!

Coming off a disappointing curry house the night before, I was hopeful my experience at Punjab would turn things around. It did.
The food was amazing. I had Grandad's Kali Daal, and even though I'm not normally a vegetarian, I was blown away by this meal. It was rich, not overly creamy (most likely yogurt-based), and perfectly cooked. The lentils were firm to the bite but thoroughly stewed. The naan was the right balance of pliable, but crunchy. Even the plain basmati rice I ordered was perfectly cooked.
The service was punctual, but as others have noted, it could have been friendlier. The waitstaff wasn't rude, just cold and non-interactive. I would have given Punjab 5-stars had the service been better. But everyone there was so aloof, I docked them a star just on that one aspect.
The interior is intimate and cozy. Nothing mind-blowing but very relaxing.
All-in-all, Punjab restaurant is well worth the visit if you're seeking a well-priced, authentic, delicious stop on your culinary tour of London.

Went with wife and daughter last week while visiting from US.  Food was Tip Top, I had the chicken tika masala which was tender and tasty.  Wife had butter chicken which she enjoyed.  Duaghter enjoyed her eggplant dish,  Apps were delicious and plentiful.  Highlight of the meal was the Naan, which had coconut and dried fruit.  When we return this summer to London I plan on going back.

3.5 stars.
So Saturday around 7:45 pm for a table of 2 there was only about a 10 minute wait. My recommendation is to book in advance for sure no matter what party size you are because why not? The line can get quite long and it isn't entirely predictable, so might as well be safe.
Shortly after we got in the line, it became quite long quite quickly. A group of about 10 behind us was told it would be a 1.5 - 2 hour wait.
Now the people here are mostly fun and jovial. There are a couple of servers who were a bit cold and impatient, but generally speaking people are smiley and friendly. The expediter at the front who passes the dishes to the servers is super friendly. 
The food here is really interesting - you'll see things here that they don't have elsewhere and vice versa. I would recommend actually going with a Punjabi dish here instead of something you can get anywhere (like a generic tikka masala or korma). 
We went with the acharri murgha and chicken malai tikka.
Acharri Murgha - an classic Punajbi pickle-style chicken, medium spiced, and a bit tangy. Now let me say a word about the "pickle-style" - the sauce is flavoured with pickles in the cooking process, but there are no actual pickles in it. The pickle taste is also certainly not overwhelming, which I was really afraid of. This was a delicious, unique, flavorful dish and I would highly recommend it. I haven't tasted much like it before and I would absolutely get it again.
Chicken Malai Tikka - chicken breast marinated with cream, cheese, and yoghurt, cooked in the tandoori and served sizzling with onions on a skillet. This dish was just ok, but nothing special. I expected much more from the dish. The chicken was super soft, tender, and creamy, but there wasn't a lot of flavour and it wasn't interesting.
The hariyali chicken tikka really caught my eye, but I was too afraid to try it because it's apparently a very very strong coriander taste (with some mint as well) and some of the servers seemed to think it could be overwhelming.
We also got steamed rice and naan, which I wouldn't say was one of the better ones I've had.
Overall though, I was very happy with the meal, the staff, and the acharri. I'd definitely recommend giving this place a try.

I do not know what all the hype is about. We had a reservation and were seated in a lovely room. When the food came we were shocked to see only 1 naan for 2 people. That's just weird. 
I ordered the Tikka chicken and it was OK, it wasn't anything to write home about. It was just OK. It was so quiet during lunch that it really was no fun. 
I will never go back again. Keep your hype, I'll just go to my amazing neighbourhood place that's yet to be discovered.

While on my first ever trip in London, I felt the experience could not be complete without an Indian food tasting.  The English food had thus far proved to be a mediocre affair, but I had heard great things about the Indian food.  While strooling through Covenant Gardens I noticed many street signs attempting to lure tourist into other Indian restaurants; Punjab did not engage in this practice but I was lured to it all the same.
Punjab is a fourth generation family owned restaurant and bears the title of being the oldest Punjabi restaurant in England, which I think is very cool.  The menu is quite extensive with over 100 different options to try and each choice complete with is own colorful description about how succulent the dish is.  And, the food was amazing.  I ordered the Acharri Murgha because it was quoted as a once in a lifetime experience, and I have nothing to say against it.  Also, props go the management who provided my mother with an off the menu version of chicken tikka that was free of spice sicne she cannot tolerate any.
The pricing is expensive and all naan and rice is done a la carte which add to the price.  The beer, however, is reasonable.  I had a Cobra, it complemented the dishes.
Excellent chicken tikka masala. Definitely one of the better restaurants in London. However, must get there early to beat the crowd. Very clean and quaint.

Wanted to go to Dishoom but they don't take reservations for under 6 people and despite being told that they turn around tables quickly, there was an hour long line outside. That's just a huge waste of time so we Yelped nearby and settled on Punjab. Glad we did because it was several plates full of awesome.
There were three of us and we ordered the right amount of food: two chicken dishes, two veggie dishes, rice and naan. We even had desert. Everything was excellent including the pickles for the popadoms.
I am very pleased that they had air conditioning upstairs since it would otherwise have been unbearably hot.

Food was tasty, but service was lacking.
I got the butter chicken and the saag paneer.  The butter chicken was as advertised, two pieces of bone-in chicken smothered in a creamy butter sauce.  The saag paneer had a decent kick to it.  I saw someone get the chicken tikka special, I think I will get that next time with a side of masala as one of the other reviewers recommended.
Worth a stop if your unsure which quick Indian place you want to jump into.

We dined at this restaurant after freshly arriving from Paris to London for the first time.  We looked for good Indian restaurants on Yelp! and this was a well reviewed one.  We had a 20 minute walk from the hotel to this place and decided to stop for a fruit juice on the way (my wife was starving and it was hot).  As soon as we got into the restaurant, one of the server rudely said "No outside drinks allowed".  And then continued to tell us that we can go drink it outside and come back.  When I say rudely, I mean he was kind of ordering us and making us feel uncomfortable as if we just sneaked a drink in at the Movie Theater.  So that was a bad first impression.  
The Menu looked good though.  Much more choices than usual.  I ordered Kadai Chicken with Garlic Naan and my wife ordered some Yellow Daal with Chappati.  The Daal, Chappati, and the Garlic Naan were good.  The Kadai Chicken, on the other hand, was really bad.  I could barely bite into the chicken it was so hard.  
After our first bad impression, the service was not bad.  I think it is important to treat your customers with respect and "ask" them to "please" refrain from bringing outside drinks instead of ordering them and making them feel uncomfortable in front of other customers.
The food that was good was average.  The food that was bad really takes the rating down another star.  And the outside drink incidence takes down another star.

After two days in London on vacation, my mother and I experienced one of the most incredible meals. Punjab is not to be missed. Right around the corner from the hotel and pretty centralized to everything else (such as Covent Garden and Holborn) it is incredible. 
We had chicken tikka masala which was fantastic, garlic naan that was soft, crunchy and delicious, and another type of chicken coated in mint and coriander. It came out sizzling, warm and tender. Perfect. Why hadn't we come here earlier?
Highly recommend this place for anyone local or anyone visiting the area. Oh and the service is outstanding. Attentive and patient. Gets the job done. A+

My family and I were looking for some great indian food on our recent trip to London, but didn't want to make the trek to Whitechapel. Thanks to yelp, we found Punjab in a fantastic location near Oxford st. The place was busy, and we were seated right away even though we didn't have a reservation. The servers were nice, and the food was great. Definitely order the butter chicken (although our bowl only had two pieces of chicken). We ordered the garlic naan, despite the funny tip on the menu. The garlic isn't really as strong as the menu warns, so I wouldn't worry about not getting any action after the meal! 
I would definitely return!
Every time I'm in London this is a must stop for a terrific Indian meal. Service is always great and why I've been coming back for 10+ years.
If you are craving a curry in Central London, this is probably your best bet.  Lamb chops came sizzling to the table. Tasty!

I had the best Indian food I had ever had here and had a wonderful experience. We chose this restaurant based on its good Yelp reviews, and we were not disappointed. When we got to the restaurant, we were greeted by the owner. He asked us where we were from and then gave us his suggestions on what we should order. His suggestions did not disappoint! I will definitely come back next time I am in London. Overall, delicious food, excellent staff, welcoming owner, amazing dining experience.

We really enjoyed this restaurant! 
This was our first meal in London and we had heard that London has some great Indian food. We wanted to go to Dishoom, but couldn't get in. In retrospect, we are glad we landed on this place. 
We were able to get in without a reservation. The bartender that greets customers as they walk in was very friendly. The service was excellent. We had 3 waiters/servers for our table of two. 
The food came out speedy fast. I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala and my girlfriend ordered Chicken Tandoori. We were both very pleased. It was very tasty. We also had an order of the garlic naan which was standard. 
The prices were reasonable (just under £30 for two). I would definitely recommend Punjab to anyone that is in the London area and in the mood for Indian food.
Food was great. The service for London was attentive and quick. The prices were reasonable. Didn't love the wine, but that was probably a bad selection on my end.

Food is ok. Nothing to write home about. They charge for every little thing e.g pappad, rice. The entree are at a higher price range and they dont even include rice. Roti or naam coats about £2.50 each just to give an idea. Rice is also not cheap. The ambience and service is just ok. I dont't think I'll be going back.

Touted as UK's oldest North Indian restaurant, Punjab is really just upscale Indian food. There are variations on the naan and the basmati rice is overpriced, but you can't argue with the well cooked curry. My acharri gosht was perfectly cooked and the lamb was tender. While my brain was telling me that cottage cheese did not belong in gravy, butter, and cream, the paneer makhani was delicious and tasted more like tofu. The prices were a bit high for what you get, but at least the food tasted good.

I've been here a few times and it's always busy.  The food is pretty tasty. However  It is standard 
 North Indian fare with a few unusual dishes thrown in.  We had chicken Madras,  chicken Korma  and a couple of veggie dishes-saag aloo and mushroom masala.  I  asked for the Madras to be extra hot. Usually this can result in a psychotic chef's revenge by emptying the entire tub of chili powder in the dish,  or alternatively  it remains resolutely pretty mild.  This Madras was bang on.   The food was very well put together.  It does what it says on the tin.  Prices are a little high though.  Service is harassed though reasonably friendly.  You can do a lot worse than the Punjab,  though if you're looking for more cutting edge Indian food then look elsewhere.

The food was fine, but if you are a tourist, check your bill carefully.  I was overcharged and thought that the bill was a little high when it was presented to me, but was in a rush to leave.  When I got back to the hotel, I had a bad feeling about the bill and checked the prices of what I ordered online.  Sure enough, I was overcharged,  It could have been a mistake, but I truly do not believe that it was.  Unfortunately, I paid cash, otherwise, I would go back to the restaurant to get my money back.  It's the principle,  I hate dishonesty.

So a disclaimer - I don't know the difference between good or great Indian food, or even what regional Indian foods should taste like. 
However what I can say, is that my family and I had an excellent experience here. We came here based off the reviews from more knowledge food folk, and the quality of service, food and the general restaurant environment was all top notch. Our server was helpful, and our choices were all satisfactorily spicy/not spicy. They were also happy to keep our box of leftovers in their kitchen while we went off to the theater. 
The other option would have been Dishoom, but I'm glad we didn't go there - the atmosphere at this place is really nice, and Dishoom just seems like it's trying too hard. plus their no reservations policy is a little objectionable.
Punjab gets a well deserved 5 stars.
