Food was good, not great.  Service was prompt,  but not personal.   Get in, get out!  Also, if you don't say anything,  an "optional service 10" charge is added...I'm guessing for tip?   Also, what the hell, rice costs $3.30!!!  It's good rice,  but it's freaking rice!

So, this was the only Indian restaurant we went to in London, but my god was it the best Indian food I've ever eaten. No where I've ever been on the west coast (of America) can hold a candle to this place. We ended up going for dinner 2 out of the 4 nights we were in London! If you get there before 6pm for dinner, you won't have to wait in their line outside.

I'll start off by first ditto'ing Rick G's comment on the putrid stench.
Second, wtf?? How is this place rated so highly? Saying the best dishes we tried were even mediocre would be flattery. Blegh. The chicken tikka masala was- ok. And that was the best we had. The spinach both tasted disgusting and was completely unappetizing to look at. You have to pay for rice. The tandoori was bland and boring. 
SO very disappointed to have wasted my one night out in London at Punjab.
And again, the chemical odor, ugh. Voila, my first one-star review.
Delicious food, great atmosphere albeit slightly packed when you're sitting at the back like we did. My favourite Indian restaurant in London!

I visited Punjab for the second time last night and was not disappointed. The place is hopping on a Saturday night, with plenty of tourists, but we waited less than five minutes for a table. The chana masala was amazing, even my dining companions were jealous. The food prices are reasonable and the wine prices remarkably low. On my first visit, service was a bit brusque, but last night they redeemed themselves. I wholeheartedly recommend Punjab!

Incompetent. Made a reservation for 7 people at 9:15pm. Had a long conversation, the man took the booking, wrote down my phone number and wrote down my name (even asked me to spell it). 
When we arrived, the man acted like we never made the reservation while my party of 7 waited outside. They claimed they dont make reservations. Complete utter disregard for us. Yelled at and everything. Avoid just to not support this business.

Great service Agnelo AKA Michael and The Governor who we had a lovely conversation with about the history of the restaurant.
Prices are like an normal sit down middle priced place in London. I've averaged 45 Pounds for 2 anywhere in London. Lets put it this way I would rather spend that 45 pounds here, good value.
We had Butter chicken which was made with real bone-in tandoori chicken (the right way to make it) Delicious.
Also ordered the Achari lamb which was equally great and I found my self ordering more Naan to clean up what left in the dish :)
So if you are in the Covent garden area and want some nice indian cuisine then this is your place.
BTW: Chemical Odder other reviewers talked about wasnt that noticeable but I caught it too.  
I think comes from the bathroom, I bet you all were sitting in the hall between the bathroom and the main door. The one on your right when you enter. I think the draft between the bathroom and the front door opening delivers the smell. At least you know that the bathrooms are clean :)

A lovely place in Coventry Garden. Dropped in for dinner and got seated straight away. They did let us know they needed the table for guest coming in a few hours, no worries. Had classic Indian form tikka to sagg paneer. Non disappointed and would make a return visit next time we come through.

Coming to London, one has to sample the curries. Punjab was perfect. Great service, great ambience, great food. And, the place has been open since 1946.
I ordered the Lamb Saag and the chicken tikka special. I always order chicken tikka and think I am getting a nice curry sauce with it, and it always comes out without the masala sauce. So I ordered this sauce on the side with the special dish. 
So the dish is prepared at your table with the server drizzling some alcohol over the chicken tikka dish, which comes out on a sizzling hot plate. The guy lights the alcohol on fire!!!! It's perfect.
The Cheese Naan was not as good as I hoped.
The guy didn't charge me for the Masala sauce.

Delicious traditional Indian fare. The restaurant is busy so book in advance. The menu is hilarious - see the Garlic Naan description. Indian cuisine is one of my favourites - this stood up well. Go with a group, as portions are large and you need to try a few dishes.

Undoubtedly, one of the best North Indian restaurants in London. I usually order mango lassi in every Indian restaurant. But decided to try salted lassi this time and I was not disappointed. It was perfect. I tried different kinds of breads(bullet naan, chapathi and tandoori paratha), kaali dal and masala chai. It was heavenly. The service was very quick. And the waiting time for a table wasn't bad. We went there on New Year's eve and I thought we would have to wait for a long time to get a table. But, we got a table as soon as we walked in. The staff were very friendly. I would definitely go there again to try the rest of the dishes!

We went there with a couple of friends: the food is exquisite, but quite spicy so be ready. Got the chicken tikka masala, daal, garlic naan, rice pilau. Everything was perfectly cooked and it wasn't that expensive: around 20£ per person

Most racist place.. Went for dinner there with family and friends and it looks like they like to cater only to English people ... Serving Indian people in A Indian restaurant is below their dignity .. The owner was disrespectful and inappropriate with even kids. Just appalling behavior !!! Honestly just full of ..: !!!! Don't waste ur money n time to bear the humility from these dumb racist idiots.

Tasty Indian food in London at a reasonable price. All 3 of us enjoyed our dinners here. I had Chicken Madras which was hotter that I've had at other restaurants. That's not a complaint because it tasted great; just HOT! The chicken was breast meat and prepared well.
We also liked the Punjabi Samosa and Chicken Tikka Masala, and Garlic Naan. 
Friendly, efficient staff help make the dining experience pleasant. I'd be happy to come back here again when I'm in London.

Not the best chicken korma in the world but the service was so nice and friendly (I ate solo and was happy as a clam) and the pilau rice was great.
Oh yeah, the tandoori wings were pretty good too.

The food was delicious. I would stop in again on my trip if I didn't still have leftovers - and if it wasn't for the 15 pound/person minimum they list in small text on the bottom of the menu. For a meal there is no worry about teaching the minimum between an entrée, rice (or bread) and a drink. It's worth it, too. 
I waited until a waiter brought me a box for my leftovers to ask for a masala chai and that order was lost. Another waiter brought me the bill and I did not check it for the chai - which occasioned many minutes afterward of curious stares as the staff wondered why I wasn't leaving and I wondered how long it took to make a chai. After a bit I asked a server, who got pretty flustered, checked my bill, and in the end have me a free glass of chai so no complaints.
Great little restaurant near the Lion King theatre. Super quick service and an unbeatable price. Loved it!

Okay, very underwhelmed by the food here.  Came here by myself for dinner based on the generally positive yelp reviews here and not sure if I feel like this place delivers.  Started out with an appetizer of the amritsari fish, then had the main dish of acharri murgha with some plain naan, with a mango lassi to wash it all down.  Yes, food was generally tasty but definitely did not live up to the hype of the amazing quality of British Indian food.  As an example, the fish tasted like it was just thawed frozen fish fried with some spices.  Nothing was bad at all, and I had a generally good dinner, but nothing at all was special.  I've had much better Indian food in a number of restaurants in NYC.  Also, just as a slight aside, I think almost every customer in the restaurant was a tourist, which while not always indicative of anything, in the context of my lackluster meal, does not bode well for the quality of the food. 
That being said, I had no issues with the service of the wait staff.  Everyone was polite and attentive and I did not feel rushed out at any point.

They have very good food and excellent service. Very tasty dishes with excellent curries. 
They need to update their restaurant, it's rather poor shape but it shouldn't stop you from going if you want good Indian food

Met a friend here this August, expected a tourist trap given its location, only to find them trying not to be even that. Their claim to authenticity is in their lack of customer service for anybody non-white. Food was mostly horrible, and I do not use the word "horrible" lightly. Only the uninitiated will find this close to Indian cooking. Unfortunately, we are spoiled by Delhi's Gulatis, Karims and any number of choices in SFO bay area.
Our meal started with Dry Kebabs that were dry and reheated. Excess of food coloring in CTM and shrimp was rubbery. Their Daal and recommended veggies(we had eggplant) were particularly bland and undercooked. Naan was ok..All in all looked like it was cook's first day at work. Servers were more interested in upping the check and getting us to leave even though we over ordered for six. Do not waste your time and money here, London can do better.

This was a great restaurant. No wait (despite not having a reservation), super food and considerate service, with reasonable prices. 
I really enjoyed the Chicken Tikka Special, which came out sizzling and seasoned just right. Garlic Naan was very tasty as well.

Very good and expensive Indian restaurant. 
Perfect service.
Very busy, so better reserve early.

Inexpensive yet delicious. I have read the reviews and heard people rave about this place for eons, and when I finally made my way in there, it did not disappoint.
The food was wonderful, the waiters were attentive and friendly, the price was very reasonable. The restaurant itself is pretty small and decorated with pictures of the family who own it and with some photos of the maharajahs (I think - it could have just been a really extravagant school uniform), which was a nice touch.
If you like Indian food, definitely go here

As always, very good.  We always visit the Punjab when in London.  The food is excellent, and the service is wonderful.  We are never disappointed.  This time we took some friends, and they were impressed too!  The house specialties are outstanding.
We had a very late lunch (or early dinner?) around 4:30 here. Loved their cheese naan! Favorite naan in all of London so far!
Outstanding is the one word to describe this place. Food beverage and staff all receive high marks.
Great authentic indian food for very reasonable prices. No queues. A good recommendation.
Great lamb curries and roast chicken.

Having been in London for a few months now upon writing this review, I must start off by saying that I've really fallen in love with the Indian cuisine offered in the city, however, as a result, I'm beginning to grow a bit more critical when reviewing Indian as I learn to understand it better.
To start off, Punjab provides customers with a great atmosphere for dining.  Located right at the end of Neal Street in Covent Garden, Punjab is a great place to go after a bit of shopping or after work.  Additionally, the service is absolutely fantastic, with quick and funny waiters who are more then willing to help should you find yourself in a bind as to what dish to have (and you will!)
As for the food, however, Punjab falls just a tad bit short when taking into consideration that you'll likely pay around 12 pounds if you get a dish with rice and naan.  The serving sizes are a tad bit small (certainly too small to split) for what you pay, and having sampled a bit from the dishes of those around me, I found that the seasoning was pretty much the same even with dishes that were drastically different from one another.  
If you're in it for the atmosphere, Punjab is a great choice, but if you're really trying to get the best bang for your buck I might consider looking elsewhere.

Let me start by pointing out that I have an increasingly large Italian friendship base, and one thing that Italian's (in my experience) can't really handle is the classic, mouth melting curry. It took me roughly 11 months to convince my partner that this really was a good place to go, and she's glad I did. The only problem I now have is that I have to argue extensively so that I don't have curry every Friday night.
The Punjab is pretty close to a tourist heavy area - not necessarily a bad thing, but the obvious fears of quality/authenticity are apparent. Within 30 seconds of sitting down though, the fears are instantly dispelled. The staff are beyond friendly, the recommendations really strong and most importantly REALLY descriptive. It made it very easy for my partner to pick what type of curry would be best for her (surprisingly not the Korma) and which starters would enable her to be a little more adventurous (she had the pokora, which were the "right type of spicy").
Beyond the food, the wine selection is, if anything, slightly luxurious for a curry house (I staunchly stuck to my cobra) and received no complaints from my partner, a minor miracle in itself. The best thing about the Punjab for me though is the atmosphere and the place itself. It's a proper curry house - it doesn't set out to be a really pretentious and ultra-modern environment, where you're served minimal portions in a stylish fashion, and it doesn't pander to touristy gimmicks - it's basically like a freshly decorated version of your local curry house - clean, warm and friendly. 
You will need to book for Friday and weekend slots, and it's always worth trying to get yourself a table on the left side of the restaurant where the atmosphere is a little bit more cosy (and the seating against the walls is a bit comfier than the normal seats). To the right is the primary room, which is great if you have a large group or if you are there on the busier nights, but on an early weekday or early in the day, you can get a little bit lost in the space and feel a little isolated. Beyond that, get the vegetable samosas every time, because the dark red/brown sauce that it comes with is the best thing on the menu.
Real taste of North Indian food. Delicious lamb. If you want to try real Indian food, aromatic, full of flavour, that's the best choice. Highly recommend.

Indian food of the highest quality with service to match.  Well priced to boot.  The only downside was a wait of about 20 minutes as I failed to book a table ahead of time.
Since my dining companion is spice averse, we ordered fairly benign dishes.  On this night, we had the butter chicken, samosas, cholay and garlic naan.  The butter chicken might have been the best I've had.  There was a wonderful smoky component to the chicken that came through despite the rich, luxurious sauce.  That sauce, well, I could have drunk that from a cup it was so good.  As it was, I tried to soak up every last drop with the freshly baked naan.
Service was extremely attentive, with the manager coming around a few times to check up on us.
Punjab was been around for about 60 years, and it's easy to see why.  In a city that prides itself on the quality if its Indian food, I feel that Punjab is definitely amongst the upper crust.

Hands down my favorite Indian restaurant in Covent Garden!  IThis review is from when I visited a few years back, but the memories of the meal were like yesterday.
We didn't have any reservation when we arrived, and it was a cold rainy London day.  We got a nice seat, away from the door, and proceeded to order.  I chose the tandoori chicken platter and it did not disappoint. The chicken was very tender and perfectly spiced.  The naan was also great as was the raita.
The entire dining experience was fabulous.  Service was fantastic and the other diners in the restaurant were very friendly.  I want to come back to London and visit this fine establishment!
Good was great and prices were fair. We enjoyed the chicken tikka masala (each our own order!), samosas, paratha and garlic naan. Great service.

Methi Gosht was incredible as was the service and presentation. The manager came to our table to check up on everything and recommended to get Methi Gosht with Paratha instead of with Naan. A great choice.
The Acchari Murgh was good but not as good as the Methi Gosht.
We ordered two desserts and they served Kulfi and Gulab Jaman just the way we liked it. 
A wonderful dining experience.

I'm torn on this one. I feel like it was four star food but a three star experience. The ambiance was very strange and it was overpriced. The food was prepared very well, the naan was tasty, the jalfrezi was exactly the right amount of spicy. But I'm not accustomed to paying nearly £4 for rice or naan. If you're in the area and looking for an Indian place to duck into, this is a reliable option, though not the cheapest for what it  is. 
They give you lollies with your bill, which strangely really excited me. I will give the experience four stars overall on account of the incredible menu descriptions. In particular, check out the garlic naan description and the brief paragraph under the Lamb Curry heading.

I've walked past this place for years, always considering it as somewhere that was likely to be a tourist trap. Glad I finally considered it as had quite a delicious meal.
I definitely recommend that you treat yourself to some Poppadoms as the green mystery sauce they come with is really tasty, whatever it is.
 I picked one of their 'traditional' options, I forget the name. It was really nice as were the chapathi and the chilli naan that accompanied it.
All washed down with a pleasant Cava. Nice all round meal.

After attempting to make a trip to Little India, we made a quick decision to get back on the tube after our mission had failed (the area didn't look safe for women to walk around at night), so we re-routed and decided to go to Punjab which was our 2nd choice after reading reviews on Yelp. I'm glad that we did! We really enjoyed this quaint restaurant. Our friends raved about the Indian food in London, so eating at an Indian restaurant in London was a must on our to-eat list.
{ORDER}
* Chicken Tandoori - the best chicken tandoori! The meat literally melted in your mouth, it was oh-so-soft!
* Butter Naan - after trying the regular naan, we decided to get the butter naan after seeing the table next to us ordering multiple baskets. We loved it! The butter made a huge difference and made the naan very moist.
{DON'T ORDER}
* Acharri Murgha Chicken Curry - we weren't impressed with the flavors and the pickled, tangy flavored was unexpected and ruined it for me.
* Garlic Naan - too dry
* None of their desserts - the wanna-be carrot cake came out super hot and did not resemble anything like American carrot cake. It felt like eating mushy carrots. The other dessert, not sure what it was called but it was in a white liquid form was a huge disaster. 
{ENVIRONMENT}
* Great service
* Quaint, clean restaurant
* Located in Convent Garden (safe area, lots of retails)
Punjab is UK's oldest Indian restaurant. That tells you something. They're doing something right!

I recently spent several days in London and wanted to eat some great Indian Food.  Looking at Yelp, Punjab seemed to be among the best so we decided to give it a try.  I won't say it's the worst Indian food I've ever eaten.  No, it's truly mediocre.  Dry, flavorless naan, poor quality rice, bland dal... everything you'd expect from a mediocre Indian restaurant.  I hope those who thought this was the "Best freaking Indian food" get a chance to eat at better places.  They can start a few blocks away, at Dishoon (it's not the best Indian food I've had, but definitely better).
What makes Punjab one star, though, is the painfully strong odor of industrial strength soap that permeated ever nook and cranny of the place.  And after sitting in that horrid stench for an hour, it also permeated every nook and cranny of my skin and clothes.  The crazy thing is that this soapy smell seems to be the result of some towels that they give you at the end of the dinner, so you can clean your hands.  Or maybe, so you can get a chemical peel.  Either way, it was ridiculous and it totally ruined any chance we might have had to enjoy our meal.
There are many more Indian restaurants in London.  Give some of them a try instead of this place.

AMAZING!! Honesty some of the best Indian food I've yet to enjoy and in such an awesome location. 
First, we got lost and looped around from the Covent Garden station to Neal Street. Not really sure how that happened, but we loved walking around, it's such a funky and fun area. Finally we found it and were greeted by such a nice gentleman who kept joking around with my boyfriend and I. From the instant the door opened you could smell a variety of divine spices and we knew that this place was going to be great.
We ordered chicken tikka massala, mixed chicken tandoori, a lamb curry I can't remember the name, plain naan, garlic naan, and white wine. SO GOOD! Will definitely be going back again. Great charm with good service and amazing food. Can't really get much better than that. It was a little pricier than expected but definitely worth it. Get there sooner than later or you'll be waiting outside because this place is so popular! 
I found the reviews here on yelp to be very helpful so thank you to you all who have enjoyed it and GO FOR IT for those of you who haven't!
Delish. Fantastic garlic naan and chicken tiki masala. Overall good service. We dined on a Monday evening and sat upstairs. Quaint location

This was the most bland indian food we have ever eaten. Did they run out of spices tonight? The black daal, a recommended dish, just tasted like cream and beans. The paneer was too dense and bland. The stuffed eggplant was really good, but that was the only standout dish.

No need to wait 2 hours for Dishoom's. 5 minutes up the street. Excellent service. Started with Garlic naan and cheese naan- very good. Had chicken acchari muggers and chicken madras-both excellent. Chicken tandoori was moist.

We had a great expiriencie, for us it was the best indian food we had in London. We ordered the lamb karma, chiken tika masala, rice with cumin and the garlic naan. Not only the food was good but the service was great.

We were looking for British-style Indian food and this place was great. Prompt friendly service and really tasty food.
This is a popular place but they hold aside some tables for walk-ins. I think if you go right at 8pm once all the theatergoers are gone you should be able to get a table.
Rice and naan are a la carte but that seems to be the custom in London.
Butter chicken was my best meal in London two years ago. Enjoyed their variety of beers as well. The neighborhood is fun to walk and offers several great options. This is one of the best.

UK's oldest North Indian restaurant serves perhaps the oldest and driest Tandoori meat. 
I must say to the 4 of us visiting this restaurant this came as a shock as it has gotten tons of high marks. The seehk kebab was as dried as the chilly used in it, the Boti kebab was chewy as an old dried leather belt and the Tandoori chicken bland. Chicken tikka on the tandoori menu was the only piece of meat that was somewhat up to the standard. In general the tandoori menu felt not tender nor marinated long enough. 
Butter chicken or Acharri gosht are the items to go for, but then again they are no better than much less exclusive and less up-scaled Indian restaurants in London. 
The portions, and we are not Americans, were too small for the price asked. Basmati rice and nan are good but nowhere as good as the prices indicate  nor are they any better than other Indian restaurants. 
The service is okay but deceiving, they do love to accommodate but they also love to sell and perhaps the worst I seen in London happened here when spring water bottle could not be opened at the table because it was "slippery" but conveniently  was replaced in the bar with another bottle which had already been opened. This is one of the oldest tricks in the book and at these prices and with this reputation  it shouldn't take place here. 
For a party of four and only 2 bottle of beers being the only alcoholic beverages served the sum of 114£ is much more well spend somewhere ells than Punjab.

Delicious, authentic and priced right! We ordered samosas, tikka masala, methi Murgha (subtle with a nice kick at the end), and of course butter naan and Keema naan.  It's location in Coventry Garden is ideal for a great meal.

Pick anything on the menu and it will be the best Indian food you have ever had. Well worth waiting in line for a table. If you don't eat at Punjab while in London, you are doing yourself a disservice.

Fantastic!! Butter Chicken...butter Naan
Enough said.
Absolutely delicious!!! Must go to for Indian food. The cheese naan and chicken curry is absolutely delicious!
I do not recommend this place. it is very small and one the starters came I found three little hairs. they took the dish away and remove the hairs. Again I would not recommend.

Dependable Indian in the heart of the West End. I've been going here for years and the place is almost always packed. Its good solid indian food and very quick service. The decor won't win any awards and its not fancy. But sometimes you want tried and true.

Brits know how to curry, and Punjab is tops. We went for the English classics like chicken tikka masala with lots of buttery naan - sublime. Perfect after a busy morning at the British Museum, and before exploring the nearby bookstores.
nice Indian/Pakistani food restaurant in London.  All the food were great. Good service and good ambience.

I have a friend who is from India and her mother flew to the U.S.  I had the honor of trying 10 of her homemade dishes and each was better than the last.  I thought going to an Indian restaurant would be a bad experience after tasting authentic homemade Indian food.  And then I found Punjabi.  WOW!  The texture and flavors of my dinner was over the top exquisite and the service was top notch.  I live in South Florida and don't have many options but I may just have to fly to London to Punjab to eat.  Florida restaurants need a lesson in service as well as cooking.  The waiters and staff made me feel like I was a VIP from the moment I walked in.  If you want the real deal....go to this place.  5 amazing stars!!

Fantastic.  Best Indian food I've ever had, actually... not that that's a ton, but still.  Plus, they have the London pub-fave Chicken Tikka Masala, which is not truly Indian but it's something that tourists love to have, so kudos to them for choosing to cater to that instead of being snooty over the fact that it's not an authentic Indian dish. 
The mango lassi that my mother in-law got, made with buttermilk rather than yogurt (which is common in the US), was very tasty.  Naan = perfection (we tried plain, garlic and cheese).  I don't remember what all we had because the names are always so foreign to me, but it was all completely delicious.  Punjab was the dining highlight of our London visit!

Best meal during our week in london. Right around corner from apartment we stayed at. Just order. Everything was excellent and reasonably priced. Bill was half what we paid at another indian place just two days earlier and food was on same level. Cant wait to return.

Been twice this week!  Food is great, service wonderful, and the price is so reasonable for central London.  Tried the house red from Spain and was pleasantly surprised with the quality.  NO reservation but they seated us quickly.

My friend and I stumbled upon this place purely by coincidence, and we're glad we did!  
I'm no Indian food connoisseur (and therefore some of your opinions may be very different than mine), but I'm still very willing to assert that the food here was pretty darn good!  Every bite was savory; the restaurant did well with combining an interesting mix of flavors.  The naan was delicious, the butter chicken was succulent,  and the chicken madras was my favorite (although it wasn't as spicy as I had expected).
We loved Punjab and will return in the future if the opportunity presents itself!

We had a group of 24 high school students and this was the final meal of our trip. The service and food were both very good and they were very accommodating and helpful. Would definitely recommend for future visits.

Excellent food at decent price (for London).  We had the Acharri Murgha (chicken), Methi Gosht (lamb in Fenugreek), mushroom masala, and Kadu Sabji (pumpkin curry).  My girlfriend and I generally don't eat lamb, but we ordered the methi gosht based on the waiter's recommendation. It was excellent, and my favorite dish, with the pumpkin curry a close second.  My girlfriends liked the chicken best. The mushroom masala was good, but not fabulous like the other dishes.
This was my second visit to Punjab and I'm looking forward to going back on my next visit to London.

We were visiting London from out of town and were looking for a low cost meal. we found Punjab on yelp and gave it a try. the food was so good the first time, we went back twice! the second time was even better than the first! fantastic chicken tikka masala, raita, vegetables khorma, and their specialty Punjabi dishes from the grandfathers recipes. the palak paneer was good- but the rest was memorable. Go HERE and be happy you did

I am so glad there was a 2hs wait at Dishoom, enticing us to do the three minute walk over to Punjab, where the staff was welcoming and the food delicious. I'm admittedly not a connoisseur of Indian cuisine, or much of an adventurer in regards to food, but I did enjoy my classic chicken tikka masala and mango lassi. My BFF was equally satisfied by the food and ambiance. A bit of a splurge, in comparison to other places about London, but it /is/ near Covent Garden, and you do get value for your money. We went on a weeknight and didn't need reservations, but I'd suggest getting them if on the weekend. I don't doubt this place fills up.

We came here for our first dinner during a work trip to London.  The food was absolutely delicious and just what I was looking for in great tasting Indian food.  The kadu puri (pumpkin in a crispy puff) was a great starter along with cheese naan.  We then ordered chicken tikka masala and vegetable curry.  Both were perfect!  
Wait staff were all very nice!
The staff was very accommodating especially with our large group and lack of reservation. The dishes were tasty. I highly recommend.

All parts of the meal went super well here: the poppadoms were crispy and fresh, the naan perfectly cooked and the chicken tikka masala was creamy and flavorful. I can't tell you how disappointed I've been with other places' chicken tikka masala. Either it is too sweet or a bizarre neon reddish color that puts me off.
The service was amazing. They re-filled our water cups multiple times during the visit and asked us how our meal was. That in itself gives them a big 'ole star from me. 
Pleasant atmosphere, delicious food and fabulous service.

best Punjabi food I've had in a long time, the chicken tikka, ghobi alu, and lamb madras were all delicious. Sure the ambiance was mediocre and the place had a weird chemical smell... who cares.. the food was amazing, stop being stuffy.

I love Indian food! We eat it at home (CA, USA) but our my trip to London we wanted to see what the UK had! We loved this restaurant so much that we ate there twice on our short trip. We went way out of our way to try many well reviewed restaurants, but back we were. We couldn't resist it. Don't miss it! One of my best memories from this trip.
This place is amazing!!! I am visiting from Los Angeles and I have had my share of Indian food and this place was extremely delicious. It is a MUST!

There are few restaurants that I will wait outside of until they open.
There are even fewer restaurants that will be completely full within minutes of opening.
And there are yet fewer restaurants that will completely justify both the wait and proceeding hype.
Punjab is one of these restaurants. 
Situated smack in central Covent Garden, I can only assume this restaurant gets a lot of love from visiting tourists, and perhaps the only reason I can think to avoid it.  (All yelpers have something against going to a place listed in every guide book as "the" place to go.)
... Unless it's this good. In which case: roll up your sleeves, perfect your perfect American accent, throw 'dem bows (if necessary, of course) and wait in line. 
It's worth it!

Not that I'm an Indian food know-it-all, let me start off by saying that eating here was like eating at any Indian restaurant worth its curry in Jersey City, Iselin or Edison, NJ - those in the know will know what I mean, but at least there you get more food for your money - I'm not looking for an all-you-can-eat buffet, far from it, but the butter chicken had two pieces of chicken in it - c'mon! The sauce was delicious, though. 
Don't get me wrong, the food here is good - Punjab is touted as the oldest Indian restaurant in London in continuance operation, and for good reason. 
The pumpkin curry was probably the best thing on the menu - spectacular.  All the food was fresh and tasty.  We ordered a variety of dishes, rice dishes, nan, chicken tikka masala, etc.  The wait staff was very attentive and there when you needed them.  The Sikh patrolling the rooms, making sure everything was done just right, transported you back to the time of the British Raj - the good times, not the bad.
Anyway, that said, food was good, prices a bit high, and typical of London you gotta eat ethnic foods or die trying.

Had samosas to start and the butter chicken with naan and raita for dinner.  We were excited after the samosas,  they were delicious.  But the chicken on the bone (it was actually the tandoori chicken) difficult to eat with the sauce. Oh, and the sauce, so greasy,  oil was floating on top. Our poor naan was overcooked.  Service was fine.

We were looking for an authentic Indian meal in London, a city known for its large Indian population. We found Punjab on the edge of the Bloomsbury neighborhood. Everything from the pakora appetizers to the tandoori chicken and lamb biryani was delicious.

I'm not super fussy (or an expert) when it comes to my Indian food, but I really like this place. Super friendly staff, good food, nice area of London. It's not a really fancy place but they still do a great job with white linen tablecloths and candles etc. I really enjoy coming here and will come back again.

Great experience from beginning to end....welcomed at the door by several staff members, sat quickly, served immediately, and the food was incredible!  Highly recommend this authentic Indian experience to everyone!

Best freaking Indian food I've ever had in my life. I can't say i didn't like anything (maybe not the cool cucumber yogurt because i don't like cucumbers)
But it was all delicious. I can't stress how much i liked it.
Mango Lassi (so good and fresh, share if you can't handle too much sweetness)
Pumpkin Curry
Chicken Tikka Masala (delicious)
Lamb Korma Curry (so bombdiggity good i just want to fly back to London to eat it again. seriously)
CHEESE AND BUTTER NAAN dipped in curry= heaven
If you want to see a video of the restaurant, its on my food blog here: 
youtube.com/my_videos_ed…

We had dinner on 10/22, meal was fine.  We paid our bill with our credit card, no problem.  Several weeks later we got out credit card bill and we had 2 charges for our dinner, one without the tip ($37), the second with the tip ($40.81).   
We've enjoyed dinner here in the past and haven't had any other problems.

We came for the first time and we'll  definitely come back! The food was amazing and they adjusted the dishes as we like (not spicy, dairy free, etc) and the service was incredible - the restaurant was full and we felt like we're the only table. We loved it!

Stopped in for lunch after a few less than satisfying meals during a quick stop in London. The food matched the reviews that I had read. I especially recommend the pumpkin curry- excellent. Also, the breads were very good.
The place was quiet and the service attentive without being intrusive.

I  am so disappointed!! 
I love Indian food, and after reading all those good reviews, I decided to give it a go. I went once, I won't go twice. 
Me and my boyfriend decided to go for lunch, the restaurant was empty, which was good after hearing stories of queues in front of the restaurant. 
I ordered Chicken Tikka Massala with plain rice. What a shame. The chicken was well cooked, but my tikka massala sauce was just disgusting. It was way too salty and just not good. Didn't taste of tomato at all. I have made tikka massala myself and I know what goes in there. No idea what they put but it was not good. 
My boyfriend ordered Lamb Korma. We had tasted better. 
In all, Marks and Spencer is better quality and it actually tastes better... If you feel like Indian good, honestly, don't waste your money, or else, go somewhere else.

I really enjoyed Punjab.  The servers were humorous, attentive, and offered up their suggestions.  We pretty much went with the dishes that were marked as specialties on the menu.  
Starting with my favorite, we had:
KARAHI GOSHT: lamb curry with tomato and green pepper sauce
KADU SABJI: a pumpkin curry
ACHARRI MURGHA: a chicken curry and punjabi specialty that the menu cited as a must try at least once in a life time
Everything was really tasty and flavorful.  The lamb was very tender, the pumpkin had great flavor and the sauce for the chicken was interesting (in a good way).
I would definitely return if I were in the mood for Indian food!

Most delicious Indian food experience EVER!  We stumbled upon this place while strolling Covent Garden. Arrived around 8 pm and were seated immediately in the back of the restaurant - very cozy.  
Service was quick, kind and efficient.  The server had family in the SF bay area too!  Small world. 
We ordered the butter chicken and chicken tikka masala with garlic naan and roti as well has basmati rice.  Both chicken dishes were AMAZING.  the spice level was perfect and the chicken was cooked to perfection.  
I was so excited after the meal and told my husband that I could eat this food daily if it tasted THIS good.  
Looking for a good place in California to try.  Too bad we haven't found one yet.  I guess it's true that London has the best indian food.  We will definitely be back.

My second visit to this gem of a restaurant did not disappoint. We made reservations and we were seated promptly. We started with the garlic naan and it was great! Then the chicken tikka, lamb korma curry and gobi aloo. Every dish was perfectly spiced and cooked to perfection. We once again had a fantastic meal to remember at this restaurant. Very highly recommended!

Good indian food.  Spent the day shopping in convent garden and stopped here for lunch.  Had the chicken tikka masala which was creamy and just the way I like it.  Also had the saag aloo which was also solid.  Level of spice was perfect (I typically like things medium, so if you like your dishes hot or mild you may have to ask for it).
Enjoyed the decor and had a window seat so also enjoyed the people watching.

We are in London visiting and it was my dad's birthday. All he wanted was some good tikki masala so I went on the search and found pun jab. I wanted something that was classic and not to stuck up or fancy and just simply good. Punjab delivered. I had the lamb korma with plain rice and naan- the flavors blended together perfectly and were not overpowering. I tried some of the tikki masala as well and it was excellent! The place is small but comfortable and we were comfortably set with a party of 5.  I loved the windows in the front of the restaurant and if I came back I would ask to sit near the front simply to people watch. I've considered moving from Houston, Texas to London simply so I could eat here at least twice a week. It seems rash but I'm still thinking about it. Overall best Indian food EVER!

Extremely mediocre food, poor ambiance, weird and powerful soap smell, and high prices. £27 for two with two dishes, a paratha, rice, and raita. Maybe for really good Indian food, or a nice restaurant, but this was not that. Felt like a tourist trap, worth avoiding.
Note that they have canned mango as a desert option for over £3. Hilarious.

We went here for dinner on our last night in London.  Since part of our group are vegetarians we figured that Indian food was a good bet to please all people involved.  We ordered a plethora of dishes ranging in Chicken Tikka Masala to their famous Pumpkin Curry.  Throw in a few more curries, rice, and naan and we were filled to the brim. 
My personal favorite was the Pumpkin curry...it wasn't spicy...more of a sweet yet savory dish that left me licking my plate.  The Chicken was good too but didn't taste that different from others I have tried at other Indian restaurants.  
Next time I am in London I am definitely coming back.

best indian food in a long time. chicken tikka masala and butter chicken.
The only Indian food I've eaten has been from Southern California. I wasn't sure how the food in London would be, but I was happily surprised by Punjab. We were jet lagged so we ate at some random time as they were just preparing for the dinner rush, but they were very quick to seat us. 
We had the chicken tikka masala and the butter chicken. Both were excellent and had just the right amount of flavor without being too overpowering. I would definitely eat here again if I were to come back - plus it's in a pretty convenient location, within walking distance to a lot of shops.

A queue at 6pm on a Tuesday evening....it pretty much should say it all...I LOVE the food there - wide selection of high-quality Indian food. It comes extremely close to the Delhi street food, which tastes like heaven anyway. It is also a gem for vegetarians - large variety of non-meat dishes, I'd easily turn vegetarian if I could've eaten there everyday!
I love the atmosphere - very homely, cozy, amazing service - everytime it's like you're meeting old friends! Though in a prime location and respectable-looking customers this place is not pretentious, it makes you want to come back there again.
When we went to celebrate India winning the cricket World cup we got free sweets at the end of the dinner!
Tip - book a table, rather than stumbling outside you'll get your table relatively fast (there is a lot, a LOT of demand...)
Service was spotty and staff. A bit rude. The 3 stars are for the fantastic garlic chicken and naan. The chicken tiki masala was ok, nothing exceptional.

I had a very very poor and disappointing experience at Punjab restaurant.
I ordered mix grill, yellow lentil and mix vegetable curry.  The lamb in the mix grill was completely dark black and I wish I have taken a picture to prove it. The other meat on the grill I couldn't even Identify what that was cos it was so black and tasteless. The yellow lentil and veg curry was  like a dish from the buffet because of complete lack of excitement and freshness.  The only that's fresh was the nan bread.  This place is a tourist trap, we are all fooled by "the oldest northern Indian food in London" slogan! There are plenty of other good authentic Indian restaurants in London. Please don't waste your money in here. DISAPPOINTED.
Terrible experience. Seekh kebab overcooked and dry. Malai tikka had little flavor. As did the Kali Daal. Nothing even close to authentic punjab food. Stay away.

I wrote a note when I last checked in, booked marked the place and didn't review it at the time. My note was "best Indian food I've had". I'd like to say I've had better from a restaurant but I haven't. Even living in Seattle we have amazing Indian and this one took the cake. I was fortunate enough to try many dishes as we were with a group of 15-20 ppl and probably ordered over half of the menu. This place will NOT disappoint you. Authentic and I hope it stays that way.

I had my doubts about the place from the moment we stepped in and saw the drab, dingy, stained, and discolored carpets, matched by carpet-upholstered chairs.  As we were ushered to the back room we were hit with the stench of industrial cleaner that permeates the restaurant.  What odor(s) are they trying to hide?  The stench was ever-present, and we didn't get used to it as the dinner progressed.
They tried to seat us in the back room in between two busy, loud tables even though every single other table in that room was open.  We asked to be reseated to a table in a different row, and after they checked with the host at the front, they obliged our request, but appeared to be unnerved that we had disrupted their normal seating pattern.
The food?  In a word, subpar.  I started with a mango lassi, which normally should be cool, thick, and creamy.  Punjab's mango lassi was tepid, watery, and bland.  I strongly believe that it was pre-mixed or came straight from a carton before being watered down substantially to cut on costs.  I didn't finish it.  We ordered a few of the dishes that had received rave reviews on yelp -- the chicken tikka masala, grandpa's daal, a saag dish, and garlic naan.  I wanted to like these dishes -- even just one -- but all were unflavorful and disappointing.
If this restaurant were located outside the touristy Covent Garden area, I highly doubt it would survive or would earn the same *shockingly* high yelp ratings.  I would rate Punjab among the bottom tier of Indian restaurants I've eaten at in my life.
Don't go.

Some of the best Indian food I've ever had - granted London has no shortage of Indian restaurants - but Punjab goes above and beyond in the service category, making this a must-stop if you are in Covent Garden. 
My friend and I had the Cheese Naan, Chicken Karahi and Acharri Murgha. The chicken was succulent and the sauces/spices flavorful without being heavy. Good selection of wine+beers and prices quite fair for London. 
Where Punjab truly separates itself is in its service - Amrit and his staff go to extraordinary lengths to take care of their customers. My friend lost a family heirloom in the restaurant and Amrit and a few of his staff personally helped us search for an hour-plus after close to find the ring, and sure enough it turned up! I recommend Punjab to anyone valuing fantastic food+service in Covent Garden.
Delicious!!!! Service was not great which is why I'm giving it 4 stars, but everything I ate was super tasty!

The Butter Chicken was absolutely delicious. Many places make it too sweet; instead, it had a complex flavor combined with a sublime buttery texture. I asked to have it spicy, and I was not disappointed! Next time I'm London, I'll be coming here again.
Solid 4 to 5 star food, I definitely liked this place and it may have been the best Indian food I had in London. A bit touristy due to its location, but this is a great place to eat.

baigan ka bharta + gobi aloo !!! ttasty
yums

Fun and friendly staff, bustling spot, yummy flavorful dishes, reasonable prices, fast service (generally), and happy customers!  The naan with a little flatter than we were used to but still fresh and tasty - especially the garlic naan.  
FYI: Had to wait 10-15 minutes for a table for two at 8p on a Thursday.
London is full of Indian food, this one is ahead of the pack!
This place serves authentic food. Had the Chicken Tikka Masala and Chicken Madras curries and both were amazing. Cheese Naan very tasty and service pretty decent. Worth a visit.

I had heard that London had some of THE best Indian food outside of India.  Living near Little India in Artesia, California there's a lot of good ass Indian food, so I had to compare the Indian food in London.  
Punjab seemed like a good candidate.  After getting lost a few times with the damn directions on the Yelp iPhone app, we finally found it.  It's near Covent Garden and Picadilly Circus, but we kept getting turned around.  
Punjab is a very nice, classy restaurant. The wait staff were friendly and quick.  There were a lot of people eating there too.  Good mixed crowd and even some customers of Indian decent were eating there, so it looked promising.  Nothing on the menu really jumped out at us, so we ordered spinach paneer, rice, and garlic naan.  The food was not bad, but nothing to knock my socks off.  It was pricey too.  Sorry, but I've had better Indian food in Artesia and at more affordable prices.  Maybe next time I have to try an Indian restaurant in London that is a off the beaten path and not near the touristy part of town.  I would've thought they had a Little India section in London too, but either it doesn't exist or I couldn't find it.

Punjab is one of my favourites in London. The place can accommodate larger parties and is nice enough for me to take business acquaintances to. Service is exceptional. 
The average curry dish is about 8-9 quids, which is a fine range for restaurants in the Covent Garden area and reasonable for the quality of the food. 
The curries are flavorful, though it is not the very saucy kind, in case you are someone who enjoys the curry sauce more than the meats in the curry. 
The tandoori dishes are fantastic; very juicy. Generally, Punjab does exceptional meats, whether grilled or in curry--very tender and juicy. Try the mixed grill for sure! 
For folks who want cheaper curry and the super saucy kind in a smaller place, you might consider Tiger Spice.

I am doubting my fellow Yelpers after seeing this has a 4-star average rating.  
Landed in London today, am put up in a nearby hotel for work and was craving some chicken tikka masala.
The naan was inedible, the chicken was dry, and the tikka masala lacked spice/flavor.  Rarely do I leave food on my plate (I have a problem of eating everything in sight!), but I didn't finish anything I ordered.  
Will continue my quest to get good Indian in London elsewhere...if you're on the fence about coming here, I'd pass.

Ordered:
Chicken Tikka Masala - 
Unfortunately have had better Chicken Tikka Masala in San Francisco, Malaysia AND Sweden which is a sad statement since Chicken Tikka Masala originated from the UK...and most food in Sweden is lacklustre.
The chicken was VERY TENDER, which I did think saved the dish from the lack of seasoning and spice.
Rice - The plain basmati rice was perfectly cooked, but was missing some basic spices that are normally added to even plain basmati rice.
Had to pay for rice which I thought was odd, but I guess that is the norm in the UK.
Butter Naan - Was very small in size and was VERY thin so it was completely crispy like a cracker which was a shame.  It was almost impossible to use the naan for dipping in sauce or using to eat the food on my plate.
I don't know if I will go back or recommend to others for the price.
16+ GBP for the above items.  I ate all the food but didn't get full, so beware if you have a big appetite you may need to order a 2nd dish or several naan.
The staff however was very nice, helpful and attentive.  One waiter saw that I was about finished with my rice and naan and politely asked me if I would like more.  But at 3.50p an order I declined.

I was pretty disappointed with this place. I rarely get back to the UK these days having moved overseas and one of the things I really miss is good Indian food. Everytime I come back I look forward to having a good tikka masala, but I was sorely let down by Punjab. It looked the real deal, cramped tables, classic menu, everything seemed ok on the surface. The food though was meh. The naan was overcooked and crispy, the chicken was likewise overdone and dry, even the masala sauce was lacking in tomatoes or spice. There is far better to be had in London.

Five of us ate here--luckily we got a table without reservations on a Friday evening.  The staff was friendly and helped us order.  I had Chicken Tikka Masala since I don't like real spicy and it was wonderful.  My son ordered Chicken Madras and wait staff asked twice if he was sure, since it is very hot.  He liked it.  Others also enjoyed their food.  Plain Naan and Garlic Naan also very good.  Not cheap but no where in London is.  Staff was very attentive.   We will go back if we are lucky enough to return to London.

My fella and I are regulars here and always get a huge welcome when we turn up :) this place is run by an extremely friendly bunch of guys who've been with the business for donkey's years. They have a near magical knack of seating groups of people even when the restaurant looks entirely full, and make really great Indian food.
 As a veggie, my favourite dishes here are the 'pumpkinettes' (on the menu it assures diners that 'Punjabis go crazy for these miniatures pumpkins'), the special kali daal and the aubergine dishes. The bread is also superb - much lighter and crispier than naan at your average curry house.
 A great place where I'm sure I'll be coming back for many years!

Great Find!
We were in London and wanted Indian for dinner since many people have told me that Indian food in London was very good..I asked the desk clerk at our hotel if he could recommend a good Indian restaurant in the area..It probably helped that he was Indian, and he enthusiatically suggested to go to Punjab. It was about a 5 minute walk and we were immediately welcomed by a friendly staff and warm atmosphere. 
Food was delicious..Got samosoas for appetizer and the lamb madras with rice and nan on side. I like spicy and the when I ordered the entree the waiter made sure to check if I like spicy food..The lamb was very spicy and very good!
We def will go back next time in London...

Wow, I can't believe that I find myself so at odds with other Yelp!ers who have raved about the food at Punjab. I thought it was just OK, nothing special. The restaurant itself is a delight, comfortable and welcoming with loads of character and the service was impeccable. However the food, which was the main reason I was there, was good, but not great.
Best of the dishes was the Pudina Gossht, Lamb marinated in fresh mint cooked with herbs and spices and green peppers. The lamb was succulent and the spicing delicate it was good but not historic. However, the Methi Murgha, chicken with cooked fresh fenugreek, was bland, the pillau had a dirty flavor to it that matched its grayish colour and the bhindi masala was unremarkable.
Great atmosphere, whether you're dating or doing business, but there is much better Punjabi food to be had. Maybe dinner is better than lunch for some reason but I won't be going back to find out.

The Punjab is a busy North Indian restaurant near Covent Garden. I called for lunch with a colleague. Despite being fairly quiet the initial service was a bit slow, but the staff seemed friendly and helpful.
 I went with one of their speciality dishes: Acharri Gosht a pickle-styled lamb curry, tangy & irresistible medium spiced dish served with Naan bread which was very flavoursome and at £9.80 for the curry and £2.35 for the naan reasonable pricing for central London.
 I'll be back! Recommended.

The best Indian in Covent Garden, serving everything you expect from an Indian. Could be the best Indian in London, but I haven't been to them all. (Yet). The restaurant always has a queue outside it, so either book or be prepared to wait for yummy Indian food.

I keep dreaming of going back here, but sadly have to go home to California. Try the carrot dessert. It sounds so unappetizing, but is one of the best desserts I've ever had. I even found a recipe online and was able to make it at home with little difficulty! The food here is perfect, and the servers are always so polite and full of the best stories if you ask. The atmosphere is surprisingly quiet and intimate for Seven Dials. It's a little on the high side for Indian food in American dollars, but you will never regret eating here!

The most agitated I've ever been while eating a meal. From the minute we walked in, they were hesitant to give us a table (even though we were surrounded by empty tables) and told is we'd have to be out in an hour if they did. When ordering, they kept questioning our order as if they were judging us for ordering so little and the waiter snapped at us for ordering out of order (kept saying to order appetizers first). The entire meal they hovered around- not allowing us to enjoy our food or have peaceful conversation and after giving us our bill, they asked if we were done paying three times within two or three minutes of dropping it off. Two servers stood and watched us count our cash which was uncomfortable. The food was fine but the entire experience made me want to leave asap.
Good food. Achari gosht was tangy and tasty. Good portions and value for money, especially considering the location. Will definitely go back.

Second visit here. This time it was early and the place was empty. The food was not nearly as good as the first time, when it was extremely busy. I ordered WAY TOO MUCH food because I wanted to try a few things. I love the masala pappadum and butter naan, of course. I also ordered the pumpkin curry, the okra and the yogurt with cucumbers. Sorry I cannot recall the proper names but I think they should be easy to identify on the menu. Everything was good, just not the "to die for" tastes of my first visit. I'll still visit this place on every trip to London but I think I will go when it is very crowded next time!

The best North Indian cuisine in London. A lovely Indian restaurant in Covent Garden. The peshwari naan has been a favourite of mine. The portion sizes are good too. Ideally book a table, as you often have to wait long if you haven't booked one.

Great Indian food in Covent Garden.  I stopped in for lunch on a Monday and order the Pumpkin Curry (ask for spicy) and a order of Butter Naan.  A great meal for 8 sterling.  
The curry was had great flavor and texture.  I had never had pumpkin curry before and I was impressed.  What is nice about Punjab is that they have a great selection of meat and veggie dishes.  
Can't wait for my next visit for dinner with a larger group to order multiple dishes.

Like most reviewers, out of towner in London who had to try Indian food. I'm glad Punjab was my first stop.
I live in the Bay Area, CA. I use to live near Little Kabul in Fremont. I've had most places down there and seeing the indian population have had my fare share of Indian food.
Punjab was great. The samosa was very good but not the best I've had (India Kitchen on Geary St. in SF has the best Samosa's in the world BTW), the pilau of rice was decent but the Lamb Seekh kebab and Saag Chicken were some of the best I have ever had. The Saag was perfectly creamy, clean tasting and delicious. The kebab was moist, cooked and spiced perfectly.

While this seems to be the "happening" spot on a busy weekend night, I've definitely had better Punjabi food. The waiters and manager were all very nice, but took a long time coming around. I did like the old photographs from Punjab on the walls, and it was nice to hear a familiar tongue in the middle of London.
Be careful if you're planning on going with a big party on a weekend night - this place is very busy and they may very likely not have enough space for you if they don't take reservations.

DON'T GO!!!  AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!! Awful food and the most Awful Service! Very very poor quality meat,  the lamb was tough and inedible and the chicken rubbery. There were 4 of us and we left the vast majority of our food and we were 4 hungry people!!!  There was a 40 minute wait in between the starters and the main, without explanation. The starters tasted as if they were pre-cooked and frozen and the mains had virtually no spice at all.  We weren't asked if everything was ok with our food but we're served the bill without asking and then questioned as to the fact that we opted not to pay the service charge when we paid, which in a our years combined and in all the countries we've visited we have never experienced that before. THE SERVICE CHARGE IS OPTIONAL FOR A REASON AND BY LAW IN THE UK!!! Good service may have asked what we were not happy with! This was NOT GOOD SERVICE!!! One of our group is a chef at the Hylton and was appalled by what he tasted and saw. 
***AVOID AT ALL COSTS ***
***TAKE YOUR MONEY ELSEWHERE ***

Riiight, I'm not sure where all these four and five star reviews are coming from. I'm a huge fan of good Indian food but this was only alright, average really. 
Maybe I was a little annoyed because we all ordered nan but only half of us actually got any. But there was an over-abundance of rice. I got a half a piece of plain nan and believe me, that is not enough. My veggie korma was only really korma inspired and lacked a depth of flavour. 
The service was far from spectacular  especially since our bill came to over £20 more than it should have been and we all paid a good bit extra to make up for it. Sorry Punjab, this was a fail for me.

The best Butter Chicken in London! I always order this dish when I go there - perfectly spiced and the chicken is roasted, just the way it should be. It must be eaten with butter naan. Tried a Methi Gosht, but it wasn't that good. 4-stars just for the Butter Chicken.
Atmosphere could be much better - they've crammed too many tables into the place, but they do make up for it by seating 2 people at a table for 4. 
Price - 20 Pounds/person.

There is nothing I like better than stuffing my face with curry, well actually there is...stuffing my face with damn good curry. This has to be one of the most supurb places to eat in the area, and that's saying something...
There was a queue actually outside the door from 5.30pm waiting for them to open and I can see why. The selection of dishes is what you'd expect with a few house specials thrown in the mix. A a new meat eater I tried a bit of everything and it was yummy, I actually had to move my plate away from me to stop myself from eating until I was sick - yup I'm a glutton! Deal with it!

Yep, going 5 stars.  When the food is absolutely tasty, the atmosphere is nice and I get excellent service, I am sold.  
The place is very large so they seem to always have a table.  What I loved about this place was that it had some really innovative dishes that I don't always see on menus.  For instance, we had an insanely delicious pumpkin appetizer which I highly recommend.  We also had a lovely stuffed aubergine which I had never seen offered elsewhere.  I also appreciated that the food wasn't overly greasy (my proof is always when I bring home the leftovers and take them out of the fridge the next day and you can see the fat congeal).  The food to fat ratio here was good.

Mmm...  pretty yum.  There were lots of us at the restaurant and I felt like they were quite accommodating and patient with our table.
On Lizzie's recommendation I went for the fall off the bone butter chicken which was yummy- tangy and spicy and extremely dippable- in fact we ended up using uneaten bits of naan off other people's plate to mop our sauce.  The perswari naan was sweet but not too sweet, though I like mine with fruit in it, so slightly disappointed it was only sweeterned nuts.
The only thing is they gave us bottled water instead of tap (as we requested) and that the poor server's arm was too short to reach over the other side of the table.  
I think Tayyabs is still much better, despite the lack of service and infinitely cheaper too.  So there you go.  Punjab, I will probably be back if looking for curry in town, but I'd rather make the trip and go east.
The best Indian food in London, if you ever visit please visit this restaurant. Great choices!! Excellent food and great people...

Oh my god, this was the best Chicken Tikka Masala ever. I eat at a bunch of different Indian places near my home base of San Francisco, and while several of them are quite excellent, what made this stand out was the texture of the chicken and the combination of a tomato-ey savory element that was, just yum. I will be back next time, and every time, that I am in London.

Dinner for one. Service was quick and efficient (rather than warm and welcoming) but got a table straight away. Starter of Pumpkin Curry Puri was fine without being worth a special mention, Main course of 'Grandad's black lentil dhal' was OK, but (for my taste) a bit runny as a main; I'd have it again as a side. Rice, chapatti and a pint of Cobra gave a bill just over £20. This included a 10% service charge of £1.87. If they'd left it off, I'd have left a bigger tip.
Turnover was fast: business is obviously good. Overall OK, but a bit wham-bam-thank you ma'am.
Go for a quick bite to eat rather than a night out or you'll be in bed for 10.

I suppose I should start this by saying that I'm not a fan of curry or indian food.
.............................
With that, I hear immigration calling...they want their visa back.
But seriously, I went with a group of friends hoping that the light would shine down and I would fall magically in love with all things Indian, and live a happy life satisfying late night cravings with poppadoms and tikka masala to my heart's content.
Well, that didn't happen. Punjab put up a good try though. There was nothing to complain about, the service was excellent, the food was good. i had chicken korma and the portion was large for the price, and tasted good. My friends all enjoyed their courses and alcohol was reasonable for being in downtown London.
The inside had some interesting colour schemes going on, and really wasn't a fan of the mustard yellow. I'd say give it a try, but don't expect his holiness, the Lord of Naan to shine down on you after your done.
I ate at this restaurant and it was not good, the butter chicken was not creamy. I have eaten at many different Indian restaurants and trust me this one is not good

We had high expectations of this restaurant but it ended up being just ok. We had the pumpkin appetizer which was served very hot and was good. We also had saag paneer (very average). The paneer cheese in the dish was chewy and didn't have much flavor. We also ordered Chicken Tikka Masala which was tangy and decent tasting but didn't best some of the ones I've had before. The naan was good. Rice was decent but not great. We also had two types of pappadum and we prefer the masala pappadum to the plain. The chutneys and spices were not very flavorful. Nothing was really spicy. I ordered Rasmalai for dessert. It was good, milky and rich.

When I lived in London about 5 years ago, Punjab was a regular stop on the way home from work.  The staff is so friendly (especially when you're a regular), the food is delicious, the prices are fair, and everyone I brought here fell in love with this place.  "Punjaaaaab!!!" became a regular chant when someone asked the question, "Where should we go for dinner tonight?"
Hope it's still as good as it was!  Definitely going to pay a visit when I revisit London next...

Not quite five stars from me, but still very, very good.
It's easy to see why you need to book or else expect to wait in a long queue, as the atmosphere is great and the food superb, giving you a great dining experience.
The menu is an interesting read.. I won't spoil it but if you read the descriptions you'll find it hard not to crack a smile or five.
And the food, what most restaurants are famous for... I had the kadu-puri for starters (after the obligatory poppadoms of course!) and it was soooooo good. A light and slightly crispy pastry/batter filled with curried pumpkin yumminess.
After that I had a try of three vegetable curries which were all cooked very well and had an abundance of flavour without being so hot that I couldn't enjoy them.
The one thing that stood out as a negative, however, was that as a vegetarian, whilst there were a lot of options, I felt that a lot of them are what in a lot of other places you'd find as side dishes. I kind of felt like something was missing, like I'd missed the main course and gone straight for the extras. That's not to say it didn't taste great or that I left still feeling hungry, but when I go back I'll see if there's not something I can order with a bit more substance.
Prices? We all had poppadoms, mains, rice, naan and alcohol and paid a little over £20 per head. In other words, not cheap, but not bad, and certainly worth it.
Best Indian food ever! Try the Pumpkin curry, I want to go back to London just to eat that again it was to die for. Do make advanced reservations or you'll never get in.

Is Punjab fancy and exotic?
No.
Is Punjab completely delicious and a pretty good deal for the West End?
Ohyesohyesohyes.
Punjab is a pretty special slice of curry heaven, right in the middle of tourist-central Covent Garden (don't judge).  Tasty, non-greasy, fresh Indian food (including "Granddad's Dall"), at prices that make you think you could come here pretty regularly.  Worth every moment on the tube, surrounded by smelly, dirty people.
But book in advance. It was absolutely heaving on a Friday night, and we had to fight off the folks waiting at the front who hadn't made reservations, because they seriously were clawing at us for our table.

The service was good, the restaurant upstairs is over lit and soul less. One does get the impression they want you in and out as fast as possible. The food seemed very ordinary, pre cooked and waiting under lights, nothing special. I always  seem compare other indian restaurants in london to Rickshaw in Battersea square which is amazing. So I was disappointed,

I live in a town with numerous Indian restaurants, so while I'm not a connoisseur I certainly have had experience with the cuisine. Everything we had here was excellent, from the naan to a vegetarian daal and flaming chicken tikka. Service was professional and efficient (not sure what the complaints are about here). My lone complaint is that they pushed our table in a bit cramped in order to keep a main aisle open, but really that's a trivial thing. People at the next table were Canadians who said they'd been here last year and made sure to come again in their visit to London this year, and I'd certainly be happy to go again. Recommend.

Wow! This place is pretty special. The décor has that authentic lick of yellow paint with pictures of classically dressed Indians and well set tables to complete the scene. At 6 o'clock there were people waiting outside for the doors to open. At 6:15pm the restaurant was almost full. Patrons of Punjab clearly need their tandoori fix.
The service is professional with many servers waiting to take your order, meaning you are never left waiting for something. As for the food, I am going to keep it simple. EXCELLENT! Whether you are here for a quick eat with friends or as a romantic couple, this Indian eatery has a touch of class you will surely enjoy.

They say the Indian food is good in London.  This is where to get it.  It is so delicious that a couple days ago, I came here, completely stuffed my face, eating well being what a healthy portion should be, got appendicitis within 36 hours, and now I've just left the hospital to share with you this culinary war story.  Might have been worth it.  
Don't over eat.

Punjab serves the best Indian food from all the places I have tried in London, Holland and the US.  When I'm there, I'm family! ;o)  There are days that I've been for both lunch and dinner!
I'm a vegetarian and usually order 1 or 2 vegetable dishes which is plenty.  My omnivorous friends are very content with Punjab as well as their chicken, lamb and fish dishes are very good, according to them.  I strongly recommend the Saag Panir, Chana Masala and Vegetable Kofte.  And the Gobi Aloo of course.
If you go on a Thursday - Sunday night, I recommend making a reservation as Punjab is very popular.  Also, if you're with a large party, making a reservation would be a good thing to do.  Enjoy!!

When I was in London recently I ate here and I have to say, this food was amazing. The experience is such that when you walk in to restaurant you feel like you are in India. The wait staff was helpful and the portions were large. The food was fresh and hot and reasonably priced. Even given the fact that it was in a theatre district area in London! Covent Garden is a beautiful area and this place is worth making a special trip to- I ate a bit of Indian food while I was in England and this one was the best! Be sure to get their Nan and their chicken tikka masala. Amazing stuff!

I agree with Danny K - 'service' is a misnomer. Waiters seem to begrudge our requests. We asked to sit by a window but we were told that that table was for 4 and we were 3 so we should sit at a table for 3. They did concede after the blast of air conditioning was raised as an issue - kind of spoiled the feeling of a treat out. Courteous interactions were sparse throughout the rest of the meal but I remember the food being good. The loos was unisex - good for some, but  in a relatively small space.
I'm surprised by all the great reviews. The food is decent, but just mediocre. The menu is quite boring as well.
This was one of the better Indian meals while we were in London although we wished one of our brown friends were with us to take us on a complete culinary tour.  When in London, stick with Indian.

Got butter chicken here. Was delicious. But I was starving at the moment. But, I'm sure it would still be delicious were I not starving. They charge extra for the rice. Also, the selection of beer was pretty lousy (I guess you a can expect that from an Indian restaurant). And the Rasmalai for dessert was delicious. So, 4 stars for them.

Thank you yelpers for the fantastic recommendation.  The pumpkin curry seemed like an oxymoron on the menu but thanks to the other reviews we read, we gave it a shot. It was fantastic! The cheesy naan was light and perfect, not a hot mess of grease.  I've passed on the name of this place to my sister and her friends as well.  The prices were extremely reasonable, it was warm and comfortable and the service and servings were plentiful.  I'd go back in a heartbeat!
So good!  I went to get lunch here with a group of friends and everything was delicious and they were very accomdating to a big group of us (8 people). Can't wait to go back.
Top notch service and food - everything was excellent.  Went there for lunch and had dal, naan and mago lassi.  Wish they had one in the US! :)

Delicious Indian food in Covent Garden. It was a few minutes wait on a Friday evening for three, but then seated and fed in great time. We family-styled peshwar naan (sweet, yum), saag paneer and another saag potato dish, chicken tikka masala, lamb korma, and surprisingly good red wine and of course big bottle of cobra (beer).

This is a "must visit" restaurant whenever I am in London.  You just simply can't get Indian this good anywhere I have been in the states (although, you could say that about almost any!).
Typical for London, the dining spaces are tight...and there can be a wait if you don't have a reservation.  But don't let any of that deter you from trying this gem.

I ate here on my recent trip to London and had an amazing dinner.  The papadums and accompanying chutneys were nice and light, perfect for a summer meal.  The entrees were fantastic as well; if you are a fan of lamb, try the Karahi Gosht, or if you prefer meatless dishes, try Granddad's Kali Daal.  Both are excellent.  My favorite part of the meal, however, was the mango lassi.  It's definitely the best I've had so far.

Best Chicken Tikka Masala EVER! I swear every time I eat at a new Indian Restaurant in London it just gets better and better. The tikka masala sauce here has some spice to it and is very addicting. The naan bread however, was probably the worst I've had. It was too hard to tear and not soft at all. I'd probably go here again just for the chicken tikka masala
anitaeat.com

The best recommendation is that my better half .. who hates Indian food .. enjoyed dinner at Punjab. 
Expert use of spices perfumed our lamb and chicken dishes. 
Friendly, expert confident table service.
Will definitely return on my next visit to London.

I've only eaten here once - and I don't even remember the name of the dish I ordered.  It was one of the recommended ones, and it was good.
However nowhere near as good as how much it cost.  Maybe 3 quid is standard in London for a plate of plain white rice, but this meal was only marginally better than what I normally pay half as much for.

This place COULD actually be amazing. The flavors of their curries are very good and the naan is of excellent quality. However, I personally feel that they skimp on ingredient quality and charge prices that would indicate higher quality. I had a fish curry and a vegetable medley made mostly of canned or frozen peas, corn and carrots. Just not up to standard for the prices that they are charging and for the quality of food that they have the potential to produce.

Had great lunch here at Punjab...  The curries were thick and complex.  The many different filled naan was nice, my favorite being the coconut fruit filled.  It went very nicely with the curry surprisingly.  Desserts were excellent here... the milk soaked cake was my favorite as well as the icecreams.  Service was good and nice ambiance.  Overall, would recommend.

The best ramen I've ever had!
The cleanest Ramen restaurant I've yet seen
The friendliest staff you can imagine
The (1 of) best finds we stumbled upon in Soho London
We both had the special tonkatzu broth with marinated ground pork. And the pork belly bun.. Both Soooo good!!
Highly recommend this place from this girl that's been to many many ramen places from the west to the east.. and some places in between.

There wasn't many ramen restaurants in the area when we were visiting but we gave this one a shot and it did not disappoint! The staff was friendly and the space was pretty standard. 
The ramen was super tasty and had a perfect broth. I loved how you can order the tenderness of your noodle!
Sushi apps were pretty good too!

Good food, terrible service.
A week ago we went to another Shoryu location (Carnaby street) and after a short wait in line we were promptly seated and served impressively quickly.
At the New Oxford location today, we arrived and were seated without a wait but then we waited over 25 minutes to have a server show up and take even our drink order. This was despite asking various servers multiple times to place an order and always being deferred. The place was almost full but not really busy so the poor service was pretty inexcusable.
After eating (tasty food), our bill had major issues twice (once it was just unrelated; the second time it had a number of extra items). Finally, a manager had to help correct the bill. We had to ask twice for the service charge to be removed.

Heatwave in London. Warmest summer ever and what better than a super hot face melting bowl of Ramen!  Gambate! Itadakimaaaas!
I peeked over the door noren and I see this place is packed already. I guess I wasn't the only one mad in the brain to eat hot ramen on a hot day. Anyhoo.. I held up 4 fingers and the hostess seemed to know I meant .. table for 4.  So she led me to the tiniest of tables, crammed next to 2 of the tiniest of tables, and with a quick Hai Dozo..
