I liked the broth, and even though it's kind of odd to have bean sprouts as a topping, it was a nice addition for me (haven't been eating my veggies since I came to London... or wait since I moved out of my parent's house). The noodle is a bit hard, but still pretty good. Green tea was served with a cute little tea pot, nice containers can always make things taste better ;).
Didn't like the mini salad too much. It's a bit too salty, I wish I got gyoza as a side instead. 
What I love the most about this place is that it's not awkward to eat alone at all. I sat  on a communal table and there were 5 or 6 people eating by themselves (most are Japanese). It makes my aloneness doesn't seem as sad.  The staff were friendly and efficient, even though none of them are Japanese they tried to greet everyone with Japanese. 
Besides food and service, the location is great (super close to Piccadily circus) , and the decor is minimal/clean, just the way I like it.  For someone who isn't a ramen geek, I totally enjoyed the experience.
Went there at 10pm for a quick feed up. Taste almost the same as the ramen I had in US. Nothing special except being a bit too oily for me though but still not bad.

Love how they offer gluten free ramen! But overall, their signature ramen I ordered definately does not beat popular ones back home in SoCal. The broth was very bland, pork tasted a few days old, the boiled eggs were delish! We also ordered the chicken steamed buns and that is a must! Chicken was crispy, sauce was sweet, bun was very soft, veggies stuffed inside were fresh and crisp. So tasty!
Waitresses were very attentive and sweet.

Fantastic food in a great space. The place is a great value - easily 5 stars. 
I had the pork ramen and a prawn steam bun. Both were perfectly prepared and presented beautifully. The price was fantastic as well - my fiancé and I were out for less than £30 for the 2 of us - including service.

Went recently for a very quick lunch. I loved the starters which were served promptly but I came here for the main event of ramen. It was cold and I needed arming up.
Compared to say Bone Daddies or Kanada-Ya all not far from here, I was quite disappointed. Did I come on an off day? I got the original Ramen Tonkotsu, which I didn't think had any depth of flavour. Pork belly also far too fatty for my liking.
I'm willing to come back one day but it did put me off considering I could easily compare it to it's rivals in Soho.

Japanese remen ( noodle ) great located , staffs really warm welcome! And noolde is so great! But sushi is soso ( dragon roll ) 
But overall its really great restaurant

This is the best ramen I've had in London and the best I've had in NYC as well. 
Its potentially true that the bao is not 100% perfect. I want to say maybe 98%? Some times there is a tiny bit more bun than filling and they can put a .5 gram of too much mayo on it - that's all I'll concede.
Add to that its reasonably priced and the service is fantastic and I will come back here again and again. The only downside is that the quality is quite good so one can then eat a lot - one time I both ate a lot and took down some beer. Its hard to go back to work after that - you kind of want to go have an afternoon nap.
Really cannot over recommend this place.

Best ramen I have had in London. 
I can't wait for them to expand in NYC and Or LA. My waitress Noelle was exceptionally amazing are her service. I wish for her to serve me my next visit. I had the Fish cakes that were to Die for, the Kotteri ramen and the TAN TAN Ramen are highly recommended. Thank You

That is a decent Ramen like the one I'm used to find in California. I had the classic one with Pork, mushrooms and the half cooked egg. Ordered and Served promptly, Finished the bowl in a couple of minutes. Even Forgot to take a picture! I will go back there anytime!

I am a big fan of ramen and am always up for discovering the best shop around town. There are two Shoryu around Piccadilly Circus, which is a highly touristy area, so I am already a bit suspicious. 
Though a gong is rung every time a customer comes in or goes out of the shop, it doesn't make the place more Japanese. Maybe most of the servers are not Japanese or the restaurant just doesn't have the coziness which is typical of Japanese ramen places. 
I went there for lunch, so I just ordered Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu which is their signature ramen. Anybody who is into ramen knows that the broth is what makes or breaks ramen. Their broth is ok flavor-wise, but nothing really jumped out at me. The toppings include pickled ginger, fried shallots and black wood ear in addition to the usual roasted pork and egg. Overall, it was a good bowl of ramen but that's it. 
Shoryu offers a lot of side dishes ranging from sashimi, pork buns to chicken wings, which are not food you would see served at an authentic ramen shop. Call me all fashioned, a good ramen place to me should have just a few options of ramen and limited number of side dishes. Shoryu seems to be a Japanese restaurant that caters mostly to tourists and serves all sorts of Japanese dishes, one of which happens to be  Ramen. If you are looking for great ramen place, I wouldn't recommend it, but if you want some decent Japanese food in the area, this is not a bad choice.

Stopped by on a cold London afternoon to some comfort food. The wait staff was very welcoming, walking me through the menu and different options. I ordered their Tonkotsu ramen, gyoza and pork bun. I thought all of the food was very average, but not bad. The tonkotsu broth lacked something, but it was not flavorful enough while the noodles were a bit soft for my taste. Not a bad bowl of ramen but not one that is memorable. The gyoza was presented on a sizzling skillet, very cool. However, the flavor of the gyoza stuffing was also lacking something, perhaps sesame oil? The pork bun used a miso paste of some sort and was my least favorite thing I ordered that day. Okay for a quick bowl if you're craving one but probably not one I would recommend people to go out of their way to get. They do have free wifi.

Why is everything in london so expensive... Came to london for a vacation, mid week through our trip of course I start to crave asian food and whats better than a hot bowl of ramen?
Shoryu specializes in tonkotsu soup base which is my favorite.  They have different option for the thickness of the broth.  If you are used to eating ramen def go with the rich broth option as their regular broth was a little on the bland side.  I love the egg as its the perfect yolk consistency.  Service was pretty good also, very fast and attentive.  
While the noodles are pretty good here, it is hard to stomach the fact that I spent almost $100 US dollars here for 2 bowls of ramen, 6pc gyoza and an icecream dessert.  It cost like $30 for a bowl of ramen and $5 to add just an egg...if you are a local then definitely check out this place as their ramen is pretty good but if you are travelling from NY i would say to skip it and save the $.

A few days ago, I came across this busy and surprisingly delicious Japanese cafe. What makes it surprising is that I was expecting a traditional bao, but in fact it was a mixture of 3 of my favorite infused ethic flavores combined in one bao bun.  Japanese karaage chicken, topped with Korean gochujang sauce and placed between a Chinese style bun. Wowee Bao-ee!! So much flavor bursts exciting my taste buds! Definitely glad I tried that. My Japanese fruit infused mojito and green tea cheesecake for dessert topped it all of to perfection!

I rarely give five stars for ramen because I enjoy a particular style and that is tonkotsu broth and not many places do it well.
I walked into Shoryu for lunch solo on a weekday afternoon and didn't have to wait for a seat. The place was pretty packed for lunch.
I got a Dracula ramen which is tonkotsu with garlic. Garlic oil, garlic chips, fresh minced garlic, which as one can imagine, gets a pretty strong flavor. Let's just say I wasn't kissing anyone for the whole day or even opening my mouth because I could've killed someone with my breath. Was it worth it? You bet.
The broth was rich and flavorful and the flavors melded together for a heavenly experience. The ramen came with half an egg perfectly done and three slices of fatty chashu. What I REALLY enjoyed was that there was some ginger in the broth, which really contrasted well with the garlic. Anyone can throw garlic inside tonkotsu but not everyone can layer flavors like a Korean girl layers clothes. My only grouse is that there was half an egg. Just give me the whole damned egg already. Thank you.
I haven't written my Bone Daddies review yet but tldr;
I would choose Shoryu over Bone Daddies. 
I have noticed a distinct difference in the crowds at both places. Shoryu has a more Asian crowd and Bone Daddies seems to have a hipster crowd. Different strokes for different folks.

Just as good as the other Shoryu chains. Key advantage of this one is that it's less busy and hectic than the other locations that are in higher footfall areas.
Food is extremely consistent and I have difficulty spotting any differences between this place and the Soho branches.
Most of the tables here are for 2 people so if you're an odd group you'll probably be seated on a group table, by the single seaters at the window or I guess they can merge some tables together.
Check out my other reviews if you want to know what the food is like.
Shoryu Carnaby - 
yelp.co.uk/biz/shoryu-ca…
Shoryu Soho - 
yelp.co.uk/biz/shoryu-lo…

We looking for a a quick noodle fix before our train back to Birmingham. This looked liked the go to place for ramen and it didn't disappoint. Up on arrival into the small restaurant a bong sounded and all the staff greeted us in unison. A unique if not strange touch. The two of us had traveling bags, so chose a 4 seater table. Even this was a squeeze. I went for the shoryu pork ramen and my partner went for the curry flavoured chicken ramen. we had pork buns on the side to share. The dishes came quickly and were well presented. I really enjoyed the pork broth and the slowed cooked egg was perfect. The pork buns though seemed a little unloved and a bit thrown together. Overall a decent quick cheap eat.

Great Natural Miso Ramen, great flavours. It was the only ramen suitable for vegetarians. Besides the Ramen the Harata buns Tempura shrimp and halloumi were great. It would be great if they had more vegetarian selections.

This is not a Japanese ramen. I ordered chicken ramen and the taste was bland and my friend ordered pork based ramen but he said it tastes so bland. The price is expensive, there is no Japanese thing in this resto and the matcha taste bitter, it is like cheapest matcha which you can find in supermarket. I used to stay in Osaka Japan, and my descendant is Japanese, I know exactly this is not made by Japanese hand. They also asked for tips which makes it worst.

Although I personally prefer a simple tonkotsu ramen, they have quite the variety for those that are more adventurous. I found the overall experience and food better here than Bone Daddies. The fried chicken at Bone Daddies is better though!
The Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu broth was rich and flavorful. The pork belly buns were.delish!!! Soft and tender pork bursting with flavor with a mild spicy kick on some fluffy buns. The fried chicken could have been crispier but had good flavor.
Pork belly Hirata bunsChicken Kara Age Fried Chicken- crispy deep fried soy, garlic, and ginger marinated chickenShoryu Ganso Tonkotsu- signature ramen, a tonkotsu and miso broth with added spinach and garlicHokkaido Curry Ramen- rich curry-soy pork broth with crispy kara age chicken, nitamago, nori, menma, naruto fish cake, and spring onion
Really not that great. I was pretty disappointed in the overall experience. Ramen broth was ok but the meat wasn't seasoned well. Over crowded an bathroom smell was noticeable. This is tourist ramen.
The ramen here is delicious, nice filling portions and quick service if you are in a hurry. They also serve "frozen beer" where the froth is this strange frozen swirl if you are curious

An absolute favorite Ramen restaurant of mine. This was the first time I'd been to the Carnaby Street branch, tucked away inside Kingly Court. From all the Shroyus it has the best atmosphere by far! It's not as crowded/ small as the others, the wood-paneled walls give it a warm feel and the lighting and decor is just right. 
The food of course is amazing. We shared the pimentos and the Chicken Karaage (a definite MUST at Shoryu), and for our mains I had the Curry Ramen- bursting with flavor and totally filling, while my friend, who likes her dishes a little more spicy, chose the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu.
Service was attentive and speedy, place was buzzing with people. You can't go wrong with this place to fulfill your Ramen Needs!
Yes, it's as good as advertised. Line is not that long. And it's nice that they have a nice heat lamp for those waiting outside.

Let me say that I'm a big ramen fan, but I think I've been spoiled by ramen I've had in San Francisco and Las Vegas.  
On a cold rainy day in London ramen is a nice antidote to blah weather.  This place does a decent job, although the noodles were pretty thin and didn't seem to be freshly made.  
Overall a decent place that I'd probably go back to.

Came here after seeing it on yelp. I was having a crazy ramen craving and this seemed like a legit spot, so I gave it a try. I'm sure glad I did!
I came at about 5 PM on a weekday and the place was about half full. I was immediately greeted by the waitstaff and seated at the tables facing the window (one of the perks of dining alone- you can people watch!). Its on Regent Street, smack dab in between Piccadilly Circus and Trafalgar Square so there's plenty of foot traffic going by. 
The restaurant is somewhat small but has a very modern-style Japanese decor theme. The menu is short and sweet, but they have plenty of varieties of ramen for every taste. I originally leaned towards the curry ramen but ultimately went with the piri-piri ramen after reading peoples' rave reviews. 
I put in my order for a cocktail (only £6 during happy hour!) and ramen, and both were out within 10 minutes. My cocktail -whose name I cannot remember- tasted like a mai tai and was definitely strong... but enjoyable. The ramen came out piping hot with lots of goodies on top of the bed of noodles. The noodles were cooked to the perfect al-dente consistency but I was a little disappointed in the lack of spiciness. Since this is their spicy option, I expected a little more of a kick. There was also a little bit too much lemongrass for my own personal tastes but not so much that it kept me from enjoying my meal. I noticed some reviews remarked on the small serving size but I felt it was the perfect size. I hadn't eaten all day and finished off most of my noodles, and felt more than satisfied. 
Overall, this is a great ramen place if you're in central London. The service was super friendly and attentive. The ramen itself was really tasty and they have all kinds of varieties to try. I definitely think its worth checking out if you get the chance!

As a ramen junkie from NYC, I've been traveling around London's ramen scene to try and find the best bowl here. Shoryu piqued my interest due to the fact that they tout their Hakata roots, which is the region of Japan that tonkotsu ramen is specialized. So I had to come by and try the tonkotsu broth!
I stopped in around noon and was seated immediately. I ordered the Kotteri Tonkotsu Ramen, a chashu pork bun, and a grilled halloumi and shimeji mushroom bun.
The ramen came out first, which was a bit strange, but I started eating. The broth was not as rich as I like my tonkotsu ramen to be. It has what I've complained about most NYC ramen - I call it the "Ippudo Problem," where the tonkotsu broth is the specialty but is not super rich. Tonkotsu broth should be thick, bony, and hearty, but the broth here (which was said to be extra rich) is pretty thin. Also, it was a bit under seasoned, a bit bland. I don't like my broths salty but I do like some flavor in the soup.
The noodles here are missing that signature bite that ramen noodles have (even when I ordered it hard), almost just like regular egg noodles.
You can thank Momofuku and David Chang for the steamed buns with ramen trend around the world, and the buns here have the same problem that the ones at Momofuku Noodle Bar in NYC does - they are overly sauced with a very strong sauce that masks the flavor of the main ingredient and you basically are eating a bao with sauce and some meat/protein rather than getting a nice complex bite of flavors and textures. It's a shame, because I only really tasted the cucumber because it was not as salty as the rest of it. I actually had to wash it down with the broth (really shows you how bland it was).
I ordered kaedama and it came out quickly, but they didn't put any tare or sauce on the noodles, so when I put it into the bowl, it watered it down a bit and made it blander.
Overall, this was a pretty average bowl of ramen. There are many better bowls of ramen in London.

I'll go here again.  Small place but packed with lots of flavor and great Japanese ramen.  I got their set (shoryu bun, ramen, and cheesecake for 11.90) and Kirin Frozen. 
Great meal for dinner.

I would give it six stars if I could. This place surpasses any ramen shop I visited in Boston or NewYork (yes, more impressive than Totto or Sapora etc.) I ordered the Tan Tan Ramen, whose soup base is AMAZING - with a touch of spiciness but not too heavy; make sure to choose to have noodle cooked the hardest way. My fiancé had another ramen (sry forgot the name lol) which was equally fantastic, and his soup base tastes totally different from mine - unlike a lot of other ramen places where dishes share similar base. Service is decent. We arrived ~9pm Sunday night and there was no queue.
I like this Ramen place lot. Great service and great food. the Bun is so-so, I will only recommend the Ramen here. I will going back if I have a chance.

I almost always try the most basic ramen when I visit a new place, but this time I made an exception and went for one of my favorites, cold sesame ramen (Hiyashi Chuka). If you've never had this before, and it's a hot summer day, you should definitely give it a chance. Save the hot soup for colder weather.
Noodles: Very good. Firm and cooked just right. Better than Bone Daddies IMO.
Hiyashi Chuka sauce/tare: A bit to much sweetness, but overall very good.
Tokyo egg: Perfectly cooked. However Bone Daddies tea smoked marinated egg is still one of the best I've ever had anywhere. 
Toppings: Menma (bamboo) not bad, needed  more crunch. Tomatoes were not the best - since they're in season now they could have been better. Charsu was a bit to dry, that's why most places use cooked ham typically (there  is no hot soup to soften the chasu). 
Nit picking now: Needed a small dab of mustard on the side (pretty standard). And cucumbers should be added too - especially since you're making it in England where they love cucumber too.
Overall: A great bowl. In Tokyo I'd give it a 3, but for London it's top notch.
Other stuff: Service was decent, but I find it really weird in London how so many servers don't seem to know squat about the food they're serving. Gyoza were good - and may have been made in house possibly (impressive).
I will return to try the basic tonkatsu ramen when the weather changes.
Very tasty and mouthful. Stick with the raman, everything else is ordinary. Staff are pleasant ans the decor is nice.

Ramen in london.  After visiting japan, the ramen was average.   Nothing bad about it although it it took an awful long time to arrive to the table.  The servers were really nice.   The price i felt was too high compared to other competitors.

Try to get here before 6pm if you are dining on a Saturday evening or you'll have to wait in line outside!
I too think their tonkotsu ramen is better than Bone Daddy's.  I had a bite of the ramen with matcha noodle, but I personally like the regular noodle better taste-wise, less distraction from the rest of the dish.  And matcha noodle seems to get soft quickly in hot soup while the regular noodle stayed firm for long.
I was very impressed with their salmon Hirata Buns.  The salmon karaage goes really with the soft bun with lettuce and cucumber, really enjoyed it :)
If you are looking for a Ume-shou type of salty tea, their Ume Kombu Cha is recommended.

I don't want to sound like a food snob, but I wasn't expecting much from an English ramen place. However, I'm happy to say that Shoryu was a pleasant surprise! I saw a bunch of people waiting on line to get in but they were in parties of 3+ so I decided to go in and put myself on a list in case there was one. Turns out there is no list, the line is 'first come first served' but because I told them that I was just two people, we got to skip the line. Lesson: don't just follow the crowd. 
As per usual in London, it took a million years for them to take our order of a beer, cocktail, the tan tan ramen and the Dracula ramen. The cocktail, which was just soda and plum wine, wasn't very good. But, the ramens weren't all that bad. The minced pork ramen (£10) was pretty much liquid fire for me, but my boyfriend managed fine. The Dracula ramen (£11.90) had a richer broth that wasn't spicy and was really good when I added some rice vinegar to it. Good spot if you're looking for a change from the fish and chips, but I don't need to go back.

My next favorite place for ramen in London, 2nd to kanada-ya. The ramen is great, and the side dishes are also delicious. Only downside is that the ramen sometimes feels abit greasy imo. Btw, the curry ramen is really good actually but it's not a popular choice so I'm recommending it here.

I found Shoryu Ramen to be much better than bone daddies!  However, I never found bone daddies to be traditional style ramen in the first place...
We arrived Sunday afternoon and we were seated immediately.  I got their classic Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and the wife got the Piri Piri Tonkotsu which is their spiciest ramen.  Both looked great and tasted even better!
They even give you the option for 4 different sizes noodles, however, we stuck with the classic thin hosomen noodles (original) ...not sure if they were homemade but they tasted very good.
Am looking forward to going back to try some of their more creative ramen like the 'Dracula Tonkotsu'?!

This place definitely hit the spot on a rainy and cold day in London! My friend and I were lucky to make it to the shop before the kitchen closes (they close 30 min before their posted closing time). We didn't have that much time left to order but we were definitely satisfied with what we got!
We both ordered the Piri Piri Shoryu Ramen, it's the spicy version of the Shoryu Ramen. We both loved our ramen! The noodles tasted very fresh and the broth was very flavorful and had the right amount of spice! I wouldn't recommend getting the Piri Piri if you are just looking for a little bit of heat. The green tea and raspberry mochi were the perfect treat to end our dinner.
I forgot to mention that service was really friendly too. 
I've had good ramen back in the a States before and I think this place is very good. The only downside about it is that everything is so expensive in London. Back in the States, you can get a lot of extra toppings and customize your own ramen for much cheaper at very well known ramen shops. However, it is what it is and I definitely enjoyed Shoryu Ramen! I would definitely recommend this place to anyone! :)

Had the kotteri tonkotsu ramen and a beer. 
Noodles were decent, roasted pork a bit small, boiled egg was good. Soup tasted like it had noodle flour in it and also the kitchen had dumped a massive pile of pickled ginger on top which made the soup taste oddly fishy. 
The draft beer was Kirin, decent but not spectacular- on the menu it said that it would be served very cold but it was several degrees above that. 
Price for a bowl of ramen 12 quid, with today's exchange rate making the ramen at least 3 times what one would pay for the same food in Japan. Service was friendly if a bit disorganized on a crowded Saturday afternoon, but the buy 1 ramen get the second half-off coupon that I used made up for any slowness and probably saved Shoryu from a trip to 2-starland, for now three is the number of the stars thou shalt count, and the number of the counting shall be three.

Was not happy with the service.  The lady did not comprehend what I was asking. I ordered the regular ramen w the fried shallots and I had asked her if it was simply the basic ramen w the Pork and egg plus the added ingredient of fried shallots. Took me about Three minutes to ask what I needed to ask until I gave up and went with it. And she still didn't understand. Service was terrible overall 
The ramen was ok. A bit oily. I prefer kanada-ya ramen over shoryu

Great place last minute when a more popular ramen place had a line out the door.
Service was a bit slow but they were just finishing up their night so it is to be expected when closing up other areas of the shop. 
Will def return.

My wife and I loved this place.  There was a short wait to get a table as the place was packed but certainly worth the wait.  The broth was savory, the noodles were cooked perfectly, and the portion was just the right size.  I don't really associate London with ramen but my wife and I will certainly be back!

Shoryu think you can cook Ramen! Honestly this restaurant was AMAZING. Great service that was friendly and quick and the best food I've had in awhile. I highly recommend the pork belly bun, edamame beans, and ramen! I would go again!

Visiting London and was trying to find a delicious Ramen place. Checked out Yelp and this was the top rated one nearby our hotel. I see how it was top rated. The service was very attentive and quick. The Ramen man it was delish the broth was super tasty. I ordered the spicy mince pork one while my bf ordered the most popular ramen dish. I prefered my broth for it was less richer. Overall if ever back in London would definitely come back!

Now I see what all the hype is surrounding Ramen.  With a sore throat and the desire for some fresh vegetables, we happily chose to eat here for some ramen. 
I ordered the vegetarian bowl with extra mushrooms and my friend ordered the traditional pork Ramen bowl. 
Although it took some getting use to using the spoon and chopsticks, we really enjoyed our fresh soup and I'm wishing there was a great ramen place in Tampa bay.

I've been to a lot of ramen places in the US (mostly in California), but Shoryu Ramen in London is hands down the best I've had. We were in town for less than a week, and naturally we wanted to try out as many restaurants as possible, but we ended up eating here twice because it was so good.
The wait was quite long for dinner, but we were able to be seated immediately for lunch. It's a small, packed space and you will most likely be seated at a table connected to another party.
I got the curry ramen both times. It was unique, flavorful, and the perfect portion. The only suggestion I have is to put the karaage chicken on the side, so as not to have them turn soggy.  Additionally, the lychee strawberry drink was amazing, but maybe not worth £6.

Delicious! 
I went to London for a weekend and I absolutely wanted to try Shoryu after all the excellent reviews I read. 
I waited for 30 min on a cold night but it was definitely worth the wait. 
I ordered a Karaka Tantan Tonkotsu ramen and loved it ! The noodles were perfectly cooked and broth was yummy & spicy.

very nice. we got two spicy vegans and one tonkatsu. the aesthetic and atmosphere itself is very cozy. service is prompt and answer all and any questions you have. food is delicous and huge-as ramen always is. and it's open late!

The Donkatsu ramen was very good.  Rich and brothy.  Much better than what I tasted in Paris.  However, not as good as in SF or Japan but well worth the 1.5 miles walk from my hotel.  Also had the tempura and sesame tofu.  The tempura was good but not too much batter.  Not as crunchy as it could have been.  The black sesame toy was new and good.  I would definitely come back!

It's very hard for me to go and change a venue for something new especially when it comes to Ramen. Although this was a good choice. Food was very tasty. Service was cool too. I will definitely come back when I am back in London. 
Thanks

Quite disappointed with the pork belly bun, the pork was great but while the bun looked well made, it seemed to have been "restored" in the microwave. Even with a full set of teeth there was no tearing through that bun. 
   But alas, then the ramen arrived, I had the Karaha Tantan Tonkosu Ramen.  I was totally blown away. I was just in Tokyo in January and this bowl rivaled my favorites there. Perfect texture and wonderful warming heat! I could not get this dish out of my mind and returned to their other Soho location two days later! Even with the bulletproof bun, I am still giving 5 stars!

Really good ramen! Okra appetizer looks deceptively simple but really yummy.  The broth is less pork-y, if you know what I mean.  This really hits the spot when you're looking for ramen and thankfully now there are a few locations so less chance that you'll have to queue.
I would have given five stars but it's a little while since I've been so I'm going to have to visit again and update my review.  A good excuse to have ramen at Shoryu again!

Yum yum yum!
Was looking for authentic Japanese ramen and definitely found it here! Even my parents approved/they loved it!
Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu: Perfect ramen if you're looking for a savory hearty ramen. 
Hirata Buns: ****OH MY GOODNESS. Must try. delicious.
Chicken Kara Age: Can never go wrong with fried chicken :)
It gets pretty busy so I'll definitely be back on a slow day/night.
The shoryu ban with pork and chicken is very delicious. The Piri Piri Tonkotsu is kind of spicy but it tastes good.

Not that good as I had too much good experience in HK. The food did not meet my expectation. The pork belly bun is too fatty for me and the steamed bun is not that soft, the sauce is not strong. The dumpling is nothing special. Will not go again 
But the staff is very helpful there

I can't believe it has taken me so long to write this review.
THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!
I remember the first time I discovered this place: I was on bus 23 towards Picadilly Circus when I saw the huge line of Japanese outside this little place. Intrigued, I went back the next day, stood in line in the cold for half an hour having no idea what was expecting me. Basically, I didn't know what ramen was until I stepped foot here.
Obviously, I've seen the light and consider myself a convert. My new religion is ramen. 
Ramen is a bowl of soup, mostly on pork stock, with noodles, half an egg, some veggies - but the description doesn't do it justice, as ramen is a state of mind. The absolutely sensational feeling of well being when you sip on the soup, chew on the noodles. Then the wonderful feeling hours after you've had your ramen.. Ahh.. 
I usually go for the Tokyo Ramen, but last time Ulrik tried the cold ramen and it was soooo good! A new favourite for sure.
Go, wait in line, eat, be happy!

Great ramen place, though not the most authentic (pickled ginger strips, what are you doing in my ramen soup??) and a bit pricey. Close to Piccadilly Circus. Make sure to go early if you have a large party, especially for dinner because this place fills up fast.

After going to Japan recently, my husband and I are now massive ramen snobs.  We've been to Shoryu in Soho before and loved it, so we gave this one a try on a Sunday night (no booking) to see if it was as good as we remembered.
It's a packed and busy place, with no room to wait inside, but it was only about 10 minutes before we made it in the door with my parents and grandmother.  I had the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu - their signature ramen with meatier broth and two eggs, as well as barbecued pork belly, mushrooms, spring onion, sesame, ginger, and seaweed.  Drool.  You can choose how firm you want the noodles too (firm all the way!) and we passed around a few sides of lovely Chicken Karaage - Japanese fried chicken.  It was, as expected, lush, although not the completely glorious closed-eyes experience I remembered from the other Shoryu (I think Japan has ruined me forever).  The broth is just lacking that particular je ne sais quoi that we ate in Asia, but everything else about the dish - noodles, pork, accoutrements, were lovely and craveable.  The fried chicken was very good, with a more delicate batter than you usually get with fried chicken, no bones, and a very hot temperature so watch your tongue!
A very affordable and delicious place to go for dinner.  Not a bad substitute if you can't make it to Tokyo!

The pork belly buns were flavourfull and yummy; the gyoza had a fresh pork filling that reminded me of homemade (although the skins were not).  I had the original ramen which was a big bowl of miso pork broth with two fatty slices of pork, some seaweed and scallions.  This was good although I did have food envy for my friend's signature ramen (there was half an egg!)  One drawback on the broth was that it was quite greasy.  Defat the broth!  It's not hard to do and really makes for a better, non-greasy experience.  It's not fun having to wipe your lips because it feels like you've put on too much lip balm.
While I liked Shoryu and would go back, the main drawback is the seating.  I think they are trying to provide an authentic, Tokyo experience by making the tables as crowded together as possible.  It is not a place to have any sort of intimate conversation with anyone because you are literally right up against the person sitting next to you.  I get turning tables but Shoryu borders on the ridiculous.  No wonder there were so many solo diners.  You wouldn't want to go here for a friendly chat or first date!
Ramen and buns are okay. Service was prompt. The price is reasonable compared to london standards. They add a service charge to your bill. Come here early as the place gets packed after 6pm.

I had their signature ramen dish. It's ok but I've had better. Broth was a bit bland for my taste, noodles were decent but could be better. Pork was very good. I'd eat here again if I was in the area but wouldn't come specially for this.

I've now had the chance to return to Shoryu to try more of their menu. In fact, their ever burgeoning menu. I'm impressed quickly they've added dishes to their menu, both in the ramen and the starter/side dishes categories
They've also tweaked service slightly. You still get the cheerful Japanese greeting but they've done away with the drum they hit with each new customer
They've expanded their ramen menu with both traditional and innovative combinations. I want to love their ramen but can only bring myself to like it. At the risk of sounding ungrateful, I think they put too much in their bowl. I like ramen because I like to taste the ramen noodles but the noodles get lost with all the other parapernalia they put into the bowl
They've also greatly expanded their starter/side dish menu. I have to give a shout out to their belly pork hirata buns. These are made up with 2 steamed buns which are quite dense but the perfect foil to the sweet soft pork which they sandwich. I had discovered these at Ippudo in New York and am so glad that I've found somewhere in London which does them
If you want a range of dishes, go to Shoryu for their range. However, if you want the best bowl ramen, I'd still recommend Bone Daddies

Delicious and fresh of the salmon 
I recommend the spicy reman.
My friend and I love this place. 
The service here is great. The waiters are friendly
When you pay the bill,it contain the tip ,10% of the cost.

Me and some friends took advantage of the massive discounts Shoryu was offering and payed the new shop in Piccadilly a visit.   I gotta say in advance that my opinion about the place was not very positive for a good part of the evening but then built up and ended on a good note.  
When we first arrived, we were left outside on a queue waiting to get in with no indication of whether it would take 10 minutes or 1 hour. Not a big deal, but doesn't get anyone any points either. When we finally got a table, we had to wait quite a while to get a menu (which only arrived after us chasing the waiter). 10 minutes later, 2 more people were squeezed in into our table - clearly a management attempt to fit in as many people as possible.  It is fair to say that there wasn't much space left in the table, but that didn't matter as far as the drinks were concerned: 3£ for the smallest orange juice I've ever seen in my life.  
Those were the not so good points... but then a storm of flavor arrived and washed that all away.  
The starters are really really good, specially the Hirata Buns - the pork ones are spicy but terrific. We also had Soft Shell Crab Tempura which were more than enough for 4 people.  
The main Ramen dishes completely met our expectations: flavorful, big portions, good balance between the ingredients. We struggled to finish them after all those starters so it's worth building up your appetite before visiting the place! I had the Tori Kara-Age Men and was quite happy with it - only negative was the size of the fish cake portion: way too small.   We also ordered an extra cold Ramen to try it out. Unfortunately, the waiter brought us the wrong one, so not sure which one it was. 
Overall the service was a bit all over the place and not that well organized, but the staff was friendly and approachable. Can't really give this one a 5 but the food was good enough to stir away from a 3.

3.5 stars
Decent ramen in London??? Not sure I even recognise this city anymore. I swear every place has only popped up in the year I was away. (Which is incredible!)
Ramen:
Any place with tonkotsu broth, I'm going to invariably compare to ippudo. The broth was good to be sure but just not as flavourful as I'd like. It lacks a certain intensity you find in other places.
Noodles here are pretty nice. Again, not big on flavour but they have a wonderful texture. Definitely Shoryu's USP.
Sides:
Had gyozas, chicken karaage, and pork buns. All were extremely enjoyable. Pork buns are a must order. 
Overall:
I'd give the ramen 3.5 stars objectively. In Singapore or New York, I'd say this is an average ramen place. It's a safe choice, enjoyable, but really nothing special. In London though, those same factors mean it's effectively 5 stars. If you're craving ramen, you'll be satisfied.

I queued in the snow for nearly an hour... just to eat this ramen.
(And gyoza and onigiri)
AND IT RULED.
After we finally got in, we got lucky and secured the only 2 seater table in the place. We were right against the window and had to turn our knees outward as they didn't fit under the table, and I had a fire extinguisher sticking out from the wall behind me. It's definitely a squash in here when it's full so be warned. But unlike Bone Daddies your lack of space doesn't come with uncomfortably loud music and petty portion sizes. So it's even more worth it.
We ordered some drinks and a portion of gyoza. They came pretty quickly and were awesome. The gyoza skins were nicely crispy and the perfect thickness.
Then our ramens arrived. I had the Charsui Tonkotsu for £10 a bowl - which is kind of expensive, but the portion is really generous and it's so good - again this beat Bone Daddies offering. There was lots of broth (GOOD) and the perfect amount of noodles and meat and lots of toppings. The broth was the perfect texture, it had that tonkotsu thickness but wasn't too fatty and greasy. My husband went for the Dracula Tonkotsu, which he loved. It was essentially the richer, garlicy-er version of the normal Tonkotsu and was a dream come true. We asked for vinegar and shichimi powder. They brought a huge metal jug of vinegar and a cute wooden container of shichimi, the waiter was quite funny about the size of the vinegar and the vinegar was really, really good. I love vinegar in my ramen so finding a place that offers it on-menu is a huge plus.
When we saw the specials board we couldn't help ordering a couple of onigiri. They were meant to come with brown rice but as they were running out they asked if we'd mind one with white rice. They were so apologetic and said if we didn't like it with white rice we could have one with brown for free! But for me this was even better as I prefer white rice. They were filled with pickles and really delicious.
The onigiri filled us up quite a lot and when we couldn't finish the ramen, we were so happy to find they'd bag everything up in a takeaway bag for us to take home.
The service was good, with one minor slip up when a different waiter tried to deliver a second plate of dumplings to us and didn't apologise for the mistake, aside from that it was pretty perfect.
I love the food here. If it wasn't for the cramped space (sorry, I know it's ramen bar style but I'm still getting used to these packed-in restaurants!) and the fact we had to queue for so long it'd be a 5 star straight away!

Great value for money in London- very enjoyable food - company and service- sure there is better about but this is a great sushi - Japanese Restrauant in a nice quite location- you will enjoy it without fuss- walked in freestyle for a Restrauant and found this gem. Was very close t giving it a 4 star rating - but is just isn't there yet

So yummy. Much Umami. Goooood!
Quick lunch in trafalgar square and around? planning for some ramen but you already tried sasuke (which is better!)? Definitely come here. Especially if you are alone.
The place is not that big with many small tables and a counter running all over the window. No-nonsense chart, solid ramens, some buns and just a couple of other dishes. But you definitely wanna get the ramen.
Take the one you prefer, I usually go for the standard one when I want to try a new place (first you show me you can cook a steak, then you can make a filetto alla rossini!), and just stare at the broth: Brown, thick, if I didn't knew it was liquid I'd have said it was a cream! Definitely something special, you can feel that it will be delicious just by looking at it! That my friends is probably the best broth I ever had in my ramen. The egg follows the same description, just absolutely amazing, cooked at the perfection, and overall a real pleasure.
The only thing missing, and the reason why it stands below Sasuke in my personal RAMENED competition (Ramen Axelrod May Eat Night & Day) is regarding the thickness of the noodles, which I found a bit too thin for my personal palate. But that's just me being an annoying stickler.
Just come here and enjoy the delicious broth!

I tried the Karaka TanTan Tonkotsu Ramen which were garlicky spicy noodles with minced pork on top.  My egg was a bit overcooked, I do like the yolk soft and runny.  My Tantan noodles were on the saltier side.  The only thing that annoyed me was that all the minced pork sunk to the bottom of the bowl, and I spent most of my time trying to fish it out. 
I think I'm gonna stick with basic Tonkotsu noodles, where I actually get slices of pork.  
To share, we had the Chicken Karaage - same as last time, nicely fried!  We also ordered Gyoza, but for 5, I felt it was quite understuffed and small.  The wrapping was a bit on the hard side.  The pork filling was good, nothing wrong with that.  But I think for the value, I'll stick with just the karaage. 
My friend ordered the Charsiu Tonkotsu - which is pretty much your classic noodles but with extra pork.  I tasted the broth, and strangely enough, it was... on the sweeter side.  I thought it was just me, but he tasted it too and thought it was definitely sweet.  Anyway, still a nice place to go to, but I think my go-to place is Bone Daddies for now.
This place is amazing.  Original and vegetarian were both delicious.  I've been dreaming about the broth and the noodles ever since.  Very warming on a cold winter night.

I got a very good Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu. The broth was very tasty and there was quite a lot of meat and vegetables inside.
The only problem is that the standard noodles are very thin. If you prefer the bigger noodles you must tell it when you order.
Every day they also have a day offer: when I went there it was 2 buns at the price of 1. Which is a pretty good offer since it means that you'll pay just 2.25£ per each.

I only had one vegetarian choice here...and I loved it! I also had the sake flight of the day and it was a great discovery. The non-Japanese staff kept yelling random-sounding phrases in Japanese. Not too sure what that means but whatever! It's a small place so be ready to wait, it's worth it.

This is a solid 3 stars, if you only order the ramen. The buns were a huge disappointment, lovely soft and fluffy, ruined by iceberg lettuce, piece of cucumber and pretty rank Mayo. Not worth queuing for, pricey, but I can forgive a little of that given it is in tourist central. Broth is made centrally and shipped in, if that matters to you. I feel kind of bad about the two stars, but don't big up the buns and leave me feeling like I've been conned out of seven and a half quid ! Will I be back, probably not.

Really solid ramen chain. Go for the Dracula garlic flavor or something more than just the plain option. We tried the third "hardest" noodle type and it was good, nothing too crazy. I'd try the hardest one next time. The noodles are thin and not too starchy, so the consistency worked well. The garlic broth was intense in a great way. I do wish they included corn as a topping. My husband ordered a "frozen beer" which was a fun gimmick. 
The place should write down orders though because they initially brought us the entirely wrong flavor for one of our bowls and had to go remake it. Then they just never delivered the appetizer we ordered. Kinda amateur service issues.

I only was told about this ramen place two weeks ago while trying out another Ramen bar ... since then I have been three time. Yes, it is that good. I like most of the broths, also some were too salty. I also tried the different sides and they are all delicious. I'm a fan. ... but I think I will stop going now, as I need to give other places a try as well.
One word of warning: on the weekend we had to queue for a place, but on a normal weekday ... if you go straight after work ... you will find a spare seat.

I've been to Shoryu now twice, once during their soft opening and once afterwards. 
This place specializes in a a different sort of white soup ramen from a particular region in Japan. Compared to places like Bone Daddies, this is more of an authentic Japanese-style ramen place (but that's not to say that authenticity=better). 
Service: When I went during the soft opening, they were definitely still working out the kinks. They have one waitress in particular who we've named 'waitress happy pants' because of her... rather surly demeanor. Quite frankly, I don't know if she was just having a horrible day or what, but I am very forgiving when it comes to bad service, but less so when they are snappy and eye-rolly and seem like they hate their job and everything is the customer's fault (even when it isn't). At any rate, she was actually more hilarious than frustrating, so whatever. 
Food: High soup to noodle content, the soup is flavorful but not quite rich enough for my personal tastes, some nice goodies in the bowl, but not quite enough of them. The ramen noodles themselves were the best thing about this bowl, really good. The first time I got the Shoryu Ramen, which was nice. The second time I had the Tokyo Ramen, which was soy sauce based broth with fish cake and bamboo. I think I prefer the Shoryu because it was one of the specialty white broths. Do order the egg, as they are well seasoned and quite nice (though it is a shame they don't come automatically with a bowl like they do at Tonkotsu and Bone Daddies). My dining partner had the yuzu ramen, which was really tasty. 
When I come back, I want to try to spicy miso and the yuzu ones. That said, and this is just personal preference, I found the overall dining experience and food at Bone Daddies to be more satisfying, but it is actually quite hard to compare the two as they are totally different ramen beasts. I'll certainly be back to Shoryu as well, when I want a soupier/less heavy noodle experience.
To be honest, one of the best meals we had in London. Despite the poor service (bad attitude) the food was very good. The soup was thick and the noodles was perfect too. Great reman!

Went today to take advantage of their soft launch special where ramen is all 50% off. The place was packed!! I've never seen so many Japanese people in one place in London :P
I had the spicy miso ramen which was awesome. Broth and noodles were legit. Loved it and you can't beat the price at 4 quid for the special price. Service was fast and friendly.  
Soft launch special prices are until Nov 24.
Best ramen I have ever had! I ordered the kimchi seafood ramen ! Spicy with fresh squid, scallops and  prawns!

Authentic and Nice atmosphere. Friendly service :)
Had the signature dish ( tonkotsu ramen) and hirata bun as side. Great value, and large portions!

Best ramen I've had!! Visiting from the US and I will have serious cravings for this place later. Cute little restaurant and friendly staff. The broth they use is seriously amazing! I got the standard ramen bowl they had with the fried shallots, no nori (just cause I'm not a fan of seaweed), and it was seriously so delicious! Would definitely recommend!

Tried the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and though it was alright. The broth has flavor, but felt like it was watery. I am comparing it to the ramen I had in California which was pretty flavorful. The ramen noodle itself wasn't anything to right about.
However, I also tried their Shoryu buns and I would recommend it to anyone who goes there. The meat is pretty tender and flavorful. 
Having only been there once, I would give this place another try. Maybe the chef was having a bad day.
Winter ramen.  Soup is good, prices anywhere from 10 to 20 pounds. Not so busy, so service alright.  No cockroaches on my food.  I'm not crazy about ramen but enjoy them from time to time.

Overall a good meal.  But the whitebait just wasn't good.
The wagyu buns were large and fluffy compared to others, but were filled with tasty beef and melted in your mouth.  
The Piri piri Tonkotsu ramen was good.  Lots of flavor with a beautiful egg and a nice kick.  
The gyoza was nicely done with a crunchy lace in the bottom of the skillet.
The whitebait was fishy though.  Didn't taste very fresh.  Didn't finish these.

Pretty good ramen by London standards, can be a little salty, but if you're in the area, is always a good choice for a bite of Japanese. Take note that queues can be long, so be prepared for a wait. I tried the black garlic ramen, which was unique and left me warm and happy. The space can be a little cramped due to the huge number of people they have, so the point is - eat fast and get the hell out of there, and reflect on how tasty it was after you leave. Worth a try for sure.
If you like spicy food, don't listen to the waitress warnings. Specialty cocktails were good but the ramen stole the show

I enjoyed my Shoryu Tonkatsu ramen but personally I prefer the Bone Daddie Tonkatsu ramen more. I found the ramen here to be very good, with generous serving portion, more toppings and equally satisfying, however, I still pick BD tonkatsu over it. My reasoning behind it is that I felt that the broths (both pork and chicken) there were much tastier and with more intense flavour.
As for the service here, my experience with Shoryu was as good as our service in BD. I had no complaints. Overall, Shoryu was good but my taste buds seek the BD flavour.

This ramen is clearly geared towards the western palate.  If you're looking for authentic Japanese ramen, this isn't really it.  It is still good though.  
We did have an unfortunate thing happen when we went; my friend's phone was stolen while we were eating there.  Keep an eye on your things while you're there!

Very good ramen place. 
We had the spicy ramen (#4) and normal (#1). Topped off with frozen Kirin (draft beer topped with frozen foam made from beer -- so it keeps it colder longer without diluting the beer when it melts). 
I added fresh pressed garlic (sorry to my darling wife). 
Although the ramen was very tasty, the presentation isn't to be overlooked. From the bowl and wooden ladle to the layout of the ingredients on top (half an egg, thin slices of pork, chopped onions, etc). 
Perfect after freezing our fingers and toes off for an hour+ watching the changing of the guards at Buckingham Palace.
This place has the best buns I've ever tasted and Monday 2-4-1 is a steal. The ramen is top too. If you're in town you just visit

The ramen was wonderful. Ordered a signature ramen. Besides the ramen, I ordered a pork bun too. However, it came out a little disappointing, as the bun is cut into halves instead of folded, like how it was supposed to be. There was also some mayonnaise used in the pork bun, which to me, was a bad idea to a cuisine like this. When it was served, the bun was a little cold, indicating that it was not freshly steamed. On the other hand, the broth to the ramen was just nice! Perfect! And I like how we get to choose the tenderness of the noodle. Overall, the ramen is good, and the ambience is perfect since the server tries to use Japanese but I would avoid the pork bun.

This is just a review of the veggie ramen - I've heard excellent things about the non-veg but haven't tried it.
The veggie ramen is wholesome and satisfying - exactly what you want on a cold day. It's a little bit bland, which is why I recommend getting it with the chilli sauce, but with that addition it's delicious.

A comedy of bad service. Don't buy the wine. They served probably the worst expensive Chablis I have ever had. They also failed to have almost any of the gluten free items on the menu. 
Finally they did not deliver one main. It was my main and I can't review the food because after a long wait I didn't eat. 
Dead loss.

Surprisingly, I enjoyed their ramen much more than the ones I've had back home in Las Vegas. The broth, noodles, and toppings...delicious from the beginning to the end. The only negative thing I have to say about this place is their price. £11 or around $17 for a bowl of ramen when I'm used to paying $7 in Vegas.
Excellent service from start to finish -fantastic Ramen and to top it off a frosty draft beer...couldn't of asked for better! whenever I'm in London I will be back.

Very good place! We got the prawn tempura and it was great! And we got the mushroom appetizer and it was good too! The ramen was also very nice- the broth was not as rice as my ramen place in santa clara buutt it was good. I thought it was a little weird that they didnt have corn as an option to add to the ramen but oh well.. come for the music, stay for the ramen!

We were extremely impressed with the Tonketsu ramen.We added some Japanese chili powder to our noodle.Wow.we thought the Ramen scene in London has come of age.
Then the MSG induced dry mouth came.OH OH.
Tonketsu with MSG!!!!!!

Good Ramen, and the buns are great too
Gyoza was amazing, didn't think gyoza can be that good

It's a chain restaurant that can be found mostly in central London. The ramen here is consistently good. The bao, though, not so much - a tad bit too pricey for the lacklustre flavour and ingredients in the bao itself. Stick with the ramen, and go for the dessert after if you're still hungry (warning: you'll probably be ultra full after their generous servings of ramen!).

Well.. was ok, I guess. In theory Ramen are just a fast food, but nvertheless it's quite difficult to get it right. This place is a quite a gimmick: A blonde greets you at the door with a forced and awkward "irah..shai..ma..sei?", hits an embarrassing Japanese drum, and shows you to your table.. the broth is quite boring.. neither memorable, nor worth writing much more about.. ok overall. 
(oh, on the way out they hit the drum again.. I have probably eaten at 500 different restaurants in Japan, and never seen this before)
Good ramen. I had the dracula ramen (with lots of garlic). Really good for a cold night.
Delicious broth, especially On a grey, drizzly day. The noodle texture is not my fave- too thin, but overall a delicious bowl of ramen. Wonderful service- very friendly and attentive
Nice food, good costumer service. The ramen was well served, well condiment. The spice plate was hot but not excessive

Will this Ramen blow your mind... not quite. 
Shoryu, either this one, or the one on the other side of Picadilly Circus, is nice for a quick stop. It's always busy -  in my option this may have more to do with the lack of alternative choices in the area vs. the quality of the food.. 
I've not found better contenders in London, but compared to other cities, the ramen leaves something to be desired. 
Avoid the green tea mochi! 4.50 for one small piece that we didn't finish because it tasted bad :/

One of the best ramens I've tasted outside of Japan. Great selections and the broth is divine. Very friendly, quick staff. There are sharing tables so if you come alone or even with just a few friends, you may be sharing a big table. I went by myself and sat next to an interesting group. I haven't tried the sushi here, but when the ramen is so good, you don't really need not. Price is pretty decent.

Solid flavor, but not enough noodles. (I got thick; those with thin noodles seemed to have larger portions). I also ordered a beer that didn't come until I was halfway through my meal and water that never came. Really expensive, but that's probably because I'm an American who isn't used to the pound.

31/3/14
Okay.......... Was thinking to change this to 4 stars or not after finish eating my bowl of noodle while waiting for my add on side order hakata roll to come.
Reason to add a star:
1. Ramen still as yummy. I ordered hakata tantan ramen. Nice n spicy. Still loving their chicken kara age.
2. They change their table n chair to proper table!!
Reason on holding back:
1. Table was quite oily and sticky. the stuff that I taking up from the table keep sticking on table which make me think about the hygiene of this consider still new ramen shop.
2. Our sushi didn't come after 20min...... Ask for a waiter to check if they did place the order if they didn't then is ok we ready to pay. He went to check n come back telling us ok Cancelled now!! -_-!!
Okay....... 
2013
Have been looking for an authentic japanese ramen shop for quite some time. Heard bout this restaurant for quite some time and finally we get to try it.
When there around 8pm on a weekday with my friend. No queue. Got seated once we were there. Their table and chair seems to be slightly lower. The chair is like those low bar chair kind.......Not comfortable type. Clearly they do not want their customer to be too comfortable and stay too long in their restaurant.
The day we went we they were giving out free sake for customer. I ordered their house special bone soup roast pork ramen (I think it call tongkotsu). It was yummy. I like it.  We also order 2 sides fried chicken and the green bean edamame. They serve the bean with brown colour rock salt which make it look special. They do give a free side which is vinegar cabbage.
Would give a 4 stars if they have more spacious space and comfy seating for  what the price they are charging their customer.

Very bad ramen. Very disapointing. The burger was beautifuk but it felt like eating a small burger at mcdonald. Pretty fade taste. wouldnt come back unless  it is for a quick lunch and there is nothing else open...

This has to be one of the best ramen that I've tasted in London.  I actually took a friend here that lived in Japan for 3 years and they gave it their stamp of approval, being the best ramen that they'd tasted outside of Japan and that it was very authentic.
The portions are a good size and you can ask for an extra serving of noodles if needed.  I've never needed to have extra noodles as the portions are pretty filling and the prices are reasonable for what you get.

This lovely Japanese style place is perfect for a dinner for two or more. The ramen is very tasty and the portion is very big. We also took a "bun", something like a steamed bread sandwich stuffed with fried chicken, lettuce and two different sauces. The staff is very friendly and able to give you a lot of tips about the dishes. I'll be back soon.
Love this place! Ordered their ramen special with pork belly, and steamed bbq pork buns. Absolutely DELISH, and made to feel very welcome!

I had the best ramen experience in London. Small cozy place with nice friendly atmosphere. I ordered hirata bun with pork (which is absolutely amazing, must try) and spicy noodle (which was absolutely amazing as well). Highly recommended

Best ramen I've had in London. It gets busy though, so be prepared to queue. The steam buns are ok, but not the best I've had. My friend was disappointed they took off the salmon buns from the menu. She loved them.

This place is always busy and I definitely wasn't dissapointed once I had jostled for the last reminaing seat!
I had the natural tonkotsu and my boyfriend had the iced chicken wings and pork buns, which he loved.
The dumplings were a little on the dry side unfortunately but everything else was great.
Not bad for local standard, but lacks authenticity.  Soup base should be richer, the noodle is a bit too soggy for ramen gurus.

Got to finally try this place out. Waited around 10mins to be seated during the lunch time hours. Ordered the Shoryu Ramen, and have to say I was impressed. Very good flavor broth and the veg was very good and the meat was cooked spot on. I pretty much gobbled up all of it and the egg was cooked perfectly. Obviously not as amazing as the Ramen I have in Los Angeles, but for London I was very happy with it. Definitely recommend this place for anyone craving Ramen around London.

Perfect place to be when its cold and wet outside. Ended up getting a spicy ramen which was incredible. Broth wasn't overpowered by the spice. We also got some bao/buns to share. Chicken came with an amazing sauce, the pork was maybe a little too fatty for my liking. (Visit - 27/05/2014 Dinner)
Easily my favorite meal I've had in London. I thought about going back and definitely would have, but I wanted to try other places. I had to Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu which was fantastic.
Excellent ramen. The gyoza (potsticker) is very good as well. Service exceeds expectation for a lunch spot. We would return.
lovely place. the waitress explains all the different types of ramen soup. the kotteri Hakkatan tonkotsu is to die for

There are queues everywhere in London, but this one wasn't so bad when we arrived around 5:30pm on a Saturday (10 mins wait), and definitely worth it! This was my first real ramen house experience, so I got the tonkotsu regular - it was flavorful with an egg, veggies but only about three slices of pork. I had a taste of the spicy tonkotsu broth, and it's a little more flavorful only if you can handle the heat!! We also didn't have to wait very long for the soup to come, which was convenient. The ambiance is charming and modern, and the servers were attentive, but since this restaurant is quite small and pretty busy, we decided against overstaying our welcome. Recommended if you're near Piccadilly Circus.

This place is in the heart of the shopping district in London. After walking around in the cold throughout the day, my gf and I wanted something warm and came across this place. The service and location are exceptional, albeit a very touristy location. Obviously, I gravitated towards this location because all tourists get sucked into the "tourist epicenter" of any city. The food is good but not great (meat quality in the buns is not good) and definitely not worth the price. I understand rent is very expensive in this area and the high costs definitely pass down to the food. However, I was still disappointed with the quality of food based on the price. After paying for the meal, I thought about selling my semen to a sperm bank to help offset the cost of this meal. I eventually decided not to do it because I didn't want my biological kids trying to find me 30 years later during their "finding myself stage" to figure out what genetic similarities we shared. At the end of the day, I thought about semen for money for ramen. End of story. End of review. I didn't do it. I'm out.

I give this 5 stars because it was just amazing. The menu had so many options and was super nutritious (even had multiple gluten-free options!) I tried the Hirata Bun first which was a rice bun with pork, lettuce, and an amazing sauce. The bun was so soft and the pork was really great. The service for the food was perfect, nice and fast. The standard origin Ramen I got after the Hirata bun was delicious!

Yummy! One star off because there was no healthy options. We got a bottle of rose and the buns with chicken karaage (deep fried). Then moved on to the chicken ramen which was better than the ramen I've had in the Bay Area even. Milky, flavourful and satisfying.  Again I wish they have grilled chicken so I could keep my diet but so yummy sometimes so worth it !
All their gluten free options were delicious - I could even eat shoryu buns again! Great for tourists and residents alike. It does seem to get crowded around peak times though.

First sip was somewhat bland but after it felt a lot more creamy and flavourful for a tonkotsu ramen.
Disagree with the Hirata Buns. Meat one was sub par compared to the many different buns offered using a japanese fusion take on things. The veggie one was different and actually special which pleased my vegetarian date.
Overall not too bad. Probably rare to find this type of cuisine in Europe but plenty of better ones in California and Toronto.

I came here on a rainy weekday at 5:30pm for linner and it was very empty. I guess everyone's off to the pubs at this time of the day. I decided to order the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu (minced pork) for a change and my friend ordered the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu. After tasting my Karaka Tan Tan, the Kotteri Hakata tasted rather bland. The sous vide egg was pretty good. But I'd have to give it to Shoryu for having the best broth compared to Bone Daddies and Kanada-Ya. The broth was spicy, thick, and flavorful. Same goes for the noodles, the best compared to Bone Daddies and Kanada-Ya. I still much prefer thick ramen noodles though. It seems to me that thick ramen noodles are nonexistent in London. Overall great service and tasty ramen. A must try!

Super delicious ramen, authentic, with some frills. Beautiful decor with the mirrored bar shelves. Close to the craziness of Piccadilly circus but a nice respite from crowds and loud children. Much better than ethnic restaurants in the surrounding area and better than any restaurant in Chinatown!

Excellent ramen. If you are looking for a bit of flavor in London, this is the place. The service is slow, though. Also, beware that there are ABSOLUTELY no substitutions. We could not even get a plate of sliced plain cucumbers (cucumber salad was on the menu). That was fairly ridiculous.

Shoryu was a top place to go on a chilly summer night. The ramen was pretty good. The noodles seemed a bit undercooked and the broth was so-so, but the egg was one of the best things I've ever tasted. Would come back next time I'm in London.

I went back on got over my ramen envy from last time and got a shoryu ramen. I will die a happy girl. 
The egg wasn't as good as last time, but I'm not sure if that whole raw food thing scared the shit out of London eateries. But egg aside, we also ordered some cocktails, initially ordered a lemongrass one, but they made the wrong one and gave me a shochu sours. But everything has a bright side. SHOCHU SOURS FOR LYF. 
Yes. It was that good.
My first visited the one near canary street and the best Ramen I ever had, then went to the one in Soho couple week later..not really feel the same at all, may be different Ramen I ordered.

"Irasshaimase!". Immediately as you enter, you're greeted with a boisterous traditional Japanese welcome. It pretty much sets the tone that you're in for something authentic. Its run by the same people as the Japan Centre across the road. If the Japanese shop there, they'll probably be eating here, so you won't be disappointed.
We ordered the Shoryu Tonkotsu and the Piri Piri Tonkotsu (which had just the right spicy kick). Both had pickled white ginger in it ...great for sushi, but too over-powering for soup noodles. It was shoved out the bowl and piled high on the complementary pickled red cabbage starter dish. We accompanied our meal with a side order of soft shell crab instead of the more traditional gyoza.
On our waiter's recommendation, we finished the meal with the sponge cake (not on the menu). It was light and filled with fresh cream, and topped off with a macha sprinkling.
Overall, a great eating experience for pre-movies or pre-theatre dining. I'd give it 5-stars, but that's reserved for Daikokuya in LA's Japan Town.
yelp.co.uk/biz/daikokuya…
The vegan white natural soup was amazing. I've tried many vegetarian ramens and this was by far the best tasting broth I have ever had. It's a pity I discovered it on my second to last day in London.

We didn't even try the food but the service was horrible. We walked in and it was packed. I stood in front of the door and I probably eyed every waitstaff there and didn't get an acknowledgment.  I didn't get asked for how many until a min later. The wait was about 10mins which was fine... I see it was busy. Then another table of 4 came in and they knew one of the workers there... And the guy started to look for a table for them. In short we were overlooked and our table was given to someone else. We weren't too happy about that, so we left. 
Doesn't matter who your customer know or not know you shouldn't be seating someone ahead of customers who came first when there is a table for them.

I have become a fairly regular customer at the Denman Street Shoryu and this was my first trip to the 'other' Shoryu Ramen. 
I can happily say that the food is just as good here. The ambience is the same as well. 
I had a cold ramen - the chef's special something, it was - and it came with the Ramen on a straw mat with ice below it. Very visually appealing and definitely worth the 12 pounds-ish that I paid for it. 
The seating is a bit close together and it can be uncomfortable if you are here to have some intimate conversation. Of course, its not a problem if you can talk in a few different languages (Hindi, Malayalam, English) according to the people sitting around you - making sure that your privacy is maintained. Haha.

A short walk from Piccadilly Circus, you'll find a cozy little ramen shop that serves up hot noodles, broth and tea. As a first timer, I took the safe route and picked the popular Karaka Miso Buta Tonkatsu Ramen (9.90), and although there was a tiny mix up with our orders, it got to us eventually, and still in quick fashion. I must say I was quite pleased with my selection... the broth was tasty, not too heavy, and the portion size was just right. Another treat was the Genmai Tea, I couldn't stop drinking it, it was so good! Oh yeah, get the gyoza. There's nothing ever really special about gyoza, but it's always good. Service was quick and attentive and they even gave us coupons for next time. Need something hot to warm up on these cold winter days? Ramen might just hit the spot.
Great service, amazing food...get the dumplings (guitar) and the shoryu buns and have fun beyond that...such a cool place

Having tried the other recent Ramen places that have popped up in London, I thought I'd give this place the chance.... Now I know it's all personal preference but this place wasn't for me. To be fair I went for the signature  tonkatsu (as I have in all the others) all the ingredients were there and the noodles were good, however the soup just was a little salty and bland. We accompanied the Ramen with steamed pork buns that were very good though!! 
The layout of the restaurant is a little bit awkward also, the entrance door inconveniences at least two tables and if you need to use the only toilet then you will again have to disturb people.
Overall, fairly good and slightly cheaper than the rest but defiantly trailing  the others in my opinion.

I've become a regular here since I first came 2 years ago. It's one of our go to restaurants when we're in central London (which is almost daily). It's always busy but we rarely have to wait for a seat for more than 10mins - service is fast and food is always amazing. I'd say this is my favourite ramen place above others such as Bone Daddies, Koya or Tonkotsu. I think the broth and noodle have the best texture/consistency/flavour out of them all! We also go to the Shoryu in King Street but this is still my favourite one.

So much ramen, so little time. And you need time if you want to go to Shoryu as the line is quite often 10-15 people long on any given evening. We went on the soft-opening week which meant the line was even longer although props to the staff for shoving us in as fast as possible and having no qualms about asking random people to sit together.  However, I didn't quite understand why they split the group up when the table the first pair was given was more than enough for all of us. We swapped the randoms for our friends and everyone was happy (except for the waitress who looked like she was about to punch a hole in the wall).
The Ramen itself was good (I chose the Shoryu Special) with a rich creamy white broth that was an excellent argument on its own for taking the slow boil method for making tonkotsu stock. The pork itself wasn't that flavourful and I remember being a little disappointed in the low amount of veggies. Those that were there were excellent and so was the egg. The bowl is a massive serving and I happily slurped my way into fatty pork nirvana.
It's a bit cramped inside with the planners seemingly hell bent on working out how to maximise the number of people per square meter. Be prepared to get close to some strangers and even cosier with your friends. Then again, we all survive the tube in rush hour so by comparison this is downright luxurious! 
In the London Ramen rankings, the overall food is good but not enough to dethrone Bone Daddies as the London Ramen King!
solid ramen place. Not the best ramen i have had but not the worst. the service is pretty good. solid place if you are in central and want ramen.
A die hard fan of ramen, I can safely say that ShorYu's ramen will not disappoint. Eggs could have been done better, but the broth was delicious!

And so continues my ramen quest!  I just moved here, and I'm on a mission to find my favorite ramen restaurant in London.  So far nothing makes me want to strip naked and jump inside the hot vat of soupy goodness, ecstatically yelling YES as I beat two slices of pickled turnips together in excitement.
Shoryu was half full by the time I got there at 7 pm, but packed by the time I left at 8.  I was seated quickly, and ordered the £9.9 Takana Tonkotsu with a £3 side of menma and £1.5 of egg, as well as the £6 shishito peppers.  Nice but quite expensive additions.  5 minutes later (I do appreciate the fast service here, way faster than Bone Daddy's), I had a hot steaming bowl of ramen.  They're not stingy with the portion either.
The noodles were al dente and the broth was certainly flavorful, but missing the fattiness that I prefer.  In fact, it was a bit watery. I preferred the pork at BD as it was softer and fattier.  
Update: I came here again, and ordered the Wasabi Tonkotsu and Karaka Miso Buta Tonkotsu.  Loved the Buta Tonkotsu, there were tons of ground pork in it and the noodles were perfect!  Couldn't really taste much of the wasabi in the other tonkotsu, definitely preferred the Buta.

IMO, far and away the best ramen in London (after Shoryu, of the places I've been I'd rank them Tonkotsu, Ittenbari, Bone Daddies, Yugo, Mitsukoshi). Good noodles, egg is of the perfect doneness, and the tonkotsu broth is fantastic, very balanced.
My personal favorite (and supposedly the favorite of the staff) is the Karaka Tantan Tonkotsu, spicier and with garlic.
I'm from the San Francisco Bay Area and I'd say Shoryu is similar in quality to Ramen Dojo there, and also similar in that they both have spicy ramen. Personally, I don't think anywhere else in London comes close.

Had a great bowl of Ramen hear a couple days back. Was really craving some good quality ramen after all the cold and the rain this week in London. I came on a weekday afternoon around 4pm, it was pretty empty at that time and I was seated immediately.
I ordered the special Hakata Tonkotsu ramen with spicy ground pork. It was very rich and flavorful. I could really taste the good quality of each of the ingredients, and then broth had a very unique taste compared to other ramen broths I've had.
Service and ambiance were good, no complaints as I did come at an off peak time.
I would recommend this place for good quality, flavorful ramen!

The key to a great ramen is the broth. The broth here is great, therefore the ramen is great.
I had the char siu ramen - the original ramen plus extra pork, and my wife had the Dracula ramen, which had caramelised garlic. I got to try her broth at the end: it was garlicky indeed, but still very nice. Noodles were cooked just right and the pork slices were nice. As you would expect, mine had a lot of pork slices which were a treat. An unusual element was the pickled ginger. It's a surprise when you eat it, but makes for a good occasional contrast to the rest of the ramen.
We got our usual sides of karaage chicken and gyoza. The gyoza came with a nice ginger dipping sauce. The karaage chicken was made from chicken breast, which was ok but I have noticed that the thigh meat has more flavour and is juicier.
We got an Asahi each too. They came with a half pint glass of the sort you would find in an English pub, which I liked.
Our total bill came to £48 with service.  This is about average or just under for the ramen places that we have visited in London. I would come back here, but probably just for the ramen.
The place is an easy walk, just down the hill, from Picadilly tube station.  There was a small queue outside when we got there at around 6:30pm and this grew during the evening.  This is something to bear in mind - however, ramen appears to be one of the trendy things at the moment, so most good ramen places would be like this.

If you're wondering about that wasabi tonkotsu, I too was curious before finally coming here on Sunday.. I had checked out their ramen selection in advance to see what they had to offer compared to the other ramen joints..and wasabi ramen is definitely a new one for me.
 
So I will start with the con. They have a scoop of pasty wasabi shavings when your bowl is brought out untouched, along with the atypical bean sprouts, earwigs, pork, and two sheets of seaweed (sorry, gotta pay extra for an egg!). The pasty wasabi shaving was not very potent, especially when I mixed it in with my broth.
