The most popular one we saw was the warm paneer salad on every table. It was really quite spicy and warm lettuce could throw you off, but definitely worth consuming. I could have eaten one whole one by myself, but then I wouldn't have been able to taste anything else due to the spice level. 
Our table also ordered the railroad lamb curry stew, which was quite good and the "burrito" like wrap for it did not quite hold in all the stew. Would possibly recommend ordering a side of rice to eat with this. And the chicken burger, but I don't remember its name off the top of my head. This was more than enough food for 2 people for lunch, though everything was so good it wouldn't hurt to order more just to try everything on the menu. Or bring a big group here so you can split everything.

What a fantastic experience from start to finish.  
We descended into the downstairs to some of the most elegant modern decor, complemented by equally polished service.  The surroundings and attentiveness was pitch perfect.
Everything we tried from the menu was delicious but the standouts were the paneer and pepper kabobs dusted with chili and from our entrees, the palak paneer, tarka dahl and chicken tikka were absolutely heavenly.  Our cocktails could have been made a little less sweeter but otherwise, the meal was perfect.  We will be returning here before returning home!
Come here a couple of times. Like, but not love it. Good food, OK vibe, decent night out, but nothing too special.

So many good reviews already for this restaurant and once you are there, it is easy to see why.  Read them and I agree with them all!
The food is so flavoursome and good portions (I've only been here for lunch).  Service has always been good with the serving staff knowledgable in what they are serving.  You can easily come her for lunch, have a good meal and be back in the office within the hour or there abouts which, is always a bonus.
Not so great on desserts but the starters and the mains are soooo nice it doesn't really matter.  So far, I've not eaten anything here that I did not like will be back and back again.

Best Indian food I've ever had. No lie. 
Downstairs dining area: 
I'm veggie, and was surprised to see so many options on the menu. I started out with the palak papri chaat. Excellent. My husband and I shared the Schezwan chilli paneer. Seriously, hold me down. Bada**. I then had the palak paneer and tarka daal, accompanied by the roti and naan plate. Wow, the paneer melted in my mouth, the palak was of the gods, and the daal was unique, and tasted like the most epic buttery daal goodness I've ever had. Broke my taste buds. Rico. Rico. Rico.
The service was excellent. The waiter and manager were both very present, without being overbearing. 
Def going back!
Update:
2 days later we went back to try the Indian street food (upstairs). Def underwhelming. They were slammed, and maybe that affected preparation/service. I wouldn't go back for the street food, but would for sure go back to the dining room food.
Not real Indian food. I lived in New York and other states and never had Bad Indian food. This food was nasty. London you need to learn better

I actually ate downstairs in the restaurant. Food was  really good. Garlic naan was amazing. Upstairs is more fast food style with different menu. Was packed so I would suggest reservations if avail as an option. Giving 4 rather than 5 due to wait staff. Brought out entree before starters (and not at same time as my friends entree so it got cold while I waited for hers to come as it is rude to eat in front of someone whom is hungry).
Good food, great presentation and a creative menu. Definitely worth a visit for those dealing with a craving for Indian food.

The service here is terrible! It's too bad because the food is actually decent. The pani puri and chicken lollipops were flavorful. The chicken curry and cauliflower veg dish were okay. Not super authentic but good enough for the price. 
I wish I could give them 3.5 stars. Good enough for quick Indian food, but do not expect anything from the service. It was some of the worst I've ever experienced.
If you want fantastic Indian, I would still go to Dishoom.

Very nice. Appreciated the space usage and the decor. Waited a short time for a table, but the staff was very helpful w/a cocktail. Food came fast, was tastie and delicious. Portions were spot on, shared w/college. Happenings spot. Go for a great night. Serve lunch too.

We ate on their lower level and found that the food was fantastic, the service was warm and engaging, and the location was convenient!  Very well done in every regards.  Our server was charming and attentive, the food was so good and they offered an interesting menu with some unexpected items.  
Happy to refer friends and family here!

If the place is full with a lot of Indians it must be a good place right? This place is full with both Indian business men and Indian families, so expect a noisy crowd but also great food.
I feel lucky to love Indian food and even more lucky to have found this place. I have not yet tried the second floor dining restaurant but I do love the ground floor street food restaurant. It's a light, clean and open, modern interior with some Indian street signs. 
The chai is tasty and has real spices, the chilli paneer is nicely spicy (really great but actually quite spicy) and comes with a lot of vegetables (a bit more paneer would have been great), the pani puri is a fun chaat dish and often not advisable to have in India because of the water used but here it's just great.
The Andra Pradesh chicken curry is a great spicy juicy curry and made me almost overeat myself, just like I use to do in India ;-)
The food is very affordable as well, great value!

A Indian New Yorker has Indian food in London. 
The YELP community very rarely leads me astray, and although they were a little bit below the mark, Roti Chai was still a decent food option. To note, I am sure there are plenty other fantastic Indian spots in this city, that this wouldn't be my first pick going forward. But if you are in the neighborhood and want quick food and service this would probably be your best bet. Let's break it down shall we?
3 friends go to Roti Chai and share some Indian dishes Tapas style, and here's what we thought!
STREET SECTION:
1. Aloo Papri Chaat (4.8GBP) - The papri (circular fried bread base was crispy, but not fresh), the aloo (potato) was well made, and the toppings were tasty, but not fresh again. It was decent, and edible, but not exciting or by any means the best papri chaat I've had. Decently priced for the portion. Rating = 3/5
2. Chicken Lollipops (5.5GBP) - Good texture, taste, although could have used more flavor, spice, and seasoning. But still delicious, and one of the better dishes we had, good price for the portion. Rating = 4/5
3. Agni 'Fire' Wings (5.9GBP) - Well made, although I thought the chicken could have been cook a tad more. The accompanying sauces were good, and the wings were indeed spicy. I will have to say, they were not "Indian spicy" but still created some heat and were well "sauced." Again, good portion for the price. Rating = 4/5
4. Hakka Chilli Paneer (5.5GBP) - My favorite dish, as the quality of each paneer was perfection. Perfectly seasoned and flavored. The paneer was also cooked to perfection and tasted more fresh than 1, 2 and 3 (above). My one qualm with this dish was there was very little paneer, and vegetables took up most of the dish which isn't what you are paying for. Quality = 4/5, Quantity = 3/5, Rating = 3.5/5.
ROAD & RAIL:
1. Gobi Manchurian (7.2GBP) - This dish was all that was wrong. The gobi Manchurian was slightly stale, the sauce ruined the gobi, and gobi itself tasted like it was undercooked, the cauliflower (gobi) was still a bit hard and the dish just 100% made me wish I could have my 7GBP back, this dish really ruined the meal for me. Rating = 0/5. Sorry for the awful rating, but do not order this dish. 
2. Railway Lamb Curry (8.5GBP) - The Lamb was decently cooked, but could have been softer. Whenever I've had lamb curry, it has melted in my mouth, so this was a bit of a disappointment. It was not really spicy, but there was a bit of flavor, could have been cooked longer, and with more flavor. Overall probably would not order it again, but it was decent. Rating = 3/5.
SWEET:
1. Pistachio Kulfi (2.9GBP) - Although I love Kulfi, and it was good, it tasted like it was a "packaged kulfi" and they just unwrapped it an put it in a glass for me to eat. Still delicious, but still not the kind of fresh made Kulfi I was expecting. Rating 4/5. 
WiFi was good at the restaurant, and the service was solid (sometimes a bit spotty as no one really checked up on our table). Rating 4/5.
Final thoughts: 
Don't go out of your way to eat here. 
Decent Indian food for a cheap meal.

Dining room had good atmosphere, very prompt and attentive (bordering formal) service, and food that was fantastic. The flavors were deep and complex. The naan was fresh out of the oven and perfect. We ordered starters, mains, and desserts. All five members of our group raved about their dishes.

My first night in London, we decided to stay near the action which luckily happens to be a quick ride from the flat where I'm staying. My bro suggested we have some Indian so we went into Roti Chai.
The upstairs of RC has an unassuming dining hall style space with a tapas inspired indian menu. Traditional diners can head downstairs for full waiter and menu service. We did and ordered:
Bengali fish and crab cakes - 9/10 
I couldn't differentiate between the two but both were of great consistency, dressed with wonderful colourful sauce and crunchy coated warmness. Near best fish/crab cakes ever had (two establishments in Chicago and Tanzania still hold those titles).
Schezwan chilli paneer- 8/10 
This was the other appetizer star of the night. A familiar dish but served on skewers for a change, this proved to be an excellent vegetarian option, and perfect for a mild palate.
Saagwala gosht- 9/10
Now as far as the mains were concerned, this is one for the books. I never order gosht but will have to remember it moving forward. Succulent goat meat in a green bath of herbs and yoghurt- almost the perfect 10 in my humble opinion. Could have been spicier though.
Butter chicken- 7.5/10
This was my main dish and met (but did not exceed) my expectations. Cooked beautifully, it paled in comparison to the other mains shared but no leftovers so don't be shy to order it up.
Awadhi lamb rack- 8.5/10
This was the best dish as far as presentation goes, and the lamb itself was tender and very flavourful, but its portion was a bit on the small side and it did not accompany the rice and naan as well as the curry and stew.
Garlic naan- 6/10- garlicky but could use some salt &butter. Bit flat. 
Rice- 8/10- your standard saffron rice, more dry than sticky. 
Wine- 10/10
This fabulous meal was enjoyed with a bottle of Pinot Grigio that I've also noted for future reference. 
Lastly for dessert we tried the 
chocolate mousse- 8/10. It was enjoyable. Small yet rich enough to be shared, it came with a cream sauce and was a great way to end the night, savour-wise. Wished I'd had a coffee with it for an ideal palate cleanser duo.
Overall: 4.5 but rounded up for atmosphere + service points. See pics.
I RECOMMEND- Exploring the menu! Nothing displeased us. 
EXTRA TIP-Slightly on the pricey side. We were in a celebratory (read: indulgent) mood but our bill was on the high end especially for the travelling diner (damn you ole GBP!) Stay upstairs in the street kitchen if you respect your budget ;)

Chicken lollipops are amazing. And the chilli chicken burger was very good.. 
expect fusion style on the first floor, tapas style portions
Highly recommended!!

DELICIOUS Indian food! We assumed that we'd have to wait a bit for a table since we went on a Saturday night, but we only had to wait about 5 minutes. We ate in the downstairs dining room.
My husband & I shared the butter chicken, the garlic naan, the basmati rice, and the Indian cheese appetizer. The food came astonishingly fast (like, 2 minutes after ordering, no joke) - but was incredibly fresh and delicious. We ate every bite!
My husband also got the Bhai Cider with his meal and said it complemented perfectly.

It's always a good sign when an Indian friend raves about an Indian restaurant.  A friend from NY was in town and thought it was a good opportunity to check out this place since it's in a central location.  My friend recommended the street kitchen over the dining room - but wish you were able to interchangeably order from both menus but anyways...
I started out with the Hakka Chili Paneer and Papri Chaat.  I really enjoyed the paneer.  I think I could just order that with a side of rice for dinner and be really content.  The papri chaat was really good - my friend says it proper punjabi!  It feels a bit on the heavier side with all the yogurt and stuff but none the less very tasty.
I had the curried chickpeas whilst my friend had the curry fish and we shared a roti basket - which had a variety of 3 different kinds of roti (stuffed, plain).  More than enough food.  
If you're missing indian snacks and don't want to go all the way out to Tooting or Southall to pick 'em up, they sell Indian snacks at the entrance - such as masala flavoured crisps!

Good food but very spicy and it is premade and they cannot alter anything on the menu to decrease the level of heat/ spice.  One of the people in our party never got her main entree.  They never brought it

This is actually two different restaurants at the same location.  I have been here three times over the last weeks. The first time, there was no seating available in the upper street-cafe area, so I went downstairs to the fairly traditional British Indian restaurant. Despite it being his first night on the job, service was good, with his mentor following-up to make certain all was done correctly.  I had a simple chicken curry and a pepper/whiskey drink.  They did not ask how spicy I wanted  the curry and it was tasty, buy no heat.  Very adequate.
On the next two occasions I sat upstairs, which is much more casual, with small-plate style menu.  My favorite dish is the warm pepper salad (sorry, I have forgotten the name) with fried Paneer.  It is wonderfully hot and flavorful. I also enjoy the "Chicken Lollipops" with mint chutney.  It is loud and boisterous.  Highly recommend the top area for a good casual meal.

FINALLY!! Had heard about Roti Chai from friends. We sat on the Main floor, the Street Food Corner, as suggested by our friends. The chaats are the best. Had chicken lollipop and Hakka chilli paneer which were fantastic and spicy. Also had tasty Railway Lamb Curry. The cherry on the cake was the Pistachio Kulfi - creamy, refreshing and yummy! If you are bored of the usual Indian food, this place can be a good change to your taste-buds.

Came back to back nights. Was seated in the dining room (had reservations). Great atmosphere, great food, great cocktails. The dining room allows babies but no high chairs or strollers. The casual dining area does allow strollers, but doesn't take reservations and you'll be waiting a bit if you show up during typical dining hours.

Came here to eat the street food, but due to it being busy we had to eat downstairs in the dining room. Food was nice, but I very much doubt the 16hour lamb was cooked for 16 hours.
Staff friendly, deserts good- but, I think the Mali cheesecake was just a dense cheesecake. Overall, very good value for money. 
Would eat here again, and I look forward to trying the street food.

My friend and I had dinner here (upstairs) on a Wednesday night. To start off - the ambience is a bit harsh (too many harsh lights etc. ). 
The food itself is quite good - we had the chicken and lamb curries as mains which were quite tasty. For starters we had pani puri and papdi chat - these were a bit disappointing. Didn't have the zing that chaat is supposed to have. 
All in all - decent Indian food that isn't too greasy and isn't too expensive.

There are two levels -- the Street Kitchen and Dining Room (downstairs) -- and each has a completely different menu so be sure to peruse them before deciding where you want to dine (by the way, they offer more than what the menus online indicate).  We decided on the more casual Street Kitchen.
There is a featured cocktail of the month, which was a Lychee Teapot Martini when we went in July.  We didn't order it, opting instead for:
* MAHA MOJITO - Made with ginger, mint and a rum blend, it was fine, but nothing of note. 
* KOVALAM BEACH - This one was a non-alcoholic cocktail made with ginger ale, lychee, guava and coconut.  It was pretty good, but the best one was... 
* COCONUT AND GUAVA BELLINI SHARBAT - Amazing!  Subtle, sweet and very refreshing.  We definitely had another.  It was easily the best drink we had during our entire trip to London!
There is also a seasonal special featured on the menu.  When we went they were showcasing the MANCHURIAN, a classic dish which they describe "was created by Nelson Wang in Mumbai in 1975 and involves a traditional Indian sauce made with ginger, garlic and chilis but finished with dark soy sauce rather than garam masala to create a unique flavour."  We ordered the CHICKEN MANCHURIAN.  It came with a bowl of steamed rice.  Very akin to adobo dishes I've had.  Good, but not the best thing we had.  The portions are on the small side on the street level, but are still shareable.  We also ordered:
* RAILWAY LAMB CURRY - Lamb and potatoes served with two chapatis.  Our server offered to substitute rice for the chapatis.  I declined but eventually ordered a side of rice anyhow to soak up some curry.  Yummy.  I preferred this one to the Manchurian.
* SAMOSAS - We chose the spicy pea and potato samosas.  You get two of them, plus chickpeas and dipping sauces.  A tad on the dry side but generally still a good choice.
yelp.com/user_local_phot…
* TARKA DHAL - Yellow lentils.  Delicious.  Must have rice or something to eat this with.
* CHICKEN LOLLIPOPS - This was our favorite dish!  You get five of these Moreish Keralan spiced chicken wings and a dipping sauce.  So good!  We almost (almost) ordered another, but as it was we had already over-ordered and this place is not cheap.
yelp.com/user_local_phot…
* Side of ROTI - Good by itself and topped with dhal, curry, etc.
yelp.com/user_local_phot…

Oh man literally my favorite Indian street food place in London (maybe even outside of India?!?). The food is so creative , and I love the decor and ambience of the restaurant. It's just absolutely perfect! And the spicy szichuan paneer is SO GOOD. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. I can't stop myself from going here again And again !!

It's a very good Indian restaurant, between Marble Arch and Bond Street (central line).
I tried it with 6 friends on January 2016 at dinner: excellent food and service.
Good modern atmosphere (not the traditional atmosphere of most of the restaurant for tourists).
Interesting price

Great food and service, i love this place. 
Tried lamb and chicken biryanis and they are so good. I think it's the best indian restaurant around the area.
The orange cake is delicious

Top notch Indian food in Mayfair area. This restaurant is kind of hidden on a back street but it is well known by locals. I have not had to make a reservation when going for lunch but am unsure about dinner. There is ample room upstairs and a huge downstairs area which they probably open up for overflow.
This is a child friendly spot with high chairs and pram parking. 
Now for the food... It's AMAZING! Everything I've ordered has been delicious. My husband and I went here when I was pregnant and ordered the hot wings to try and induce labour. While it didn't work, the hotness level was intense! We both have high tolerance for spice so this was prefect for us!

We were only in London for a week, and ended up eating here twice... once upstairs and once downstairs.
The concept is great... indian street food.
The decor is great... downstairs looks like the inside of a train, with the overhead compartments, etc.... and the upstairs reminds me of a market area.
Service was also great both times.
Downstairs is a more formal area, where you can make reservations.  Upstairs has a more cafe type feel to it, and does not accept reservations.
The menu is different in both spots.  Downstairs is more meals, and upstairs is more focused on snack items.  Both were great, but my preference was definitely the downstairs menu... but only marginally.  Food was excellent either way.
Downstairs, i think we ordered almost all of the appetizers.  My favorite was the shrimp, and also the kebabs.  Upstairs,  the best was the lamb burger, but we also had 10 different items.  the only thing i was disappointed in was the chicken wings.  Didn't have too much to it.... and seemed really mild and plain compared to the rest of the meal.
Love Indian food in London, and this place did not disappoint.

Best Indian food I've ever had! 
I'm from Germany but I'm going to fly to London only for this restaurant. 
Love it!
Great dinner for my wife and myself. Food was exceptional and staff was very attentive. Enjoyed our first evening visiting London.

Everything my mom and I ordered was absolutely amazing and from the moment we walked in every person working was beyond kind and helpful! Our server Veronika was not only attentive, but she was also a great guide towards what to order and was incredibly kind. For dinner we had the Hakka Chili Paneer (very spicy and flavorful,) vegetable samosas (more so mild but good,) chicken samosa chaat (WOW! So decadent and yummy,) the pulusu chicken (decadent,) and last but certainly not least the duck porridge. The duck porridge was by far the favorite item and despite being full I nearly devoured the whole bowl. The duck meat is minced and is absolutely fantastic. I am not usually a duck eater, but this porridge has won me over! Definitely give it a try. For dessert we finished off our wondrous meal with a mango kulfi and a pistachio kulfi, which was the perfect end to a fantastic meal.

I have been going to Roti Chai for a couple of years, but just getting around to writing this review. It is a very authentic indian experience, without the strong smells. The main floor is indian street food (recommended), while the basement is a bit more formal (although I have never eaten there). 
My suggestion is to try out a few items family style from the vibrant and diverse menu. Everything is worth trying (bun kebab, chicken lollipops, papri chaat, railway lamb and chicken pulusu) are all unique and tasty. If you like to try a fancy drink, I suggest trying their special martini. I forget the name but its pinkish, served cold in a kettle and very obvious when you look at the menu.
Amazing food! We stop by because of the Yelp reviews. Our last night in London and we got lucky with a table available downstairs. Everything was really good. Prawns appetizer TOP TOP !!!
Authentic street food. Fun vibe. You'll always see a lot of desis here which is a good sign! :)

Excellent food. I wish they had this in nyc!  We loved the appetizer and buns and the entrees were delic!  There's so many atypical dishes that u have to come back & try again. It's definitely worthwhile. We tried fire wings, chat, and chicken bits for appetizer. Also had the chicken bun & fish curry. All delic! The masala chai was authentic.  Yummy!

My wife and I walked into roti chai with a lot of high expectations because last year we were here, it was fantastic.
We were seated straightaway but it took sometime for a waiter to come and talk to us.
We ordered two masala chais. two pani puris and a fentiman's rose lemonade.
The pani puris were very good and felt very well on the palate. The pani had the correct amount of tang, sweetness and hotness to it.
The masala chai, however was a disappointment. it felt more like someone had boiled some hot water in a hurry with a tea bag and a drop of milk in it. I mean, an establishment called roti chai serves a deplorable chai and that's a bit ironic.
Nevertheless, 3 stars for a good pani puri, quick seating and decent customer service.

The hostess definitely saved the day for us.  We had to wait a very long time, and then after being seated nobody even came by for about 10 minutes.  She noticed and came to take our orders.  She's definitely the heroine of this establishment!
We had a bun chilli chicken which was amazing!  Full of flavor and just unlike anything we've ever had.  The chicken lollipops were decent too.  Ironically, the lamb curry was the worst part of the meal.  It was not very good.  Also I wouldn't spend the money on chai tea, it wasn't anything special. 
I'd definitely come again, but just for that sandwich!  It's going to haunt my dreams!

Outstanding Indian Food.
Delicious!!!
Recommended to my GF and I by the friends we were staying with...  We walked there, waited a few minutes, its casual...
Also, there are 02 restaurants here so don't get confused..  01 upstairs, 01 downstairs.
We went to the one upstairs!
Everythang was extremely yummy.
If/when back in the area I would def go again.
And definitely I recommend!!!

I have only eaten upstairs and not really sure if I would try the more upscale experience downstairs. If you like Indian food - you are going to find Chicken Tiki Masala here... this is Indian Street Food and so glorious! Come with friends and order a bunch of different things - you can't go wrong!

I have absolutely nothing to complain about. Very cool two story setup. Tapas upstairs, sit down restaurant situation downstairs. We opted for a sit down meal. Very prompt and friendly service. Varied menu options and an abundance of cocktail and wine options. The food was prepared very well. Incredibly delicious. The prices were more than reasonable. I will be returning whenever I'm in the area.

I've been to Roti Chai twice. Once for dinner downstairs with a friend and again this week upstairs for a big group dinner. I can now attest to Roti Chai's excellent food and recommend them for large parties too.
When I booked our table we were given the option of four menus, two for upstairs (street kitchen) and two for downstairs (dining room). I liked the casual feel of the street kitchen upstairs and preferred the menu there too.
Our party of ten started with the Hakka chilli paneer, tandoori chicken pao and the aloo papri chaat. 
Normally not a fan of paneer, this version was spicy (thanks to the fresh chillies), wonderful and nothing like any paneer I've sampled. I think I had thirds. 
The tandoori chicken pao might seem like some fusion creation but small bun sandwiches like these are served all over India (particularly in Mumbai where they're a ubiquitous street food). 
Whilst I thoroughly enjoyed them all, my favourite of the starters was the aloo papri chaat - a flavor explosion brought to you by chickpeas, yoghurt and chutney and something hard to find in my neck of the woods. 
Overall, I liked the starters slightly better than the mains during our dinner.
The standout among the entrees for me was the rustic Punjabi chicken curry. The new-to-the-menu duck leg was also a standout (especially its accompanying sauce).
 
For dessert almost all of us had the mango kulfi. (I mean, who doesn't love ice cream on a stick?)
 
Service was uneven at best (seems most of the staffers were on their first or second shifts) but that didn't but a damper on our meal at all. We got everything we ordered and it arrived in a mostly timely manner.
I'd definitely go back to Roti Chai with a big group.

First class Indian food - at least to my clumsy American palate - and clever spiced cocktails that tend toward the sweet side.  The duck is the clear winner here, but the starters were fine all the way around.
Service could use a refresher course, but I don't really care when the food is this good.

I went a little weak at the knees over a Roti Chai lamb bun at the Feast food fair earlier this year, so I was pretty excited to try out the actual restaurant. In case you were wondering, the name means the equivalent of Bread & Tea - but fear not, there's a lot more interesting stuff on the menu!
Step 1 - Find it: It's tucked away on a quiet street behind Bond Street tube, which reminded me I should never walk down Oxford St and ought to do more exploring around it. The ground level street kitchen of colourful Indian signs and posters is kept for walk-ins (or bookings of at least 6), so we'd booked a table for 4 in the more formal downstairs Dining Room to be on the safe side. When we arrived though there was plenty of room in the brightly buzzing Street Kitchen, and as we were after a more casual meal they were happy for us to move up (I got the feeling this happens a lot).
Step 2 - Drink: Not to be overlooked - it's an Indian restaurant that actually serves more beers than just Tiger/Cobra! Though I was having a girly girl moment and chose the most flowery thing on the menu with my friend - a rose and lychee martini for two, that arrived in a teapot with 2 baby glass tumblers. I found it a bit weak and there was a lot of ice in the pot, though the novelty cuteness factor carried it. The cartons of Frooti mango juice were also nice to see (just don't think about the mark-up). They do an ok job of the masala chai too, so end with that to aid digestion!
Step 3 - Eat: We went for the lots-of-smaller-dishes-to-share option, which is clearly the way to go here. Staples like the bhel puri and papri chaat are done well, and definitely try something in a bun (both meat and veg options got a thumbs up). Meanwhile the hakka chilli paneer was my tastebuds' fave, though the paneer-to-veg-ratio needs tweaking as I got a bowlful of spring onions back after making the mistake of offering it to others first. We ended up ordering a second round of our favourites, though it takes a while to flag down a server so do this as soon as you're running low. Overall have to say I wasn't wowed as there's a few things that could easily be better, but it was all flavoured well and quite authentic.
Step 4 - Repeat as required :)

I don't often go to Indian restaurants in London. Maybe it's because I prefer my mother's cooking. Or maybe it's because I'm almost always invariably disappointed. But not this time. After reading the reviews, decided to book this place for a friend's going away dinner.
First of all, the place looks amazing (see the pics that I posted). The ground floor has the street food menu, and has a really nice feel to it. I wouldn't say authentic, because emulating the streets of Kolkata is neigh impossible. However there is an attention to detail that makes you feel like you're travelling to another place, another destination. I didn't eat off the street food menu however, and headed straight downstairs to the main restaurant, which is tastefully decorated and a bit posher than the ground floor restaurant.
I was immediately surprised to see that they had Sam Adams Boston lager on the menu.... a first for me in anIndian restaurant. For once, I ordered that instead of the standard issue King Fisher beer.
For starters, we had the Gilafi seekh kebab, the Bengali crab and fish cake, the Chicken 65 (a variant on Indian indo-chinese food), and okra. It was all very good, although the favourites were clearly the fish cake and the chicken 65. The chicken was super crispy and perfectly cooked, and the hot sauce that it is served with is addictive! One thing that I immediately noticed was that they are not afraid to turn on the heat. The food here is definitely spicy! 
For the mains, we ordered the Saagwala gosht (lamb curry with spinach), the awadhi lamb rack, the pork belly, and for me, what was essentially the star of the evening, the Kerala duck roast. Let's talk about that duck for a second. I was very worried when I ordered it, because the menu speaks of a duck confit served with a Kerala tangy/spicy sauce. Now I know my duck confit. I make this stuff about once a month for my friends. I'm super picky about how crispy the skin should be, and how easily the meat must fall of the bone when served. Let me just say that they cooked that duck leg perfectly. And the garnish of carrots, the sauce was absolutely divine. Now this is a diwali special, and I don't know how long this dish will stay on the menu, but if you get the chance, do yourself a favour and order it.
The sides and garnishes were good, but not over the top amazing. We had the veg kulcha, and the roti, which was good, but hardened pretty quickly and was a bit too dry. The tarka dahl was good, and it was refreshing to see this served. It was spicy and had a decent amount of garlic in it!
We skipped dessert and ordered the Masala chai which was excellent. Not too sweet, and perfect balance of cardamom and sweetened condensed milk!
All in all, it came down to about 30£ per person. Won't break the bank, but don't expect a brick lane tab. This is Marylebone.
I have to agree with the other reviews about the service. It needs more attention to detail, follow up and diligence. But hey, at least it's not rude,just a bit lazy. The food makes up for this, which is why him giving them 4 stars.
I will definitely make plans to go back. Roti chai, together with Trishna (in the same vicinity), have fast become my favourite Indian restaurants in this city.

Really loved this place.  The paneer salad was amazing.  Shocking in a sense that it was sort of a fusion of Chinese inspiration with Indian...I could be totally wrong, but that was the take I got.  Highly recommend getting it!   The Chai was great too as was the service and the prices

Conveniently located for a quick business/shopping lunch just off Oxford street, this place offers good food and good value for your money.
I only tried the upstairs "eatery" for lunch, not the downstairs area, a proper restaurant where you can try more refined/elaborated stuff. 
Upstairs you can try some typical Indian street food and some traditional mains with a creative touch. I was delighted to find one of my favourite street snacks: pani puri, that's something you don't get in restaurants. It's some spheric, hollow crackers which you fill with a deliciously seasoned "water" and then eat in one gulp.
The other stuff I tried was very good too, even if the mains were a bit "rushed" perhaps, but after all this is a quick eatery not a 3 star restaurant.
I like the interior design, sleek yet cosy, with all those colourful Indian billboards.

OK yet forgettable Indian. Had a couple of similar fried chicken dishes, a tiny pani puri, a fine lamb curry, and a nicely presented patri chaat. The best part of the meal was my Beaverton Neck Oil IPA from a local London brewery. I can't see myself going back here, so three stars feels about right.

Very crazy and disorganized! 
The upstairs area is very informally set, and they have really cool decorations on the wall. The menus are laid out on the table when you're seated. 
If you're looking for butter chicken, this isn't the place to go! However if you're looking for a wide variety of Indian foods from across the continent then roti chai is a great place to check out. Their roti selection is pretty good - some naan, chipatis, and a couple of very good bean stuffed roti that I couldn't identify. The only paneer dish they had was ridiculously spicy in a good way - if you want spicy food it's definitely the dish to try. The trio of chutneys is also good, and their cucumber yogurt tastes cool without being too overwhelmingly yogurt-y. 
Main complaint is probably the organization. We went on a pretty busy night, and they just seemed like they were crazy understaffed. After the waiter took out order, three other waiters came and tried to take our order again. Additionally, people kept bringing things to our table that we hadn't ordered. We were also charged for still water when we ordered tap, and it took them 15 minutes to get us another order of roti. Service is quite slow if you consider that everything is premade. The staff just seemed like quite a mess, but they were gracious and quick when it came to correcting mistakes. 
Worth coming to! Pretty delicious food.

Tucked away behind the craziness of Oxford St is Roti Chai. There are two dining options which include the street food upstairs and the more formal dining room downstairs. We opted for the dining room this time around but would love to try the upstairs.
The pork belly and chicken tikka were the best items! Super flavorful and juicy, we loved every bite. We were a bit disappointed in the small naan portions but overall it was a great meal. Excellent and fast service as well!
Pork vinha d alhos
Tarka Dhal
Malai Chicken Tikka- marinated with cardomom and black pepper 
Butter Chicken- Darya Ganj style with a touch of fenugreek
Garlic Naan

We (Americans from Colorado) visited Roti Chai (Downstairs Dining Room) during a family trip to London (including three kids and grandparents). 
Monday night offered a fixed menu with 2-course (£19) and 3-course (£22) options. For a starter, the Malai Chicken Tikka was excellent. This is my favorite Indian dish, and they knocked it out of the park. We all agreed that we would have preferred this as our main course. There were four adults, so we shared our courses family style.
Roti Chai has two distinct dining areas, each with its own menu. The "Street Kitchen" is on the ground floor (sometimes referred to as "upstairs") and offers items such as Chicken Lollipops and Samosas, which were not available in the Downstairs Dining Room. I actually like concept, as it provides yet another reason to come back.
Also, we chose this restaurant, in part because some reviews indicated this was a good place for kids. This might be true for the Street Kitchen. However, if you have kids and are eating Downstairs: It might be worth instructing the server to bring out all of your courses at once. There was some confusion about when we were finished with our first course, and this needlessly added at least half an hour to our dining time (which can be tenuous with a five year old).
Overall, the Best Indian Food that we have ever had. The Chicken Tikka was amazing (try to get it as your main course).

Excellent food, we ordered a variety of dishes all of which were received with great satisfaction .  Portions slightly on the small size but not humbling small.  Cannot wait to try this one again.
Thank YELP for being spot on with 4.5 stars.
Good place which is perfect for dates or for larger groups - the bar had a great selection of drinks (reasonably priced) and the food was tasty.

I had a good experience at this restaurant. It had a nice atmosphere and the food was good. They ran out of the beer I wanted to try and that was a small disappointment. The food was good but the menu was small. My Indian dish was a chicken curry. There was too much ginger in it and it made for a spicy but not so tasty combination.  Overall it was good and i would probably go back.

Had a great meal here. I definitely recommend the "Chicken lollipops", which were basically crispy deep fried chicken legs. Everything else was top notch too - you'll probably want to order a number of small dishes and eat family style. After all, sharing is caring. Certainly a good place for lunch, as it was busy but not too crazy. Probably worth booking ahead though.

Food is okay. The hostess needs to be a lot more organized... She kept us waiting for almost 30 minutes, and when I saw that a table had been kept open I finally inquired about it (thinking there's no way she would keep us waiting when that table is ours). As a matter of fact, she HAD forgotten about us! Space is chill and cool though.

Great in theory...poor in practice!
I should have known that something was wrong when I saw that not a single patron, server or chef was Indian. While the menu screams of the promise delivered by authentic Indian street food delights, the reality is that you end up with deep fried chicken and bland, watered down colored sauces masquerading as spices.
What is really shocking is that people pay so much money to stomach not just the poor excuse for food but the pollution and congestion around Oxford street as well.
My advice, find the place the local Indian people frequent to find real Indian food. And avoid this tourist trap like the plague!

Indian Street food with lovely decor throughout. 
Food was good, wish I knew what to order. I had a rice dish that was a bit unexpected,  Felt a bit like a fish out of water with the cuisine but we did the best we could. 
I would definitely try this again for a better pov. 
Service could use some work. I sat around for a total of about 40 min waiting for service to bring menus, to order drinks, to order and a long time for the check.

Great dining experience! Had dinner around 8:30 at the bottom level (there are separate menus for the two levels; the top level is more street food/tapas-like and crowded in terms of seatings, with a slighter friendlier range of prices; the bottom level has that dimmer lighting, nice restaurant atmosphere). Was taken away by the butter chicken and the house special lamb! Flavorful seasoning and extremely tender meat. Would actually prefer to eat here with friends compared to Punjab!

What can I say guys... Yelp did not disappoint with this place. It's basically an Indian tapas place so sharing is a must for the best experience. I dined at both the upstairs (street-style) and downstairs (restaurant) two days in a row. That's saying something...
I guess I'll just list what I enjoyed from both since my group tried a whole ton of stuff.
Street Kitchen (upstairs)--
Hakka Chilli Paneer - Mmmm... fantastic and comes with a lot of veggies.
Parsi Chicken Farcha - Pieces of breaded chicken with a wonderful dipping sauce.
Manchurian Chicken - Get this!!
Hot Wings - Damn I forget the exact name, but I know it started with an 'A', anyways, you need to try them, because they're spicy and amazing!
**Tried the Chicken Lollipops & thought they were whatever... nothing special there.
Dining Room (downstairs)--
Szechuan Chilli Paneer - on skewers and are delicious!
Prawn Curry - Forget the name, but this was my favorite menu item! The sauce is to die for!
Chicken 65 - Very similar to the Parsi Chicken Farcha upstairs
Pork Ribs - not bad, a little dry for my taste because I like ribs saucy.
Pork Belly - I'm not a huge fan but my friends really liked it.
**Gilafi Seekh Kebab - if you like lamb, you might like this. I do not.
Roti Chai has really good food and service isn't half bad either. Get the Chai Tea! I couldn't get enough of it. Unfortunately, it only comes by the glass. If you can, try both the upstairs and the downstairs, you can't go wrong either way!

I had heard about Roti Chai through a friend of mine who had nothing but rave reviews for the restaurant. Many months later, I finally get the chance to try it... And am completely and totally underwhelmed.
When I got there, I had no idea there was an option of upstairs vs downstairs dining, and that the menus would be different depending on where you were seated. It was only after placing my order for banana chips and lamb curry did I find out about the dining room, where it seems there is a more extensive menu - and perhaps more satisfying dishes because I, personally, did not enjoy my dinner.
It was ok, and nothing more. Neither of the dishes I ordered were anything to write home about, and the service - while attentive - lacked personability (as if my waiter was only there in body, going through the motions). 
I may give this place another chance, based solely on the rave reviews it's getting for its dining room menu... but Im certainly in no rush to go back anytime soon.

Really great Indian street food concept. I would say that the food is better than Dish00m although the service is a bit slow and the restaurant is a bit cramped. I love the Indian movie posters and paraperhanlia/memerobilia dressed in garish colors. Throw-back to the dhaba restaurants that dot the highways in India.

I have been to this restaurant several times, one of the best restaurants near the Oxford Street.
Railway lamb curry deserves a trt

We visited Roti Chai because we were starving after battling the Boxing Day crowds, it was raining, and we needed a place near Selfridges. This place fit the bill.
The Ambiance: This restaurant is cute...reminiscent of modern Indian.  The place is spotless and lively.
The Food: My absolute favorite thing was the Fruit Chaat. Covered in Tamarind chutney, this was top notch (and I know my fruit chaat). We also had Idli Sambar (just okay) and my husband had a chicken dish. Can't remember the name of it but he wasn't too thrilled with the chicken quality. The Naan was also amazing...he plowed through 5 pieces.
The Service: Super busy place and overworked servers. They are nice and they do try but I think Roti Chai could stand to hire a few more people.
The Prices: Decent. Especially for the area.
The Bottom Line: I might come back on another trip...the fruit chaat is calling my name.
I would give this place 0 stars if possible. The food was subpar and the service was terrible. Not an authentic experience.

Why I ended up at Roti Chai is the perfect example of why I love Yelp. After a 5 hours shopping marathon around Oxford Street I was really hungry. I didnt know any restaurants in the area, I was loaded with shopping bags and I needed food. Now. So I checked Yelp for restaurants in that area and Roti Chai popped up amongst some others. The rating looked really good so I took a quick look at the reviews. Turns out, one of my friends just ate here a couple of weeks ago and left fabulous 5 stars for the place. Done deal, thats where Im going, I thought.
And it was a great decision. Staff was really friendly, the food came fast and steaming hot and made my belly a happy camper! I went for the Hakka chilli paneer (pretty hot!) and another dish, but I cant think of the name. Both choices were great and just what I was craving. I would definitely recommend this place. Upstairs is the "street dining area" (more for a quick meal and cheaper prices) downstairs you have a different menu and more of a restaurant feeling. Go check it out!

Really great Indian food that was tasty and very filling! We ate in the Street Kitchen area and the atmosphere was really relaxed.
We opted for the chicken lollipop and Chilli Paneer. The sauce for the lollypops was nice and refreshing and the chilli paneer was super delicious! It was really refreshing and spicy at the same time and the paneer tasted super fresh.
For mains we got the fish curry and the pulusu curry. The fish curry was nice, a little bland though. The pulusu curry was delicious! Really nice flavours. We also ordered a side of aloo gobi which set the meal off perfectly.
Tasty food, nice people, good atmosphere... will defo be back!

Doing some business in London and stopped in with a colleague.  It's a place that gives you two very different dining options.  Street food upstairs in the kitchen or a more traditional dinning room below.  After a long day of walking around the city we opted for the quieter options downstairs.
My first take on the menu is here is a place butting their best foot forward with 7 or 8 small plates and the same number of larger dishes.  As for the openers, the dumplings with chili sauce were great.  Fresh chillies with just enough bite and a rich smokey flavor.  On the large dish side was a chicken dish in a butter sauce.  The chicken was tender, flavorful and slow cooked.  The butter sauce would make even my mother's food taste good (sorry mom).
The menu varies and I wish we had something like this in the states close to me.  A great take.

Food is extremely tasty. Ordered the butter chicken, tarka daahl,  palak paneer, and gosht. The lamb was amazing, it was tender and flavorful. The raita was good although portions were slightly small. Restaurant is aesthetically appealing and lively. Would've liked service to be better. None the less, would return.
We had a wonderful dinner. Food was great and service was very nice. There's no take away so order accordingly.
Food was very good but service was lacking. The waiter brought the food but didnt check back for a long time.  The restaurant was soooo noisy...not their fault. Overall good restaurant.
Authentic Indian food served in an inviting atmosphere.  Try the daily specials or simply ask your server for advise, they're very knowledgeable and friendly.

I was in London for a two week business trip and made it my quest to target the highest rated Indian restaurants near SoHo and ended up at Roti on the last night.  This place is very popular and seems to have crowds arrive in waves, but I walked in after 9:30 pm.
 I anticipate this will change as the season warms up and i may be completely wrong on a weekend.  You can make a meal of the appetizers by sampling through each of them and for main i tried the Saagwala gosht ( lamb) and Koliwada fish.  This will be on my todo when I return to UK.

Yelp has done me right again: this place was awesome!  Went for lunch which was the street kitchen menu (the dining room is closed during the day).  It was a little empty at 12:30pm but we were super hungry so we settled in.  Not 20 minutes later, the place was full of locals (mostly business lunches, it looked like) who knew this was some good food!
I had aloo gobi which was deliciously spicy. I had to order the roti (bread) afterwards to dampen the spice but in a great way! My friends loved their meals as well (one was fried chicken bites with a lovely sauce, another had chickpeas and chai tea). 
Big recommendation!

Great Indian in London! 
Tasty food, perfect portions and superb service! 
Don't miss chicken samosas, spicy cashews, and there's a rice plate with vegetables and raita that was spectacular!
Okay food; tried chicken, lamb and aloo gobi; appetizer section was larger than entrees; seems like a casual appetizer place more than a serious food place.

The Roti Chai was beyond our expectations, which were very high based on the Yelp reviews. Every dish we had was well spiced, but not overwhelming and absolutely delicious. We have never had such an amazing Indian meal.
We ate in the downstairs section (restaurant), which was very pleasant, full of folks but it did not feel crowded.  The menu will work for vegetarians as well as meat/fish folks like us. 
Service was excellent - prompt, polite, and attentive. Th chai tea that my wife ordered at meal's end was simply too good!  Put any negative reviews you might occasionally read here and trust what I'm telling. You will NOT be disappointed.

My friends love this place. I'm not so sure. The food is very very good but it isn't the best in London. The service is good for small groups. I didn't have perfect service with a large group - which is super hard to do - but would recommend. Defo in the top 20 Indians in London, just not my favourite.

We happen to visit this Indian fusion when another restaurant didn't serve lunch nearby, and we were happy we did.  Authentic Indian chai tea, amazing Chicken Samosa Chaat with yogurt topping was my favorite. The others ordered the Parsi Chicken Farcha (chicken masala) that resembles chicken nuggets with chutney sauce that was ordered again and again by the younglings.  We also tried the Pulusu chicken and Manchurian chicken, but was so so.

I was around Edgware road and was looking for something to eat with no idea what to choose. Surrounded by Lebanese Shisha restaurants, I was looking for absolutely anything else. Step in Yelp Nearby and after a short search (this place is hidden!) I was sure this place was gonna be good based on the street menu and the wonderfully inviting warmly lit close quarters street dining experience on the ground floor. 
There are two menus here, and it appeared at least to me that most people were here for the street menu. You have amazing starters, from potato chips with yoghurt and pomegranates, chicken lollipops with cool mint yoghurt sauce and even better mains like Railway Lamb and Pulusu Chicken you'll leave here extremely stuffed, full and happy. It's not often I leave Indian restaurants happy with the quality of each and every dish, or the quality of the cooking or meat choices, but everything here was A quality. The dishes are all perfect for sharing, but the Pulusu chicken which I ordered was amazingly soft and tender and very good quality.
In all, there were 3 of us, we ordered 3 drinks, starters, mains and desserts. The final bill came to £21 per head incl. tax. Quality food, atmosphere, great staff (apart them forgetting my request for water 3 times and delivering this to other tables nearby). This is my fave indian restaurant in London and hopefully it can remain on the down-low for some time before you'll need a reservation to eat here.
There is a dining menu too downstairs which I may try some time too, but that didn't seem as popular.

During the visit in London, I was looking for a trendy spot to dine in because that's what I love to do when I travel: go to places I can't back home. Being in SF definitely has its perks and standards. So when I stumbled upon this place with Timeout, I was excited. 
I knew I was going to enjoy my time here even though the pub next door was packed with people on the sidewalk beer in hand having a good time. 
We sat in the street level part of the restaurant which served "street food"
We ordered a fish curry, lamb curry, and chicken curry. Each curry came with it's own starch; rice or bread. The portions are perfect there but being from America we were used to eating a little bit more so I ordered a side of Roti. I was surprised that 3 pieces cut in half came in a basket and even more surprised when they were different kinds! 
Ambiance was wonderful there was a lot to look at and take in.

Roti Chai is one of those places that make me thankful I'm a Yelper. I've seen them at Yelp events and tried a couple dishes from them which were consistently good, so when I was in the area I jumped on the opportunity to go.
It was a Friday night so it was packed but since it was only 2 of us we got a seat in around 10 minutes. The ground floor is more of a tapas/street food style restaurant and the downstairs is more classic Indian fare. From what it sounds like the street food is much busier, and for good reason.
We decided to get a bunch of plates and bread to share, and everything we ate was delicious. I'd particularly recommend the bhel puri (one of my favourites) and the aloo gobi with roti. All the dishes were of a nice size especially for the price, about on par with a reasonably priced Spanish tapas restaurant, maybe a bit less even. We also had their special Pimms which had rose lemonade in it and was really tasty.
Also of note, they have a nice amount of vegetarian options, so go crazy, veggies!
An interesting little eatery with cheerful staff and a colourful decor. Great to pop in after work and grab a quick meal, not great for groups or a long evening meal.

My husband and I were very much looking forward to having Indian food in London.  Our first place was Roti Chai downstairs, the more formal dining area downstairs.  
We shared the paneer and fish and crab cakes appetizers.  He got butter chicken and I got the spinach curry lamb.  Each got different kinds of bread.
Our take is that food was good but quite pricey (60 British pounds).  We are from New York and probably have had better Indian for less money.  But hey, that's what happened when you're on vacation and it was Boxing Day when only a few restaurants were open.  So it was a decent experience all in all.

Came here for dinner for a special occasion (My wife's birthday). So was a little bit surprised to see the street kitchen atmosphere upstairs, More Wahaca than Cinnamon Club.. I was pretty sure the website photos were different. Oh dear I think... this is not the type of place we were dressed for or what we were really expecting. Fortunately we were swiftly led downstairs to the much more upmarket dining room - Cue the Giant sigh of relief.. 
Had a great meal here. We tried a number of dishes, the Bengali Crab Fishcakes, a Paneer starter, Butter Chicken, Kozikode Prawns, Palak Paneer, and some lovely Orange and Cumin Tandoori Roti. 
Overall the food was very good, a little on the spicy side, but lovely all the same. Our Saffronic Gin and Tonics were also excellent. 
As it was my wife's birthday I was happy to see staff remembered my request for a candle lit cake at the end of our meal (I had mentioned this when I booked through Open table). This was the Cardamom and Chocolate Tart, very nice, but added to the bill all the same..
Super meal... no complaints..

Best Indian food I have ever had, including my dear Indian friends that have cooked traditional Indian food for me. The spices were perfect, not too overpowering but just enough kick to get your taste buds excited. We had a tandoori chicken starter, Zoroastrian butternut chicken dish and also a chicken tikka with rice and garlic naan - all of which were incredible. Service was decent, a bit slow but the staff was very pleasant so we didn't mind. 
I might try to convince my husband to return again before we head back to the states.

Roti Chai. Yes. Best indian street food I have tried hands down!
I'm not the most adventurous when it comes to food, so I stuck to what I know and had a chicken curry and rice with some plain naan bread. It was beautiful and filled with flavour, spices and magic? Yes, definitely magic.  Also the Paneer is particularly appetizing.
Nice environment, great location just off Oxford street so convenient for a quick shopping or working lunch.

Searching for Indian restaurants near our Marble Arch area hotel, this looked like the safest bet. We got there and were encouraged to eat at the proper restaurant downstairs. The space is very nice but the staff did feel very standoffish. While there were seats open throughout, we were seated by the kitchen. 
The food was very good but since we were in the mood for traditional Indian fare, the fusion elements were lost on us. It's also on the expensive side and for the price I regretted not going to La Porte des Indes a few blocks away.

Just what I was looking for on a cold London night-some delicious Indian food. It was interesting in terms of flavors but if spice is a key ingredient then a must is a side of the chopped chilies. This was provided for heat to taste. I am a sucker for spice with a burn but the subtle flavors were inherent in the cooking style. I dined in the restaurant vs the street food that was offered as a tapas type food fare upstairs. Very enjoyable and I recommend asking the knowledgeable staff for a tour of the offerings. Go for it!

Business is good and all that, but the floor manager's got a cocky attitude and basically told me "you will get your table when your name is called" when I asked him politely about the wait time. Left immediately without looking back.

Food Hunting goes to Roti Chai
After a very long week at work and university all we could think about is when we are going to get our next bite of scrumptious gol gappes and bhel puri.
Determine to try a new restaurant we hunted down Roti Chai, which we now call "Our little box of Indian heaven". It's located behind Selfridges making it easy to access and very convenient.
Roti Chai has two floors; the ground floor is called "The Indian Kitchen" where you get all the yummy Indian street food, set in a very colourful quirky yet incredibly retro Indian décor and downstairs is more of a sophisticated "Dinning Room" with dim lights with beautiful table arrangements.
check out out the full review on our page
facebook.com/permalink.p…

Wow!
Roti Chai, you impressed a Silicon Valley girl! 
I thought Silicon Valley had the best Indian restaurants around but Roti Chai surpassed my expectation!
This restaurant looks way more sophisticated than our normal Indian restaurants in California (after all this is Central London), so at first I was skeptical. Is this one of those over-priced places with lame food?
No! The food was full of flavor and the service was superb! The price was reasonable also!
I liked this restaurant so much I even bought their logo T-shirt!
Best Indian food in London, IMHO. Indian Street food, so something different than you are used to. Very, very good! Moderately priced as well.
Yelp shows 11 pm close we showed up at 10:30 and were rudely turned away. Awesome customer service !

I can't remember how many times I've walked past this place and thought "I should eat there one day!"..... Today was indeed that day!
The restaurant is divided into street food upstairs and more traditional downstairs. Both were busy and either choice was a 10 minute wait. We opted to go down stairs where we were politely greeted and directed to a comfortable waiting area.
Annoyingly a couple who came in after us were seated first, but upon realising their mistake we were quickly seated in a place set for 4 (we were a couple) in a bit of a hurry we immediately made our order and pleasingly it turned up quickly.
The food was ok, portions were just right. My partner always has the same thing in Indian restaurants, butter chicken. Comparatively, it was very good!! I went for a chicken dhansak, this tipped my scale at "average" the accompanying bread were all "average" also. 
To summarise,  the place is welcoming with friendly staff. The food is good but as there price point is at the higher end of what you would want to pay for the cuisine I would want a bit more. If like me you've passed it and thought you should try it..... Give it a go. (Unless your heading towards covent garden, then go to dishoom.... The place this is aspiring to be like)

The place is nice and although it's noisy it didn't matter for me. I liked the food which mattered most for me. Chicken lollipops and chicken curry with naans were my orders and they were perfect. The food is not too spicy.

This place is a bit off the beaten path but it is totally worth trying to get there!
There is an upstairs and downstairs at this restaurant. The upstairs is geared towards street food and smaller dishes while downstairs is a bit more formal and focuses on big mains.  My friends and I stayed upstairs and we ordered really delicious dishes.
For street food, my favourite pick is the bhel!  The puffed rice. Seriously so good!  For my main I got a fish curry.
The food was great but I knocked a star off my review because I did not find service to be spectacular.  The waiters seems a bit disorganised and it didn't seem like we had 1 person assigned to take care of us, which can be frustrating because as a patron you don't know who to speak to.  Our food order was forgotten and also we ran out of water for our table twice.
I would come back to try the lower floor's mains, but I hope they figure out a more efficient way of servicing tables,

Horrible service! Got seated and waiter took our order, but we waited a good 20-30 min without getting any drinks or food. Tables seated after us were getting their food before us. When asking manager what happened, he was very rude and dismissive, asking us to leave if we were unhappy with the service! We left without getting our food or drinks, and every other dining experience here in London has been great up till now. Would not recommend this restaurant nor will I ever return. Good riddance!
This place was great! Loved the layout as well as the food. Great price with helpful and friendly staff. Would define you come back.

Was hoping to get an iced chai and found out it's only served hot (iced comes with ice cream??) Ended up getting the tarka dal and a beer. It was delicious, perfect level of spice and very quick service. I'll go for the hot chai after all...watery but has a very aromatic flavor. Very good spices.

This place had great food, although there were not many vegetarian options for an Indian place. Excellent fish curry, rich in flavor, and very spicy. Roti was done well as well. 
Loved the mango ice cream! So rich and delicious.

This is what I came to London for! To try real tasty Indian street food, and dishes I have never had before. I loved the casual "Street Indian" upstairs area. Seated next to me, were a bunch of Indian tweens who had designer handbags worth thousands, and other families with a lot of money. So you know this place had to have good Indian food. We got a variety of dishes, the starters I was not too impressed about. I would not get the chaats or the lollipop chicken, the chaats were too organized, and the lollipop chicken was just meh. Chaat salad is messy and crushed up, the way it's meant to be eaten, whereas here it's organized into a neat little bite. Fortunately, the main dishes were much better. The Pulusi chicken was really flavorful and packed a good punch, it tasted great over rice. The ground duck dish was really different, but also tasty. I've never had duck in an Indian dish before, but I had to get something I have never seen at home, and glad I did. The ground duck didn't really taste like duck, but nevertheless the spices and and the meat were delicious over rice. I wish Roti Chai was in DC, I would definitely go there again if I was in London.

Do  not go if you expect good service. Never consider if you like great service. This is my first trip to London and based on yelp reviews, I decided to go there. I was told that there is 30 min wait. I said ok. But the guy at the front desk was least interested in taking down my name so that he can put me on the queue. Then I asked him about downstairs area. That's when he told me that there is no wait downstirs. So I went downstairs. There my family and I were seated immediately. But no one showed up to take the order. Or wasn't even offered water until I asked 4 times. 
I was getting flustered so I asked the manager to see if he can help provide better experience. But still no one offered to fill up water or came to check if I need seconds. 
Lastly no one showed up to collect the credit card for bill payment.
But they were quick to charge 12% tip/service charge.
How does this place get so much raving reviews.  Or Does the quality of service depends on skin color?
Fabulous -- flavorful, interesting food, traditional but with a modern twist, and drawing more widely in Indian regional and street food than your usual places. We will definitely be back!

The Veg Samosas are delicate and perfection-- the well orchestrated blend of spices that make me actually do back flips. Alas.. wayyy to stuffed on Aloo Gobi (tender and delectable) and Roti (served piping hot) to move from my "sprawled out on the bench" position. I've never been to India but I bet this is better than your grandmas dishes!
Such a great place!! I ate at their street food ground level place. Such interesting, delicious food!!

I've eaten here twice, once upstairs in the more casual "street kitchen" and once downstairs in their formal dining room. The first time I was with a friend visiting from the US, and the waitstaff gamely allowed her to order, for herself, an entire 500 ml carafe of wine--hey, we don't use metric in America, so sue us! I had a very tasty, but not too strong, ginger mojito. We split an order of samosas that were exemplary of the form--definitely get them! She had Hakka chicken Manchurian and I had the lamb curry with potatoes and roti. I enjoyed her Manchurian more than I enjoyed the lamb, but I think maybe I'm just not a huge fan of lamb. It was definitely tasty, but the roti to gravy proportions were off and I would have appreciated more bread to sop everything up.
The second time, I ate downstairs with visiting family. You MUST get the shrimp curry if they have it. It is incredible. We also split the chicken 65, the seekh kebab, a fish curry, and the butter chicken, which were all very good. That was more than enough for a family of four, and I would recommend a family-style setup if you have enough people, so you can try everything. My mother and I also split a pretty epic bread pudding, and my brother loved his malai kulfi.
Roti Chai is very close to the Marble Arch tube station, but it can be hard to find for new visitors or foreign tourists. It's on a side
street that's pretty out of the way across from the Thistle hotel. Just keep looking and you will find it!

Wanting some good Indian food while visiting London, I found Roti Chai via Yelp (where else?) while doing some research after biking through Hyde Park.  Located right off of Oxford Circle, close to the Marble Arch, it was easily accessible via metro.  When we ate a late lunch it was not crowded at all.
We opted for the street menu and ordered the Railway Lamb Curry and the Bun Tikki with a Naan sampler.  The portions are small, which would have been an issue if we were hungrier, but we were fine with what we got.  If we were doing dinner perhaps we'd have ordered more dishes.
Lamb Curry was "off the chain".  We searched for it everywhere afterwards.  Roti Chai is a nice option if you're tired of the touristy fish & chips!

For what it is, it is exceptionally good, so I gave it five stars. There are, as the other reviewers note, two restaurants: a formal dining room downstairs and a more bustling street food place upstairs. We reserved downstairs, but when we saw the upstairs we opted to eat there instead. Food was delicious. Everything was fresh and hot. We had samosas to start. I've had some bad samosas in my life (rancid oil, greasy, heavy)--these were terrific: hot, tasty, fresh and, for samosas, light. We had a special chicken and lamb curry for our mains. Both fabulous. They came with rice and bread, which was nice, since some Indian restaurants tend to upsell the sides. 
Service was good and the crowd enthusiastic.
A very nice, informal experience. I'll definitely be back.

My family and I ate at the lower level restaurant. I personally really enjoyed the curried potatoes, pork belly and butter chicken. The spicing was perfectly intense. However my Indian food novice mother found the butter chicken too spicy. If you have really sensitive taste buds this may not be the restaurant for you. 
The service was excellent when we started our meal, which was early by British standards, however it got substantially worse as the place filled up. That's the only reason it didn't get 5 stars from me.
Charming restaurant and delicious food, although super pricey. But hey, this is London. :) I loveddddd the papri chaat and the biryani! It was beautifully presented and cooked perfectly. Yum!
Good seevice, friendly waiters and very delicious indian food! Most meals are a bit spicy but very delicious. If you go there as a group I recommend to order some different starters to share!

Am on a street in  Bangalore? No!  Am I riding an elephant in Mumbai? No!  I'm right here is London, home away from home for Indian Food.  Roti Chai is a indian restraunt in the heart of London specializing in regional street food in their bar area, and more sophisticated regional dishes in their downstairs main dinning room.  
All I can really say is fresh fresh Yum.  Spicy with a great kicking heat, the appetizers were only a teaser for the main courses.  (apply London accent ) Lovely Samosas, Lovely Chat Papri and Lovely Paneer... just all around Lovely ! (end London accent)
This was serious authentic and fresh indian food from selection around India.  I had the indian beer too.  Roti is located next to a pub, so go get drunk then have a curry just like the Brits do!

When I arrived in London, I was craving Indian food.  I found Roti Chai on yelp, and had a wonderful dinner there.  There's the downstairs dining room, which is a bit fancier, than the upstairs room which is more focused on street food.  I ate at both & had great experiences in each.  Downstairs, I had the chicken tikka and it was delicious.  I would definitely go back the next time I'm in London.
Little bit of a wait, but once I sat down the food was served quickly. Yummy and modern take on classic Indian dishes. I had the palak papri chaat. So good.

Second time I've come here and I absolutely love it. Good service, fast, great flavors, good proportions, price ok, The concept of tapas/Indian Food and the interieur are great, can't say much except I'm a fan!!
We tried the chicken lollipops, bhel puri, chana, and pulusu chicken upstairs. The food was decent; nothing special. Great service.

I ordered a chicken curry with rice which was great, we also ordered an assortment of breads, and they were fantastic. My only criticism was that the serve of curry was quite small. 
There was a 12.5% service charge which was a bit of a surprise when we received the bill. 
I recommend this restaurant.

Delicious! We sat upstairs in the "street food" diner of the restaurant ---
We had:
-chicken loli-pops
-hakka chili paneer
-pea & potato samosas
-roti with yogurt & chutneys
-pulusu chicken
& of course a glass of chai
All were absolutely delicious & full of flavor. My favorite was the hakka chili paneer ---- but everything had terrific flavor - my taste buds are slightly on fire and completely satisfied. YUM!
Will definitely return :-)

Amazing butter chicken. Very aromatic and meat was very soft. Naan bread - delicious! That's a must whenever you come there. Loved it. Good selection of drinks/cocktails. Place itself is nicely arranged so very pleasant for spending time with friends and enjoying the food. Definitely worth recommendation.

Love this place, I have even had cravings for this specific place and trekked up to this venue from afar!
Firstly, beware that upstairs and downstairs are two different restaurants for all practical purposes and the downstairs is a fancier, pricier option which I have not tried out yet. Upstairs is a more casual dining spot (street style might be a stretch though) that attracts yuppies and busy city-folk. 
Their ambience feels less like a curry house and more a modern, clean place with sophisticated crowds and their menu is short and crisp, a far cry from the menu booklets at most Indian places. Some of their dishes on their menu are distinctive to this restaurant and must not be missed. The Hakka Chilli Paneer, as every review seems to mention, is a must-order for its distinctive kick that settles in well after the first few bites. Would also highly recommend the Idli Sambar (for those with a milder palate) and the Railway Lamb Curry (for a spicier mix). Beware that portion sizes are on the smaller end and this is not the cheapest of Indian food spots.
Full disclosure: I might be a tad biased in my opinions because the founder is an alum of my business school :) But the degree is bias is not so much that you need discount the views too much ;)
I prefer the downstairs menu.  This is one of my favorite restaurants in the world. Their chicken tikka is one of the best dishes I've ever had.
Ate downstairs. Food was very delicious but fairly small portions compared to the prices

We went there for dinner during a working day but we had to make a reservation.
The room upstairs look more like a fast food kind of place but the room downstairs is a real restaurant.
The food was really good and the service was good. I would only regret the very busy and noisy room.

I come to Roti Chai pretty often with my parents and it hasn't let me down yet.  I'll admit that when I initially heard about the place, I got very excited followed immediately by disappointment as it was not, in fact, a Roti Canai restaurant.  However, the food here is consistently good.  The restaurant is split into two - the upstairs section which is more geared towards Street Food, and downstairs which has slightly grander dishes (in both construction and price).
Upstairs:  came here again last night, had the Bhel Puri (mixture of crunchy puffed rice with a tamarind sauce and other goodies) and chicken lollipops for starter.  The bhel's not bad, but I prefer the one at Horn Ok Please - this one's a little sweet and misses the mix of textures that I've had in other ones.  The chicken lollipops are excellent though, they're really moreish and nicely spiced on the outside.  For mains, we had the Railway Lamb curry, pulusu chicken curry, idli sambar (vegetables and lentil curry with rice cakes) and rotis.  All the curries are good - my favourite was the pulusu chicken which had a nicely rounded spice combination; I do like that the curries aren't overly oily and I'm yet to have something here that I could define as bland or unbalanced.  The curries aren't huge by any means so you may have to order 3 between two (depending on gluttonous tendencies).  The rice/rotis are likewise smaller than you'd expect; however, I do really like the breads here - they're not greasy and they're just right (not too dry or soggy).  We had a lot of food between three here yesterday and it was still less than £20 a person.
Downstairs:  been here 3 or 4 times.  I do like the food here, but I also feel that the value for money isn't as good as upstairs.  Some of the more 'serious' curries cost in the £15-£20 range and I've not had anything that's really blown me away.  That said, I really like the orange peel naan that they do down here.  That's something pretty nice and refreshing.
Definitely a place to check out - despite its location, you can usually get a place here without too much trouble (although to be fair I mostly come here after 9pm, so don't take my word for it).  The food here is consistently decent and you won't be wanting for flavour.  It's also totally legit if you just go in and order 4 plates of chicken lollipops.  That would be wholly acceptable in my eyes.

I eat in this restaurant for the first time last week and it was a  very good surprise.
When I'm in London, I always eat on an indian restaurant and I found this one with the goog comments on Yelp.
The food is nice, the presentation is great and the taste is like a true indian street food.
The waiters are friendly and helpfull.
I recommend this place and hope to see a Roti chai in Brussels :)

Im obsessed with this place. I'm heartbroken i don't live in London. But when i do visit, it's my first stop after dropping my bags at the hotel. Which happens to be right across the street! 
They serve street-style indian food. Dishes you will not find at any regular Indian restaurant. They're all incredibly delish. 
I could eat the Hakka chilli paneer e v e r y d a y! I went there three days in a row on my last trip to London. Upon leaving the waiters would shout: "See you tomorrow!"
p.s. I have an addictive personality but also really good taste.

A Seattlite, a San Diegan, a Londoner and a mutt Singaporean walk into a yuppie Indian restaurant and order two samosas, prapi chaat, Manchurian chicken, aloo gobi, and Railway lamb curry...
The Seattlite enjoyed the aloo gobi, the San Diegan loved the chicken samosa, the Londoner loved the lamb curry and the Singaporean felt everything was decently done - save the samosas and the Manchurian chicken. 
So, what is the moral of the story? 
Don't bring the Singaporean to a yuppie Indian restaurant, because while it was all very tasty, there was too much anise / cardamom in the vegetarian samosas, the wheat flour chapati that was served with the lamb curry was too chewy and the Manchurian chicken completely out of place. 
Other than that, the lamb curry was tender, and the aloo gobi delightful. Bit pricey, but this is south Marylebone, so I can understand the reasons behind it...
