The omakase was amazing (8 or 9 courses of deliciousness, I stopped counting after 4 courses).  The fish was sublime and fresh.  A couple of courses were ordinary (miso soup, sushi) but the rest of the courses more than made up for this, very creative and different.
Mojito's are very good (I had Pear & cinnamon).
Tip- do not turn up late if you're ordering the omakase.  They are heavily booked and hence very strict with their two hour seatings.  Due to a mix-up I was 25 minutes late and the last few courses felt a little rushed.

4 stars for food, 3 starts for service & ambience. 
They offered 2 Tasting Menus: One traditional and another contemporary.
I am glad that each of us had the different one and shared everything.
Every dish was FANTASTIC: Well-prepared and gratifying.
What was missing was a bit of creativity, which compensated 
REALLY WELL with traditional side of Japanese cuisine. 
The service and ambience were medium scale restaurant level:
Limited-attentiveness, extremely casual & loud crowds with 
Nordstrom department-food-court decor. 
Since I enjoyed the Tasting Menu dishes, I do not mind trying their 
NY and Tokyo locations.

I LOVE Nobu, I have been to 4 locations and plan to go to many more. The highlights
Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno- amazing
toro sashimi with wasabi sauce(not sure of the name)- thought that i had ordered something else(different menus at different nobus) it was amazing... we ordered another order of it.
Nothing more can be said about this place then hasn't been said.  Great meal, I brought a party of 6 here and let the waitress just keep bringing us food, nothing was bad, it was all outstanding!

Bottom-line-up-front: it's very solid japanese seafood, but the hype is so overbearing it crushes the place. The surroundings are... not my scene.
The vibe is basically that of any of the major Asian carriers' business-class lounges at LAX, but with more 60 year old men with 23 year old women.
The waiters are knowledgeable, and the menu is fairly impressive.
Advice: stick with the specialty cooked dishes, the sushi is nothing special. trust your waiter. get a view of the people, not the park - the former are infinitely more entertaining.

I want to take Nobu behind the middle school and get it pregnant, thats how much I like it. 
This restaurant is without a doubt my favorite place to eat and drink. It brings japanese fusion and cocktails to a new level that make me feel that other food just isn't worth eating if it isn't as great as the level that Nobu takes cuisine to. 
I had a japanese mojito as recommended by the waitress, it was a mojito with a hint of vanilla, which turned out to be an absolute gold mine. 
My friends who I went with has been to every location of Nobu's now and did all of the ordering, so I couldn't tell you exactly which dishes to order, however I doubt that you could go wrong. I recommend the flash fried shrimp and any of the fish dishes. 
It is rather expensive, but I would dare to say worth the money if your wallet is big enough.

My favorite restaurant in London especially for special events.  Recently my wife and I brought my brother, sister-in-law, niece and wife's best friend from the US to Nobu.  We each ordered one of the omakase tasting menus.  The food was outstanding.  The black cod is the best I've had anywhere in the world including Japan.  You must try this wonderful gem of a restaurant.

It's only taken me 13 years to get around to eating at this eponymous eatery. Not knowing the lay of the land, while strolling in from the rain it's hard not to think when you check in your coat on the ground floor, whether that cloakroom was 'the place' that Boris Becker had his 'moment of madness'. But stroll up the stairwell and you're greeted by (for the most part) uber efficient front of house staff in a light and airy dining room with large windows that provide a panoramic view of Park Lane. Not my favourite part of town, and certainly not as convenient location wise for me, per se.
I'm gonna say it, but wasn't keen on the somewhat unnecessarily loud 'nameste' style greeting that is chanted to you by staff when you enter the actual dining area. Because ultimately that means you have to hear it many more times after you're seated! 
We sat at a window banquette and like Berkeley Street, the tables are SMALL! Food wise for me the tempura while expensive remains a must (a perfect case in point that quality over quantity wins the day). And my spicy garlic vegetable Donburi was extremely delicious and generous (I almost finished it all). 
Although you can't help but think, despite the Michelin star, at the end of the day, my meal format at a linear level was akin to an (admittedly) upscale Wagamama Yasai Cha Han, right down to the sides of Miso soup and plate of pickles (or maybe Waga's is copying Nobu?) 
My friend's Bento Box though was in a class of its own, both in presentation and the vast array of foods on offer including the signature black cod. She also ordered her favourite drink, a watermelon Martini (which you won't find in a Wagas!), which she swears by. I opted for a more pedestrian Diet Coke and tap water, because let's be honest the Fijian mineral water they serve is a rip off and pure marketing hype. The carbon footprint must be horrendous.
The dining room was busy, but I reckon you could have walked in without a reservation. Times are hard, it seems, even for Nobu. I'd be tempted to go there for a (special) dinner date, but for lunch I'd probably stick to Berkeley Street.

Our experience @ Nobu London was pretty disaster.  Don't worry about Nobu London, there are better high end sushi restaurants in London.  Just look at the picture I uploaded, the sashimi was pretty unappetite, the toro are fat toro but it wasn't a very nice piece and presentation was just so so.  I had been to other Nobu & Matsushiha in Beverly Hills, by comparions Nobu London was a disaster.  Services was ok, it was very slow and under attended during our visit but it doesn't bother me too much since I am very busy checking out all the high fashion people.   Seen and be seen is the only positive star I can think of.   Don't worry about the bill, it's expected you are weathly to dine there, 100 pounds per head minimum, we wasted closed to 300 pounds for 2 there and I wasn't rich, it was a mistake !
BTW, how come only people from the US write about Nobu London, no one from London writes about them.  Either they know it's a place to avoid or this place is really a trap for tourist ... especially from the US of A.
:-)

We had a great experience, which was defined above all by the food. We loved every dish, full of subtle flavours and presented beautifully. It's certainly not cheap - £80 for the 'set meal' (before the pricey drinks), but they can charge this because they make the food like pieces of artwork.
Whilst I'd prefer to give the restaurant 90% rather than 100% (the food was mainly fantastic, but a couple of dishes were only 'really good'), giving an 80% would seem unfair. This is clearly a place for foodies with a sense of style. I won't be back every week, or even every couple of months, but I will plan another visit at some point. It's a place for special occasions.
Service was good - polite and friendly. I know some have said the service is mediocre or poor, but we were very happy with the attention we received. The ambience was classy, but not romantic. There was a bit of a buzz, a bit of a vibe, and it felt good to be sitting by a window looking out towards Hyde Park. I bet it would be even better on a summer evening at dusk. 
Overall, I've given a 5 out of 5, as it's the best dining experience I've had in a long time. I'd highly recommend for those looking for something a bit special.

I used to work in Ubon by Nobu in canary warf so i've had plenty of opportunity to taste the food and i recently came back to London so i've tried this Nobu and the food and cocktails are just great. My Highlights are:
Yellowtail sashimi with Jalapeno, Rock shrimp tempura, Beef Toban, Black cod, Pan fried dover sole with shizo salsa and the chocolate bento box Loads of other dishes are amazing too, it's pricy but worth it for such a culinary art!

Disappointed. This is a great brand and the Honolulu location blew me away twice last year. It could be the crowd, the new staff or both. The food is fine, but the service has slipped a bit and it's not because of lack of people. There were plenty of them standing around.  It just doesn't have the energy it used to or of the other locations. Nobu, this one needs some attention.

Master Nobu, you are the best. I love the place. yes, it is expensive and some dishes are really a little too steep but the place is worth it, if you like fusion Japanese food.
 I have had the chance of experiencing Nobu in London, Tokyo and Los Angeles (Matsuhisa). They are both excellent and have the same menu. My favorite by far is the LA one as the croud is far less "wannabe" than the London Met Hotel one.
 Nobu Matsuhisa is a really creative chef and the must tries in my eyes are: black cod with miso, the new style sashimi, Sashimi Salad with Matsuhisa Dressing, Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno, Rock Shrimp Tempura with Creamy Spicy Sauce, any tempura (avocado and sweet potato are my favorites), Beef Toban Yaki... and of course the very very good sake!
 One of my favorite restaurants in the world.

I was attracted to try Nobu for the first time because..I like Robert de Niro
(such an admirable actor) and also because i love Japanese cuisine! Heard so many good words about it , that had to try it myself- and i wasn't disappointed! its superb, in any aspect -the location, the service, the atmosphere, the diners, and of course  the food! The flavours, the variety, the authentic scents and spices , made me feel as if I'm at the heart Tokyo, in one of the finest restaurants there. Magnificent and very rewarding dining experience  the only thing that could have topped it up was seeing Robert de Niro in the flesh

I do not think they provide sushi in good quality especially compared with Japan. And it's a bit noisy at night. The sauce and ginger are too salty to eat with sushi. Not A good choice considering its price.

I was here in Jan 2011 so this review is based on my visit then.  
Great quality, great service, Although the lights were a little bright.  
This one is much better than Nobu Berkeley by far and one of the better Nobu restaurants (compared to Honolulu, Malibu that were good but not worth the extra cash)

Pretentious, overpriced "japanese" food. I mean seriously, black cod with miso for 42 quid!? You can get this dish in most family style japanese restaurant for MUCH less. The fish here is supplied by Atari- Ya in Bond street, which has some of the cheapest sushi/sashimi to be had in London, so here they decide to pretty much destroy the natural flavour of the raw fish by adding all sorts of crazy sauces... (easy way to cover up if the fish isnt the freshest)
"Chocolate Bento Box" is basically the most widely available american dessert-chocolate lava cake. Its put into a bento box with green tea ice cream... pretty much tastes like every other lava cake out there.
Save your money and go somewhere else.... ANYWHERE else. You wont see any japanese go anywhere near Nobu, with good reason.

I've never been much of a 'fine diner'. My long-term boyfriend is an ex-chef for Gordon Ramsay so often I get Michelin-star food in the comfort of my own home which is a lovely bonus! However, for my 21st birthday my family took us to Nobu - a restaurant I have lusted after (and hinted to my boyfriend about!) for many years.
 The atmosphere is lively and fairly casual which wasn't what I was expecting but it made the whole experience much more enjoyable as we were all chatting and laughing without any evil glares from the richer patrons.
 The food, needless to say, was absolutely divine - my favourite dishes which I recommend to EVERYONE are: Yellowtail Tuna Tataki with jalapenos, beef sashimi, wagyu beef, shrimp tempura, black code with miso and Choclate Bento Box to finish. Don't be swayed by anything else on the lengthy dessert menu - I had to send back to Mexican Chocolate Cake as I had massive food envy after seeing my mother and sisters Bento boxes! The food comes all at once and they make it really easy to share dishes (we had plates passing around all 5 of us all evening long) and it's better that way as you get to taste a little bit of everything.
 Impeccable service, lovely cocktails, great ambience - if I was a millionaire I'd dine here everyday!
Good -- not great quality. Very Expensive. Beware.

5 stars for food, 4 stars for ambience, and 4 stars for service.   My companions and I had some wonderful food, I initially liked the Namaste greeting but then it got old as I had to hear it a lot during my meal.  Theu had cheap wooden chopsticks that you get at any chinese takeaway and had to break up on your own and get wood splinters, c'mon Nobu...I would cut you some slack if I went there for lunch but this is dinner.  I asked for real chopsticks and received a puzzled look.  My friend asked for a black cloth napkin as she had black slacks on, again..another bewildering look from servers.  All that being said, the food was wonderful.  We shared some sushi rolls for appys, I had tempura, yum. My friend raved about the black cod.  The desert selection was incredible and artistically served.  Oh, and the cocktails were delicious too although could have been stronger.  All in all a wonderful dining experience.  :)
Getting a 4 because Nobu Las Vegas was better.  You should still check this out :)
Good sushi but overpriced.  Certainly not worth going to if you're visiting and live somewhere where you can get quality sushi anytime.

Of the two Nobu's in London I prefer this one for the dining experience.
The bottom line (lets get this out of the way) .....Yes it is pricey... Whooohooo yes sir it is. But I say worth it.
Now unless you are well off enough to eat here on a regular basis without needing to re-mortgage (good luck in this economy) this is ideal for special occasions for the hoi polloi....anniversaries...dates.... celebrations etc
Of the four times I have been the food has been spot on. I have always left sated and glad to have been. You cannot ask for more.

Back in California i would have a craving for sushi about once a week. funny enough though, at my favorite Japanese places, i would always stray more towards the other dishes, because  they would just be amazing.
such was the case with Nobu. yes the sushi was amazing. fresh, tasteful, gorgeous, all that. but it was the other plates that blew me away. they had this deep fried full fish thing.... holy hell. it was filleted, so the meat was sitting directly in the sauce (the sauce.... hmmm... in my world, everything is just a vehicle for the sauce....) and the bones were fried so you could actually eat them like a crunchy snack. i was skeptical, but it was amazing.
funny enough, the food isnt as pricey as it could have been. i'll tell you what gets you: its the cocktails that bump up the bill. amazing drink list. and the servers just know when to show up at your elbow and say "would you like another?" and of course you would, if you *should* or not. 
my one issue: the decor and space felt very... lacking? cold? corporate? it needed something. yes i know its in a hotel, but really do we need to be reminded of it? at a place like this, the whole thing should be an experience. a change to get away from the ordinary.
but anywho. still...
sigh.
nobu. till we meet again.
Sometimes the seafood gives a strange feeling in my mouth. But the sushi there is simply delicious. I like the variety of food in this restaurant and I'm planning to go there soon.
For first class delicious Japanese cuisine this takes some beating. this is where to bring someone you want to impress-the food and service is excellent and the desserts to die for.

Excellent tempura and black bean Dover sole
Food was good but Service was not very good
Sushi came out incorrect but they fixed it
One meal came out more than five minutes after the other two meals

I have been to several branches of Nobu and the Mayfair location is my absolute favo(u)rite.
My mom and I went and sat at the sushi bar. We ordered the chef's sushi dinner and plenty of saketinis. Everything was fabulous. The fish was as fresh as what I ate in Japan and everything was seasoned perfectly. Coincidentally, this was also my first Nobu experience. Maybe the sentimentality is tainting my perception... Haha.

Always superb and special. Its the elegant high end side of sushi but as a sushi addict, if I could afford to eat here every day I would. cant remember when I 1st went- many moons ago, but if you want to treat someone special (if any of my friends read this review take note!!) then you cant go wrong with Nobu xx

Sure, Nobu has great sushi - super fresh, good variety, but you don't come to Nobu to eat sushi. You go to have his superb Peruvian-Japanese inspired dishes. The famous black cod with miso is famous for a reason - it's really good. Soft, light, flaky cod smothered in salty, earthy miso paste satisfies that part of you that can never get full from eating raw fish. Another stand out dish is the seared kobe steak, seared rare, with some delicious alcohol-based sauce. The fat from the steak is for sure an artery clogger, but it almost melts in your mouth. Very, very tasty.
The decor leaves something to be desired - it's rather plain, but then almost all Nobu restaurants are rather plain. It's perhaps a nod to the zen-like simplicity of Japanese decor, and almost a reminder to focus on your food.

Not a meal for the sustainably minded, that's for sure. Only the popular fish get any attention at this celebrity luncheon spot. And wow this place is expensive! (£60pp for lunch). I will say that the food and drinks were really nice. The bar serves a surprisingly subtle bloody Mary with wasabi and tankatsu sauce. I'll definitely be making this one at home, so thanks for the inspiration! 
Sadly I couldn't justify spending £32 for their signature black cod with miso. Instead I had a Latin spiced ribeye over rice, which was a delightfully spicy riff on the Japanese meat over rice dishes like katsudon and unagidon. On the more traditional end, my lady had the prixe-fixe sushi lunch, which featured only the highest quality designer fish (like bluefin and wild salmon). The hand rolled maki (the lady called them Japanese tacos) were particularly delicious. 
The low point for me was cultural... while the excellent service made me feel like I was getting my money's worth, it's make me wiggle when all the servers yell "irashaimase" when customers walk in and there's not a Japanese soul in sight.

I've been to Nobu in NYC and Vegas and decided on this location, which my wife told me was "less of a scene" than the other London location. I love the food here. Fresh, light, creative and spicy. 
We started with some sushi, which is always excellent here. We had spicy tuna and a California roll. It was as good as sushi can be in my book. We then chose a selection of small plates as we always do, instead of going with the larger entree portion. Grilled Asparagus with spicy salsa was an exciting opener. The always delectable rock shrimp in vinegary Ponzu sauce followed and reinforced its claim as the best selection at Nobu. Squid "pasta" with asparagus and shitake mushrooms in an oyster sauce has become another dependable selection that we enjoyed. Our last small dish was Peruvian Spicy Chicken skewers, which brought the heat. The staff was helpful with our wine selection and we went with a nice fruity white that balanced the heat of our dishes nicely. They also kept the wine flow perfectly measured with our meal. and it lasted for our entire dinner. We finished with the Fuji apple, which we enjoyed very much. 
Always the scene, this Nobu location did not disappoint either. There were certainly a few very large tables of glitterati and scenesters and I have never seen dresses and skirts like that outside of Vegas. However, my wife and I were able to have a delicious meal and had no problem hearing each other or being too crowded. 
The one thing I don't get is what is up with the bar. We arrived on time for our reservation and although the restaurant had just opened and was empty, we were shuffled off to their bar/lounge. I'm here for dinner and am going to put away at least one bottle of wine easy. I guess if cocktails are your thing this probably wouldn't bother you, but I looked at it as a delaying annoyance of padding the bill with overpriced drinks. My wife and I always get a kick out of places that are part club and part restaurant. As the saying goes "a jack of all trades is a master of none." 
That said, I was here to eat and it lived up to every great memory I have had of dining at Nobu. Excellent food and impeccable service. Enjoy.

Yummy yummy yummy!!!!   I am so much more a fan of this location of Nobu than Barkeley Square.  Everything I tried was absolutely delicious.  This was the first time eating in Nobu that I did not go heavy on the sushi, and I was blown away!!!

If you have the money, and you want some good sushi, go to Nobu. It's nothing particularly special and the atmosphere is casual and relaxed.
PS- Always go to Nobu Berkeley, not this one.

I rate it a 4 for the generous serving and authentic taste. Though to be honest, I appreciated the quality/flavors of the Japanese food I had at another Japanese restaurant of less prestige called Miyama on Clarges Street.

Went there with two friends, for lunch they have the set menu for 26 quid. I was really courious because it's such a famous place, it has to be THE BEST.
We tried the luncheon menu with beef in wasabi sauce, a mixed sushi and sashimi lunch and their signature dish, highly recomended by the waitress: the balck cod everithing with the sake tasting.
The food is really good, fresh, amazing flavours.
The cod was surprisingly delicious, perfectly cooked and with a lovely subtle sweet flavour.
I have to say NOBU has god a way with dressing sauces, everithing was so well balanced and delicious, even the salad dressing (we've been told that's made with 10 ingredients, the main 3 are onions, black pepper and japanese mustard).
The beef was perfectly cooked and the wasabi sauce simply delicious.
And I'm still thinking about the mouthwatering of the tuna.... sooooo good.
Then we tried a bento chocolate box wich is practically a choccolate souffle', served warm with green tea ice cream on the side.
The souffle' was perfect, light and crunchy outside with a warm creamy heart. And the ice cream itself was really nice, gentle taste.
But the match of them wasn't right for me, the ice cream is just too delicate for the choccolate flavour. It's just not right, the ice cream disappear on your mouth leaving only a cold sensation when you eat the two ingredient together.
The staff is really nice, our waitress has been very helpful.
Still I didn't like that they cleaned the plates away without asking if we were done (they took away the salad I was slowly enjoying on the side of everything else).
They gave us the wrong beef at the beginning, and even if everything was really good, I definitely have to say that is overpriced. It's true you're in central London and you're overlooking hide park but this is not a good reason to let me pay 32 quid for a portion of cod!!
A special mention for the toilet which are pretty small (specially because are shared with the meetings room on the 1st floor, but I find amazing the special make up side with armchairs, white light and mirrors to retouch your make up.
Still I think whenever I want to eat great japanese food I'll go back to TOSA in chiswick, same level of quality for half the price.

Have eaten at Nobu quite often and have to say that it is unfailingly excellent if horribly expensive...the portions are tiny so you'll end up ordering quite a few dishes and spend more than you meant to but as with everything in life............ you get what you pay for.
 Try to aviod ordering the things you are familiar with and stray from the beaten track....the wait staff are delighted to oblige....the pork belly was just incredible...cooked perfectly with the fat melting into the meat...also love love love the tempura, light as a feather....
 It's not just about the food, the atmosphere always good with an expectant air of A list spotting never too far away....appropriate attire for a night out for a girl is tight jeans...sky scraper heels and a sparkly/sexy top.....which will take you nicely down to the Met Bar for a cocktail and a bop.

Nobu is definitely one of the best restaurants I have been lucky enough to try in London. Although just some of the full height windows benefit of the view on Hide Park, the inside environment is intriguing and pleasant; the designer managed to mix a contemporary-fashion style preserving a easily perceivable Japanese influence. While waiting to be seated at the table, one can enjoy a cold glass of champagne in the comfortable love-seats in the waiting area. Wine list absolutely remarkable although the waiters tend to pour too much wine in a single time. Had delicious fresh filleted tuna and desserts but what absolutely stood out was the black cod. Apart from the exquisite taste, smoked at the right point, it literally melts in your mouth. The black cod is definitely the reason that makes me want to be back. One caveat: when one walks through the glass doors of The Metropolitan Hotel, he has to be aware that his dinner will most likely be very expensive. However, Nobu fully deserves both its Michelin star and the price paid for some of the plates.

Went there one night on our vacation last week. The restaurant was around the corner from our hotel. I have been to numerous nobu restaurants and i can't believe that this is a nobu. are all the other reviewers blind to the decor. half the experience of a restaurant is the experience and ambiance. this truly looks like a cafeteria. there is literally nothing on the walls, the tables and chairs are pine and there is zero ambiance...zero. the food was fine, but for the price...no way! i can't believe chef is putting his name on this restaurant. don't go.
Discovered the place only last week. Sushi was excellent quality and my girlfriend was in love with the dessert. Very chic atmosphere. Great for once in a month treat.

doesn't top the NYC Nobu but does a good job of serving fabulous sushi in London
the scene was much more tacky/trashy at this one than I've ever seen in any of the NY locations, but think this is a function of the Eastern European / Middle Eastern focused wealth in London. 
risk: too much mink with your sushi
reward: delicious Nobu staples across the pond

Extremely expensive, more expensive than America. Cool ambiance. Good service, good attitude, beautiful sighteseeing, a view to Hyde Park.  It was the most expensive almost 400 pounds for two. Around 8 plates and a bottle of wine.

4.5 stars. really - it was quite excellent.
we had the steak starter, a bamboo with chilled sake, king crab claw, scallops in spicy sauce, tempura roll, and i'm totally forgetting what else.
everything was so good. the steak was amazing - i literally wanted to lick the plate but then i remembered where i was (oops, silly american..). the three of us couldn't get over the tastes and how fresh everything was. 
definitely make reservations so you don't have to wait. i'd totally go back - except i'm 5400 miles away. ;)

My experience here was nothing spectacular unfortunately.  Being sushi snob myself and having visited other Nobu locations (NY, LA, etc.) many times, I had to say this place did not meet my expectations.
I don't usually order stuff from regular menu and it works just fine at other Nobu locations, but the server here had no idea what I was trying to order.  I asked to speak to one of the Japanese chefs and the issue was immediately solved.  Still the sushi I had was nothing special.
Considering the price I paid, I had way better experience at Zuma for sure...

I was glad I stopped here for dinner after s long walk about in London. I was hot, tired and hungry. Unfortunately, their air conditioning was not quite up to par. I sat at the sushi bar and had a gat conversation with the Japanese young lady who served me. The sushi was fresh albeit small for my standards. The restaurant was busy and the staff professional and very friendly. Pricey but in line with their quality and level of staff.
No better sushi ... perhaps my best meals ever are eaten here.

This was fantastic. 20 year ago. Now it's seriously overcrowded, the staff think they are too cool to be even remotely polite to non-celebs and the food is not a patch on the much better Nobu Berkeley (the one where the celebs actually go). Thank God I'm teetotal so it was just irritatingly expensive rather than really annoying.

Took my 11 Y/O daughter for diner on Friday evening and managed to get a table without a reservation.
 She's a real sushi lover so we wanted to try what is supposed to be the best and yes, it was very good. Everything tasted very freeh and the flavours were very crisp, but 200 quid for two of us, it ain't worth that!
 I will go back but not as often as I would have done if it didn't suffer from quite as much of the London hype as it does.

I love the Nobu I will miss it when I will leave London even if it will be a good thing for my economy.I did not see any celebrities but the food is so goooooood!! The best sushi and fresh food. 
Nice bar also and perfect sushi bar

I went to Nobu a few months ago for lunch with a friend, and we had a lovely experience. We had a seat by the window overlooking Hyde Park, and it was a nice sunny day.
We had 3 dishes, some sushi/sashimi, dessert, and a couple of drinks each. The 3 dishes we ordered were - shrimp and lobster with spicy lemon sauce, pan fried dover sole with red chilli salsa, seafood toban yaki. We also ordered a selecton of sashimi - yellowtail, salmon, sea bream, mackerel, sweet shrimp. For dessert, we both had the chocolate bento box. I had a couple of mojitos with the meal, and my friend had a raspberry cooler.
Shrimp & lobster with spicy lemon sauce - A salad of fresh leaves and enoki mushrooms, topped with shrimp and chunky lobster pieces, and a tangy lemon sauce. The dish wasn't swimming in sauce, but there was enough to coat everything and it helped to lift the flavours of the shrimp and lobster. This was a perfect way to start the meal, as my tastebuds were now tingling.
Pan fried dover sole with red chilli salsa - this came out next, and I was blown away by the presentation. There were 4 fillets of fish, on a frosted glass plate, swimming in a red chilli salsa, and right in the middle, was the head and backbone of the fish, deep fried and curled up into a "C" shape, with the tail suspended in mid-air. The fish was nice and fresh, and again, the sauce was very tasty. Not overpoweringly spicy, but enough to make my tastebuds tingle. We wiped the plate clean.
Seafood "toban" yaki - this came out last, and I am glad they left it til the end. It was basically a flat claypot with a lid (the "toban"), and when you opened it, the aroma that came out was unbelievable. It had a lovely savoury, vinegary smell, and inside the toban were clams, shrimp, fish, swimming in a lovely soy/vinegar sauce. The seafood was firm and fresh, and the sauce was the best of the 3 dishes. It was so good, for the remainder of the meal, I kept stopping to savour the smell as other tables had their "toban" yaki delivered to them. I really enjoyed this dish.
The sashimi came out next, and by comparison, the "wow" factor wasn't there, compared with the previous 3 dishes. The fish was definitely of good quality, but I suppose there wasn't much difference between Nobu's sashimi and other places I've been to (e.g. Inaho, Yoshino). As before, the fish was firm and fresh, but the sweet shrimp was slightly slimy. 
To finish, we had the chocolate bento box, and it was a chocolate fondant with a scoop of green tea ice cream in a bento box. The fondant itself was good, nice and warm with a lovely gooey, liquid centre. The ice cream was the best green tea ice cream I've had, it had a lovely deep smokey green tea flavour. A good way to end the meal.
I also had the vanilla and apple mojito, and the pear and cinnamon mojito. I enjoyed both, and preferred the apple over the pear, as the apple flavour was more distinct, compared with the pear. The glasses were quite generous, and the vodka was nice and strong.
The meal ended up costing over £200, which is quite expensive. I would definitely recommend their special dishes, but wouldn't necessarily go back for the sashimi, as you can get similar quality sashimi at other top japanese restaurants. Worth going to for a treat.

It was our initial visit. Having spoke to good friends and examining the testimonials we had been quit eager for dining here. The service was extremely fine. Very attentive. The climate was satisfied yet inviting.They're going the extra distance to be certain their guests are content.This was the most amazing plate That i've ever had!I strongly recommend this restaurant for anyone who loves foodstuff. Very accomodating staff, and always there when you wish them.
The sushi chefs are fantastic and just serve the freshest sea food. I've recommended this restaurant to a lot of, lots of individuals and none have already been dissatisfied!!

This is home away from home for me. The service is excellent, you're taken care of from the moment you enter the restaurant until you leave. Everything is delicious and made with the freshest and highest quality ingredients. You have to get the yellowtail sashimi with jalepeno, tuna tataki with ponzu, rock shrimp tempura with creamy spicy sauce, black cod with miso, and the chocolate bento box which is flourless chocolate lava cake with green tea ice cream. These items are just a few of my favorites, you can't go wrong with anything you order.

I was lucky enough to be taken here for a corporate event, which meant a private room, someone else picking up the tab and the chance to try a bit of everything. All I can say is 'wow'. This is one place that lives up to the hype and (if it's possible) tops it. I'm not even a big fan of Japanese food, but you'd have to be mad not to love Nobu.
 I don't think you can go wrong no matter what you pick from the menu, but the famous black cod with miso lives up to its reputation, the yellowfin sashimi was absolutely outstanding, and the seared beef with spring onion and garlic chips left me speechless. I've never eaten so much raw or seared food in my life, but I am now completely converted.
 The staff were friendly, incredibly efficient and looked after us brilliantly, and I really can't fault the place for food and service.
 The main restaurant looked bustling and atmospheric from what I saw, with plenty of movers and shakers and an appearance from Kylie (or so the tramp outside told one of my fellow diners!)
 If you want a memorable dinner, this is definitely the place to go. Just bear in mind that everything you eat afterward will be a disappointment!

I have been to both the Nobu restaurants in London, and this one is my favourite. The restaurant area is spacious, and the large windows all around one side provide a nice effect.
 As you would expect from a Nobu restaurant, the service is of a very high standard, and they really made me feel fussed over (I like that). We had various delicious dishes, and my favourite was definitely the black cod - that is my recommendation to anyone reading this review!
 I'm not at all interested in 'celebrity spotting', but for those of you that are, you are sure to spot some famous person or other in Nobu.

This is the restaurant that changed the landscape forever. Japanese cuisine in London was almost non-existant and inedible 15 years ago and then Nobu came along and set the standard. It's still one of the best - simple, fresh and minimalist - not fussy. It's not 'fun' or particularly 'trendy' but it serves some of the highest quality sushi in the city. Ask them to deep fry the shrimp heads when you order amai ebi.

While the Nobu (s) in California rock, this pretentious "Overdressed Red Lobster" is awful.  From the crappy drink I got at the bar to the snobby, anorexic hostess, I knew I was not in for a fun night.  I got sushi and several items I had loved at the Nobu in Malibu only to find that everything smelled "fishy" and the signature Black Cod with Miso was like eating a "Dr. Scholls gel insole with Miso"....

HOW COME MY PREVIOUS REVIEW IS NOT SHOWING??
 anyway, 
Just wanted to say...
 I wonder if NOBU uses MSG in their food OR SAUSES. I keep getting a migrane EVERY SINGLE TIME after eating there. I DO NOT have food allergies and I do not drink alcohol. If I ask the metre'd, I'm sure they will say that they don't use MSG... I wonder...?

The first time in my life at Nobu London was in 1999, we were in London on a short break and had on the day the brilliant idea we want to go to Nobu, and got a table through a few pestering phone calls to a great friend and chef I know, he worked with Mark Edwards on some promotions. (Mark is sort of Global Head Chef and a partner of Nobu Matsuhisa, Nobu has 15+ places from LA to NYC, London to Hong Kong. These are part of the Myriad Restaurant Group, where Robert De Niro and Drew Nieporent are amongst the partners, all big playersthen there is a brand owned by Nobu himself, called Matsuhisa, more boutique style, all very complex and strategic)
 Back to our experience, I only realized once seated in the restaurant what a celebrity packed hotspot this was. We came from a Swiss mountain village, so this all in a sudden felt like being seated in the first row of a Film Premiere. Anyway, I don't think this interest anybody, the point is, today in 2007 the restaurant still has a great energy, buzz and nothing is inferior then it was back in 1999, except that the customer base is a touch less celeb-ish, more mixed, tourists, punters out for a great treat, business men, etc.
 Nobu London maintains a 1 Michelin Star since years, and still has one, the service is still very efficient, not always over the top friendly, but the prices are kept steep if not over the top. The Japanese Food with a twist of Peruvian influences is absolutely wonderful, the energy and vibrancy in the restaurant is world class. A magic place that has its price tag.
 If you go there, never miss the signature dishes that are part of the fame. Edamame beans, Yellowtail Jalapeno, Rock Shrimp Tempura (order with 3 sauces) or Creamy Spicy Shrimp, Black Cod Miso, and then have a selection of Sushi, it is top end, can't get much better then this outside Japan. No matter what, don't miss the desserts, they are a class of its own, from a pastry chef that worked for Adrian Ferra at El Bulli. To drink, maybe try a Bamboo pitcher of Junmai Daignjo quality Sake.
 I am not always convinced about the new dishes; they are great if one is a repeat customer dining often in Nobu, but for a one off treat, stick to the classics. The thing with the one off treat people is a bit reflected in the customer picture, at the steep prices i.e. for 2 people you easily hit the £200+ mark, and an exorbitant service charge knocked on top of the bill, understandable
 For quick and more affordable meals, the Sushi counter, where no reservations are taken, is also a great treat. You can get a good flavour of the buzz in the place around £110+ for two.
 Overall, it is an institution and there are newer places on the market, the likes of Zuma, who are for sure heavy competitors and have taken over some of Nobu's regular clientele and fame in the last years. In the end I think, one is a Nobu-san or Zuma-san, all depending on the first experience you had, maybe I am influenced from the 1999 one, and therefore definitely a Nobu-san.
 ("Nobu - The World's Sexiest Restaurant" The Observer, April 2001)
 NB: Then there is the new Nobu Berkeley Street, for great food go to Park Lane, then for drinks to Berkeley, more clubby feel, the food is not the same, just the prices.

This is one of the best Japanese restaurants I've ever been to. 
I went last month for a friends birthday and i had a brilliant meal and evening here.
The food was very well presented and even yummier than it looked. The only downside was the tiny tiny portions. I had a great sushi dish and the waiter recommended a wine - which happened to go with the meal very well indeed. One of my friends tried a black cod and i have to say it looked and tasted delicious. But my sushi was better ;)
 The staff are really helpful and friendly - not what you would expect in a ''celebrity hang out''.
 Our meal was expensive, myself and my partner put in £150 for the two of us.
 Was it worth it? Yes. Would i go again? Only if i couldnt find somewhere just as good but cheaper and without the off putting paparazzi outside!!

I went to Nobu with a coworker and was looking forward to an excellent dinner. To start with, the restaurant is very posh, everyone looks better than you, but at least its dark so you can't quite be sure. I really do like the vibe and the music playing during dinner.
We decided to get a few sushi dishes (both nigiri and rolls), some cooked dishes (some tempura calamari, some sort of lobster, etc) and overall the food was just ok. I am from San Francisco and believe we have fresher tasting fish in the bay area.
If you plan on going, I would suggest to stick to a variety and ask for waiter recommendations (though ours, to be frank, was not very good at suggestions). Overall, if you remove the ambiance and good looking folks, this place is just mediocre, and I would have to say all hype.

This place is excellent because of their Sushi. The bar is very impressive and the sushi fresh and delicious. You can taste the quality.
Service is okay, but it takes some getting used to. Prices are above average but you can have as much or little as you want. :) Noone will stare at you for ordering only two pieces of Sushi!

Nobu is London's own Nobu partly owned by Robert De Niro and a trendy spot with real sleek and minimal decor. 
Food is great, I recommend the Chef's menu with a variety of the restaurants dishes, all perfectly sized and superb in taste. 
Although prices are very expensive the restaurant is worth visiting if you can afford it. 
Luckily I was invited :)
It is one of the most talked about restaurants in London but not the best in my opinion.

U can't find anything nicer tha Nobu! I have tried a few Nobu in different countries and i am impressed with the one in London. Although the food isn't that surprising, nothing really particular. But the atmosphere of the restaurant is fabulous. I am a big fan of sushi and sashimi, basically a super fan of all sorts of japanese food. i think whoever loves japanese food should visit Nobu one day!!

The sushi was pretty damn fine here. My boys have been eating sushi since they were being potty-trained and they were most impressed. We ate at the sushi bar and were entertained by the mastery of the chefs. I have since eaten at Nobu's in NYC and this London location was much better in sushi quality and taste. This was a great meal to the end of our short trip to London. We'll be back--one day!

Haven't tried Nobu in New York or Hawaii, but boy, did I have a nice meal here.  The BF had a business dinner elsewhere (and while usually I can wangle an invite, it wasn't to be, despite my belief that I'm the life of any party) (narcissist), and so I came here.  I ate at the sushi bar and met a great French guy eating alone too, so we ended having a very nice dinner and swapping restaurant recommendations in San Francisco, London, and Paris.  Just my kind of evening.  The food was excellent, and the restaurant was not snobbish at all.  (I'm so used to San Francisco low-key, and excess formality always hits me as, well, excessive, so it was very pleasant.)  The service was a bit stiff, but the sushi chefs were fantastic and warm.  Very enjoyable.

I've only relatively recently started to expand my tastes in food and had tried Sushi elsewhere with some friends, I liked it but wasn't convinced one way or the other.
 However, I was fortunate enough to be taken to Nobu by the Chairman of my current business and it was a great evening. I may have been a bit lost on my own but he knew the ins and outs of the menu and ordered a selction of dishes that blew you away. When your not the most confident with new menus it really makes a difference to go with someone who really knows what he's talking about so my Nobu experience was really of the highest order.
 This was food on another level completely and really gave me an appreciation of what quality seafood is.
 My wife was more interested in if I'd spotted any celebs but it was a quiet evening on that front

This time they had removed Blue Fin from the menu because of it being endangered. i thought that was very responsible of them. They could just continue raking in a bundle and leave it on the menu- but they are doing the right thing. The new style sashimis are all awesome. Try them all.  it's the hamachi and jalapenos that have me coming back for more.

I love me some Nobu and this location is one of the easier ones to get a reservation at or a walk in for the sushi bar. We ate here twice last week and as such I can say that the service was good, as was most of the food I ordered. The only downside was that they kept taking my menu from me despite my protests and that they also seemed to be impatient when we were ordering and not offering much help. That aside...I know what I like and had no problem finding a number of tasty dishes to satisfy my hunger. While this location is accessible I recommend the one in Mayfair, its a bit nicer and more upscale.

Nobu had been on my restaurant hit list for quite some time when a friend was rewarded for some sterling work by her boss offering a rare carte blanche for her to dine wherever she liked, with a friend. Lucky for me, I was the friend. We somehow nabbed a Friday night reservation and kicked off with cocktails at the bar before being guided to a lovely table looking across to Hyde Park. Everything on the menu looked great, but when the waiter came to take our order and we looked up with those we can't decide faces, he kindly suggested we select the chef's tasting menu. What the hell! We weren't paying. 
The miso was delicious, the sushi fresh and sashimi dissolved on the tongue. The famous Nobu miso cod was just as good as we'd heard, with a subtle sweetness lingering after each bite and spicy prawns came sizzling to the table in an oh-so Japanese way. Finished off with the refreshing taste of green tea ice cream. Now Nobu has changed rank to my Restaurants to Hit Again Soon list. Warning - NOT credit crunch friendly unless some kind benefactor donates the cost of dinner here.

I love visiting Nobu at The Met whenever I visit London. My must haves are 1 - 2 portions of the creamy spicy shrimps, black cod and the crab sushi.
With a dry cold sake.service is always good, I try to grab a bite when I arrive in London and usually manage to find a space at the bar.
It's slightly expensive but well worth the price.
Much better (according to me) than Nobu Tokyo.
Nice place and good food, but a bit overpriced I find.

Eaten here a number of times and it has always been very good. Black cod with miso is a must try, but the Dover sole is also excellent. Warm wild mushroom salad is also very nice. The novelty does, however, wear off after seeing the bill so try the Nobu bento box which is great value, has the black cod as a taster within, and at about £20 will not break the bank. Although the majority of the lunchtime guests are dressed very casual it can still seem a very formal restaurant so be prepared as the odd waiter can be a little off  guess the friendliest are sent to perform on x factor. Seriously though, a must visit for lunch just to taste some real tasty treats.
Lovely restaurant, loved food and sake. i and my friends were there last week, I like it, of course I prefer Berkerley, it looks more romantic and chilled out place
Good stuff.  Yellowtail blew me away.  Nice vibe.

What i fantastic experience i had here. Food always taste better when you dine in a stylish and modern place. the staff were pleasant and very helpful. I didnt expect how much the staff try to help you. A great place. Highly recommended.

Great, great food. Never thought the dining space was that special and its a nightmare to get a table. But for once, it's one of those in-demand venues that you understand what the fuss is about. The food is outstanding. Sushi fresh and in the main hits the spot. The whole Peru/Japan fusion thing works really well too- I guess cos they're on either side of the Pacific! Everyone raves about the Black Cod. Yes, it is cliched to rate it. But I'm sorry, it IS out of this world.

Pricy but still my absolutely favourite restaurant in the whole world. My favourite dish is the yellowtail sashimi with jalapenos - YUMS! The sushi's great . . . the tempura with the three dipping sauces is divine. Lovely setting - great service, great food . . . what more could you want?

I love the Nobu in Manhattan, and this (original) London outpost comes pretty close in terms of food quality. Sushi ranged from good to nearly great, plus a memorable salmon skin salad (though slightly too salty). Sakatinis were reliable and we had a decent onigoroshi sake which was good and not badly priced. Overall, a good place to eat, but be prepared to pay over the odds (just make a reservation for the New York branch instead - better value) and the ambience is somewhat hotel restaurant like. In summary, Nobu London epitomizes London - you get great stuff (food, service etc.) if you are prepared to pay, and pay. All your staff will be foreign (eastern Europe), well dressed and pleasant. I hope they get some of the massive tip revenues the place generates.

If you're feeling fancy or want to impress someone, Nobu is your perfect destination. It has the best japanese food I have ever tasted. But the suroundings that you're eating in is the most impressive factor. It has a very clean, sleek feel to the restaurant and the view is one of the best in London, right out on to the beauty of Hyde park and the twinkling lights of Park lane.

This is my favourite restaurant in London, and probably in the world, along with Nobu Berkley. Yes it is expensive but I went expecting that and it wasn't too much of a shock. It is possible to spend £200 for two people on just food here, if you go for things like the wagyu beef and lobster, but it is also possible to spend £60 going for the cheaper dishes. A must every time for me is the black cod with miso - it just melts in your mouth and the taste is exquisite - well worth the £26 price tag. Definitely recommend this restaurant.

My experience here wasn't great. Very bad service, noisy. The food good but very expensive according the general value of the rest. Not really worth the high prices I don't think. Would have been better off going to another restaurant I think!

Outstanding! Me and my parents went and the waiter offered to make us up a tasting menu. We got to try nearly everything and it was all absolutely amazing! Well worth the price and gives me faith in Michelin stars.

Nobu, well known to be the best Japanese frestaurant in London and rated the 17th best restaurant in the world. We went there for my friend's birthday last month. Booking is essential in this restaurant on any day as it gets really busy with bankers, celebrities, businessmen, etc. We ordered Nobu signature's dishes (Black Cod with Miso, Braised Pork Belly with Miso, Ginger Salsa, Snowcrab with creamy spicy sauce) and Green Tea-ramisu, and Chocolate Bento as dessert. The food is excellent, and the bill came to £200 (wine, service charge inclusive). A bit pricey but it's definitely worth a try.

The Service was really good . The staff were really friendly and helpful. Very attentive and quick. They presented the menu really well .
 The Food was excellent . Really tasty and each course was served in the right quantity. The presentention was unique and made the difference. The price i thought was reasonable and i really enjoyed every minute of my dinner I will definitely go back soon.
sushi is yummy! cocktails are delish!!!!! fab place to go with mates!

Was leaving a review for somethng lse ant though I should put my 5 cents in. Still one of my favorites along with Hakkasan but Some excellent food with a cool crowd. Only downside is the resident Papparazzi outside ignoring me as I come and go with friends.
Amazing and varied Japanese cuisine in a modern decor.

I have fond memories of sitting at the sushi bar here.  The sushi was fresh as can be and the otoro just melted in my mouth.  The sushi chefs were mesmerizing.  I was expecting more of a scene but was pleasantly surprised by the casual nature of this locale (even a few families with small children in the mix - aren't those kids lucky!).  I look forward to returning on my next trip to London.
overall, the place itself is nice. the food is delicious but pricey, the decor is nice

Went for lunch nach with a colleague. 
Staff is probably Japanese. 
They have a live stream of a camera on their website which makes it easy to check how busy they are. We went on a Thursday and is was rather quiet. 
Food was good. The portions are pretty good and you get extra free rice with some dishes if you are still hungry but is is not necessary. 
I would go again.

If you are a fan of noodles, this is a prime spot. We had the Udon (tofu) and Soba (chicken), and now I'm hooked. This visit was really worth the cost: We had sashimi, beer and noodles - total cost 38£! Also the green tea is really nice and refreshing. Service was very quick and polite as well.
The place looks a bit rough, but don't be dissuaded. The food is yummy.

I've had better, but if I lived in London, I'd be a regular.
What I liked about Tokyo Diner was the interior design of the restaurant. When inside the restaurant, I really felt like I was in Japan. I didn't get to see the second floor, but the first floor is very cramped. I had to wait outside the restaurant for about 20 minutes.
I got the gyu don, and it wasn't too special. I am huge tofu fan and I enjoyed the age-dashi tofu.
-- 
taste / 3
aesthetics / 3
vibe / 4
service / 4
price for quality / 3
OVERALL / 3.4

Dined here with my family last night .... positive reviews on Yelp. We were tired after a long day of touring. This spot had such positive reviews on Yelp and it fell SO FAR SHORT of our expectations. Pros were quick service & good green tea. Cons were the food ... ordered the Chicken Katsu Bento ... fried, breaded chicken cutlet - dried out, no flavour. My sons had the Chicken Teriyaki... soaked in sauce. Husband had the Salmon Bento - better. Seafood salad was forlorn & limp. Chicken was dry and without flavour. Cold, cooked veggies accompanied the meal and had an odd taste to them. Beyond disappointing.... DON'T GO. A disappointing & a disastrous food experience.

I'm shocked I've never written a review for this place before, but seriously my favorite Japanese restaurant in London! It's one of my priorities to eat here at least once during my stay, and been here more than I can count even before it became so popular. Definitely happy for their success!
Typically I always order the salmon don, but I've tried the salmon bento box as well and thoroughly enjoyed both. I had ordered the crispy tofu, which was so fresh and silky! Amazing!!!!
The restaurant offers authentic Japanese cuisine as well as the tradition of not accepting tips, which is pretty cool. Feels like I've been transported straight to Japan!
My favorite restaurant!!! Try it!!

An amazing and real Japanese restaurant! I really feel like I was back in Japan
The restaurant itself is really small but feel comfy and welcoming, especially on a cold day. The atmosphere and the decoration really reminded me the kind of restaurant I've been on a weelky based when I was living in Japan.
The service is nice, quick and they're paying attention when you need more water or warm tea.
The food itself was delicious and as good as in Japan! I ordered the chicken katsu don: it was big and fullfill and warm, exactly what I was expecting !
I totally recommend this place for people looking for real japanese food and for Japan's restaurant atmosphere. Of course it's much more expensive than the same in Japan but, the price worth the quality and these real japanese culinary experience.
Real Japanese home food! Feels nice and cozy and would love to come again to try other menu!

This place has become a reliable choice for me - not somewhere I'd travel into town for specifically but perfect for a reasonably priced meal in central (usually pre/post cinema nearby!).
My mister loves it, I think because you can order an extra large 'omari' portion of rice for free if you're feeling hungry (which he always is). I think we both also appreciate its simplicity, with basic wooden furnishings and straight-to-the-point staff, which I guess lends it authenticity. There's also something endearing about its no-tips policy which I'm told is the norm in Japan.
It's a menu of no-frills Japanese dishes and I usually go for one of the donburi bowls which I find quite filling (and the boy usually finishes mine too). He's quite fond of the chicken katsu curry too, and we usually pair it with mugs of hot green tea. The food is nothing particularly creative then but executed well.
It's not the cheapest at c£9-10 a main but very reasonable for the area, and with the added perks of speedy service and a haven from the crowds (esp if you sit in the quiet basement area). Recommended if you're craving an asian food hit in the area - I know we'll be back!

There was a wait early on a Weds night. This had to be a good sign of greater things to come. After our twenty minute wait, we got seated in the downstairs dining room. We ordered Katsu don and the spinach with sesame seeds. I have to say that this was the best katsu don that I have had in a long time. And it was wonderful to be served Japanese tea and for it to be refilled constantly throughout the meal. This meal was thoroughly enjoyable!

Fantastic place, tried a bit of everything. Drinks wise: the plum wine's delicious, but very strong and sweet and the Asahi beer is fantastic, but it's a bit dry, so take that into account.
As for the actual food: we had a Bento box, which was larger than it seemed from the pictures, the salmon which has absolutely delicious, the rice tofu which also served as a great starter and a salmon sushi set with two nigiri which hit the spot. 
The waiter was terrific, very nice and prompt with fast service. I can confirm that you get free green tea with refills and snacks, and absolutely no tips. Great Japanese vibe to the place as well, feels like a corner of the country right there near Leicester Square. Absolutely delighted with the experience. We came out full and satisfied and what we paid was more than fair!

I was skeptical about eating Japanese food in Chinatown, but I was pleasantly surprised. They have a pretty limited menu but do cover the basics. I ordered zaru udon and chicken karaage. The zaru udon was average. The chicken karaage looked really ugly but ended up being moist and tasty. 
It is higher than my standard of normal pricing for Japanese food, but for the area seems average. 
Seating is limited but there is a downstairs section if you're not picky about being able to see out a window.

I love this place. Despite a fascination with Japan I've never been and this place really hits the spot. It's very affordable and has a minimalist atmosphere. The food is truly Japanese dinner food it's not fancy but it's very well made and tasty.

Decent place to get Japanese food. They offer complimentary tea and snacks. They have a wide selection of Japanese food. Service was also great. They donate all "tip" to charity ehich is a very good cause.

Stopped using Yelp for a while after returning to the States, but I saw this partially finished review and it brought me back to my experience of the place. 
Food: We had the Tofu Don Ju, Katsu Curry, Nigiri Set, and Wakame Green Salad. All of the food was pretty good, although I wouldn't say it was amazing. Definitely check the place out and try their food, but don't expect anything gourmet.
Service: This place has absolutely amazing service and I love their tipping policy. They were extremely fast with taking out order and were always available to help us out. Our tea was never empty because the waiter always refilled it for us when it got low. As for their tipping policy, the waiters don't actually accept tip. Rather, all tips go to a local homeless charity. To me, I think that's a really nice gesture for the restaurant to its community.

You've likely walked past Tokyo Diner a dozen times and never thought twice about it. It's the fun looking Japanese restaurant in the middle of Chinatown, and to be fair, you've probably been walking to a Chinese restaurant when you have actually gone past it, so fair enough if you haven't been in. 
Stop! Go in. Eat. Enjoy. 
Tokyo Diner offers some truly authentic Japanese food, with great service and atmosphere. The dishes on offer are exactly like what I saw on offer while I was going through Japan, and it was great to see such traditional dishes like cold noodle dishes or the simple tofu side dish with spring onions and ginger.  
It's not exactly the cheapest restaurant, both in Chinatown or for Japanese food in London, but when you consider there's no tip asked for, green tea is included and the food is great tasting (plus you can order extra rice for free), there's not much you can really complain about!
4 stars overall for great service, great food, but not the best nor cheapest!

I really like this place. It's cheap and cheerful. It kind of reminds me of being in Japan too.
It's reasonably priced given its location, with bento boxes ranging from £12-20. While the quality is not the best of the best, it delivers. The service and food is quick and efficient too.
I was also surprised by how tasty the sashimi was. There might be a wait though as this place is small. Oh and the Szechuan place next door, Baiwei is very, very good! I once did starters at Tokyo Diner and main courses at Baiwei.

A consistent performer! This is a restaurant you will want to keep coming back to! 
The restaurant is set on the ground floor and basement and can get packed very quickly. But don't worry, you're likely to get a table from my experience.
The staff are always happy to serve and the food is prepared in good time. The food is always outstanding and I don't have a bad thing to say about the place - so what are you waiting for?

Very good food, good portions, and great prices. 
We were promptly greeted by a friendly hostess, and our party (including children) were seated in a nice corner table. Shortly, free green tea, and crackers arrived while we reviewed the menu. 
Authentic Japanese items are abundant throughout the menu, however you can tell they are accustomed to different taste choices (or picky little kids). You can simply pay 70p to change from bone in chicken to boneless in some of their dishes for example. We were not rushed to finish our meal, only asked if we needed anything every little bit. They don't take tips, but you wouldn't know that given the attentiveness of the staff. 
We will be back!!

Good Japanese restaurant in Chinatown. I had a craving for pork Katsu curry on a rainy day and looked on yelp for recommendations. This place received quite a lot of good reviews. The place is no frills and simple service. You can let the server know whether you want more or less rice. I asked for less rice because I don't really eat much rice. The Katsu curry came with a side salad which is nice because I have to consciously order a side of veggies or a side salad when I'm traveling and living out of my suitcase. Portion size was still big, taste was good, and price was affordable.

I popped here before a yelp event for a quick bite to eat and was really surprised by this place! There weren't too many vegan main options, but most side dishes were suitable and not too pricey so you could get a few. I had the hiya yakko which is a chilled tofu cube. A great big chunk!! It was plain, but lovely and fresh and i ate the whole thing up. I also had the veggie maki, which was six pieces of sushi with cucumber and six with Japanese radish. Yummy and veryyyyy filling. The prices here are quite random. Veggie dishes are generally cheap, but meat ranges from reasonable to pretty pricey. One of the many benefits of eating vegan =p
This place is interesting as a business as they are focused on using sustainable produce and give lots of information about their principles on the menu, which I thought was really cool. Their website is also interesting as it has a live webcam of the restaurant, which they say they use to attract potential staff and chefs =] very different!

Great Japanese food, nice staff and an okay environment.
We waited in line for about 10-15 minutes before being seated.
We ordered quite quickly, and got out food in pretty good time.
The food itself was really great, I wish I'd order more.
I got two side dishes (as I didn't think I was going to eat that much) and my partner got a main course.
We both had miso soup which was brilliantly made, and quite a big portion.
The prices were a bit high, but we were happy to pay due to the quality of the food.

If you are exploring Chinatown, this place is hard to miss. Husband and I decided to share a bento as we wanted a light snack (but weren't starving). We ordered their teriyaki chicken bento and paid extra for substituting the thighs with chicken tits. 
The neat thing about ordering here is you can ask for a bigger portion of rice at no extra charge. We did that and even though the portions were good, everything was so bland. From the teriyaki chicken tits to the assorted marinated veggies - ehh. Really fresh sashimi though. Good presentation but probably will venture off to try another place for Japanese bento. 
Side note - if you bring in bubble tea from another place, you cannot consume it in the restaurant. 
Side note 2 - The black shaped large ceramic spoon in the center of the bento holding three green beans is not to be used as a spoon...oops.

I really like Tokyo Diner. It's by far the best affordable Japanese restaurant I have visited outside Japan. I will admit that having first tasted Japanese food in Japan, I'm truly spoiled and have always found it hard to find the same level of excellence elsewhere. The vibe of this place reminds me very much of Japan though and that adds to the experience.
I have been here on three occasions and would definitely return. I tried the bento box with salmon the first time and thought it was definitely worth the value. The next times I tried the sushi (simply delicious) and a good bowl of curried udon. The free tea that is served makes me incredibly happy and I'm happy that the restaurant is relatively small, even if that means you usually have to wait for a bit to get a seat.

Really good fast food that will not break the bank.   wine £8.50 a bottle!     
I always feel like a pig when I come here as I always feel that I order half the menu but I end up eating it all as it is sooooo good.
Good Curry Katsu. Wish it was more spicy but overall amazing. Small cozy space. Free hot tea.
Cold broccoli was delicious.  Had the bento box.  Many things I have never tried at any Asian restaurant before.

The service was friendly and quick, and we were enchanted by the food!
The zaru soba was fresh and tasty. The nigiri, however, really took the cake. Every piece had wasabi lovingly nestled between the sashimi and the rice, which made for a savory and authentic taste. Unlike some other Japanese restaurants in the area, the portion of rice was not overwhelming compared to the size of the sashimi, resulting in a far more balanced flavour.
Another pleasant surprise was their eco-consciousness. All their fish is environmentally sourced, as is their electricity!
Tip: they don't take tips. Which is why we're writing this review, because the least we could do is spread the word about their amazing food and warm service!

Excellent sushi! I got the nigiri set (some sushi, some nigiri) and the miso soup. Soup was quite good, not too salty, but no tofu in it. The sushi+nigiri were excellent! Rice was a bit sweet and delicious, and the fish was quality.
Ambience was relaxed; not loud, not quiet. Easy to hear anyone you're there with. The venue is quite small, I wouldn't go there with a group of more than 4, but 1-4 is appropriate. Service was solid; they're friendly and attentive, and our food did not take long to arrive. Bit odd that the soup came at the same time as the nigiri set.

I've been coming for over 10 years, amongst the dross in Chinatown this is a really solid restaurant that ticks all the boxes. 
It's clean, fast, friendly and everything there from the donburi, to noodles to the sushi are all solid.  It's classic Japanese food done well and it's nice to see it still going strong.  It's not haute cuisine you go for here but comforting meals you know and love.

Good meal for the price.  Located in Soho and very busy area in the evening.  I got the chicken katsu curry.
Recommend this place for a cheap meal.  Cash only.

A good spot in Chinatown to grab some quick sushi or a bowl of rice and protein. Nothing special but the staff is nice. It's biggest pro is that it is open late and not the typical dark pub. Serving staff is very friendly.

The food here is great and very authentic Japanese cuisine. So far, we tried the katsu curry with rice and the nigiri set. Both are extremely delicious. One great thing here is that you can get a bonus on rice if you ask for them with any donburi or curry rice. 
But there is something less to be desired about the owners' attitude toward their customers. I tried to be friendly and speak Japanese with them, but they were extremely protective and replied in English sternly. Service level could be improved to make this store a better experience to be honest. But at least people will not be disappointed with the food! This place can also get quite crowded during weekends due to being a relatively small place.
Found this place via Yelp. I love the tofu appetizer and spicy fried chicken better than katsu chicken over rice. Gosh, I was simply amazed by the tenderness of the tofu

Amazing place and great food! You should definetly go there if you want real Japanese food. 
I had the Gyu Don and my mom the vegetable curry... both were incredibly good! 
When you arrive they give you tea, I also ordered the Miso soup that was lovely!
Highly recommended!

I was a bit skeptical as Tokyo Diner is right in the middle of Chinatown and the name sounded a bit odd as well. The ambiance is simple and clean with attentive staff. Prices are very reasonable and they do not charge service nor do they ask for tips.
We tried the sashimi, kastu curry, and chicken karaage. The chicken had a great crust and was super juicy. You have the option of white or dark meat for the chicken karaage which I do not see often. The fish was fresh and nicely sliced.

Tokyo Diner is a gem. For starters, the food is delicious--this seems like a good place to start. I've been here twice and have tried the udon noodles and their salmon teriyaki set lunch. The shop itself is small and cosy. The staff is courteous but no-nonsense. Table turnaround happens quickly here and they are unapologetic for it. That being said, the staff is extremely accommodating to diners and offers a great deal of information about their food and the customs associated with a Japanese meal (no tipping, free tea, free extra portions of rice) on their menu. 
Another thing I love about this place is their extensive lunch menu (so cheap) and the further discounts they offer--if you rock up between 3-6pm (their least busy hours) they offer a £1 discount off of their already affordable fare. 
When planning a meal in Chinatown it can be difficult to be decisive--as delicious food surrounds you from all angles--but the next time you're faced with a moment of indecision, I urge you to check this place out.

Very good katsu curry, but nothing exceptional. If you enjoy having the traditional Japanese katsu curry, this is your place! I also read on the menu that you can get an extra-large portion of rice at no additional cost. 
I really enjoyed my food. It has been a while that I just had a katsu curry without anything fancy or the chef hyping it up. Good tasting and fresh :) It reminds me of what a katsu curry originally taste like.
The place is nicely decorated to look traditionally Japanese, so very simple. They do try to maximize the space as much as possible, so I felt like I was having lunch with the people sitting at the next table. Perhaps this is part of the appeal. 
If I am hungry in Chinatown and unsure of where to go for a sure-thing good tasting meal, I would certainly return. However, I would not travel just to eat here.

Katsudon! That's what you should get here :). They make a mean katsudon and it's very good values (large portions). You get hot tea and rice crackers while you wait for your food. It gets a little crowded in there, but I've never had to wait too long to get seated.

Yuck. Ordered 4 rolls. None of them tasty. Fish wasn't particularly flavorful, too much sauce on top of rolls that had it, and 3 of the 4 were mostly rice. No refills on the green tea, and no sight of these rice cakes everyone is talking about. No low-sodium soy sauce. No WiFi. Edamame was fresh, crisp, yummy. Miso soup was also good. We ordered an extra edamame, ate the centers of our rolls and left hungry. Boo

I love myself a bit of Tokyo Diner.
Having not been here for about a decade, I needed a good post-cinema meal, and a lightbulb went off in my head reminding me that I hadnt been here in 10 years.
Note: my stomach has just started rumbling thinking of what I had here :)
Small,  but perfectly formed, Tokyo Diner is kinda on the outside of Chinatown, but it reminded me of Asia: relatively understated in decor with all attention going to the food, with service very quick and no nonsense. The staff were very friendly, and I like how, if you're especially famished, you can ask for an Omari portion which is larger but free serving of rice. Mmmm.
As it stands, I was particularly hungry and got myself Omari with a Katsu which was dreamy. Tokyo Diner's authentic no-tips policy took me back to the land of the rising sun, and I shall be defo coming back here, as soon as I can.
The maps of Japan have also had a knock-on effect of making me wanting to travel again, so at least I have something else to daydream about for a few days :)
Price wise, £10 for a meal which isn't bad for the centre of town.

A girl took me here on a date once. It was great. We had sushi and we also had a big tofu thing that looked disgusting but was delicious. 
Things didn't work out but I kept returning to the Tokyo diner. On dates. And the girls are always impressed by me. "Wow, what a find." 
When I say impressed by me, I mean by the sushi. They soon forget about me. 
And pretty soon I'm going to take some girl there and I'll bump into the other girls there and it'll all get a little awkward. Especially if the first girl is there, because she'll know that it wasn't my little find, it was hers. 
Anyway. The sushi's good. If you're pretty and like sushi, maybe I'll take you there sometime.

I'm a great, great, great fan of Ramen or any other noodle soup. I always wanted to go to this authentic Japanese diner, but it was normally too full to even step into it. Meeting up with some friends on a schedule that included a pub quiz later on in Walthamstow, we were early enough to get seats. 
The service is nice. The chairs are incredible uncomfortable. The menu is great. The food is great. the space is so small that whenever someone opens the door the draft will hit you wherever you chose to sit. The food is worth it!!

We where strolling around Leicester Square really hungry but didn't want any of that fast food stuff... there in a corner we found this nifty little place just waiting for us. 
Place is small but nicely kept, menu has several choices to choose from and we pretty much liked everything, but mostly: Salmon Tataky, sushi plater, sashimi and the chicken karate. Everything was fresh and quickly served and for london, I don´t believe it was that expensive for what we got.

From the exterior, Tokyo Diner looks simple and isn't eye-catching. However, the inside is beautiful, clean and as if you walked into Japan. 
The menu is descriptive, explaining what goes well with what and on the front of the menu is a little description explaining they don't accept tips. I felt this was helpful to avoid embarrassment or avoid any insulting behaviour. 
I ordered the Nigiri set which was plenty for lunch along with edamame and miso soup. The fish was very fresh and presented wonderfully. There was just something about the restaurant I really admired. It was quiet, many diners ate on their own and they were comfortable doing so. 
The price was extremely affordable, the restaurant very clean and the service I found helpful.

Beautiful Japanese food, lovely service, given the location, I thought it would be one of those "fake Japanese restaurant" - secretly own by non-Japanese Asian. However, I was pleasantly surprise that this is not the case - if it was, they hide it very well.  Lol
I particularly enjoy the curry, and for those who are VERY hungry, you can even ask for extra rice too!
Highly recommend!

Eating here honestly just made me miss home more, I guess. I'm not Japanese, but growing up in Taiwan there was no shortage of good, cheap Japanese food, and I guess this place is the closest to that standard I could find in my short stay in London, with somewhat reasonable prices.
Their katsu curry is my favorite. Crispy fried pork chops in hearty curry - what more can I ask for, really. As for appetizers, I often get the chicken karaage - it's just simple, no-frills Japanese fried chicken. Yum. The free tea and rice crackers give it an even more authentic feel, and the staff was always nice to me.
Unfortunately they do not do takeout (apart from sushi, if I remember correctly) - hopefully that might change? At any rate, a nice place for ordinary Japanese fare, nothing fancy.

My mum lives far enough out in the sticks to not have a good sushi place close by, so as soon as she gets into urban areas, she has one craving: SUSHI.
So after a long morning of shopping in Covent Garden, I unleashed my Yelp App to pick the best place for sushi - and Tokyo Diner popped up. I've been past the place a few times and never considered it since I thought it looked a bit "gimmick-y", but if the Yelpers say it's good...
... And as usual, Yelp did not dissapoint. It was really good!
The prices are what you would usually expect. And even though the place is a bit "cliche", it does feel very authentic.
