It seems to me that the staff at Veeraswamy believe that they can rest easy on the reputation of being the "oldest Indian restaurant" in London, as well a star in the constellation of London's most popular (and expensive) Indian restaurants. However, our waitress was lackadaisical, slow, snobbish, and flippantly rude. And when I say "slow", I mean excruciatingly slow with suggestions like "I'm sure you want to wait until the next course." Well, actually, no. I don't want to wait 15-25 minutes between each course.  It cast a pall over the lovely dishes - which were, indeed, fine - but certainly not awe-inspiring by any stretch of the imagination. The lamb knuckles were delicious and tender. The chicken in the chicken curry, however, was tough. Great naan. Mediocre rice. The best thing was their interpretation of "street food" chaat - which was fantastic. We had the tasting menu - 75 pounds with wine per person. After cocktails and the chaat (which we ordered separately) it's a pretty hefty price to pay (about 200 pounds - $320 or so) for the "thanks" that she tossed off with a shrug of her shoulders. She seemed offended that we didn't want coffee or tea. How barbaric of us. I don't recommend this restaurant - you're much better off at a smaller, family-run place - where the quality of food will be very similar and with a staff who is glad to serve you.

Ever wonder about how Indian cuisine matches up with cocktails and wines? Well ponder no further, here is your savory savior. They have a small but diverse French wine selection and a mixture of bubbles and liquors that that will challenge that tingling tongue.  
Just bring your plastic. Cause it's guaranteed to hit a new $$$$.

Figuring that we could find more than decent Indian food in London, S & I decided upon Veeraswamy.
The food was amazing! It was great, if not better than some of the places I've been to in SiliValley.
However, I would have appreciated the memo telling me that Indian food in London is like a jillion times spicier than it is here in the states!

Good choice of curry
 Staff = good
Food = good
Price = High
Value = average
Location = close to Oxford St shops
 Overall _good atmosphere and we will go again.
 July 2010
 Went again and was delighted
 Atmospheric, friendly, easy access
colourful ...somewhat special
Food was just average. Bland spices. They don't have "typical" indian restaurant food, but the food I tried was bland. Service was mediocre at best, took forever to get check.

Just to clarify this review does not reflect the quality of the food but the service of the establishment. Although we had a reservation at 5:30 on Saturday 4th Jan we decided to not dine there solely based on the level of service provided. We reached Veeraswamy at 5:20 and were told by the maître d' to wait outside on the street till the restaurant opened. When asked whether we could wait at the long seating area where a couple was already waiting, we were told that the area would get crowded although the sofa at the waiting area could seat at least 5 more. We went down and immediately after another couple walked up. We waited to see whether they would be told the same. But to our surprise they were not asked to wait on the streets as they never walked back out. When we went back to ask about that the maître d' acted as if he was not sure what we were talking about. We decided at that point not to dine there and went somewhere else. To me this is a first and quite discriminating and in most parts of the world would be considered racist as we were the only people of Indian origin who were waiting at that point of time. I was also surprised that an establishment of such stature have such disappointing service. To be fair we were contacted after half an hour but by that point it honestly felt because they had an empty table left. The food may be fantastic but if the service is this bad I honestly can't recommend it to anyone.

Definitely memorable and delicious south Indian food and awesome decor - I love their pineapple pachadi so much here - i even make it for myself now! I am a veg and i don't eat onion and garlic etc. so they make something off the menu for me -- my std order is pineapple pachadi, a bean or bhindi dish, some dhal and some whole wheat roti and raita - that's literally all I have ever had at this restaurant - that and this delicious fresh juice thats a blend of OJ and blood oranges (Yummmmm!!) -- so I can't speak to too many things on the actual menu - but what I get is so awesome that I keep going back for more! And the food is so unique - I'm from South India - and still the tastes here are so unique and subtle!! And again - the whole restaurant is beautiful and peaceful - its like a bit of a retreat in the middle of oxford street!

"Indian" food is my vice and I have bad it for a long time. Purely because V iis the oldest restaurant meant I had to add it to my list along with the spurious Top 10s etc.
 I knew it was expensive so had waited for my 50th birthday to justify dragging the family 120 miles south for a curry.
 Every restaurant will have mixed reviews, why? The decor is impressive but I have seen better. Whether the the food is poor, good or excellent is your opinion, I think this is often down to people not really knowing what they've actually ordered. Indian, Pakistani and the more common Bangladeshi restaurants have their own characteristics. 
My tip for a good meal is take your time, talk to the waiter and question the menu and (if in doubt) make sure you know exactly what your getting, it's your money. One man's bhuna is another man's mulligatawny.
 My experience was overall very good but it I thought it wasn't worth the money although my wife & kids did. I particularly disliked the fact that none of the staff had Asian heritage but appreciate it could be different on another night.
Great Indian food - highlight was the Kerala Prawn Curry.  Addictive sauce that means you'll want to lick the plate!

Established in 1926 (on the same day as Queen Liz's birth), Veeraswamy is Britain's oldest Indian restaurant, one of London's oldest surviving restaurants and possibly one of its most lauded. Indeed, National Geographic reckons Veeraswamy is among the ten best destination and special restaurants in the world. If you've got the cash, love Indian cuisine and fancy a superb view over Regent Street, I highly recommend a visit.
 Menu highlights include a starter course of irresistibly crisp green leaf and okra bhajias (whole okra and leaves of fenugreek, ruby chard and mint coated in a light rice flour batter, £9) with a particularly creamy coriander and mint sauce and a tangy tamarind chutney with pomegranate seeds. For the main course, consider the Sholay chicken tikka smoked with garam masala (£9 as a starter, £18 as a main). Charred right bits of especially tender chicken with a bit of kick, I'd definitely choose that dish again. Another item I'd certainly be keen to enjoy again is the side dish of fresh pineapple curry (pineapple, curry, mustard and green chilli, £9). Unusually savoury, I'd go back for it alone. Veeraswamy's flaky on the outside/fluffy on the inside layered naan (£3.35) are delectable, while kaala jaam (large black gulab jamun with vanilla ice cream, £6.75) for puds ends any Indian feast on a moreish note.
 Right off Regent Street (the restaurants' first floor dining room hovers above it), with an ethnic without being kitsch atmosphere, incredibly attentive service, fascinating history and an exceptionally tasty menu: Veerswamy is an elegant restaurant serving delectable Indian cuisine.

Veerswamy is purported to be the oldest Indian restaurant in Europe but it certainly doesn't feel like it. The modern brightly lit decor is spacious and welcoming. The dishes are varied and very very tasty including the traditional curries with recipes from across India. The service is impeccable with attentive and helpful wait staff who are prompt but never rushed. The only big detraction is the price...even for Indian food or London upscale dining this is an expensive restaurant which puts this to "On Special Occasions Only" category. BTW, for the geeks in the house the Apple Store is down the street.

Wonderful Indian food with amazing ambiance and lighting.
I patronized this place in an attempt to find a quality Indian restaurant in London.  I was here in London for the first time and put this on my list of things to do.  
The food is delicious, the service is impeccable, and most of all, the ambiance and decor is absolutely awesome.   
As others have said, come here ready to spend some dough but rest assured you won't be disappointed.

Not your average Indian! Stands a head above the rest, menu was very different to usual Indian restaurants. Cooking style was very light compared to many heavily oiled dishes at other places. Staff were very polite and the service was great. Highly recommended.

Whenever I'm in London, I look forward to a meal here.  The food is great as is the service, ambiance is nice and one of the worlds great beers is available here - Cobra.  This is not your average, run-of-the-mill Indian restaurant - this is upscale dining and well worth the price.

I booked a table at Veeraswamy as it brought back childhood memories and  was disappointed that the authentically dressed 'bouncer' wearing turban and massive sabre, who terrified me as a child wasn't standing vigil on our arrival.
The restaurant is extremely snazzy and has a great ambience. The service was attentive without being intrusive. The food was very good, although portions were small considering the prices, but that's Regent Street for you I suppose. 
We enjoyed our meal, but were starving first the next morning. I am disappointed to say that it didn't quite meet my expectations having dined there regulary 'some' years ago.

My father had been here about 30 years ago and wanted to go back when he visited me in London this year.  Great food, great service and killer martinis.  Also it's a very pretty restaurant.  Given the price I would save this for special occassion dinners.

Veerswamy is definitely an older, if not the oldest Indian restaurant in London.  They have pictures of all types of Indian dignitaries making spots here.  Trying to find this place is a bit confusing, since the entry is small and in an alley and the actual restaurant is upstairs.  They food was great! Definitely modernization has updated their dinning room and created a chic ambiance.  All together this was a great stop on our European vacation.

I see that Angela covered the history lesson, so I'll get right to the food.  The dishes and curries here are great, served in a dazzling array of bowls and pots.  The Indian food here is a bit more spicy and a bit less sweet than the Indian food I'm used to having in Los Angeles, but definitely full of great flavor and aroma.  Excellent service as well!

The longest established curry house in the UK (or so they say), this is not your run-of-the-mill establishment. Updated with colourful, ethnic design the restaurant serves modern Indian settings in a contemporary setting reminiscint of a Maharaja's Palace. Pricey, but worth the money, a great venue for a fun night out.

Doubtless, I was more impressed when I was there the first time, 1967!
Now I don't like the - much praised - ambience and atmosphere of this place very much. It has coulorful lights like a cocktail bar.
A third of the food impressingly good, a third of standard quality and the last third boring in taste.
The prices are really high and are not justified.
 The service is polite and tries to be really good - not always successfully.

I'm a bit of a foodie (really its the only reason why I go to the gym) and I LOVE LOVE Veeraswamy.
The food is authentic and some of the best that I have eatern. The staff are attentive, without being overbearing.
The decor was getting slightly tacky, but they have had a refurb thats great (but not as great as Porte Des Indes).

Holy %@#$.  I just about died eating here.  I hated Indian food before and had a great experience at a hole in the wall elsewhere in London, and then a few days later came here, and became a total die-hard.  I'm a vegequarian and I even eat the Chicken Tikka here it's that good.  It's the only restaurant that I dream about on a regular basis and can't wait to get to after a year away this summer!

Had a very good lunch here.  Food was really well prepared.  Good flavor.  Unique preparations that are not very common in Indian restaurants.  Service and room were very nice.  Slightly modern decor. Nice space overlooking Regent St.

My husband and I ate dinner here before the Lion King show and had a fantastic time! 
This French restaurant is clean, classy, and romantic. We were immediately greeted at the door and sat at a table. 
Our server, Ridas, went above and beyond to make sure that our dinner was amazing! He was such a hard worker and the restaurant is lucky to have him. 
We started with the Burrata with tomatoes, olive oil and basil. Every ingredient in this appetizer was so fresh, kicking our meal off to a great start.
For dinner, I had the veal schnitzel holstein with green beans served with a fried egg on top. This schnitzel was delicious! The veal was tender and flavorful and fried to perfection--crispy and not greasy. The green beans and egg were done perfectly and added to the dish well. 
My husband is allergic to onions and garlic and was super bummed out when they told him that the side of macaroni and cheese had his allergens. We wanted to split the mac n' cheese. Our server and the chef went ABOVE AND BEYOND to make this mac n' cheese possible for us. Ridas advocated for us and the chef made a special batch of mac n' cheese just for us. We were blown away and the mac n' cheese was so good! It was perfectly cheesy, not oily and the pasta was cooked perfectly. 
Overall, superb service, outstanding food, fair prices, and great ambiance! We will definitely be back when we go to London again!

The hosts are very rude, it made me leave before even thinking about asking for a table, but we decided to give it another try later on. Hosts are still rude, so we just decided to grab drinks and a dessert rather than spending money here on dinner if it was going to be just as disappointing as the staff. Luckily, the bar staff is a little nicer. We ordered a carafe of red wine and dessert, which was not worth remembering the name. It was like a panda cotta with a creme brûlée top (torched sugar) which was unevenly torched, the middle too burnt and the sides left with raw sugar. I did feel like the flavors were wonderful, but the presentation was unimpressive. Overall, my experience here was not worth coming back. If you're looking for nicely done french food, keep searching. I will say the ambiance is aimed for a more romantic feel, but the decor is very similar to that of the Cheesecake Factory (an American chain restaurant.) 
I apologize for the not so great photos, the lighting inside at night is not ideal for photos and I didn't care enough to waste my time editing them.

Ordered take away from their bakery for a quick bite to eat! We got a sausage roll, mushroom & hummus sandwich and roast beef sandwich, totalling to £14.40. If you dine in, the cost of each dish is increased by about £1.50.
The sausage texture was soft like a minced meat. The roll itself was extremely oily but it tasted great (probably because of all the oil). The roast beef sandwich was great toasted, although it had too much bread and not enough sandwich contents. The mushroom & hummus sandwich came with a SURPRISE EGGPLANT. I feel like there was more eggplant than mushroom, and instead should've been called "eggplant sandwich with mushroom and hummus." I'm not mad at it though because I love eggplant, but just a warning for those of you who are expecting mushrooms and hummus and end up with an eggplant too.

My wife and I were just walking out of Covent Garden and spotted the restaurant. Went in and the atmosphere just felt right. The couple seated next next to us were finishing with some amazing looking desserts. So, we decided to split an entree (I.e., we are retired and ate lunch three hours earlier) and each have a dessert. The beef stroganoff was some of the best we have had anywhere. The desserts were great. Service was attentive and done as a team. This was the best meal we have had in London in over one week.  Will do our best to return again.
Back again after two years. Still good food. On Thursday evening, it did seem noisy but still at a level where conversations could be held.

**Review is for the Boulangerie** 
Found myself daydreaming about food (surprise, surprise) - specifically Balthazar's hazelnut rocher. 
It's been a while, but I still think back to my halcyon summer of snagging a fresh lemon tart or fluffy croissant each morning. Balthazar (the restaurant proper) and their adjacent Boulangerie are stationed in bustling Covent Garden. The restaurant remains woefully out of my price range, so the bakery became my preferred haunt. Grab one of their canary-yellow boxes, load up on some heavenly carbs, and resist the urge to eat them until you arrive at your dining location. 
The shop has great versatility - everything from fresh loaves of French bread (served with giant butter pats) to whimsical, fist-sized meringues. The bread is good stuff. Full stop. Soft, warm, and perfectly crisped. Grab a loaf, head to a market for some cured meats or lox, and make some causal tartines in a local park. I've never regretted doing so. 
My favourite desserts were the chocolate hazelnut rocher and their lemon tart. Likely in my top 5 pastries ever consumed to date? The richness and texture of the rocher's mousse was remarkable. Think a Ferrero Rocher but ten times the size, softer, and far more rich. Needless to say, the first time I tried one I was back the next day for a repeat experience. As for the lemon tart it has a thick, eggy curd. Many tarts I've had in the US suffer from that artificial gelatine-based filling (you can't even really call it a curd), but Balthazar's tastes like true sugared lemon. Their oversized macarons - almost comparable in size to a hamburger - are adorable, but just a tad saccharine for my tastes. The flourless chocolate cake sphere was like pure cocoa magma and sensationally rich. It's heaven in there. 
Didn't know there's a sister location in NYC, so my mouth is watering at the prospect at having some Balthazar bread and sweeties within (conceivable) driving distance.

Visited Balthazar at around 10:30 PM after watching "the women in black" at fortune theatre. Really nice Ambience. Huge french restaurant.  Helpful and decent staff. Quick service. 
Must visit restaurant. 
They have a good veg options too. 
Nearest underground station- Covent Garden.
Stumbling along with no food plans we came upon an offering of a NYC favorite. Same menu, oddly lower prices, great service and packed as any of Keith McNally's places are.

I'd been meaning to go to the NY location for ages and was excited when my friend suggested we grab dinner here. We got here around 7 PM on Friday and there was no wait at all, perfect. Our server was super nice and patient! We hadn't seen each other for years so he let us catch up a bunch and was nice about the fact that we hadn't even opened our menus the first two times he came around. 
I had the Rocket and Spinach Agnolotti as an entree. Loved the bitterness of the arugula and the simple flavors worked well together. The hazelnut also added a nice tough. It seemed unnecessary oily though and felt heavy in my tummy. My friend and I then split the Creme Brulee. Good thing we did because it was massive. I enjoyed the sugary crust but the rest of it was just okay. It could've been creamier and more flavorful.  
We left around 10 PM and there were way more people than when we got here. Guessing it attracts the post-theater crowd. Good vibe and nice service, but mediocre food.

The food was good, not great...but we finished our plates ;-)
The service by our main waiter was good, but was overwhelmed by training a new assistant/ busboy...who was in waaaay over his head. That made the wait for our dishes to be cleared as long it takes to walk Covent Garden and back... we feel sorry for anyone's first day on the job, but between hearing the manager berate the waiter, the waiter berate the busboy, and the busboy sinking hopelessly, we were all to exhausted to enjoy the meal. 
To bad, different circumstances, I'm sure it would've been much better for this quaint and well appointed French restaurant. Only a 1 Star minus. Give it a try!

Nice French restaurant right outside Covent Garden.
The steak tartar I had was authentic and perfect.  But the pre fix menu was just ok.
Steak was about 4 oz and was cooked well done.  Not much flavor this the need for brown sauce. Cream brûlée was freaky but the crust was thin and clearly pre made.
Romantic place but brasserie quality you find in Paris.

I love the NYC location so I had to try this one while I was in London recently. It did not disappoint. I had the chicken Paillard followed by profiteroles for dessert. Everything was excellent and the service was great too. As soon as I sat down the waiter asked if I wanted a glass of wine and he gave it to me on the house! The restaurant itself is in a nice area and the inside looks just like the New York location. It also wasn't overly expensive which I appreciated since I was on a business trip. Remains one of my favorites!!

My husband and I came here in March 2017 for dinner one night during our time in London. We had reservations (which were relatively easy to secure) and arrived to our table. The restaurant is packed and busy on a weeknight. We ordered:
1) Ribeye steak - my husband ordered this and was underwhelmed. maybe his expectations were too high but he said it was only OK
2) duck confit - I really enjoyed this dish and felt the flavors were tasty and just right.
3) onion soup - my husband ordered this too and again, he thought it was just "eh".
Overall, the service was friendly although they were so busy that it didn't feel as welcoming. Even though this place has high marks, we left feeling like the experience was only mediocre.

Nice decor, friendly service.
The tables are too close together. I felt I could have easily joined the conversations next to us.
I had the chopped salad. It was very good. There were more toppings then actual lettuce which was weird but I enjoyed it. 
My fiancé had the full breakfast. Great portion size and good food.

The short: you can expect a solid meal and great service at Balthazar. 
The longer: I came for a weekday breakfast business meeting, and was greeted by a kind hostess who coat checked my coat and umbrella. 
We had a round booth table, the restaurant was beautifully decorated with tons of staff. Our waiter immediately got us water, coffee and iced tea. 
I ordered poached eggs with smoked salmon. The homemade English muffin was delicious, the salmon was fresh, and the eggs were perfectly cooked. I was able to get the hollandaise sauce on the side. 
Overall, great meal, excellent service in a prime location.

We visited this French Brasserie after seeing Mama Mia.  Very vibrant atmoshere and the food is stellar!  Cool vibe, amazing food, and open late. Perfect for after show or just late night bite to eat!

These guys saved me from the ineptitude of the corner bakery, just down the block, who couldn't seem to handle 2 customers at once.  Being familiar with the patisserie and restaurant in NYC, I knew I could find quality and service here.
They came through with my Americano, and small almond loaf, that was just enough to take the edge off my jet-lagged feed cycle, before lunch.  Two pleasant young ladies waited on me, and chatted with locals.  It wasn't crowded in the 5 stool interior, and it was just a nice and relaxing respite.

I passed by a week ago and find out they do a good deal of prix menu and promised will treat myself for that. Glad that i booked the restaurant to secure our table for lunch. When i walked in...the interior look so grant with high ceiling with hanging fans.The prix fixe menu is simple and has a good selections and inexpensive. We has three courses only cost £22.50. Lovely Starter including soup of the the day, squid ink risotto..and i love the main course..roasted pollock..thick cod with peas. Desserts of the day look creative..it has peach with creamy white chocolate shell. The meal taste good and we really enjoy it.

Still good after a few years, but maybe showing its age a bit. We managed to walk in without a reservation, at around 8 pm on a Monday. We've eaten here before, as well as  dining at the original NYC location, and have always had a nice time and decent food. The scallops were a fine starter, and the onion soup was classic. Both Lamb and steak frites were tasty if perhaps unmemorable. Service is fine but can get a bit thin if the place fills up. We prefer to sit at the banquette tables overlooking all the action ( there wasn't much this visit ), though the padded seat is getting a bit lumpy. Many diners prefer the closer together tables in the middle of the classic bistro space. We have spotted the occasional celebrity here but most diners are having pre and post theatre dinners. 
Great Covent Garden location.

What a wonderful evening -- I owe virtually all of it to the wonderful barman who attended to me. The check says "sam p" was serving, so I'm going to say it was sam. 
First, he made an absolutely impeccable martini, and even paused to inquire about my preferred dryness. It was wonderful. I noted the wonderful lemon presence, and he cut a fresh lemon peel and squeezed it over the back of my hand to show me the freshness of lemon oils and the difference they make. Then, when I expressed an interest in the vermouth he used, he very enthusiastically shared their house blend (cocchio + standard dry). 
I mentioned I'd never heard of cocchio, and what followed was a tour de force of making a guest feel special -- he personally walked me through the different kinds of vermouth cocchio makes, their characteristics, their history, their relationship to other aperitifs like Lillet -- and then he gave me a taste of each. 
I mean, not only did I have a great time, enjoy a spectacular martini (and a perfect rare steak frites), but I actually learned something that I can bring home with me. 
I will consider my next trip to London incomplete without a visit to Balthazar for a drink with Sam. 
Sam, you are a gentleman and a scholar. Thanks for a great evening!
Classic brunch food with a lovely atmosphere. Good portion sizes and if you get the bread basket they give you four different types of jams/spreads for the bread!

I've been the the NYC location and had high expectations already going in. And let's just say, I was not disappointed. 
From the friendly service to the food- thumbs up!  Ordered the traditional English breakfast and it was worth every bite. The bacon is not fatty like the one back in the states, the sausage was soft (not chewy), the beans weren't as sweet (which was nice), the fried bread was interesting (not my cup of tea, but nice to try), and my eggs were prepared to perfection.
They also had green juice, which I desperately needed after eating such a heavy meal.
Great breakfast. Loved the omelette and my friends loved everything else on the menu. Great Food and service. Definitely reccomend.

Yummy! Balthazar is a popular choice for me! I usually go in New York, and this was my first time at the London location! It is the same typically as the NY location, but I still love it! The food is great, the staff is friendly, and the wine is flowing! ;) I love it here and it's so yummy! Get the steak frites!!

This is my current favorite place for afternoon tea in London. Just don't plan to eat dinner on the same day. Our tea service included 10 tea sandwiches, 4 gorgeous and huge scones with Devonshire cream (of course) and some of the loveliest jam ever, and 5 beautifully crafted and extremely tasty pastries. Oh, there was tea, too. If you're anywhere near Covent Garden, don't miss it.

Wonderful restaurant, excellent food, wasn't overly heavy. They have an economical 2or 3 course fixed price option with limited choice.  Wine by the glass had a reasonable selection and moderate price

Pretty Disappointed with this place.  The service was decent and the staff was nice so I have no complaints there.  The steak tartare was pretty good.  Sad to say it was all downhill from there... I had the baked cod and my girlfriend had the lobster spaghetti.  While the pasta was properly cooked the seafood in both entrees was brutally overcooked.... Not just a little over done, I mean absolutely terrible.  At over 80 pounds for a lunch I would expect much better.

Meh...
Maybe I'm just a hard sell but my steak could have been more blue and the fries were semi soggy.  The latter was especially disappointing because they are supposed to be really good fries. They were even on "the best thing I ever ate" on Food Network as Bobby Flay's pick.
These were not the best thing I ever ate.
Like the New York location, it's crowded (even on a weeknight) so you should definitely make a reservation unless you don't mind sitting at the bar.
Would I go back in London? Probably not. There are better places to eat.
As good as the ones in NYC. Great environment, yummy dishes and good service. What else can you expect from a restaurant? A strong recommend to whoever is looking for a good combo of everything.

I had the fortunate experience to enjoy this spot with cousins friends and sisters.  Two separate reservations but the kind hostess was able to put us side by side to accommodate the group of 8.      For starters we ordered Burrata (fresh and amazing)  Beetroot Apple and goat curd salad, not a fan of goat cheese (Fiona and Deb loved )  Pumpkin Agnolotti and scallops were devoured by the second hungry table....  MARY DALE MAUD AND Christine AKA CHISSY ..Our waiter Steve was so kind professional and very accommodating !    We had the pleasure of meeting the manager,  Dominik Powroznik, a gracious host!!

A fabulous restaurant with classic decor, and tucked away in Covent Garden. I met a friend here for a late breakfast and catch up and we were not disappointed. We were promptly shown to our table, the waiters are very attentive, and the food came out quickly. My friend had avocado on toast with poached eggs, and I had the scrambled eggs with Cornish crab. Both options were delicious. Tea is served in a large pot, and our water was topped up continuously. They didn't mind that we stayed for a couple of hours talking. This is a good place for intimate dining, though the tables are too close together and you sometimes feel as though the people at the next table can hear everything you say. I would definitely return here.

The Balthazar Bakery is located next door to the fabulous restaurant Balthazar. There is a beautiful selection of artisan breads, sweet pastries such as cakes and tarts, sandwiches, and salads that you can either take away, eat there, or have delivered which is free within the WC2 area.  The majority of the bread and croissants are made in house. The shop is small. This is a traditional French bakery...quality not quantity.  Everyone and everything was as wonderful as the restaurant. If you order any fish dishes, ask them to debone the fish...unless you prefer the bones left in the fish.  We had the Daily Special...it was too much work and it ruined the dish and the experience for one of my friends.  
balthazarlondon.com

While planing to have breakfast in somewhere around Covent Garden we came across this place. In NY Balthazar was in our list, but we did not have time to visit. So without checking the menus outside we just entered in! 
For breakfast, menu is quite extensive but nothing special in comparison to other French cafes/chains/restaurants/bistros. Ah, maybe more expensive! For single eggs royale in Balthazar, I can get eggs royale (w 2 muffins) and drink in my fav places with same price. 
I must note that the waiter was so attentive. I was not sure about to order Le panier -selection of mini pastries and bread basket - he brought the basket to show us what we would receive. Pastries were a bit hard but I liked homemade jams and marmalade. 
Another note is tea pots are big that you can almost have 4 full cups. Nice! 
Nice ambiance, tasty food, I will arrange my next visit soon for dinner.

I knew coming to London I had to try Balthazar's. I wasn't able to make it to the one in NYC, so why not? We made a reservation for 8pm and when we got there it was packed! We ended up waiting for about an extra 20 minutes for our table. The restaurant kept apologizing for the wait and were kind enough to offer a bottle of champagne while we waited for our table to clear out(bonus!).  I was just surprised and pleased in a way with the profuse apologies...Not used to it in America! Ha.
I ordered the steak and fries (go figure) that they are known for and everyone else got the special of the day which was a pork belly dish. We also ordered the burrata.  Get the burrata if you love cheese!! Even if you're lactose intolerant, I'd still highly recommend it ;) Don't let me forget to tell you about the fries. Omg. Actually, I take that back. I can't tell you. You just have to try it for yourself. You will seriously feel like you're being whisked away into the clouds while sitting on a bed of fries. That was me.
Besides the wait, I loved it all, and would come back. Great service, awesome decor, and delicious red wine with amazing people :)

French restaurant with great food and superb service. I had the Duck Sheppard's Pie and my wife had the filet. Food and service were top notch. Super attentive staff. Tables were close together but that didn't bother us at all.

Went here with a group of 8 people for dinner on a Tuesday night. Service was attentive and patient with our rowdy lot. We were given bread for the table with some nice tasting butter to accompany it. We started with the oysters which were superb along with ceviche and steak tartare, both delightful. I ordered the sea bass as my main, which I highly recommend! From the silence after we were served, I take it that everyone else enjoyed their meals as well! We ended the night with a few desserts including my fav of the pick which were these cream puff type things filled with ice cream instead of cream...amazing!

So many good eating choices, keep looking. The menu was not very exciting. The food was so full of pepper, it was inedible. The cheese plate looked like it was sitting around for a while. The bread was delicious. Servers were busy, the nicest person in the restaurant was the guy who took our credit card.

For breakfast, this place is hard to beat.  It is very similar to the NYC restaurant that it is spawned from; in fact I really felt like I was in New York.  The portions were very American sized, without sacrificing the quality.   I would happily come here every week for brunch.
I tired the English Breakfast and was only able to get through about 2/3 or it so make sure you come hungry.

I love a poached egg, and they don't come better than at Balthazar! 
The staff are very friendly and attentive, and although we were initially told it would be a 40 minute wait (we arrived at 11am on a Sunday without a booking), we were seated within 15 minutes. The food took a little while to come but when it finally arrived it was DELICIOUS. I had poached egg & avocado with a side of bacon, the portions were very generous and filling!
It's a little pricier than your average brunch spot, but well worth it. The atmosphere is that a  40s Parisian diner, it definitely injected a hint of sophistication into my Sunday morning hangover.

I stumbled in here when looking for somewhere to grab a bite on my lunch break. Not realising where I actually was I ordered the French onion soup and a chicken BLT. 
It took me a few minutes to realise that this wasn't your typical cafe. Bread lined the walls, the cakes on display looked ridiculously good - especially the donuts - and everyone (the staff) was speaking with a French accent! I still haven't sussed if they were real or fake accents yet...
The price for a soup and sandwich was costly (£11!!) but at this moment SO worth it for a warming lunch having been out in the cold for so long. The French onion soup was everything a French onion soup should be and you could tell it had been stewing for quite some time. It also came with some large cheese croutons for dipping - a nice added bonus. Highly recommended.
Then to my sandwich. I was actually rather full from my sandwich so I saved half for Jody but I must say it was a pretty decent sandwich - the bread, as with those hanging on the walls, was fresh and tasty and the fillings distributed well - no sandwich gaps, woo (big pet hate of mine)!
I finally realised, after stuffing my face, that this was the cafe section of infamous Balthazar (which I am yet to visit)... Definitely worth a visit for a nice alternative to the hustle and bustle of Covent Garden and a much cheaper option than the main restaurant itself.
Awful service. Poor customer experience and utter lack of customer care. Arrived at 11:15 after calling ahead to be told that the kitchen would actually not take orders after 11:15. Awful.

My search for a late breakfast led me today Balthazar Boulangerie just moments from Covent Garden. Pleasant vibe of the area is continued inside with the relaxed yet elegant interior. As a bread lover I had to try their bread selection which was presented in a generous basket (Le Panier in the menu). Alongside the baguette, white and dark bread and a variety of croissants came a choice of small jam jars and some delicious butter. The overall quality was very good and coupled with the pleasant vibe there is really no reason to give less than 5 stars.

Love the vibes of this spot right off of Covent Garden! It's a must hit while in London. They have a yummy breakfast selection and great coffee. Both the English Breakfast and Eggs Royal are delicious. Don't forget to try a pastry!

Came here a few times, though the last time was certainly memorable. As my friend was visiting from abroad and wanted to book a fancy afternoon tea. After trying to balance showing her a good time and me not falling for my usual go-to's including Sanderson and Sketch, I decided to opt for their specialty Bobbi Brown themed experience, since my friend is a huge makeup fan. 
Usually I try to avoid too touristy cliche French Restaurants that attract people for 'impeccably luxury feel' service and overly prices carbs slapped with sauce on a plate. However Balthazar lives to it's reputation with good service and impeccably classic setting and dishes. The themed afternoon tea brings a little more 'edge' and quirkiness to their concept of elaborate dining. 
The restaurant very much reminds me of Cheri in Barcelona. With cloudy yellow lighting to create intimacy, mirrored walls and monochrome marble floors give it that 'socialite' feeling of you being in an occasion spot in Paris in the 1920s. The formally dressed staff just add to the classic feeling of being served in something a bit more exciting than you typical urban bistro full of design enthusiasts with their macs. 
The afternoon tea menu's included savory sandwiches with classic ones such as the cucumber, which is my guilty pleasure. The scones were nearly perfect with a lovely light and airy texture, sweet clotted vanilla team and classic blackberry jam. The highlight of the themed experience were the sweet pastries that were shaped in lips, eyeshadow palette and a mascara. My personal favourite was the yogurt mousse in the shape of lips. The rhubarbs shaped into an eyeshadow in a chocolate cream tart was also a close hit. 
Overall I think this afternoon tea is wonderful quality, considering the price with the perfect atmosphere of fancy dining and being a hot-spot in Soho. It's amazing if you're looking for something in central that offers the traditional afternoon with a themed twist, though nothing overly strange nor experimental. The unlimited offer of tea, cakes and sandwiches available also to take home was a big plus. The professional staff service and atmosphere makes this place a go-to for any fan of French cuisine.

Despite living in NYC, I've never actually visited Balthazar in soho, though I do delight in their sticky buns as often as possible. Anyway, we happened upon this location in Covent Garden and decided to dine here. Of course I had the steak frites, and it was sooo good. The meat was a little on the rare side but I like it that way, and the French fries were perfect. I also ordered the salad with butter lettuce and hazelnut - delicious. Great ambience and the staff wears old-fashioned uniforms. Plus, I think the menu was priced less expensively than the NYC one, even with the conversion!

grilled langoustines (yabbies) with green tomato salsa, chives and aromatic oil served with Jacob's Creek Reserve Adelaide Hills Chardonnay 2013 - a very light white wine that makes it a great companion to shellfish and white meat seafood - I think I just came up with the term, white meat seafood. I am thinking sea bream, bass, monkfish and halibut. Probably mackarel and tuna would be too strong and cloud the taste of the wine. The wine has also a very strong oak aroma and smoky bouquet that is not present in it's taste. I was glad otherwise it could all be a little too much. 
hot smoked duck with cherries, beetroot and braised lettuce accompanied with an Adelaide Hills Pinot Noir and cherry sauce served with Jacob's Creek Reserve Adelaide Hills Pinot Noir 2013 - with some serious buttered vegetables together with the layer of fat in the duck was, to some, delightful. I only managed one and had to take the other two off because it was just too much. The meat was a little tough and chewy but the intensity of the deep dark cherry sauce was very nice. The wine was easy to drink, very mild tannin that brought out the gameness in the duck.
kangaroo with pepper, cabbage, pancetta and carrot with Barossa Shiraz sauce served with Jacob's Creek Reserve Barossa Shiraz 2013 - It was the best kangaroo meat I've had but I can only compare to Iceland supermarket's frozen kangaroo meat (there, I said it!) and I thought that it was a slightly unfair comparison so I referred to a true Aussie foodie that was there that night. She confirmed that it was very good indeed; so lean and cooked to perfection. It was good with the suggested Barossa but I thought that it was equally good with the Pinot Noir too.
dark chocolate sphere with mint, eucalyptus and a hot chocolate sauce served with Jacob's Creek Reserve Coonawarra Cabernet Sauvignon 2011 - after seeing so many media videos of chocolate desserts melting when sauce is poured, this was my reality moment. But chocolate sphere did not entirely melt and the waiter was not going to wait for my silly phone camera to come on. Shame...
tea, coffee and petit fours - macaroons, lemon meringue and chocolate were delicious. The cold coffee was not great but these petit fours, especially the lemon meringue, were delicious! I had the last sip of my Chardonnay Pinot Noir Brut NV with this sweet tangy dessert and to mark the end of a wonderful evening.

Quick Review:  A French brasserie with an old school steakhouse type of feeling.  Standard dark wood traditional restaurant with great tasting food. Great service, set menu for large groups
FOOD
Escargots (w/ garlic butter): it came with about 6-8 pieces but its a very rich dish so I would say a good enough portion for 1, maybe 2 if you just want to taste.  Shell is included, a little weird if you are not accustomed to eating escargot but very good.
Steak Frites:  the meat was cooked perfectly and the frites were just as tasty, it was VERY well peppered which I didn't mind at all.  
Vanilla Creme Brulee:  yummy custard goodness.  Cracked the torched sugar is always my favorite part of eating creme brulee.
SERVICE
Excellent!  We had a group of 8 very hungry women.  Though we had a set menu (standard for parties over 6), we were still indecisive but our server was a good sport.  He was french and gave his honest opinion about the menu which I can appreciate.  We each got our own dessert but they also brought macarons for the table to share, such a nice gesture.
AMBIANCE
Quaint Parisian restaurant.  Clean, with a good amount of space.

Had dinner here on our first night in London. We split pate w/crostini and french onion soup to start. Both were delicious! For main courses, we ordered the beef stroganoff (not traditional with noodles, but served with white rice) as well as the gnocchi with artichokes. We also split a bottle of granache wine. Was't crazy about the beef stroganoff but all other dishes and wine were great! Service was also very attentive and friendly.
Balthazar is always solid.  The Chicken paillard was super thin and very flavorful.  The baked scallop appetizer was also great and they have an excellent wine list.

Main reason for the mediocre review is I felt really rushed though my meal. I can appreciate wanting to ensure I made my show time (reservation at 6pm, show at 7:30), but still I had an appetizer and my main in front of me by 6:20pm... and that was after leisurely looking through the menu! Also, the restaurant itself gave a very cramped feeling. So much so the couple next to me and I commented on it.
The appetizer (octopus, tomato, basil) wasn't exactly flavorful. The main (stone bass) was more up to par with a delicious artichoke purée. 
 
The bottle wine list was very extensive with plenty of French wine to choose from. The wines by the glass had reasonable selection.
All-in-all, I'd say a touch above average for this caliber of a restaurant. If someone brought me back here it'd be ok, but I would seek out another place for myself.

Amazing....Beef stroganoff.  It's been a long time since I can remember a meal that got better bite after bite. It was so good I didn't want it to end.  The place appears to have a perpetually long wait (unless you have reservations of course) but I got right in by sitting at the bar.  Wait staff was incredibly responsive (unlike many English restaurants where you have to flag them down).   Very highly recommend.

Living away from the US has really made me miss brunch, so one of my agendas in London was to eat brunch (it is no joking matter). As I missed out on going to the SoHo restaurant while I was living in NYC, I redeemed myself (a little bit) by checking out Balthazar in Covent Garden.
To me, the interior is expectedly like an "Americanized" French brasserie, and the open dining space with many chatting diners/busy servers made the atmosphere very warm. We were lucky to get a table immediately on a Saturday early afternoon, followed by quick service.
We started with the chicken liver & foie gras mousse as starter. My friends described that it was smooth like cheese spread. We then proceeded with scrambled egg & cornish crab with a side of mushroom fricassée, sweetcorn fritters, avocado on toast with poached eggs, and hazelnut waffles. All the entrees were delicious, and we devoured our dishes in no time.
I am glad that I got my brunch fix.

Great ambience and food. Reservations highly recommended. Wine list was considered a bit pricey by somebody in our party, but had good selection. (Or so I was told).
Went for a work function, but seemed like a great date spot, girls night out, or celebrating a special event.

I had breakfast here with a friend while we were in London. Great location, easy to find. Lovely restaurant, very upscale. The food was really good. We shared the pastry basket which had more pastries than we could eat. I had the caramelized grapefruit which I'd never tried before. The caramelization took any bite the red grapefruit ya have had, it was very good. The only problem I had in eating it was they didn't provide a grapefruit spoon to dig out the fruit with so it was something of a trial to eat. My friend had the full English breakfast which looked wonderful and she said was terrific. The hostess and wait staff were superb and we lacked for nothing, and didn't have to wait for them to assist unlike most places in Europe. This is not an inexpensive place for breakfast but the prices were reasonable considering what you receive and that London prices are very high anyway. Overall I highly recommend Balthazar's for breakfast or brunch. Next time I'm in London I plan to give it a try for dinner!

Another solid London brunch destination. It's a French brasserie, reminding me a lot of Colbert on Sloane Square and some of my favorite brunch places in the US (Parc in Philadelphia and Left Bank in San Jose, CA). The location could not be better (it is right off the Covent Garden Piazza), and the venue is grand and beautiful, with enormously high ceilings and loud jazz music playing throughout. We had a reservation for 2 people, which we managed to get by emailing the restaurant, despite no availability showing up on the online booking system. This is the second time that I've been able to get a reservation this way, so I would highly recommend it if your desired times are not showing up at first glance.
The food and service were also stellar. It was actually just like being back in America. I ordered scrambled eggs & Cornish crab, which came served on a piece of toasted sourdough bread and with a side of creme fraiche. The eggs were wonderfully creamy and the crab was plentiful and just perfect. I could not have been more pleased with it. One piece of toast doesn't seem like an awful lot, but I was so full by the end. My friend got the avocado on toast, but managed to switch out the poached eggs for mushrooms and tomato, since she doesn't really eat eggs. She also asked for some goat cheese, which the staff happily obliged, even though it isn't a standard menu item.
I was very impressed by the whole experience. No complaints about Balthazar and would definitely come again... the rest of their menu looks equally amazing.

Although greeted and served by very friendly staff, we found the food ever so disappointing, despite hearing great things about Balthazar London. 
Crammed in between very noisy small, darkly lit tables, our food came out suspiciously fast - within two minutes of ordering. 
The spinach in my eggs florentine was wet, bland and a rather small portion, definitely not worth £13.50, for a bit of bread, veg and hardly any sauce. Sadly nothing special, overpriced and overrated. I could definitely think of better places for brunch in London.

It is a pleasure to review a restaurant like Balthazar.  In a nutshell, the food is excellent and the service is impeccable.
Here are the details:
- Bread - I simply have to start with Balthazar's homemade bread. Every single kind of their bread is spectacular, but I'd like to single out the sun dried tomato olive buns.  5 stars all the way. (Btw, their butter is great too).
- French Onion Soup - very good. Savory, beefy and with a healthy amount of gryere, very intense.  One minus - too much bread in the actual soup, which sucks up a lot of the liquid, making the soup a little dryer than I'd like to.  That said, still a solid 4.5 star dish.
- Escargots - very good, garlicky, buttery and just yummy.  5 stars.
- Garlic Shrimp - the shrimp is good, but the sauce it comes in is out of this world.  It has a slight kick due to the addition of chili peppers.  5 stars.
- Mac & Cheese.  Very creamy and not as intense as I expected it to be.  Made with gryere. It deserves 4.5 stars, and the reason I'm not giving it full 5 stars is because it was the least memorable dish I had.
- Burgers - Very good burger, cooked to a perfect medium rare but not the best burger (not even in the vicinity) I ever had.  The meat was excellent quality but underseasoned.  Two other major issues: 1. Bun - too big and 2. the patty is on the smaller side.  For that size of the bun, the beef patty has to be at least twice that size. 4 stars.
- Beef Tartare - Excellent! Prepared "au couteau" (hand cut), well seasoned with the slightly higher note of acidity.  Add some hot sauce a freshly ground black pepper for a heavenly concoction. 5 stars.
- Moules Mariniere (mussels) - great.  Fresh and fenomenal. 5 stars.
- Rubharb Souffle - WOW! With a side of creme anglaise this was the home run of the evening. 5stars and it doesn't do it justice.
- Small dessert pastries - every single one was better than the other.  The macrons, the cream filled dark chocolate  and the chocolate filled cookie cups. 5 stars!
I hope you'll enjoy Balthazar as much as I did.

Best. Eggs. Florentine. Ive. Ever. Had. 
Gorgeous french looking brasserie. Although an american chain, so included a special 4th july menu and of course pancakes, this is actually supposed to be a french brasserie. With great choice of french dishes. 
Had the eggs florentine - and honestly best ones ive even had! And ive tried quite a few places! Everything was perfect - the spinach, the muffin , the poached runny eggs and that hollandaise sauce!!
Definitly want to go back and try more things, if everything is as good as those eggs!!! Miam miam!!

You know, I expected it to be better, much better.
I've been to the one in NYC and it is an institution so was looking forward to trying the London version of this cosmopolitan French styled bistro. It looks very much like the one in downtown New York, but much bigger and along with that it loses some of its intimacy. What was imported across the pond was a good helping of New York type attitude. The service was a bit cold and always seemed to be bored with whatever was said or asked for. Our waitress could barely be bothered to help with the wine when I asked if they had a Bordeaux by the glass she seemed confused. There also seemed to be the bare minimum of interest shown while just getting the job done properly. 
The food was good but not amazing. You would think that a pretty straight forward Steak Frites with Bearnaise would be delicious in a place like this.  It was fine, but lack luster. Starting with the meat which was not cooked the way asked more medium than medium rare, and also not the best cut of meat. The Bearnaise was a bit thin and vinegar-y, overall just a bit off and not what you would expect. Dessert of Tarte Tartin was delicious though.
Nice enough, and for Covent Garden Piazza a bit of an oasis if you want something a bit more upmarket. The bar makes a great place for pre opera drinks.

Comes close to their NY restaurant, offers a good vibe to eat in, fairly loud but not too loud you have to shout. People eat there late so the room is well filled. Food was good, had the raw seafood tower and the steak. Only slight negative was the service which was good and friendly but seemed they could have had a couple less tables to cover to provide a quciker response. All in all, this restaurant is good place for a date or drinner with friends/family.

I came here for a solo lunch on a Tuesday afternoon, with no reservations, and I was seated promptly. 
I had half a dozen oysters to start, which came with a choice of two salsas/vinaigrette to spoon on the oysters, but I asked for Tabasco anyway. Oysters were fresh - no complaints. I do wish the bread they served prior was freshly baked...
I asked for a recommendation for my main, and oh boy! My waiter recommended the plate du jour, which was vaguely described to me as pork belly. I do love a good pork belly so I went along with it. Goodness gracious me! The pork belly arrived, on a bed of poached greens, with the skin crispy and slightly sweet, and there was additional pork crackling on top, and blood pudding on the side. They didn't forget a sauce, and to go with all that goodness, puréed apple was hiding somewhere to complement the pork perfectly. Despite the sheer amount of pork elements on the plate, it wasn't overly porky and there was a lot of difference within these elements to wow me. Party in my mouth, it was. 
Loads of places can do a decent pork belly. But not many places can combine it with other pork elements, and do the classic pork and apple combination to a T. I didn't get dessert because I was stuffed, but I thoroughly enjoyed my lunch here.

A beautiful large, French bistro in Covent Garden with tablecloths and waiters in uniform. Service is attentive but the waiters are particular about their respective areas so you can't call on a different waiter even if yours is busy.
We went here for lunch: grilled salmon on warm spinach, walnut and lentil salad; club sandwich with frites; basket of warm fresh bread. All delicious and fairly large portions. Very quick to bring to the table. Maybe we didn't order the right things but they weren't particularly special. The chips were very bright yellow which made me the think the oil may not have been the best. I enjoyed the club sandwich despite it falling apart in my hands because of the soft French sourdough loaf bread used. Two lunch mains for £38 is a bit steep but good if you're in the area and looking for somewhere fairly refined to eat.

It was date night and my husband and I have been wanting to try Balthazar in Covent Garden.  Balthazar was a classic in NYC and I was very excited to try it here in London.
Food: We started off with the onion soup which was ok and the escargots which were top notch.  For our mains we ordered the lamb rump and the moules frites.  Both were good.  I also had a side of onion rings (why not!) and they were delicious!
Drinks: We ordered one glass of champagne and one glass of white wine.
Price: 100.69 GBP for two people.
Ambiance: The restaurant feels just like NYC.  Bustling with energy.
Service: You felt a good vibe as soon as you walk into the door.  Everyone from the hostess, the bartender, and to our server was friendly and attentive.  One of the guys dropped a few plates at our table and about five different people came to apologise.  They brought us two glasses of champagne which I thought was a nice gesture for the broken plates.
Would I go back?  Definitely, especially for the escargots.  They have so many great things on the menu that I already know what I want to order next time.
really good brunch menu. everything tastes fresh. friendly service. i would definatily go back.
Brilliant brasserie! Had some epic brunches here. The wine list is broad and the service is great. Definitely recommended.

Although the food is terrific and delicious, the
service is spectacular. Waiters and bus boys are
Superb. It is a treat to meet delightful people
from a variety of countries. All were fluent in
English but we enjoy using our limited language
Skills in French and Spanish. Tonight will be our
third meal this week! My wife Caro' will return
next week for an encore!

This is a popular spot at all times of day. Great spot to catch up with friends. Atmosphere is lively, classy but not overly pretentious. 
Visited in the lead up to Xmas so the festive decor was up but even without it it has a dramatic grand appeal. 
Initially tried to get a table for lunch without a reservation but nothing was free. Turned up again, hopeful, two hours later and got a table for four easily. 
Front of house was great and waiters were perky and professional. Toilets were very clean but a bit tricky to reach, staff were on hand with helpful directions. 
Food ranged from usual French options of onion soup to extravagant veal. I opted for a macaroni and cheese dish which was just right. My friends ordered steak and cheeseburger meals all very tasty. Terrific place.

I really liked the atmosphere and interior design in this restaurant. My friends and I went for brunch, so I ordered pancakes and some poached eggs as a side. Both were delicious. The service was good, not great, but we had a nice time regardless. I look forward to returning for lunch or dinner sometime.
It is just like in New York. They have this French decoration with a really nice food and beautiful decoration..

I came here for brunch to meet a local friend. After a 9 mile (15km) run, I was HUNGRY.
My friend beat me here, and had a reservation. When I arrived, the place was bustling, and I was quickly shown to the table. 
Service was friendly and helpful, but not overly so.
I had the duck shepherds pie. The shredded duck was perfectly tender, and full of flavor. If I hadn't just done such a long workout, I probably could not have finished, but I was pretty famished, and I ate every bite.
My friend got the avocado toast, which looked amazing. 
Great ambiance... high ceilings, large windows which bring in a lot of natural light, and well decorated.
The bathroom is up a steep flight of stairs, but has room for several people.
It seems pretty busy, so I would suggest a reservation.

Balthazar is so difficult to book for dinner and brave it by trying to get a table for walk-in. We ended up waiting ovee two hours for a table! So i do recommend to get a table booking. Was it worth it? Well I wouldnt do it again but since it is one of those place I have been wanting to try ever since it open then of course it was worth it for the first time!
As a French brasserie you will find steak, French onion soup and one of my favourite Escargots. There are not many places in London that I have tried that does it well. Balthazer escargots was nice and better than other place. But it just does not compare with ones I had at Galvin bistrot de luxe which comes in a wonderful garlic butter sauce that you want to scoop off with bread.
Balthazar serves two different pie including a duck pie which is very rich in flavour. The one I recommend and the dish that I give a big thumb up has to be the Fish Pie. This was true comfort food and an indulgent to have for dinner. It has to be my best fish pie I have had in London.
You can not leave with out ordering the soufflés. It is £10 each but they are big enough to share between two people. The waiter who was serving was friendly and a laugh. Even before our soufflés arrive he explain how to eat it - make an indentation at the top and pour the creme in to it. Then you ready to enjoy a light raspberry soufflé. I have to say that this was the only reason I have been wanting to visit Balthazar!
Fish Pie and Soufflés is what I would want to visit Balthazar! Delicious!

Solid food and friendly service. 
I had the steak frites which came slightly overdone from medium-rare but it's a minor detail. It was tasty and the fries were very good. 
My friend ordered the sea bass en papillote which was perfectly cooked. 
Wine was delicious and reasonable. We got glasses of the Corbières for £6.50 each. 
It's a lovely setting to have a meal. They took a lot of time with the decor from the low lightening and distressed mirrors in the dining room to the awesome tiling in the bathroom. It makes got a decadent experience!
Good service, nice milieu, and above all great food. I had chicken parfait for starters and ox cheek for main course. Both were nearly perfect.

I loved you in NYC and I love you in London....
I started off with the Escargot and loved it, but then again, its just a vessel for garlic and parsley. Nom.  And my husband had the Onion soup which must've been amazing because he ate it before I could get a taste in. He said it was the best he thinks he's ever had. Trust... he's had many. 
Followed by the FILLET DE BOEUF AU POIVRE with pommes frites and spinach, it was downright great! So peppery, perfectly cooked. Just splendid. My husband had the grilled salmon which he wasn't too happy about. He was expecting grilled marked but it looked more like steamed than anything else and also was lacking in salt n pepper. 
For dessert I had the most incredible party in my mouth thanks to the Apple Tart Tatin.... OH MY GAWD! I will have to go back just for that. its so good. 
So good!
Food mediocre.  In our case Wiener Schnitzel just horrible.  Wine by the carafe reasonable. Service only OK.

After searching for a place to have brunch in both Angel and Convent Garden with no luck whatsoever, my friends and I decided to try balthazar as it was 1:20pm and hungry. Although we waited for 15 mins (to be fair we were told it would be a 20 mins wait) we got seated and ordered. I opted for the eggs royale but was told by the chef via a waiter that it contained alcohol which i'm allergic to. I was told the chef would try to create a sauce but it didn't go well - again, i was told. I honestly tried the dish and it tasted dry as it needed hollandaise sauce to give it that special oomph. My friends could see my distress and garnered the attention of a staff and I was given the menu to make a whole new order. I opted for the "avocado and eggs" dish as recommended by the chef. The tomato salsa was to die for and hopefully I'll get to recreate the dish as everything worked undeniably well.
PS: To the staff at balthazar, sorry if I came off rude but I was extremely famished.

I have finally tried Balthazar after lusting after them for some time now. I came late night with no reservations and they where able to squeeze a party of 2 in with only a 20 min wait. The Porn Star cocktail was beautiful. I was not starving so I didn't go for a heavy plate. I ordered the Moules Frites. I feel like I can't give it 5 stars as mussels are pretty easy to make and a place that can't cook Mussels and French fries probably shouldn't be in the food business. It is pretty hard to ruin that dish. 
I did try a bite of my friends Beef Fillet Stroganoff and it was devine! I have never had Stroganoff before as the name alone never appealed to me but wow! what have I been missing out on?!? I also tried her Chocolate Fondant, I don't even like chocolate but wow! Just wish they served more vanilla ice cream with this dish as I have never seen so little ice cream on a plate. Overall this place is a solid 4 stars in my book!

This is for the grab and go side which had a beautiful pastry display (wanted it all). Had a Chelsea roll which was delicious. Really friendly staff as well.
Particularly love the NY'ers asking if this was the original location. Speaking to the great branding on balthazars part.  the staff very politely informed them NY was the original.

This was one of my top choices when my partner and I visited London. Overall, I was not disappointed. The restaurant, decked out for the holidays, was bright, cheerful and bustling with an energetic crowd (bar was packed). 
We arrived 20 minutes early and the hostess, without asking, graciously arranged for us to be seated 10 minutes sooner.
Started with the French onion soup, which I had read, was highly recommended. The gruyere  cheese was bubbling and browned and when my spoon broke through its lovely surface, a flavorful (but not at all salty) broth with plentiful onions and bread awaited. I would have been satisfied eating just this, but I had to try the steak friites, which also did not disappoint. Fries did not overwhelm me, I must confess. They were a little undercooked and not seasoned enough, but the steak itself was fantastic.
Of note was also the side of green beans with shallots. I devoured them with the steak. They were the perfect accompaniment to the steak.
We did not save room for dessert but the plates looked great we saw going to other tables.
London has definitely become more of a destination for dining in recent years and this restaurant is one that helped to turn the tide. I look forward to checking out the New York location and will definitely return to this one next time I am in London.

Despite being in the hustle and bustle of Covent Garden, Balthazar provides a relaxed and friendly environment for a delicious meal - and they even serve decent coffee.
It took me quite a bit until I made it to Balthazar in Covent Garden, but one afternoon I finally managed to go there. A few months ago, I read a rather interesting article about the New York company and ever since wanted to gain some first-hand experience. Usually, Balthazar was always very busy when I considered visiting, but on this late Sunday afternoon, it was easy to secure a table.
Supposedly, the London branch is almost a 1:1 copy of the New York venture. I cannot  verify this, but I can tell you that the main dining room is huge and grand, with heigh ceiling and some vintage coolness. The rose-inspired lamps hanging everywhere are cute, while also pretty kitschy. And in case you want to know, the toilets are beautiful, too.
I started my late lunch with a lemonade. And what a lemonade! It was kind of a bespoke service, freshly pressed and delivered with a supply of cold water, like a do-it-yourself drink where I could decide how much water or sugar I wanted to add. The waiter was overly friendly and I instantly liked the place after this great start. He and his colleagues continued to impress by topping up my water seamlessly throughout my stay.
I went for the cheese burger with fries and crispy bacon. It was a mighty and pretty messy beast. After I had removed the tomato, the gherkin and the onion, the burger became much more compact and shrank down to a size I could handle. Still messy, but manageably messy.
Initially, I wondered why I was offered no condiments. As I ate my way through the massive burger, I noticed that all kinds of delicious juices  and sauces were oozing out and my plate quickly became the right place to dip my fries, no need for additional condiments. 
The fries also deserve a separate mention. The thin-cut potato strips were golden, crispy, superbly spiced and overall delicious.
To complete my meal, I ordered the profiteroles. This dessert was surprisingly big, packed with lots of ice cream and a dark, strong chocolate sauce.
After all this food, I felt really full and decided to do something about this and concluded my visit with a coffee. I was happy when I learnt that they use Monmouth coffee - a staple choice in the London coffee landscape, and they are almost neighbours in Covent Garden. 
I must say, that I was very satisfied with the food and service at Balthazar in London. Really a place I can recommend, even though the location makes it come across as a tourist trap.

Great restaurant with many mouthwatering options on the menu. Could be tough to get a table at dinner time, so make sure you make a reservation. I was dining alone and a seat at the bar was perfect. Its not a place where you need to dress up...but don't show up in a t-shirt, you'll just feel out of place. Very friendly service.

Sat at the bar which I was happy to get as a walk-in on a busy Sunday.  But I don't recommend it. The bar is particularly uncomfortable mostly because the counter does not extend out enough to get your knees under it properly.  Also no hooks for bags and purses so where are you supposed to put those things? Wayyy down on the floor is where.  You will also be jostled by people waiting behind you as you eat. I had the fines herb omelet which was fine and came with a side salad that was unmemorable and an equally unexceptional pain au chocolat. All in all a big "meh." I might return and sit at a table and have something at which excel.  Maybe.

One of my favorite NYC restaurants and the hype of 'designed to be identical to NYC' we had to check this place out and make our assessment as loyal NYC patrons. 
Result: Pretty Damn Amazing. When greeted at the door our jaws dropped and we were impressed at the likeness of the NYC look and feel. The gentleman host said to me the only difference you'll see is outside there are black cabs instead of yellow ones and then he offered to paint one yellow... now that's service. LOL
On 2 March we were transported to a mini-NYC at Balthazar after tapping redial 24 times we were about to feast! I can appreciate my fellow yelper, Kate H.'s experience of 137 attempts to get a table. I realized I needed to modify the reservation which resulted in 67 calls. CRAZY but this was a must-try for myself and some special New Yorker friends.
Everything was great and aside from a few opening hiccups (all places go through them) the staff gave us a great night. I started off with the winter kale salad followed by the linguini "Fruits De MeR" and both were quite good. There were 8 of us and we had two reservations since they were only taking a max of 6 per table. The staff was so kind to try and seat us close together however we ended up with a round table and managed to get everyone seated cozily in the same place. There were many great dishes served up at our table, rock oysters, salad niçoise, côte de boeuf, duck and stone bass. One person's only minor complaint was the stone bass was already deboned. (personally I find that a bonus) However he prefers to demonstrate his skills of removing it as one piece before enjoying and like I said minor thing. Each person said they enjoyed their meal and would recommend it.
Due to the newness of everything serving times were a tiny bit delayed but when you have great company it doesn't get noticed as much. So after bottles of champagne, red wine, fabulous food and yes, dessert followed by dessert wine our time at Balthazar came to a close. The restaurant is beautiful and the food was very good. I'm sure with time their service and delivery times will improve. One of the managers was kind enough to drop by and chat with us. She was visiting from the NYC restaurant and helping get London on track. I look forward to my next dining experience at Balthazar and I'm almost certain you'll enjoy it as well. Cheers to a little piece of America right here in London y'all!

I've been to Balthazar last Sunday for a quick brunch with my love and I've been immediately surrounded from the elegant atmosphere, It has been a pleasure taste the rich and elaborate food they served in elegance and accuracy. Share the experience with my love it was great. I really suggest the place for also the accurate list of alcoholic and non alcoholic cocktails they have. Thank you again.

I loved the New York version of this restaurant when I lived across the pond, so I was really interested to try out the London version that seemed to be years in the making. I met two friends with whom I had been the NY version - just so we could compare notes! 
Walking in, I thought I was back in New York. It is almost identical! 
I had the snails to start with - they were delicious (well, they were unbelievably garlicky - which is about all you want from snails really). I actually swapped a snail or two for a couple of my friend's oysters - also really really scrummy (the oysters, not my friend. although she is pretty hot to be fair). I then followed up with Chicken Paillard, which was damn near perfect. 
You know what I like most about Balthazar though? It's French cuisine, in London, run by Americans. This means that the food is exquisite, I can get to it without boarding a plane or an international train and the service is bloody excellent. Really, they can't do enough for you - which is such a pleasant change when ordering French food!

This is a fancy food factory. The dining room is quite nice, but there are two main problems with this place:
1) The service: everything goes too fast. It is very clear that they have been instructed to get as many seatings in as possible. You barely get to sit down before someone is there to take your order, the main course comes directly after the first course, and they start clearing the table before you have finished. That being said, the staff are all very nice.
2) The food: I got a steak which wasn't bad, but not something very good either. The chips which came as a side was like McDonald's chips with less salt. An with that came a bernaise sauce which isn't really worth mentioning.
I have had far worse dining experiences, but it doesn't change the fact that this is tourist trap although of the better kind.

we had brunch at balthazar and enjoyed our time immensely.  our friend was a  wee bit late so we started with the champagne and OJ (ok less OJ), and had the chicken liver pate, which was delicious and smooth !  We then went on to order the crab and scrambled eggs, delicious and fresh as well as the duck confit -- OMG that was the star -- fall off the bone yummy!! 
decor was great -- loved the distressed large mirrors -- beautiful!  and the SERVICE! they were so great --  gracious and welcoming.  Love that place :)

So swanky, so glam - the attempted Shoreditch hipster in me was waiting to find something wrong at Balthazar.  A lot of the staple London must-eats have disappointed in times past. But alas. This was the real deal.
My partner booked us a spot for my Sunday Birthday lunch here. We received a perfect corner table tucked in, in the middle of the restaurant - a perfectly romantic setting.
Despite the restaurant being full - of families, couples, etc. the acoustics were great and it was easy to carry on a conversation. From a service perspective, everyone was really attentive, providing space to enjoy our meal but always coming over to keep the champagne flowing.
For food, my partner went for the eggs benedict and I opted for the eggs norwegian. We shared escargot to start. The eggs were made absolutely perfect, in fact I'm now convinced that almost every other brunch place I've ever been to needs a lesson on "how to make the proper egg".  Once our plates were delivered, we opted to have some bread from the bakery with our meal (as opposed to the basket which just seemed like too much food with everything else) - and yes, save space for the bread if you want a little taste of France with your meal.
The escargot in garlic butter was pretty much one of the best starters I've ever tried. I've attempted to now order it (thinking it was my new thing) at other restaurants since, but nothing has compared. Highly recommended even if you don't fancy yourself and escargot eater, or are trying it for the first time (though be warned...it will never be the same after). 
In short, make a special occasion with someone special and go!

I went to Balthazar years ago in New York and really like it, and I was happy to find in in London right at the heart of Covent Garden. You get that French Bistro feel as soon as you walk into the restaurant. They have a lovely display of fresh seafood: lobsters, crabs, shrimps and, of course, oysters. 
The menu here is big and quite French, so if you are in the mood for steak tartare, escargots, duck and steak and frites, you have come to the right place. Since the restaurant is in London, you can also have some British flair, like a duck shepherd's pie. We must not forget the daily specials. The evening we went was a Sunday, so I went for the ox cheek bourguignon, because the server highly recommended it to me. It was adequate but not great. The sauce was way too heavy and instead of the flavor Burgundy wine, I just tasted salt. However, the meat was well cooked. I think next time I will not ask for the waiter's recommendation and just stick with steak and frites.

Balthazar is a french brasserie set in the heart of Covent Garden. Lovely atmosphere and decor - great to take a date or your visiting guests from abroad.  The food is of a high standard - the duck confit was as good as we have sampled in France.  The afternoon tea was good value at £25 compared to the high end hotels such as the Ritz or Claridges; scones were delightful and the patisseries beautifully presented. The sandwiches were rather average and dry though.
