During the day, the venue is casual enough for children however the acoustics of the room means it gets very noisy. There were large groups of ladies-who-lunch, sipping their tea and we felt slightly out of place in the grand settings.  Highchairs available, tables a little tightly packed to house buggies. Staff were extremely helpful and friendly - top marks there. 
londonfoodiemama.wordpre…

I just had the perfect Bloody Mary. Never mind how insanely great my breakfast was (which it was). Perfect Bloody Mary. I've never even considered that there could be a perfect Bloody Mary. It's just the brunch drink. But swear to god, first sip of this and the entire world brightened up.

The London balthazar is even better than the new York balthazar!! I had a soup, sandwich and chocolate tart a SD they are delicious! I had a quiche (was not a big fan) and another chocolate rocher and that was awesome! They have mint water which is refreshing!

I was so keen to try out Balthazar in London, as I'm a fan of the NYC Original. I was not let down either.
The only blip was slightly slow service between the starters and entrees otherwise, this is a solid 4 star place.
They have managed to capture the NYC buzz within the restaurant, likely courtesy of it being in the middle of tourist central or as I also suspect, it's the damn good food and service in here.
This is an exact replica of the NYC original and we were seated promptly. I needed to try the Escargot since it's been a while since I had them - queue NYC Balthazar. DELISH!! They were so lovely, I thought each was cooked individually - not one chewy mollusk in the bunch.
Onto the scallop & courgette risotto...creamy, morish goodness. The scallops were melt in your mouth goodness. The vodka cocktail washed all of  it down nicely.
My mates had a variety of dishes and all were tucking in heartily too. Not an empty or unsatisfied stomach among us. Compliments to the chef, the helpful and friendly waitstaff and our lovely waitress.
If you haven't been and need a NYC or faux Parisian fix of coolness get in there!

Delicious brunch. I had the scrambled eggs with sourdough toast and Cornish crab, which was absolutely divine. It's not the cheapest, but certainly not too expensive. It's a popular spot so quite busy, but we still felt like we had our privacy. Bonus points for the posh bathrooms. Would definitely go back and highly recommend.

This was in all likelihood going to be the review that got away. I've spent time in the original Balthazar and had some lovely lunches but, especially in a white hot, can't get a table for love nor money, opening period, I'd resigned myself to forgetting about the London branch. And anyway, who really wants to go to the London branch of a slavish New York recreation of a traditional French bistro? I could be on the Eurostar before they'd answered the reservations line.
As it goes, it's reasonably quiet, even on a Thursday lunch, and therefore the perfect spot to slide into a banquette opposite the International Man of Mystery. He's never sure which city he's in at any given point in time, so this level of high class generic internationalism is perfect for him.
It's not cheap, their range of French classics, but if you've come here deliberately you know that and are comfortable paying £24 for a plate of Steak Frites and £17 for a burger. If you're a wall-eyed tourist who has just stumbled across its prime Covent Garden location then congratulations. You're going to be fleeced, but in a much more pleasant way than if you'd wound up in the Angus Steak House.
Get a back wall booth if you can, perfect for people watching amidst the monied buzz and much, much more room than on the cramped banquettes filling the centre of the room.
After being spoilt by their homemade bread, the ceviche starter was utterly underwhelming, a few rings of squid or octopus in a vinegary coleslaw of mandolined bell peppers and onion. From a distance it looked perfectly pleasant, but ended up being pushed around the plate.
Confit duck on the other hand was perfect. Rich and unctuous, it fell off the bone like a dark brown silk dressing gown sliding from a dressmakers dummy. Definitely a contender for comfort dish of the year, though at the price it bloody well should be.
It's a lovely cavernous space, with decent food slightly over-assiduous staff (that'll be the New York influences rather than the French) but for the money, the ambience and the attitude, I'd much rather be in Zedel, sucking down champagne with the money I've saved on my steak. If it's a power lunch that I need, then I'll be back at the Wolesley first.

On a freezing night in November, some friends and I stepped in for what we thought would be one beverage. 
The ambiance is warm and the wait staff was knowledgeable and enjoyable, so we ended up sticking around for hours. 
We sat in the bar area so I don't have insight on the food, but I was served good whisky and great conversation. 
Tip: the bathroom is upstairs and tricky to access with anyone else, so it's not recommended to travel in packs.

Went for Saturday brunch.
Coffee was great, but my meal was blasé.  No one else at my table seemed to be all that jazzed about their meals, either.  I ordered the New York pancakes and, to be clear, these pancakes are not 'New York' pancakes, nor is there any such thing, for that matter.  They are, perhaps, an attempt at American-style pancakes, but that's about it.  In any event, this New Yorker who arrived with an appetite for some heavenly pancakes wasn't impressed with the effort.  Folks who enjoy more of a Dutch-style pancake (mmmm, lekker!), for example, would also be greatly disappointed in this effort.  They just weren't good pancakes in any regard.  Fairly decent pancakes are just so easy that to get them all wrong speaks volumes of a restaurant's kitchen.  
I also ordered a side of scrambled eggs, and the eggs arrived barely above room temperature and, as with the pancakes, were fairly bland and disappointing.  Again, eggs are not astrophysics in the world of culinary arts, so c'mon Balthazar.  Get it together.
As a side note, I'm really tired of these otherwise fabulous U.S. restaurants and businesses (Balthazar, Shake Shack, Whole Foods) opening up spots in London, getting a ton of business from their reputation in the U.S., but then half-@ssing it over here in the UK and getting away with serving sub-par dishes that would make most of the kids back in the States grimace, and certainly the New York crowd.
In sum, Balthazar London is just no match for the New York location, and not even close.  In fact, I don't think that Balthazar would have ever made a name for itself if the dishes flying out of its New York kitchen were as boring as those at its London location.  Such a shame.

I'm a big fan of Balthazar in New York, so was over to the moon to hear one had opened in Covent Garden. While the look and feel of the restaurant is similar to the original in NYC, it's lacking a little something that I can't quite put my finger on.   While the food is nice, it can be a little bland - the burger for example, at £17 you'd hope for something with a little more pizzazz. But it's a cute little stop off if you fancy grabbing a coffee and one of their lovely pastries. You can sit in a little area by the bar, do some people watching, not break the bank.   The real winner here is the bread & desserts (not at the same time) - which I know may sound odd, but it's certainly one to try. The Pavlova is lovely.

I love the fact that this place was totally abuzz at 10:45 on a Friday eve.  Most places in London are shutting down and shooing you out, but not here.  Here we were welcomed in with open arms to be served and fed and not rushed out even as they were closing.
Great traditional French menu and wine.  Bring on the escargot, steak tartare and dauphinoise s'il vous plait!

With Shake Shack, 5 Guys, and Balthazar all in the same area, I wouldn't be surprised if American restaurants slowly infiltrate Covent Garden the way Chinatown did to Little Italy in Manhattan.  Bring over Trader Joe's, and then we'll talk.
Despite the quick seating and the fabulous service, I never really understood the hype of Balthazar in New York either.  I loved its baked goods, but I was never blown away by their food.  Same with my experience at Balthazar in London.  Bf's Balthazar Bar Steak (16 quid) was tender and juicy, my 22 quid bouillabaisse (a special only on Friday) was delicious, but it's definitely more of a place to be seen and checked out, rather than a place you'd go for your anniversary.
Do, however, get the 10 quid raspberry souffle, even if it takes 10 minutes to make. I would skip the clafouftis as it was pretty dense.

Came to their cafe in search of some awesome baked goodies for lunch -- and walked away thrilled!
I had a sticky bun and the salami/mozzarella/tomato (or something like that) sandwich on a potato-onion roll -- loved both of them. The sticky bun is both dense, chewy, and perfectly flaky, with rich flavor and texture. The sandwich was also quite flavorful and the bread certainly unique! 
A friend bought a scone box (which was actually rather well-priced) and I've a mind to go back to try it later.
Staff are very friendly and seem to really enjoy working there (and like interacting with the tourists). Definitely go!

Came in on a Monday evening 7pm with 3 other girlfriends without a reservation. We were seated promptly without a wait-- we're off to a great start! Our waiter was knowledgable about the specials and was helpful without being too pushy. The restaurant itself is grand. High ceilings, chandeliers, wine bottles were lined up on the wall of the bar, and a plethora of fresh oysters and shrimp were displayed on ice. 
I started off with a chicken liver/foie gras appetizer. Very generous portions and tasty. For the main, I ordered the grilled dover sole and it was perfectly cooked! My friends ordered the lobster spaghetti, salmon, and steak frites and they all enjoyed their dishes as well. If I wasn't a broke college student, I would have ordered the chocolate souffle for dessert-- it sounded divine!
Balthazar is a great place to people watch and treat yourself. The ambience is ornate, the service is wonderful and prompt. A little pricy, but I'd definitely come back!

The plan was to come here for a late Saturday Brunch and get some eggs. We arrived to find a queue but had looking booked, so we went straight through. After we walked in and were seated I managed to glimpse so amazing dishes which made me think twice about the original plan. I ended up going for the burger. Cooked to preference, with a great homemade sauce and bun. It also came swimming in a sea of French fries. Normally I wouldn't complain but maybe it was a bit too much as I don't like to waste food. My partner stuck to the original plan and got a cheese omelette. I tried this also but it was overly cheese and quite small. Coffee was also top notch. Staff were very friendly, attentive when needed but let you get on with your meal in peace. (Visit - 09/05/2015 Lunch)

*Bolsheviks beware, seriously bourgeois review is brewing along with the coffee*
______________
Sometimes I just love being bourgeois.
Frothy coffee and pricey pastries quelquefois, really is the only way to start the day, darling.
If, like myself you were sheepishly excited at the expansion of Keith McNally's faux-Français New York establishment into exciting new territory (London), yet were NOT terribly thrilled about the prospect of hitting redial on the phone every minute for three days in vain expectation of securing a dining reservation (I mean I have so many better things to do with my precious bourgeois time, right) the Balthazar Bakery located right next the the restaurant proper may be a nice solution for a coy little indulgence - experience the atmosphere sans the wait.
Having lived a block away from the original restaurant-bakery duet in Soho NYC (I know, how bourgeois), I was of course excited to relive my (occasional) self-spoiling mornings and thus decided to breakfast à la Balthazar aujourd'hui. I was not disappointed. In fact, I was exuberantly delighted to sample their twist on a classic croque monsieur [soused in béchamel-sauce finished with Lea-and-Perrins lacerations]- the textural experience was sumptuously akin to that initial and rather glorious creme-caramel fracturing moment. I'm afraid biting through the crispy, grilled bread surface into the soft layering of jambon et fromage interior, is simply worth the excessive £4.50 it demands.
Bien sûr, the usual boulangerie window-pageant of baked goods is certainly inviting, and the gleaming white-tiled walls bedecked with cursive 'B'-inscribed wholemeal loaves exude a constructed charm one only thought possible in a Hollywood studio (you have ACTUALLY been to Paris, yah). Though I would even be so bold as to suggest that the B-B London even trumps its NYC predecessor in terms of the open space and ability to convince its patrons that they are actually there to shop (market-style) rather than just queuing for a costly caffeine and butter-filled petit déjeuner, distributed in a somewhat nonchalant and brusque manner (although that would probably be the most authentically French thing about it).
Bon appetit, comrades.

Had the Chopped Salad along with onion rings, my other guests had the Salad Nicoise and the giant Mac and Cheese. The Mac and Cheese was particularly awesome. Great way to transition back from great French vacation food to good US fare...

We had such a positive experience here, I can't wait to take the rest of our family back. My daughter and I were shopping in Covent Garden and we stopped for lunch at the bar.  I had a delicious chopped salad and the manager and bartender were so kind to chat with us and make a special crepe for my daughter who was hoping for the pancakes.  I lived in NYC for 7 years and used to love going to Balthazar.  This one is equally as great--fabulous atmosphere, staff and food--a few of the people at the bar were clearly regulars and it felt like Cheers--where everybody knows your name.

Happy dance for one of my favorite NYC staples making its way to London!
For the entire three years that I've been living in London, I've been hearing rumblings of the prodigal son, Keith McNally bringing his French brasserie juggernaut across the Atlantic. And with much fanfare and panache, the will-he-won't-he speculation finally ended last Monday evening. They're currently only open for dinner service, but brunch and lunch service is coming soon. 
After 137 tries (thanks, iPhone for keeping track) to get through the booking line last Friday morning, my fortitude was rewarded with an opening week dinner spot. So, last night we sat down for an early-ish dinner, that is very much what I remember from back home. 
The staff is an eclectic mix of London's restaurant service elite; NYC Balthazar linchpins; and an eclectic mix of French servers representing the best of The Hexagon's diverse regions. It's an impressive bunch! 
The American hospitality smacks you in the face as soon as you walk through the door. At first blush, it can be a bit much for those of us used to the cold shoulder presented at so many London establishments. But we acclimated almost immediately--it sort of made me miss home. Sigh.
Water appeared via busboy -- what!?. Our Breton waiter brought us expertly made cocktails (Brian and Tom were both poached from other top London cocktail establishments). Fine de Claires on-the-half-shell were ordered and brought in a flash. Briny and fresh, I was in heaven. Bread from their boulangerie next door was devoured with French butter (of course). 
I started with the onion soup, which was unctuous and just a little bit sweet. The hubs had a small portion of the beef tartare, which he figures is some of the best he's ever eaten--and he eats it a lot. Another member of the waitstaff recommended a bottle of red from the Jura, her home turf, that was one of the more interesting bottles of wine I've ever had. Slightly effervescent and light in color, it takes a couple of sips to fall in love, but amazing once you get there.
It accompanied the whole chicken for two very well. The chicken itself was roasted to perfection and served with jus, a mix of veg, and velvety potato puree. By this point we were stuffed to the gills, but dessert was needed--for research purposes obviously. I ordered the tart du jour, lemon with a raspberry reduction. Lemon tart is my Achilles heel as of late, and this one was very good. Although, it was more of a lemon mousse with crust, than a lemon tart. Even so, still delicious! My partner in crime had the cheesecake. It was a small portion, but it was so rich, there was no reason for more than they served. He nearly licked the plate clean. 
My only complaint at this point is the timing is a bit off. The coffee came before we had finished our dessert, and after presenting us with the whole chicken, it went back into the kitchen for plating for what seemed like an eternity; I think it was actually more like 15 minutes in human time. But it's their first week, so I imagine things will get smoother with time. 
For those of you who've fallen for the New York Balthazar, you'll recognize the room as an almost exact replica. Other brilliant American aspects include walk-in seating at the bar, the seafood tower, and a true New Yawka working the door. Did I mention the busboys? Oh, and how could I forget? It's reasonably priced; I mean, for Central London anyway.
Yes, as my husband said, it seems like the universe is finally throwing us a bone on the London dining scene. I think a standing weekend reservation may be in order.

In a word, the breakfast I had here was incredibly underwhelming, and the other people in my party said the exact same thing.  The service was not bad by any means, but the servers did come off as a little bit scattered.  My waffles were quite dry on their own, and the fact that they gave me no syrup with them really did not help.  One person in my party ordered scrambled eggs, and they were essentially in liquid form.  It was actually quite disgusting, even to look at, let alone eat it.  I know that this place has a good reputation, especially the NYC location, so I was disappointed by the experience.

Everyone was talking about it so I decided to check it out for lunch. I must say I have never been to the NYC one.
The decor is respecting what the americans probably think it is (or was?) a french posh restaurant, a  bit "ville lumiere" with a lot of big mirrors and lamps.
the food is good and the service is good and polite. My dad and I had a big steak with french fries, while my mum had an omelette. We were satisfied. 
I kinda like the place, probably will come back since I have heard that the brunch is very good.

As far as brunch spots go I'd say this place is a safe bet. The service was good and the food was tasty. The eggs Benedict was good but didn't come with a side so I was left hungry. A half order of the NY pancakes finished me off and rounded out the meal. 
The meal was expensive relative to what you get. That could be a function of the location being next to covent garden square (great place to grab a cup of coffee and listen to the street performers. Exactly what I'm doing as I write this review) or London being expensive...full stop.

As many of my fellow Yelpers have said, it's the perfect Americanized French brasserie brunch spot.  Very NYC in Londontown.  Very good service, very good eggs, very good champagne.  Amazing soufflé, worth it if it's just for that alone!  It was the perfect way to celebrate my birthday before catching the matinee performance of The Book of Mormon.

The American influx of Central London eateries continues! My mate had to book weeks in advance to scoop a Friday night reservation and the place was buzzing. Uber prime location with cool interior that lets you pretend you're in NYC (or at least that Sex and the City ep it appears in!). Very much a place to see and be seen with a price tag to match; the food is just 'ok'. Service is top notch though and left me with a smile on my face, even after a disappointingly squishy chocolate soufflé.

Setting: This restaurant is big and airy and it really feels like you could be in a mid-20th century French brasserie. The atmosphere is very relaxed and is great for brunch. Even the bathrooms are big and bright. Being in Covent Gardens this is a great location to meet someone from the other side of the city for brunch.
Service: The service was excellent. The staff were attentive, friendly and helpful without ever being overbearing. I really enjoyed this aspect of the experience.
Food: I had my first ever Escargot here and despite my hesitancy over eating snails they were delicious. As brunch goes I wold recommend the Moules Frites. The mussel portions are very generous (I was full before I got to the fries). However the fries are more crunch than substance and a thicker cut (if going off the french fry vibe a little) would make them even better. I definitely want to try the rest of the menu and would come back.

It was really just ok....and I cannot understand the hype of this establishment other than the fact it's from New York and therefore that MUST mean we should all love it for the ''New York chicness'' or whatever.......
The decor was very French bistro, the lighting all soft and yellow toned so you felt as though you walked right into an instagram photoshot. I'm sure it would be a very ''chic'' place, there is no other word but chic for this place, to hang out for brunch on Sundays. But I was not impressed with the food selection nor the quality of the seafood. 
The chairs also had no cushions on them so you were sat in this hard wooden chair for the entire evening which makes your bum sore and your skirt sticking to the back of your legs. The tables were tiny and they tried to squeeze as much cutlery, bread plates, bread baskets, glasses and what have you, on this tiny (again hard topped) table. 
There were also A LOT of tables crammed into the whole place, as if the proprietors were trying to simulate a cosy, vintage style, café atmosphere....but actually, to me, did nothing more than to increase the noise levels and made everthing appear very messy.....
Verdict - dislike!

visited Balthazar London after a number of visit at Balthazar New-York - same menu, different currency! food was excellent, as expected, although in London they have quirky hours . Seemed that the pricing was significantly higher than NYC - Why?

Visited this bakery a couple of times now for lunch. They do really tasty sarnies, and normally I'm not a huge sandwich fan. The bread they use is really good and the fillings are quite interesting - I've tried the roast beef and celeriac slaw in a focaccia and the ham and butter baguette - it has hidden tiny gherkins! Yum! They sell salad boxes and lots of different yummy looking cakes (unfortnately haven't sampled any yet).
The bakery has a couple of counter style seats inside but not many. The place is quite pricey for a bakery but I would say worth it if you need a lunch time treat to brighten your day!

I come here for brunch at the weekends or for lunch when I'm not feeling well. Sometimes when I dine alone I receive a complementary glass of sparkling wine, which definitely helps me to feel better. 
The brunch pancakes are superbly well balanced with fruit, syrup, and creme freche. And for lunch my favourite is to have the skate wing, which is cooked just like my Mum used to. Whatever I have I find the flavour combinations to be perfectly balanced. Unfortunately the price is a little higher than I would like so I don't come as often as I want.

Came here last night. This is a lovely traditional looking French restaurant with American features. I was bewitched by the interior and by the very good service. They put a rush on for us when we let them know we had a show to get to, but it didn't affect the quality. I had the garlic prawns to start with the most delicious olive bread. The sauce was rich with the aroma of prawn and fish; very moreish! I then moved on to the steak frites but I found the sirloin a bit tough. I had someone else's fillet and that was perfectly seasoned and tender. Don't go for the house sparkling white unless you prefer it less brut. The champagne was much better. We also had a Pinot noir which was excellent. I had a brilliant evening in this vibrant and buzzy restaurant. Truly I can't wait to go back!

Been going to the New York one since the the 90s, never had a bad experience, the one in London is a copy of the NY one intern of atmosphere, service quality, and quality of dishes.. Few dishes are different in the menu in London.  Very good wine list reasonably priced.

Well get that dialing finger at the ready because you're going to need to book ahead. This isn't a 'let's wander around Covent Garden and see what we find' kind of place, but once you're in, you'll be glad you did. 
The service is very American, which is lovely and refreshing at times, it's nice to be a bit catered to by an army of staff. The decor, like everyone has noted, is a replica of the NY one with loads of French charm. We did a brunch and aside from one of the best bloody marys I've had, the food was pretty epic. An eggs benedict that will not leave you feeling peckish afterwards.. oysters, baked mac & cheese, soufflé... you can easily go overboard with the decadence meter but you'll have to do it sometime, no?
There's a bakery attached where you can take away some of the tempting sweets and fresh breads. It's a must stop for anyone that loves eating, you'll agonize over what to order and end up getting the entire menu like we did. It's not totally overpriced either, for what you get it's actually quite reasonable.
Wow. What lovely bread. The new salad of beets and carrots with burnt orange dressing  is just out if this world. The steak au poivre was just perfect and the service top notch.  I'm coming back.

Sadly this was a let down and isn't a patch on the NYC one. I suspect the location in London is one of the issues as it ends up being full of tourists and almost feels like an Angus Steak House!
Our waiter knew diddly about the menu and when i asked for a standard drink - fresh lime and soda, he got a proper sweat on and then told me they didn't stock that cocktail?! 
The actual brunch was so so but nothing special.

Yum! Had read negative professional reviews in the papers and was hesitant to try it, but so glad I took the plunge.
Pros: Lovely ambiance (similar to Delaunay), excellent front of house staff, excellent waitstaff. Asked to have table changed during a busy lunch hour as wanted more privacy for a lunch meeting and was accommodated immediately and gracefully. 
Plats du jour are an excellent deal. Food is consistent, menu is varied, pricing very reasonable for quality of food. Balthazar house salad had just the perfect touch of truffle oil and seasonal ingredients. Mains are superb. Even the bread basket offers a step up from the standard dry baguette that one finds elsewhere. And the takeaway bakery next door is charming.
Cons: Forced to come up with something, simply that there can be a bit of wait it seems others have discovered this gem as well!

Done the NY one. Enjoyed the buzz. So when it opened here in London we thought we should give it a try.
But getting in at a reasonable time is a different matter. All booked up.
Just so happens we had tickets for Charlie and the chocolate factory at Drury Lane on Thursday. 7.30 kick off. Balthazar right outside. Why not try a pre-theatre raid.
A 6pm table of 3 was duly booked. We got there on time and the place was already busy. The bar was full and three quarters of the tales were taken. Bags were swiftly taken and we were at our table.
Balthazar London feels exactly the same as New York. Loud. Thronging. hot. Nicely decked out in authentic French brasserie tiling and furniture. Serving staff whizz round all over the gaff and there is a big seafood bar at the back to whet the appetite. This is proper tourist London stuff, and I don't mean that in a bad way. Slap bang in the middle of covent garden and full of hip things out for a good time. It feels great.
The menu is what you'd expect from a good French brasserie. Nice bread arrived to munch on, plenty of it. Followed by a good moules et frites which was lifted by the inclusion of caramelised fennel. The boy had macaroni cheese sans the bacon and the missus had a skirt steak that was full of taste. 
My chip were a little soggy was my only complaint on the food. But it was pretty expensive for what we got I thought.
However, you're paying for the great atmosphere, not the food. And for a bit of a treat if you're painting good old London Town red, it's definitely got it. Go there and show out. It's fun. Not perfect food and a bit pricey but great fun nonetheless. Not quite a 4 but a high 3 stars well earned.
Nb If I did theatre reviews I Would give Charlie and the chocolate factory 6 stars. It was truly brilliant. And I hate the theatre.  Book it. And try Balthazar before for a proper night out!
The place was heaving by the time we left at 7. So do book.

Popped into the small takeaway section next door to the main restaurant, greeted promptly by the very friendly staff, purchased a selection of fresh bread (you can ask for half a loaf if you require) this time I got a spelt, white and an olive ciabatta. The olive ciabatta is one if the tastiest I've ever had, loads of flavour and full of olives! 
Good selection of fresh sandwiches and small cakes to tempt you.
Located very close to the piazza.

Well priced for what you get. Superbly cooked sharing steaks and sparkling service from our supremely rude (in a naughty way!) French waiter who's grasp of innuendo was second to none. Desserts were also pretty good and was overjoyed that they resisted the urge to put a f***ing raspberry or dome such in the bottom of their creme brûlée (a pet hate of mine and all too common these days)
Thank you for our lovely meal, pre and post opera. Food delicious, service excellent. Staff very knowledgeable and kind. Thank you.

A Near exact replica of the famous SoHo location in NYC, i have to love this spot as it reminds me of home. With classics like moules frites, steak tar tar, the seafood platter and excellent bloody marys, this is the perfect brunch spot for any event.

The bar is very impressive.  This is the sort of place the word über was invented for.  The wine list is great, the bar menu is great, it isn't cheap and doesn't feel it.  I was only here for drinks and snacks.  If you're in Covent Garden and haven't decided on where to go this wouldn't be a bad place to start.
Impressive dining room,  nice for a special treat. I've been for breakfast twice now and had the avocado on toast with poached egg. Lovely. They have a private dining room now for larger groups.

On a recent trip, went to Balthazar with a friend who had great food at Balthazar in the past. Possibly this was the one-off day but the food was very average. We both essentially got a steak and it wasn't great. The wine though was brilliant - we got recommendation from the sommelier and it was a great suggestion. Will visit again though since it possibly was just a busy Friday eve.

Spent an enjoyable afternoon over a classy bottle of beautiful tasting wine and a bowl of mussels and fries cooked to perfection, what more do you want in life. The ambience is great, the staff are attentive and understand how to look after the customers. Great place, priced accordingly but worth it.

I had to wait for my friend so I spent about 45 minutes in the bar area. I love the bar! Great selection of wines and friendly bartenders. Food was excellent. I had the beetroot dish for a starter, the salmon with spinach and lentils for my main, and chocolate for dessert. Service was excellent. I actually felt like I was in New York in this restaurant, they've definitely captured the NYC buzz.

Went here last night with 3 friends, good atmosphere although very noisy (we were in a nice semi-circular booth but I could hardly hear my friend across from me). Started with a cocktail, nice but at £10.50 a little steep for a small glass with a lot of ice. Food was tasty, I had fish pie which was rich but delicious, packed with fish, then the lemon posset for dessert, which was fine but nothing special.  Overall I came away with a bill for £50 (including a glass of wine) and felt that for the quality of the meal (and the wine), although good, it was a little overpriced. I had been expecting more because of the hype. Service was excellent. I probably wouldn't go again, too many amazing choices in London!

Ambiance: perfect, busy, cute French bistro restaurant!
Service: friendly, helpful, and a little slow. ( which you should expect from the French, they like to take their time)
Food: perfect menu. Lobster, cooked perfectly, oysters, nice selection shucked just right, French onion was ok, nothing to ride hoe about. 
Reason for a 4: Balthazar in NY is better. They have a better selection of seafood. In NY, you can order jumbo prawns that are a true jumbo.  Also the baked bread in NY is fresher.  I still enjoyed the London restaurant and would highly recommend it.
Nice ambiance, great service, but definitely overpriced. Ordered the spaghetti with lobster--expected the meal to be a lot tastier. Overall, a good experience; I'd go back to try something new.

Great bakery (haven't tried the restaurant). One of my fav stops in Covent Garden. Try the delicious spinach and mushroom croissant. Lovely presentation too.
Super friendly staff and classic European (French) look. The classical music soundtrack is a bit old-fashioned but frankly better than some of the pretentious affect-pop one might hear in the more hipster coffee shops.
A place that makes one feel good. If prices were a little lower, I'd give 5 stars (but they're within the norm).

A "New York" brunch never quite had the perfect venue in London. There were a number of places that came close: Breakfast Club, Automat, Tom's Kitchen all came close in my books... but none ever truly captured the essence and food (read: pancakes) of those Saturday and Sunday mornings that I used to spend in Manhattan. Balthazar, which looks and feels identical to her sibling across the Atlantic, fits this niche perfectly. The food is well executed (the Huevos Rancheros were delicious during my visit this weekend), the staff attentive, the room well decorated, the sound level loud without being deafening. Balthazar is a place I could see myself returning to for dinner, for a drink... and certainly for another weekend brunch with friends.

Came here for breakfast. Familiar with Balthazar from New York and was eager to try a traditional full English breakfast. it was yummy and didn't disappoint. My husband got some selection of pastries and jams. Carb overload but he enjoyed it. Overall, it was as expected: good food, a little pricey, and a little crowded. Not sure if I would even consider returning here for dinner as it seems to get booked up and there are tons of amazing places to have dinner in London (*cough cough Great Queen Street *cough cough*).

We booked Balthazar for a pre-theatre supper on my birthday. First impressions were great as we arrived early to have drinks at the busy bar. It had a buzzy atmosphere at 5pm and we ordered drinks whilst we waited for our table. I had an Aperol spritz which was watery and rather expensive for 9.50 but we perused the menu which sounded good and got shown to a nice corner table. This is where it all started to unravel. The wine list is ludicrously expensive and we ordered two half bottles as the house wines did not appeal. I ordered saffron risotto to start which had 1.1/2 (!) scallops on the top. It arrived with a skin on it so had either been sat waiting to be served or had been microwaved to high heaven. My boyfriend's game pate was not pate, more like a thick over seasoned terrine. Bread was a little stale and butter ice cold. My main was 1/2 a lobster which arrived served on a bed of ice with no fork or cracker to open it. Every time I tried to get some flesh out it was submerged in a slushy, icy bath and it felt like I got an 1/8 of a lobster! Pretty revolting and served with what appeared to be Heinz seafood sauce. My boyfriend's duck shepherd's pie was greasy, small and swimming in fat. All in all the bill came to £160 which we certainly anticipated, but for this price range you would expect high quality French food. We will not be returning, considering brasserie Zedel is not too far away and has a far more spectacular ambience for half the price I cannot believe Balthazar gets away with the terrible expensive food it has to offer. Please save your money and go elsewhere! London has so much more to offer than this overpriced mediocrity!

Very attentive staff made our first visit to Balthazar easily enjoyable. We didn't have a reservation but were promptly seated. Girlfriend had the eggs royale, I had the eggs hussard both of which were absolutely delicious. 
Afterwards we shared the waffles which were a bit dry and didn't come with enough berry sauce to make a difference. Staff very helpful again though and brought a generous serving of chocolate sauce on the side. 
Menu a bit boring but exactly what you would expect from a bistro brunch. 
Great service. Most food excellent. 
Highly recommended.
Simple set menu with everything cooked perfectly! Sometimes it's nice to have very few options. This place does one thing very well. Steak and frites!

This was one of the first meals that I had in London and it was really good. This restaurant is known for two things, steak and fries. The restaurant loves serving this so much that it is actually the only two things they have on the whole menu.  The steak was cooked perfectly. Also just when you think you are done they bring you out more steak and fries so that you can have even more.  
The waiters and waitresses are just nice but not the friendliest of people I have ever met.  The food was really good, but the place inside was not the largest.  
The best part about this place is the simplicity of it and the fact that you know your going to get good steak and good fries when you come here.  I would highly recommend to people looking for steak and fries in London to try this place out!

This is probably one of my favorite places in London. The atmosphere is very good inside, always crowded so may be you will need to wait outside to wait for your table! But trust me it worth it. There is no menu only one menu salad, meat and chips thats it. But everything is cooked with heart and Quality always same. Enjoy it!!!

Just amazing. The most delicious restaurant for steak and fries in London. I've been to the one in Paris, and the one in New York City and they are all spectacular. This one does not disappoint. And if you see a line out front don't worry it moves quickly.

A great dinner here with two close friends.  Atmosphere and pace is frenetic, but the close tables and loud conversation levels leads to a very communal experience.
The steak Porte Maillot with "special sauce" was executed perfectly...especially since it is the only main dish on the menu!  You simply chose the "doneness" of the meat.  By American standards, we ordered the "medium" version and it came out medium-rare (my actual preference)...just know this to help determine your desired meat temp.
The salad was simple and elegant, three total ingredients and that mustard-based dressing was certainly unusual but quite tasty!
We shared a bottle of their house (red) wine and I had a nice dessert with ice cream and bitter chocolate "balls" (les profiteroles au chocolat).
A fantastic meal in a lively setting, what more could you want?
Delicious food, friendly customer service...I love the  sauce it is definitely special and hard to find any where else. I can't wait to go back here in my next visit to London.
Mmmm this place takes the cake in how to create a hype, not much to write home about.. Dresserts aren't bad though

We went for lunch and loved it.  It's a fixed menu that includes a green salad, thinly sliced steak, and French fries.  When you think you're done, you aren't because they will bring your second serving of meat.  The quality of the food was excellent and the atmosphere very nice too, although tables are very close together.

A little bit of Paris in London. The authentic Entrecôte right in the heart of Marleybone. From the service to the atmosphere to the food it's exactly like the original in Paris. Well done! This will be a regular stop on my London trips

When there's one item on the menu, you better believe they get that right. Your only choice is "How would you like that cooked?". I picked medium rare, but the waitress informed me that this is cooked in the French style and medium would equal my idea of a medium rare.
A salad was delivered first, which was greatly appreciated! The salad was a really nice, light touch to what would be a heavy hearty meal. Then the steak arrived with french fries, both which melted in your mouth.
For dessert, we ordered the tower of ice cream and meringue (i forgot what it was called) and the profiteroles. The latter was my favorite of the two.
Excellent steak. Love the "Secret Sauce" great service. Opens at 1800. Be there early or stand in line.
Excellent food. Perfect salade, perfect steak, sauce and fries. 4 stars and not 5 because you can't book and the queue can be horrendous.

Melt in your mouth steak L'entricote with that classic sauce they do. I don't know what exactly is in it, but always ask for an extra pot on the side it's so damn good. 
Just when you think you've devoured it all, they come back with a full second portion of all this too. Ohhh seconds?? Yes please.
All this is after you enjoy a wardorf salad as part of your main, which is fab too.
This place has a few restaurants around town as well as NYC and Paris were it originated from. With one thing on the menu, sit back, order a glass of red wine and wait for the sensory delights to arrive (twice). It's consistently good whichever branch I've been at (note- I once went Canary Wharf and they had 50% off at weekends).

"WOOHOO! AS GOOD AS IT GETS" definitely describes this place. A friend first brought me here on a cold day where we ended up waiting 20 minutes for a table. But I came back the following week with friends, and then again with my family, until we figured out it was best to come before it opens to be the first wave of customers in. And then it became a regular thing with anyone visiting, ever. Or any catch up, or any birthday celebrations - yes - we're going to Le Relais de Venise L'Entrecote for dinner.
The experience starts with a mouth watering walnut salad with this yummy sauce, but the unspeakably good star of the show is the sauce that comes with the steak. Let me rewind a bit and say that steak and fries is all you're gonna get. You tell the waitress how you like it (blue, rare, medium or well done - there is no in-betweens), she writes it on the table and off she goes. When it comes out - you are presented with a plate of delicious steak and fries to mop up all the excess sauce you manage not to cram in on every single bite. 
I was so shocked the first time I came here because, as normal, I finished my meal in record time still lusting for more. AND MORE THERE WAS. The waitress comes back with the SECOND HALF (?!?!) of your meal, the steak that was still in the kitchen so that it won't go cold, and an extra helping of fries. Lord have mercy.
And once you think you can't go on, you have a look around and get massive food envy as all these delicious looking desserts start piling out. Now, I don't speak french so you're just gonna have to figure this one out on the menu yourself but the MUST orders are the profiteroles (which I usually don't like, but these are filled with vanilla ice cream instead of cream and are DELICIOUS!) and this stack of ice cream, meringue, praline, amazingness.
This place is definitely a 10/10 in my books!

I don't understand what the whole fuss is about: we waited in the queue outside (or in American term: we waited in the line!) Then we were served two small portions of steak with a special sauce but frankly speaking I had much better steaks but the fries was great. The waitress was super serious and when we asked to have our photo taken, she commented that if it is quick! I know it is hectic but a photo at most takes 10 seconds! Anyway, I don't think I will go back here.
I was told rare is bleeding but what I really got was medium rare, no blood, and the famous sauce that was really just supplementary rather then complimentary to the very mediocrely cooked meat...

This place had only our reserved table free when we arrived, it was packed and I understood why after we ate! The menu is set and in my opinion, perfect. They start you off asking how you like your meat and then bring you a little tasty salad with a mustard vinaigrette. Shortly after you finish your salad they bring you a plate with a semi small amount of steak in peppercorn sauce and fries. Don't worry about the size! They come around after you've eaten your way through it with plate refills of fries AND steak! I was full from my first plate (looks can be deceiving with size! Eyes bigger than stomach!) I can say without any doubt this is the best steak I've ever eaten. It was cooked perfectly and the meat was flawless, zero gristle to trim and full of flavor. I had a delightful Peruvian beer with dinner and creme brûlée for dessert - my man had a small bottle of red wine. The waitress was friendly and checked in with us a few times. I dream of this meal!

Intimate and vibrant french restaurant that serves up only one dish, which is steak and frites. The cut is "La Entrecôte" which is the cut from the ribs.
You only need to make two choices:
1. What to drink?
2. How you like your meat prepared; rare, medium or well
After that it is cruise control. The meal starts with salad dressed with a mustard dressing and bread. Next comes the delicious steak and frites. The surprise is the second serving of both steak and frites. That put a smile on my face.

Yes, it hit the spot!  Simple and Delicious steak and frites! That sauce is A+
Highlights:  Steak cooked to perfection with generous portions of frites...plus SECONDS! Reasonably priced, Good and fast service all inside a nice, clean and big dinning area.  Also, desserts are awesome.  
Can improve:  Take reservations and Give Ketchup or Tomato Sauce.
Benchmark:  I am not a big steak & frites guy and even I found it irresistible.  They set the steak & frites benchmark in my book.
Word of advice:  They don't take reservations so go early when they open for dinner around 7 pm and you should have no problem getting a table.
Dined in April 2016 and will definitely return.

We arrived when they opened and got right in.  The service was excellent and the food was delicious.  I loved that I didn't have to decide what to eat, just told them how I like my meat cooked and they take it from there. The salad was fresh and delicious, they provided bread which was crispy on the outside and soft inside.  The steak was perfectly sliced and done to my liking. The sauce was amazing, and the fries were perfectly cooked.  They even offer you a second helping if you want. For desert we tried the Le Vacherin du Relais, it was layers of meringue and ice cream topped with hot chocolate and whip cream - it was incredible. I wish they had a location in Los Angeles where I live.

Great restaurant experience here. Excellent service, perfectly cooked steak and delish crispy French fries. We had the house red wine which was also very good. They have a location in New York too that I want to try :)

Le Relais de venise only does one thing, but it does it well: steak frittes. On being seated, the server will ask how you want your steak cooked - if you're vegetarian and/or have a nut allergy, this is your opportunity to shout. The green salad brought to you before your main has walnuts on top, but if you ask for them to be left off, it's not a problem. What may be a bigger problem is that the chips are cooked in groundnut oil - if you have a peanut allergy, you will starve.
I believe vegetarians can substitute their steak for a lot of cheese, but it's an expensive option. £24 for steak frittes or £24 for fromage frittes with a dessert. If you're a veggie, I just wouldn't bother.
The steak is brought to you in two parts, which effectively works out as two giant plates of cow and chips, so it's a big undertaking. My advice is to skip lunch because if you can't finish the main, you will be disappointed with yourself.
The desserts are around the £5/£6 mark and are nice (the crème brûlée is a reliable offering) however you will probably be too full to manage one. House wine (around £5 a glass, £10 for a carafe, £20 for a bottle) is drinkable enough.
You can't book a table even if you're a group, so eat early (5.30pm) or expect to queue out the door. Although tables are a little close, that's because there are a lot of people who want to get in and don't mind sitting on their neighbours.
All in all, this isn't a cheap meal, but it's a substantial one, cooked well.

This is my second time here for dinner. I won't say the food isn't good but what I can say is the service is really a DISASTER! 
One girl who served at our table always put on a shit face and was very rude. We had four people here and she was keeping pushing the table to my friends side which made them really uncomfortable, and she didn't say anything about that. Apart from that, my friends went shopping afternoon so they had some big bags, in case that those would block the aisle, they saved their belongings temporarily at the cloakroom. When we about to leave and asked staff to get the stuff back, one girl just stared at us with very disgusting face and chose to ignore us.
So, if you want to experience this kind of world standard shit service, please come here, I bet you've got little temper to lose here.

YES! FINALLY A RESTAURANT THAT COOKS MY STEAK THE WAY I LIKE IT! 
(sorry for the all-caps intro, but I'm just so happy!!)
So, anyone who, like me, likes their steak rather under than over and is getting tired of the whole 'the least we can cook it is medium rare' bullsh*t, head to Le Relais de Venise. 
But with the food being so good and the whole thing being VERY good value for money, you'll most probably have to queue. Though chances are I'll be in the queue too, so maybe we can have a little chat then?
It's one of those London things.. although not exclusively. Sauce is delicious. Meat is good quality. Salad is yummy too! No nonsense place for a fun casual meal.

My first Le Relais experience was in Paris where I accidentally walked into that restaurant. And I enjoyed that experience. When I learned that there was another version in London, I had to make sure I had to bookmark it on my trip here.
Walking in the London version, it even feels like you're in Paris. The tables are very cramped and that you are literally right next to another stranger only inches away. So you need to pull out the table to move around.
And just like the Paris versions, there are no menus. Just steak and frites with a small salad in the beginning. But it's the sauce that makes this place standout compared to other steak joints. It has a nice, tangy vinaigrette flavor that only this restaurant can provide. The steaks by themselves are just normal steaks, served in only "Rare" or "Medium." Even "medium rare" is not allowed. Again, just rare or medium here in London.
And just like the Paris version, you get your second serving shortly after you finished your first plate. 
And as for the dessert, you may need one of the French waitresses to help you out since the menu is in French. But I went with the Profiteroles au chocolat. Nice warm chocolate smothering some vanilla ice cream with shaved walnuts. Now that is a great way to finish the meal.

The steak was excellent. I loved it. The fries were excellent--very crisp without being dry and not too fat. The sauce was probably the best part about it, however. I feel like I've gotten comparable steak and fries elsewhere, but the sauce really brought the whole dish together. It really makes you wanna go back for more and more! I will say, however, that I've had better steak elsewhere. I may have a skewed view, though, because I had a really intense conversation with relatives while eating there and was somewhat distracted. Overall, though, this place was amazing! I'd totally come here again if I am in the neighborhood.

Excellent, faultless meal.
The service was attentive and efficient, but most importantly -- savvy. We all know they're trying to get customers through quickly (this place must make a FORTUNE!); however, I never felt even a little rushed. Everything was perfectly timed to allow us to enjoy a relaxed meal.
The house Bordeaux is super drinkable, not overly tannic, and well-balanced (even if slightly lacking in depth), with a seemingly minimal price markup for a bottle. 
What you get is what you come for. Delicious steak and fries. It's an excellent and simple meal perfectly executed. What more does one need to say? 
Show up early if you don't want to wait, otherwise, expect to wait!

I was meeting a girlfriend for lunch and she wanted to go to Le Relais de Venise.  I was excited because it's in my neighbourhood and I've been wanting to check it out because I've heard great things about it.
Food: There's no menu.  They only serve steak frites and as much as you want of it.  They will ask how you would like your meat cooked.  They then start off with a simple salad, the steak comes in small slices, frites and a wonderful sauce that makes you want more.  Very simple.
Drinks: We ordered one sprite and tap water.
Price: 56.10 GBP for two people.
Ambiance: The restaurant feels like a true bistro in Paris.  It was very crowded and bustling for lunch.  It's first come, first serve and they will not seat your party until everyone is there.  
Service: This is why I gave three stars.  Here's where everything went wrong.  The service was horrible.  Our server was a woman who seemed like she hated her job.  She didn't have the time of day for us.  She was very unfriendly, curt, rude and kept bumping into my girlfriend's chair without even saying I'm sorry.  There was a table next to us that was empty and when they were about to seat two people she looked at the diners, said "oh sh*t" and then slammed down the cutlery and glasses onto the table.  The icing on the cake was when she was serving me the frites and dropped one in to my water glass.  She didn't apologise or even come back to replace my water.  I waited for 10 minutes, asked for a new glass of water only to find her very annoyed.
Would I go back?  Maybe.  I wouldn't rush back and if I did go back I would definitely not sit in the section of that server if she's still there.
Love this place. No choices, just a question of how you want your steak cooked. Amazing salad; a few wine choices. This is the epitome of do one thing and do it well.

One of the best restaurants in the chain compared to other locations. Always good prompt service and the food is great. You know it's good when there is such a line outside waiting to get in, so it may be better to turn up a little bit earlier than you want to eat, just in case.

The steak was good but not as good as some of the other locations. The restaurant was crowded and the service staff did not care much. We went quite early so even though they don't take reservations we were able to get a table fast.

They only have one entree on the menu and that is steak. When you get there, you are asked, how do you want your steak. So the only other decision you have to make it is what to drink and what dessert to order. 
They serve a good, fresh and healthy salad. Then comes the most sumptuous steak ever. Melt in your mouth, flavourful steak, with chips (fries). When you are done, they bring you a second serving of steak and chips.
Amazing food, fast efficient service, and very affordable. One of my favourite spots in London, as well as in Geneva. 
Be prepared to wait in line as they don't accept reservations. I have stood in line on weekdays as well.

It's a good dinner but just prepare to wait in the long line around the corner. It's all you can eat so you do get some bang for your buck. I do think there are better places  to get steak. The meat wasn't particularly good and the tight tables are a bit claustrophobic.

I hate decisions.
So, you can see...that means I quite love Le Relais de Venise L'Entrecote (especially when a colleague selects it, and the time) -- even though I can scarcely remember the ordering of its name. 
I assure you though, once you've been -- you'll never forget! 
To do but one thing so well, is sometimes as magical as the green sauce the steak and chips come drizzled in. What LRdVLE lacks in choice, it makes up for 10-fold in quality. 
You'll get this, my pretties: 
1. Steak. (the ONE option is -- "how would you like this cooked?")
2. Salad. 
3. Chips. 
4. Greeeeeeeeeen sauce. 
In perpetuity. Served by lovely French people in trim black and white uniforms. 
Quite fabulous for a business lunch (though it does fill up quickly) -- as you'll not be waiting around for everyone to make decisions and can be back to your office swiftly. The guesswork has been removed. You'll be having steak. And salad. And chips. And that green sauce everyone moans about for days and days... 
And if you're like me, you'll be thrilled. Yum. So French and so disciplined. 
*no reservations. 
*great deals at their Canary Wharf location, ask the servers.

There is only one thing on the menu, apparently that's a bit of a trend around London right now (see Burger & Lobster). Delicious steak and frites, which also comes with a starter salad. The steak sauce is super buttery so prepare for a post meal coma. Also neat how they serve your main in two portions so the second half stays hot, thoughtful!

Bloody Hell (for lack of a better commonwealth expression, I apologize), this place is fabulous!
I arrived at 6pm (when they open for dinner) sharp after attending the theater, and the line was already one block long!  We were the last group to be seated snagging the final open table, and we had a minimal wait of 10 minutes.  If I had to wait 45 minutes, I would have done it gladly.
Intriguing fact number 1: There was no menu. I was so confused. My date (sister in law) was getting the giggles off the bat watching me trying to piece together this culinary puzzle. A lady came to take our order, simply asking how we liked our meat. Strange, what if I wanted fish....? I said rare, and then she took a marker to my side of the table with a large "R" (clearly it is paper table cloths!) 
Intriguing fact number 2: Then they brought out a salad. I didn't ask for a salad, but I certainly didn't send it back!  Butter leaf lettuce with walnuts and a mustard vinegrette. It was so simple and yum! 
Then the waitress came to the table and served me beautifully butterflied steak strips with a green sauces and hot chips.  The chips were long, skinny and crunchy!  And the meat, well, it was one of the best meals I've ever had. The meat is imported from Scotland, and it is in a league of it's own!!!  Intriguing fact number 3: I got my entree, twice! Oh yes, what is better than one delicious meal? Having two helpings of it! SO don't worry when you polish off your plate.... more is coming!!!
Head out there (early) so that you can roll out of there like I did, content and happy as a clam. I wish we had one of these in Nor cal because I would be there all the time!!!

You ever meet those people that are really, REALLY good at one thing? Like, you have that roommate you went to school with who knows trivia from "The Matrix" movies better than anyone, or there was that girl you crushed on who could mop the floor with anyone on Wednesday nights when the local pub is having trivia for the week and the theme is H.P. Lovecraft and you're both impressed and terrified? This place is like your friend, only they are incredibly good at serving steak and fries. Oh, and being awesomely personable. And being able to tolerate a table of out-of-towners (from Texas, to boot) with the patience and sass of someone who can easily blend patience and sass while also convincing me to have not one but two scotches after a bottle of wine. Yes, this place and the staff are that good.
We arrived around 8:00 on a Friday night per the recommendations of the locals. The place is a small restaurant with a line wrapping around the corner and extending back into a corner of an alley where you can look up at the guy living in the apartment across from the place who methodically paces while on the phone and organizes his shoe collection (sorry guy who lives across the place - but your shoe collection is boss). There's a reason people are willing to wait 45+ minutes in the cold and rain for this place. And if you're still reading this review, you're about to find out why.
We probably waited around 25 minutes, but we got lucky. A professional and polite hostess greeted us at the door when our turn in line had come and we were walked to a table in a crowded dining room. Let there be no doubt: L'Entrecote has figured out how to maximize their space and the maximum occupancy here is probably 6,000 despite being the size of my hotel's lobby. You'll be making new friends at your table, such as the traveling couple next to us who were absolutely sweet, so if you're shy, you may need to get over that real quick.
Our waitress came over and took our order and immediately panic sunk in. No "medium rare" steak?! Send me back to Texas where our beef is still moo-ing when you cut into it! Turns out there was nothing to fear as the "medium" steak was heavenly. My advice would be to placate the salad beforehand and save room for the main course. Don't get me wrong - the salad may rock your socks off but the steak and fries will also send your socks to the cleaners and bring them back with a complimentary breath mint. 
The whole place operates on a "steak and fries are our entrees" menu, and there's a reason: the sauce. If you've tasted their sauce and found it anything less than a miracle on your plate, please book a trip to the local funeral parlor because you clearly were born without a soul. I went back for seconds, another in our party went back for thirds. Add all this up on our bottle of red wine and you have a meal fit for anyone who plans on eating themselves into a coma. This doesn't even take dessert into consideration, with the absolute best profiteroles I have ever had. Bonus tip for those of you still reading: get a round of scotch (or two, in my case) with the profiteroles. Not only will the sweetest bartender in the world deliver them, but you will find out that this is a combo no one can beat without some serious effort.
Speaking of the sweet staff, everyone working here is an undercover angel. I'm convinced of it. I never call out staff in my reviews but our server, Asia, was phenomenal. She not only put up with our relentless questions and my request for scotch after wine and port, but she did it with a level of quick wit that immediately endeared her with all of us. The team here helps each other out, with one girl removing empty glasses deftly and naturally, the bartender delivering scotch with a divine smile, and the food runners polished and focused on their destination. Make no mistake, the reason this place operates as efficiently as it does is because of the immaculate workers under the roof.
Sure, you can knock on them for wanting to turn a table quickly to get the line out the door moving, and you can complain about the limited menu. Doing either of those is providing a grave disservice to this establishment, a hearty dining option filled with delicious food, professional staff and a diverse enough dessert menu to ensure you need to come back. And if this is your first time eating here, I genuinely envy you and what you are about to experience.

After a little confusion about whether this was an all you can eat place (it isn't), a group of 8 of us headed here for dinner while in London. After looking on Yelp I was really worried about just how long we'd have to queue for but thankfully on a Thursday if you arrive around 6 - 6.30, you won't have to wait at all. Score!
We were seated at a large table and they quickly took our orders - I mean, super quickly. The only thing available is the steak and chips (with a salad to start) and they simply ask how you want it done. Options are blue, rare, medium and well done. I went for rare as I figured this being their speciality it was better to go for less cooked than over cooked. 
I didn't particularly enjoy the salad starter, to be it was just a normal kind of salad with dressing. There was also bread on the side which again, didn't win me over as it was just a standard kind of baguette. When the steak arrived though, I was in heaven. Lovely and pink with a delicious gravy kind of sauce and a good portion of chips. I quite like that they served your meat in two goes although I'm sure the second portion that was served to me was my workmates order of blue steak as it was a hell of a lot more bloody than my first portion (that being said, I still ate it). 
Service here is weird - they are all aloof and abrupt. I didn't realise we were still in those days of service, I thought that died along with Gordon Ramsay's popularity in the early 2000s. Stuffy, unfriendly service is never going to win me over no matter how good the food is. If the staff were a bit more upbeat and accommodating this place would have been upgraded to 5 stars for sure.

If there is a crowd waiting outside, do not fret! The service is extremely quick. 
If you like steak and frites, come here (because this is all they offer).  The salad has a simple mustard dressing.  The steak is covered in a green sauce that is amazing. The frites are fried to perfection. :)

I visited the restaurant last night with a group of people 
I've been a huge fan of L' entrecôte for many years, I hadn't been since 6-7 years 
Service was poor, the waitress didn't speak or understand much English, the fries were cold and soggy, the meat was cold. We complained & returned the plates. Second time around they were a little better but nothing like 6-7 years ago. It was not worth the 45 min wait outside & I will never go back. So sad I always dined at the L' entrecôte  here and in Paris every time I visited. 
They have become negligent because of their popularity
Worst service have seen in years. Abysmal. Food swimming in dressing. Major disappointment

I was pretty excited to come here because of all the great reviews but it was just ok. There was a huge line and it was crowded but I don't understand why.
 The menu is just steak and fries with no variations at all. My husband didn't like it at all because the steak just tastes like the sauce, and he is a fan of the true taste of the steak itself which a good chef can bring out. He also didn't like the sauce that much. I like sauce more than he does so I didn't think it was so bad, but it still wasn't anywhere near as great as these reviews make it out to be. It was just a steak that was slathered in an okay sauce and as long as you like that sauce you'll be fine, because that is what everything tastes like.  Not bad but nothing special.
The moment we walked into the space we knew it was going to be a great experience. Delicious food, nice atmosphere.  Loved it.

Respect for a place that can make it their business to serve just one entree. There's no "choose from the menu" situation. You're served a plate of salad, a plate of steak and fries, and then another plate of steak and fries.
Steak is a food people are pretty picky about and this places manages to sell only steak and also do it successfully. You can get your cut done any degree of rare-ness and it is properly executed.
The merengue tower dessert is also quite good.
I realize it doesn't sound as classy but it might be more pronounceable (and also straightforward) to call this place Steak, Steak, Frites.
Having visited in Paris as well I can say these people have their stuff done!

Came for dinner with a friend - plan was to eat around 8:30 PM on a Wednesday, but the line was insane, so we went to the pub around the corner, had a pint, came back and the line was gone. We were seated promptly and put in our orders. I was a little hesitant to go to this place as I like my steak a certain way (blue - as in, almost still alive) and it almost always disappoints in the UK (because a steak ordered blue in Britain often comes out as medium rare or even medium - ick! And British people get twitchy if you send food back in restaurants, so it really is rolling the dice). But my friend really wanted steak and this seemed like a good option in the neighborhood.
As others have noted, there are no menu choices - only desired level of doneness for steak. I ordered mine blue. We also got the house Bordeaux, which paired nicely with the food. When the steak came out, it actually was blue! Success! But the plate was so ripping hot that it was starting to convert the beautiful bloody meat to a grey overcooked mess, so I had to be uncouth and evacuate it to the bread plate. The server gave me a "wtf" look and I tried to explain, but she didn't speak English, so they probably just thought I was a weirdo, but whatever. That's better than ending up with overcooked steak.
Overall, it was a reasonably good dinner, but for £24, I could make myself better steak frites. Nice atmosphere, though. I'd say it's worth it if you want a simple, pretty good meal, but it's definitely not worth waiting more than a few minutes. If the line is long, probably better to find someplace else.

This is my favourite restaurant - though the original in Paris trumps this one, bien sur. The food is the same, just as amazing, but the atmosphere is not quite the same as in Paris. They probably treat you a bit nicer here, and ain't nobody got time for that. From the baguette to the walnut salad (the vinaigrette is divine) to the steak-frites with the extraordinary secret sauce, accompanied by the house white or a flute or two of champagne - leave me the hell alone because I'm officially in heaven. 
No seriously, piss off. Ommmmmm...

Le Relais de Venise is the centre of the steak world. There is nothing to decide here, no options, you can either order the steak frites or you will be asked to leave. Seriously, the surly waitresses will throw you out if you don't order the steak frites. You can however, select if you would like your steak cooked blue, rare, or medium.
So does Le Relais de Venise live up to the hype? Most definitely. I'm still dreaming about the secret "green sauce."   At 21 quid for a walnut salad, some bread and 2 servings of steak frites you can't go wrong. That's right, course 1: salad. course 2: steak frites. course 3: steak frites. So worth a visit.
This place was awesome from the start. A delicious salad followed by steak cooked to perfection, in a crazy good sauce, served with fries/chips. How could it get better? Seconds!!! :)

My husband and I had dinner here with 2 friends on Monday night. The food was fantastic, I love the simple but perfectly cooked menu - and very reasonably priced. Service was prompt and friendly. I thought the house red wine wasn't great (having eaten at the same restaurant previously I remember it being better the first time).
Will definitely go back!

I start this review with a question. Is there a chance for a single option menu to represent a fantastic option for a restaurant? Le Relais de Venise L'Entrecôte proves anyone that this is indeed possible, besides the first impressions. You are probably going to be waiting in a queue in the cold for a good while, but I can guarantee it is going to be worth every second. 
Steak and fries (as much as you want for the later, obviously not for the earlier) with a wonderful sauce that is their big secret. No one knows what the recipe is, but I assure you are going to be willing for more after you finish your meal. I am not much of salad person, so that is why I am not commenting much about it (they serve before the meal).

After all the hype, it was a bit of a letdown for "affordable authentic French food" and it felt a bit touristy. 
My context: At my local taphouse in a collegetown back in America, there is a Monday night dinner special where I can get a similar quality steak with mashed potatoes for $5 (with purchase of a craft beer on tap). So when I heard that this steak dinner would be an amazing deal and the sauce would be what seals it, I expected more.
What I got (everyone gets) for 24 pound deal = 
*To start: a fairly run-of-the-mill waldorf salad (walnuts, romaine, mustard-based dressing) and half of a French baguette, which was soft but cold and I would have liked some butter to go on it. I ended up dipping it in dijion mustard, as there was a jar of it on the table and I liked the kick 
*Supposed star of the show: Two servings of steak frites (cooked only at rare, medium or well, already slice and covered in a mustard-based sauce) - This might sound like the typical (possibly ignorant) American tourist, but I'm not used to already have my steak cut for me and not being able to order my desired medium rare. The sauce also tasted a bit bland to me. The frites were fine - shoe-string so extra crispy. Overall, this was plenty of food but afterward, I felt unsatisfied so I ordered dessert (rare for me!)
Ultimate letdown - the lemon tarts. I was shocked to receive what seemed like grocery chain store quality dessert as they had rock hard crust that seemed to lack sugar and a filling that tasted more saccharine rather than zippy from citrus (which I craved).
With a glass of the cheapest house red wine and gratuity added on to the bill, my dinner ran closer to 40 pounds total. So I suggest to avoid waiting in line, and instead save your money for street or pub food of similar (sometimes better) quality for a quarter of the cost.

Waste of time and money to be honest. Don't believe the hype - go to Entrecôte in any other city but London puts this name to shame. 
Obviously it took long to be seated but that was expected. So was the subpar service. The food was the only thing we were really there for, and it was thoroughly disappointing. We both ordered medium steak and it came pretty much well done and at room temperature. The sauce was average and they provide a lot of fries but a really stingy portion of meat. The salad was the best part but is the equivalent of what a 5 year old can make with basic kitchen ingredients. 
Apparently the profiteroles are amazing but we were both too disappointed to devote any more time or money to this establishment. 
While it is not steak frites, burger and lobster knows how to perfect its dishes while providing outstanding service. What do you know, it seems possible after all.

I don't know what we were thinking when we strolled over at around 7pm on a Saturday night. The line went out the door and around the corner. We waited patiently for an hour. Believe me, it was worth it. 
They've got the formula down to a delicious science, so there's little room for personalization. They won't do your steak medium-rare, for example, and wine list is pretty much "Red or white?" Still, those are minor inconveniences when the result is so satisfying. The one real misstep was the crazy overload of mustard in the salad dressing. 
This location is ideal: on a quiet side street around the corner from Marylebone High Street. The interior can be a bit loud and more than a bit crowded, but it feels lively rather than annoying. The service is pleasant and appropriately brisk. And they'll wrap up your leftover steak if you just can't move on to Round 2.

I am OBSESSED with this place. I believe they have a few other restaurants across London, I've also hit up the one near Bank, which was fabulous as well. 
No menus, no BS. You get a waldorf salad, steak (sorry vegetarians) , chips and the most incredible sauce you will ever taste. You pay a flat rate (I can't remember exactly how much, I want to say £20) and you can basically have as much as you want to eat. The chips are crispy, the steak is super, and again, let me just say, THE SAUCE. You will dream of this sauce for days afterwards. I think there must be some highly addictive substance in it, because I was getting major withdrawals during the hazy weeks that followed. 
The staff are attentive, the wine is reasonable but good, and it's always a buzzy atmosphere. I'm uncertain of whether you can book a table, but normally the wait isn't too long.

Yes, we had the steak. Yes, we had the fries. And yes, it was delicious. 
It seemed hugely touristed - and a warning - there's nothing on the menu besides steak and fries... So go for that and wine in mind, and enjoy!

It's amazing what you run into these days with a simple "French restaurant" google search.
Le Relais de Venise (which I believe to mean "Over from Venice") is one of those cozy little restaurants neatly packed away in London's many streets and alleys. From outside it looks like a classic French cafe, which sits two minutes away from the city's busiest shopping epicenter (bond street/oxford street). 
I didn't have high expectations for this place despite the many glowing reviews my peers had given it; I quickly withdrew my preconceived notions when the meal began.
We arrived at 6:15 pm (15 minutes before the restaurant opens) - mind you, this is a Tuesday night, not the weekend - and the line of eagerly waiting customers was already curling around the corner. I knew I was in for a treat. It was rather funny once we were seated because I picked up the menu card (see photo) and there was literally ONE choice listed: The walnut salad and entrecote with a "famous sauce." I'm a sucker for guarded restaurant secrets and I knew that must have been the reason why everyone frequents it. The meal is split into "first" and "second" service (first and second helpings) and only costs 23 pounds (~$35).. That's like restaurant week prices back in America. 
The salad was quite simple and leafy. As I savored the tangy dijon flavor of the dressing, I took a minute to survey my surroundings. The waitresses were hustling around taking orders and serving customers. The restaurant had filled up in the first 5 minutes and there were already another 100 people waiting outside. 
Our first serving had arrived and it was a perfectly medium-rare piece of tender beef. Entrecote typically comes from the rib side of the cow, but could also be a sirloin, depending on how it's cut. I digress. The meat could have been a little warmer, but then again they were entertaining a full dinner service and the food came in a timely manner. 
The beef was smothered in the most delicious french sauces I've ever tasted. It wasn't a bearnaise as far as I could tell. And I definitely don't think there was any pepper in it. The consistency was somewhat soupy and the greenish tinge must have been taken from an herb. After several tastings, I feel like it might be basil (perhaps an allusion to Venice/Italy?).
