The perfectly cooked steak with a divine herb butter sauce and heavenly fries were each simple, but together like all great meals far more than the sum of their parts.  NOTE: remember this is French, so if you usually like your steak medium-rare, go medium, if you usually go well done (philistine), then ask for it burned....
7.  The price - Awesome... I see someone has had a bit of a whinge in one of the earlier reviews, but I reckon £20 for a two course dinner, paired with £17 fine wine (Making it around £60 for food and wine for 2) is damn fine value!
I will definitely go again, the only question is whether I have to wait until I have an excuse to take someone or whether I will just pop in on my own the next time I walk past... It may well be the second!
Awesome! Awesome! Awesome!

omg amazing. there are no words to describe. some people say it's a bit pretentious (they literally serve one thing: steak and fries) but its damn good. 
i've been here a few times, both with friends and my boyfriend. its just simply excellent. you sit down, they ask you how you want your steak cooked (rare, medium, well). they bring you a salad and french bread, and then bring your steak and fries in two waves.
a few tips:
1.) you have to get here early. it opens at 6:00pm. if you are there before 6:45pm you are fine, otherwise expect to wait in line.
2.) order the house red wine. it's good and the cheapest on the menu.
3.) for dessert, i recommend the profiteroles and creme brulee and if you want an extra treat the dessert wine is also fab.
4.) they do not take reservations so don't even try.
love love love this place.

Novel steak frite joint built Parisian stylee... You have to wait in a queue that evaporates quickly enough.  If you're a group of two you can get in pretty quickly.  Excellent steak (but you can get better, see Goodmans or Hawksmoor), great frite and tasty side salad, feels good value for £20 and normally in and out quickly.  Highly recommended for something a bit different.  Good date place if girl/man/man/girl like meat.

This place is pretty amazing. There's a no booking policy, but they shift people pretty quickly (it's not the place to come for a long drawn-out romantic dinner).
 But OMG the steak. They only serve steak frites, but they do it very well. Best of all? Once you've eaten your yummy dinner, the come back with a second serving. Yep, steak frites twice! I don't know why, but having steak frites twice is going to improve my evening. And I was having a pretty great time as it was.
 They do demi bottles of wine, which is a good thing - if there's two of you, you won't get chance to finish a whole bottle before they're asking for their table back.
 The profiteroles weren't great (ice cream instead of cream) but when you're paying £19 for dinner and you get STEAK TWICE, who cares about the desserts?
 Did I mention you get steak TWICE?

Great food. The sauces a the meat are definitely amazing. The single menu and the great house wine make the ordering process probably the fastest in London. The queue and the price a bit higher than the expected move it down to 4 star.

This is a great place to have a casual lunch whilst at the same time feeling like you're doing something special. This is of course courtesy of the set menu and the tastiness of the food. Of course casual is not in the pricing, but then again, neither is steak-frites with a mystery sauce.
On the sauce: it's good, but not mind blowing; it's not that I've had better, I just don't know if that's as good as it gets.
Overall, nice ambiance, courtesy of the waitresses' uniforms and decor, and a nice place to get a special meal with family or a good friend.

If you can't deal with a long line or only one choice on the menu, this isn't your place. 
But if you love a proper steak frites served with a perfect sauce Diane and a yummy salad, a good wine selection, and many sweets to choose from after, look no further. 
The food is impeccable and exactly what it is supposed to be. If you don't like it, then you don't get it.
Le Relais De Venise is known for its steak, frites and walnut salad.  It's pretty simple but the special sauce is rich and decadent and you get two portions!  It's a very comforting meal.

I have been going here for 5 years and its fantastic. If you like steak, chips and a fabulous secret sauce then this is perfect. Ok, the service is very French but overall, its a great place to go with friends, family, lovers etc. 
The house red is excellent value and the best tasting wine on the list. Fave pud is the gateaux du relais (chocolate cake 2 ways) 
Lastly, dont forget that if you want more sauce, fries or bread, they will gladly bring it to you as its all included.... if you can manage it!

I had high expectations of this restaurant since it was highly recommended by friends who've been to the original Parisian branch (which was unfortunately under renovation when I visited one Summer).
 Alas, I was rather put off by the service (snooty, impersonal French.. it's like being in Paris all over again!) and small portions.
 If you are a steak lover, you'll find the steak decent, but nothing to rave about. My impression was more of a factory production line, where the waiter asks how you want your steak done - medium rare, medium or well done. They then serve you from a tray of pre-cooked meats, rather than prepare your food individually.
 The result can be disappointing, as the meat is at times luke warm, and the standards can vary.
 I was rather incensed that the waiter served me a very small portion of beef, and gave a much larger portion to the couple beside me. We were all paying the same price! Not only that, when we were given the choice of a 2nd (and final) helping, my portions remained small! Call it bad luck, but I was NOT impressed.
 To be fair, they made very good thin cut fries, and you could have as many servings as you desired. But I was hardly there for the fries, and had not intended to fill myself with a stomachful of oily high-caloried potatoes!
 If you're after good steak, by all means try this venue since it's received a lot of thumbs up from other patrons. But I doubt you'll leave feeling much impressed - it's one of those been there, done that experiences. I won't be going back.

When I first lived abroad in Paris I had a challenging time finding, in two words, good grub.  Yo France, stop drowning everything in mayonnaise and cheese. What the hell?  So after munching on baguettes for a month I found three GO-TO places in Paris: a Lebanese restaurant where no one spoke French or English, a breakfast place called Breakfast In America (#1 and #2) and L'Entrecôte. 
I just had dinner at L'Entrecôte in London and it brought back all the fantastic memories of when I used to dine at the Paris location. 
The menu is simple. Sliced steak and fries...and if you want, a second order of the same. A salad to start and wine. You don't have any real choices, which is great when you just want to eat. 
Expect a line, and it's really cramped quarters, but that's a part of the experience.  They don't rush you but expect to get mad-dogged if you try to hang out for more than an hour.

We got there in time to beat the lunch rush and were immediately seated. The salad was OK, but the steak and fries were spot on. And just when I thought I had finished a petite European lunch, the second round of steak and fries showed up, perfectly cooked to order. 
Paired with a few nice bottles of red wine, it was the perfect Friday break for our group.

I know the original in Paris and was excited to see that it made it across the pond. Lovely atmosphere. Great staff and the food is delicious. Definitely worth the long wait. The famous green mustard sauce tastes slightly different from the original in Paris but still very tasty. The red house wine is a lovely treat. And once you had one of those amazing desserts you know you are hooked forever.
Enjoy!!

Words alone cannot express what a joy the food is like at this place. They say when you get older food replaces sex as as the main joy of life...I now know why.....this place should have mirrors on the ceiling....  the food is that good. The price is fair and the house wine is good also.....and oh my god they give you second portions.  I only go occassionally for fear that my love of the dining here may lead to over exursion or public indecency due to over stimulation of my taste buds.

There's no menu at this place, they don't take reservations and only seat you when all of your party are present. But I've got no problems with that, because the food is so yummy. When you sit down, you get a starter salad with walnuts and some bread. Once that's done, you'll be served steak with some amazing sauce and seriously yummy fries. My favourite part is when they come back for a second round and give you more steak and slather it with more sauce. My kind of heaven. Dessert is where you can pick what you want, traditional French desserts like creme brulee, profiteroles or sorbet. I went with the Vacherin, a towering mound of meringue, ice-cream and chocolate sauce. You get lots of jealous looks too.
 Prices are fairly reasonable - all up I paid about £30 (includes 1 glass of wine and dessert). This place makes me a really happy bunny - I couldn't stop grinning like an idiot throughout the meal. Sooo going again.

I came by myself for dinner! That's correct, you read that right.  All by myself while everyone else in line waiting outside for a seat were either in pairs or a group. Pft - yea it's awkward at first but you start to not care after a while. Plus I found this place through yelp..gotta try what my fellow yelpers recommended. It was pretty good..not sure what they hype is though. The salad was GOOD...very interesting wasabi vinegarette..i likey. So not much else to say, set menu for 20 GBP - salad, steak and fries (2 servings), dessert will cost u more than the set 20 GBP, but none of them were more than 5 GBP.  (I had good creme bruelee - perfect for one). The half bottle wine that I bought...not sure it's what everyone says it is..it's ALRIGHT..but not great for 9 GBP. meah.
Hey..my first London review! yes!!
Awesome and different. It loses one star for only letting you choose Rare, Medium and Well. No medium-well etc. But the desserts are to die for and it's a very unusual experience. Highly recommended.

Wonderful.  Delicious steak frites and a green salad with a mustard vinaigrette are basically your only choice.  Service is business-like but not unfriendly.  It's an appealing setting and great food.  Well worth a visit!

Original (no menu), good (decent meat in London), exotic (French), the deal is clear and most people will like it.
 If I may say:
 - £20 for steak should include a glass of wine. If they dwelve on their French style, the wine is missing.
 - it's not the best steak you can eat. Come on, guys, are you American or what ? It's good, not exceptional.
 - on Friday and Saturday evenings, there is a queue outside. It can take you more than half an hour to get in...
 Don't go there with your girlfriend, but with your mates :-)

Having looked at many of the reviews I felt an urge to put fingers to keyboard. I lived in Marylebone for sometime and was always very surprised by the ques of people waiting to eat here. If you are a steak fan and looking for great meat this is not the place to go. The meat is ok, covered in a "secret" special source that I managed to knock up my kitchen 2 days later to as near as perfect. The service is ok, but they are a high volume restaurant, dont expect to stay to long! They do, what they do, very, very well but I still dont understand the endless Ques! What is more surprising is that directly opposite you have what is widely regarded as the best fish and chip restaurant in London, the Gun hidden behind the high street and the Autre Pied 2 mins away, which in my book knock spots of this place.... Oh and its not that im ignoring the providores its just that if you dont want to Que for dinner then I wouldnt go (sunday breakfast used to amazing, then the papers ran an article on it and you now Que for hour to get)... Start at the Prince Regent and have great night in my old manor!

This place has the same business model as a restaurant in Geneva - Le Relais de l'Entrecote - and it seems just as popular. We went on Tuesday night this week and as the desciption says all they do is walnut green salad to start and then steak and frites for the main course. Its superb, served in two portions for £19. When we left they were q'ing out of the door.
Average. 2 hour wait for small sliced up steak! I'm a South African and I know my meat....I wont be going back for it. Way too expensive.

You cannot find better steak than at this restaurant. Although slightly pricey at just under £20 per head for a meal (not including drinks), it is well worth a visit or two or three! The staff are extremely efficient, sometimes friendly, sometimes not, but that doesn't matter when your meal arrives. There is no choice about what you eat. You start with an amazing green salad, followed by steak, chips and sauce, followed by seconds of steak. There is however a choice of puddings, all equally delicious. This has to be one of my favourite restaurants in London.

First you get a salad, then the only thing you tell the waiters is how you wish your steak to be cooked you are then presented with half of your steak and when you finish that your waiter brings the rest of it, this is complimented with chips and their authentic steak sauce. A beautiful restaurant right in the heart of marylebone village and a must for steak lovers!

A very unique experience and food! No real menu, No reservations and only able to to be seated once all the party is present! You may think it will be a mistake visiting this restaurant, however, I can assure you the opposite is true!! You start with a decent Walnut salad but what really makes the visit more than worth while, is the Steak which is cooked in an amazing sauce, along with the best pom frites you can get anywhere in London! I promise, you will be licking your fingers afterwards!! They also have very tasty dessert list (alebit a small one) to finish of the evening with. This restaurant is simply the most addictive restaurant I have been to in London and there are only 4 of them worldwide, including Paris, New York and Dubai. I have also been to the one in Paris and it is exactly the same in terms of food testiness and set up! Cannot recommend highly enough!

This place is cute and delicious!! I came with my boyfriend and we each had a bowl of ramen as well as the fried chicken to share. It was all yummy.
The service was relatively quick and the ambiance is casual and fun :)
One of my favorite meals while I was traveling!

One of the best ramen I've ever had. It beats a lot of the ramen places I've been to in New York. The spicy yozu ramen is SO GOOD. The noodles were the perfect texture and the soup didn't taste like it was full of MSG. When I went the line was crazy long, but there's a reason why people wait that long to get in. Honestly if I had to wait that long on line again I would. Wish I could've gone back at least one more time before leaving London.

Dubbed one of London's top ramen shops, I can only think of one word to describe Kanada-Ya: underwhelming. 
Perhaps it is London's pre-eminent ramen shop with lines flying out the door. Across, you'll find Ippudo, a world-renowned ramen chain that has hours-long waits in its NYC shops, sitting slightly emptier. Has Kanada-Ya taken the throne away from them in London? Maybe.
I waited about 15 minutes on a Tuesday night. It is a very small, quaint corner restaurant that can fit less than 40 people. As I was approaching the from across the street, I could already smell the heavy truffle aroma from their popular Truffle Ramen from the swinging door. The patrons leaving, too, smelled like truffles as they dashed past me. Being a truffle fanatic, I was so pumped for the Truffle Ramen.
I'm no ramen expert but this was far from the best ramen I've ever had. You might like this if you like light broths, but it's not creamy at all. The truffle oil felt more like it was there for the smell, and maybe some flavor. The pork was a bit on the dry side and took me awhile to get through. For the most expensive ramen on the menu (£14), I wish they'd included a Hanjuku egg or something because it felt...plain. Kanada-Ya is definitely overhyped. I can't speak for Ippudo in London, but I try to avoid it altogether like a plague since it's overhyped in NYC. London doesn't seem to have a very competitive ramen scene and that's sorta sad, given how many trendy Japanese restaurants there are in the area, I might as well have just gone to Japan Centre.

It's kinda sad if this is the best ramen that London has to offer. I got their classic Tonkotsu X which was very very plain. The noodles were too thin and the broth didn't quite any punch. I should've ordered an egg to go with it, but the side black garlic sauce was a good choice.

I gotta say. I was kind of disappointed with the ramen here. Maybe it's my picky New York tongue, but I expected better out of supposedly London's best ramen restaurant.
I got the Tonkotsu and the char siu don. The Tonkotsu broth was good. It salt level wasn't too high, and it certainly packed a punch! However, the noodles certainly let the meal down. It lacked that special pizzaz that great ramen-yas have. 
The two redeeming factors were the meat and the char siu don. The meat was absolutely amazing; so soft like I was eating clouds. It was juicy and OMG my mouth is now watering just thinking about it. The char siu don (using the same meat) was equally as good. 
As weird as this sounds, if I go back in the future, it would definitely be to just crush three of those char siu dons.

Great place to grab ramen on a cold evening, but not a place to go if you're in a rush, because of the wait. Once you're in the door, everything is quick to come and fresh! I had the spicy yuzu ramen and some karaage japanese fried chicken. Big portions, so I couldn't eat it all. Both were awesome! I would definitely come back.

From the reviews, best ramen in London. Not surprised as it was quite good. First off, it is a small place and they don't take reservations. Be prepared to wait in line (no wait list to sign up). There's a bench outside and they provide small cups of tea sometimes while you wait. The turnover is quite fast so don't be too intimated by the amount of people. 
The food comes out ridiculously fast. I got the only in London ramen and my husband got the truffle. The ramen is pretty bare bones in terms of toppings. If you want anything like an egg or garlic oil it's extra. You can pick your noodle toughness which is nice. Portion is just right so you can order something else. The broth is really thick and flavorful. I personally enjoyed the charsu and I normally don't.  
Karaage was pretty good. 4 pounds for three decent sized pieces. Nice crispy outside and good sauce. 
Not the best I've had but it was pretty good. If I was a local I would come back but not often given how expensive it is.

Great ramen option in London. We were swayed by seeing the line when we were initially planning to go to Ippudo across the street. The line moves pretty fast. Be ready with what you want to order before you get inside. You could always grab a beer at the convenience store next store and have it while you wait. 
Ordered the spicy yuzu which actually had a good amount of heat with the soft boiled egg which you must add to any ramen you get. I would even budget more stomach room for more eggs! Also ordered the chasu with garlic oil and egg. Both were amazing with hard noodles. The noodles are thinner than most ramen places. The chicken katsu was the perfect amount of salty and crunchy. Definitely filled my ramen craving. Also pretty large portions so be sure to budget stomach room.

Nothing special, and I still needed to wait in line for 30 minutes.
I hail from San Francisco where we have a very competitive ramen scene. After eating at Kanada-Ya, I have to say that if this is the best that London has to offer, I feel really bad for people who live in London. 
I decided to come to Kanada-Ya at the last moment, so when I got there about 15 minutes after they opened, there was already a line of about 20 people waiting to get inside. I waited about 20-25 minutes and was allowed inside. Because we were given menus while waiting in line, before I even sat down, I placed an order for the tonkatsu X ramen with noodles cooked hard, umeboshi onigiri and the chicken karaage. I figured that if I was only to come once, I was going to order everything I wanted to try. 
The food came out relatively quickly. The chicken karaage came out first and was the highlight of the meal (that's sad considering that the ramen is supposed to be the highlight). It was crispy, very well seasoned, and the dipping mayo was very good. I highly recommend you order this when you are here. It was a reasonable portion for the price. 
The ramen came next. I prefer the thicker ramen noodles, and these were the thin kind. The broth didn't taste very special. They claim that this broth takes a really long time to develop, etc., but it really doesn't taste like 20 hour (or however long) broth. There were no complex flavors that you would come to expect from a broth that took so long to make. The char siu was pretty good, but when I eat ramen, I expect the broth to be the highlight. 
I don't recommend the umeboshi onigiri. I grew up eating umeboshi and they give you the large, cheap, sour kind, not the expensive honey somewhat sweet and sour kind of umeboshi. Sure they were big, but definitely not worth the price. But honestly, what did I expect from a place that specializes in ramen.
If there is a line for this joint, I recommend going to the Ippudo across the street with no line. There is no reason for you to stand outside in the freezing cold (if it's winter) for 20-30 minutes to eat a bowl of subpar ramen. My friend did try this place out before me, and suggested I not go because this was nothing special, but I didn't listen to him because I just love ramen.

Great ramen with a decadent and rich tonkatsu broth. Noodles were also al dente and perfect amount of tender chasu pork. Only issue was the lack of air conditioning! Slurping ramen in a 80 degree room was not fun hahhaha

After living in the Netherlands for a few months, I was craving ramen like no other. I tried to get it in Switzerland (major mistake, their ramen was from the instant ramen packages from the supermarket) and then tried it again in the Netherlands for brunch (also mistake, the noodles were soggy and the broth/meat had no flavor). So when we were going to London for a weekend, I decided that ramen would be our first meal. 
Kanada-Ya doesn't take reservations, so we got there around 7:45 and there were about 6 people waiting outside the store. We got seated in about 20 minutes which was much better than I expected. I got the truffle ramen and my boyfriend got the Tonkotsu-X, and we split a chicken karaage. This was too much food for the both of us but I really liked the chicken (not overly fried or oily). My ramen was good, but not amazing. I love truffle but I actually didn't really like it in my ramen, but the Tonkotsu-X was great. The ramen also doesn't come with an egg so make sure to add one if you want! They recommend you get the hard noodles which were perfect to me. 
Overall, great ramen spot in London.

Quite a delicious ramen place. From the reviews, I guess this must be one of the best ramen houses in London. I've been to ramen places around the world from Tokyo to San Francisco, Kanada-Ya is probably somewhere in the middle on my list of great ramen places (still pretty good!)
The seating inside is quite tight but that's pretty typical of ramen places. The broth they use is a classic and you can tell that they brew it for over 10 hours with pork. I absolutely love this style of heavy broth, it gives the ramen a richness that is quite unique compared to other styles of noodles. The chasu is decent but nothing that floored me.
All in all, a decent place for a bowl noodles. It is quite expensive but that's expected in the heart of London. If you need ramen in London, this is probably the place to be (as evidenced by the rave reviews and long lines).
Possibly best you can have in London. Qualified evwn for Japanese. However please surely come to Tokyo for much better ones. Forget Ichiran or Ippudo

Very good ramen and queuing is worth it, doesn't take too long anyways. Chose the Tonkatsu with black garlic oil, which had to pay extra for. 
Also had the chicken karaage, which was very crunchy on the outside and chicken was moist. Highly recommend! 
Overall delicious taste. I would've given it five stars but only four stars as had to pay extra for the black garlic oil as well as a portion of the eggs on my bowl of ramen. I would go back, but not quite in a hurry.

Amazing ramen but you will end up waiting a long time if you arrive at peak hours. Service is also great and friendly and I would agree with other comments that probably best ramen in London . We are now regulars here and have learned when to be there to avoid the queue

Kanadaya does the best ramen in the UK! Try avoid 1-2pm or 7-8.30pm slot as you will most likely be queuing for their seats. Early lunch like 12.30pm or early dinner at around 6.30pm are always good time slots with no queues. 
Even though their speciality is added truffle oil, I find the truffle oil smell a bit too thick and strong in noodle soup or with the edamame beans. My favourite dish is their Tonkatsu x with 'hard' noodles (yes, you can customise your noodle!). No matter how many times I dine at Kanadaya, I can't get enough of their noodles and I will always be back!
The Ramen here is simply amazing, the best I've had. I tried both the spicy options at different times, and they both have a good level of spice, while maintaining great flavor.

Hi. We really liked this little place. There was a fast seating line - true to ramen houses.  We all had different ramens and I loved my chashu ramen. We also got a side dish of chashudon and the rice under the meat was so good.  
I think everyone wants to go back.  So far we've tried a dumpling house, fast Japanese food and Indian in London and surprisingly it was not good.  
So glad we found this little chain

The broth is kinda light, and mixed with noodle's smell. Go there 5 minutes before they open and avoid lining up.
Unfortunately, I can't finish their ramen because the strange taste of the broth.
The spicy yuzu ramen was so delicious I had a dream about after eating it. The spicy, savory, tangy flavor was insane. Loved every bite of it! This is my new favorite ramen spot!!

Cute little ramen shop on the corner of St. Giles High Street.
Can only speak to the experience of making a light and early lunch out of a few side dishes, the chicken karaage (small portion for £4) and the truffle edamame (large portion for £4). I went there with the intent of having a nice bowl of ramen, but they were out of char siu, which doesn't make much sense for a ramen house since char siu is such an integral part of the dish in general. Every single one of their bowls contains char siu, and the Yelp photos suggest hearty portions, and to not have it available is like saying they're out of ramen broth or noodles, hence my reasoning for just ordering a few sides at that time.
When time came to pay the bill, I was told by the staff that if I want to ever dine there again, I have to order ramen. Okay, that makes sense, and I came with the intent of having ramen but decided against it since I would be paying full-price for a meal that lacked an integral part of its essence: the thick slices of char siu. So it was a little off-putting to be blatantly told this. 
Next time, I'll probably opt for a different ramen joint in the area with better prepared karaage and one that would have char siu in stock.

Pretty authentic Kyushu Tonkotsu Ramen, definitely one of the best in London. The broth could be heaven for some and too thick for others.
I've been here for many many times so you know how good it is.

Yes!  Finally, I have found it after eating hundreds of ramen.  The best ramen in London!  This establishment has only tables for about 24 people.  I suggest coming here early to ensure you are the first 24 go get in the door first.  If not, you will need to wait for one (or more if in a group) to finish the first round before the line starts moving.  The queue here is definitely long especially on a weekend.  I arrived 20 minutes before it opened and there were already at least 20 people queuing.  When it was time to open, I guesstimated that there were about at least 60 people waiting in line.  You definitely need to come early or you will have to wait in line.  
This place is a no fuss, quick and efficient place with a quick turnaround like a pure ramen bar in Japan.  The menu is also very short so you will already know what you want by the time you sit down.  I suggest when you sit down, order straight away.  They expect you to eat and leave so best not to hang around too long.  I got in alone bang on at 12noon and out 20 minutes after.  That's how quick it was.  
The noodles was cooked to your liking and this is what I love about this place.  I suggest the extra hard noodle so it is 'al dente'.  A lot of other ramen place has the noodles cooked too long and soft which is not what I like.  The broth is simply the best in the city and it leaves you wanting more.  Rich, creamy, smooth and so much flavour.  Do not bother with the sides as they are not worth it.  Just go straight for the ramen.  Make sure you get the mayu and marinated eggs together with your ramen.  Oh the eggs, so good and I usually have 2 of them instead of one.
The ramen here is definitely worth the wait for no doubt.

This place specializes. Pork ramen is their thing. The menu is basically 1 pg, and that's for the best, because what they do, they do very well. Come here if you love ramen, pork, and dedication to craft. Don't come here if you give a shit about fancy decorations. Was hot and steamy inside like a bowl of ramen. The front window looks out onto a much fancier, much more expensive Japanese restaurant called Ippudo. Pretty sure this is the way to go though. Compliments to the chef.

Good ramen. Nice portion size and filling. But not sure if it merits the 30 CAD price tag per bowl. Service is friendly enough. 
No reservations. But there are benches outside. 
Repeat: Perhaps.

I love the Truffle Ramen.  My second trip to London this year and I had to order this dish again!  I would say they have my favorite broth.  However, I wish they can do soft boiled Instead of hard boiled egg. My son got the spicy Gekikara ramen, which he also thoroughly enjoyed. The chicken karaage was also excellent.

Hands down, best ramen in London. Better than ippudo or shoryu. The broth is the real deal. Love the thin ramen noodles. The different flavors you get with tonkotsu x, yuzu and gekikara broths are so satisfying in their own ways. Tonkotsu x has a nice creamy taste and not too rich like some other places. I was able to finish the broth. Yuzu has that extra kick in it with a slight citrus (note: not lemon or lime.) More of a tart, pepper zesty taste. It cuts through the richness of the tonkotsu broth. Perfect for me. My fiancé had the gekikara and wow. The minced beef adds a deeper taste of beef to the broth. I think I have to get it the next time I go. 
I was able to come here twice on my trip. First time I had tonkotsu x and fiancé had yuzu. Second time I had yuzu and he had gekikara. Next time I'll have gekikara and he will have..??? :) probably spicy miso!  
Also I'm usually not a fan of chicken karaage. Actually I don't like it at all. BUT I tried it and it is better than most other ones I've tried. Not oily and very crunchy. Their onigiri also comes out hot! Very homey in the winter time.

Ok so im a Japanese ramen aficionado. In California I have been to all the top Japanese ramen spots.. This by far is the best i've had. Put it this way Ippudo is right across the street and I did not go there. Why? Because a line started to form before they opened so I walked over and started speaking to the locals and they said by far Kanada-Ya was better and I have to agree. This broth is so rich.. The broth is simmered with pork bones for 18 hours and you can really tell. 
I ordered the classic and just added eggs which were perfectly cooked, you know what im talking about, that dark yellow runny yolk in the center mmmm. It was perfect for the chilly 40 degree weather in London. Im a westerner I use fahrenheit so excuse me lol. I also got a side of spicy miso and added a little to spice it up! 
Kanada-Ya you guys know how to cook up a bowl of delicious, comforting ramen! Definitely recommend!!!

The place is very small and everyone is a bit crumbled inside, plus, there is usually a waiting time. But the food absolutely makes it up. Amazing ramen and fried chicken. 
Service is fine, could be much better. A really good non expensive option for ramen.

I had the fried chicken which was just OK - not something I'd order again. The Spicy Yuzu Ramen on the other hand, was INSANE! So freakin' good. Spicy, with citrus and a buttery lobster-like broth. I ordered the egg add-on which was good, but not a game changer. The odd thing about this place is that they don't have takeaway containers that you can carry leftover ramen home in, so skip the appetizer and come hungry so you can eat every last bit of your ramen. This is a must-return spot.

The Good:
  :: it's a local business!
  :: this place is the real deal. you see tons of asians eating here, and we all know that is instant street cred. :D
  :: they have a simple menu and they do those few items really really well
  :: their ramen is LEGIT. the broth is rich, the noodles are cooked to your preference (soft, normal and firm), the fixins in the meal are tasty and fresh...everything tastes DELICIOUS.
  :: the karaage (japanese fried chicken)...so so so so good
  :: service is friendly
  :: clean and bright inside
The Bad:
  :: it can get CROOOOWDED bc everyone loves this place. prepare to wait in line outside, which can suck if it's really really cold out or if it's raining out. but remain steady bc the wait is worth it!!!!
  :: very small...not good for crowds at all. think you or you and another person, that's it.
The Ugly:
  :: none
Would I go back? A thousand times yes!!!! For an authentic ramen house, you won't go wrong here, I promise.
This place is IN.

I love Ramen. Whenever I have the opportunity to try out a new ramen spot, I go for it, so naturally, I couldn't just leave this one out. Having read a lot about this restaurant I wasn't sure what to expect and whether it would be the real deal or just a massively overhyped tourist-trap. Now that I've been there, I do believe the hype.
The first thing that caught my attention was the line in front of the restaurant, which is perfectly normal in Japan but rare to come across in the West. Like in Japan, you are handed the menu in advance so you can already decide on what you want before getting a seat as the line moves rather quickly. We opted for a classic Tonkotsu Ramen, a spicy Yuzu Tonkotsu and some Karaage (fried chicken) as a side.
I wasn't sure what to expect from the Yuzu Tonkotsu but it was absolutely delicious. The acidity added by the Yuzu was just right, combined with a hint of spiciness it nicely balanced out the fatty broth, adding a little freshness to an otherwise hearty and earthy dish. While the soups were stellar, what really stole the show was the Karaage. Coming with Yuzu-flavored mayo and a slightly spicy batter, the fried chicken was modeled after the flavor profile of the spicy Tonkotsu, which worked great. The meat was super juicy, and perfectly cooked through while the spices didn't distract too much from the chicken itself. Probably the best fried chicken I've had in my life.
If you like Ramen and you're in London, I'd highly recommend giving this one a try.

Super tiny ramen shop located right across the street from Ippudo and likely to have a queue during peak lunch and dinner hours. I came here at 1:30-2:00 pm on a weekday by myself and didn't have to wait which was awesome.
It's easy to make a decision on what to order since they don't have a very extensive menu. They make a few things very well. They serve some karage, some other appetizers, and 4-5 types of ramen. I got the Tonkatsu ramen, added some spicy miso paste (which came in a spoon so you could control how much you wanted to add), and added an egg. I like that you can specify the texture of the noodles (hard, medium, or soft).
The broth was rich and flavorful, and the noodles were perfectly al dente, and it was certainly one of the better bowls of ramen that I've had. But having just eaten at Ippudo in NY the week before, I just preferred Ippudo a touch more. I'd wait for this ramen again for ~30 min, but not sure I'd wait 1+ hour for this. Perfect for a grey, cold, blustery day. My total for the ramen, spicy miso paste, and egg was £16 so it's not exactly cheap, and it seemed to be smaller than the Ippudo NY ramen I had.
Come solo or with only one other person, and be prepared to eat communally at the bar or a long table. The space is small and fits only ~30 people, so if you have a party of 4+, go elsewhere!
I'd say it feels like a typical Japanese ramen place. Ordered the Tonkotsu X and the noodles tasted okay (pretty thin noodles) and the broth was pretty good.

I thought the ramen here was well worth the wait (approx 30 minutes during dinner time)! I had pretty high expectations for this place, as it came highly recommended, and it didn't disappoint. I had the tonkotsu x, and my friend had the spicy yuzu. Both were great. Quite a small space, so don't expect much wiggle room.

We continued our venture of Ramen in central London and we went to their original branch.
The menu is as small as the restaurant, with a choice of only 4 types of ramen. As we went as a party of 4, we got to order all of them to try.
Original Ramen (£10.50) - The Original Ramen at Kanada-Ya forms the basis to all their ramens and what you see is what you get! A generous portion of ramen noodles served with an 18-hour pork bone broth, topped with slices of chashu pork belly, wood ear fungus, nori (seaweed) and spring onion. The menu also says there's a secret sauce in this, not sure what it was, but it definitely tasted great! The broth was intense and full of flavour. The slices of chashu pork were melt-in-your-mouth tender. All the different toppings not only made the bowl of ramen pretty, they also added to the overall flavour and texture. If you like the simple things in life, then you won't go wrong with this Original!
Moyashi Ramen (£11.50) - the Original Ramen, topped with steamed beansprouts. This is one for those of you that like a bit of veg in your ramen. The steamed beansprouts were just cooked, so they still had a bit of crunch to them.
Chashu-Men (£13.00) - the Original Ramen, but instead of the pork belly slices, you get massive pork collar slices. The pork collar had just the right amount of fat, evenly distributed across the meat. Which means it was super tender, but also had a bit of bite to it.
Gekikara Ramen (£13.00) - Served with spicy 'tan tan' style minced pork and pork belly chashu. This is perfect for those that like a bit of a kick in their ramen. As you can see, it's pork mince, with pork belly slices, in a pork bone broth. So this is pretty porky! The spiciness isn't too overpowering, so you can still taste all the different levels of flavours from the ramen.
We also had a side dish of Karaage (£6.50) - which were deep fried chunks of chicken, served with creamy Japanese mayonnaise. These were super crispy and moist. The seasoning was in the coating and on the chicken itself. So we could tell they were freshly cooked for us. Extremely yummy and a must try if you come to Kanada-Ya. We think they would've tasted even better if they were spicy tough.
Although the ramen was nice, the broth could've been more intense. We also felt that the ramen needed the additional toppings of the pickles, garlic and sesame to really bring it to life.

THE BEST RAMEN IN ALL OF LONDON! 
Sorry for the capitals, but it's true! You won't find a better Tonkotsu Ramen in London than the selection you'll find here. I found myself as a bit of a ramen fanatic this passed year... Trying all the varying ramens in London (I have a lot under my list now!).
I almost always for go the Tonkotsu or Chashu Men Ramen. The Chashu comes with more pork than the Tonkotsu, but is slightly more expensive. The taste of both as fantastic. Always get Hanjuku Egg to accompany your ramen, the way Kanada-Ya boils these eggs is amazing.
To accompany this incredibly tasty ramen I always have a Calipis to drink, and Salmon Onigiri and Karaage as sides. 
Seriously, there is no better ramen in London. You MUST come here.
Tonkotsu ramen X is quite like what I've had in East Asia. All in all, good place to enjoy some delicious ramen.

After 2 Museum walks, We were looking something different, We saw Ramen and walk to this small place to give it a shot, Well is really good, We ate Tonkotsu and was deliciuos. Packed with flavor, I add the spice red sauce and then it really came to life.

We originally wanted to visit Ippudo that was across the street. But after talking to my friend who lives in London, we decided to visit Kanada-Ya, as she said was much better. I'm very glad we did! We came on a weekday evening at 8PM, and there was still a wait outside. The place isn't huge but they utilized the space very well to maximize the number of people they can seat. We got an order of karaage to share, along with a bowl of ramen for each. They also serve onigiri, but it would've been too much food for us. I told my boyfriend that the ramen was comparable to the ones we had in Japan. And afterwards, I found that they actually do have stores in Japan! Anyways, super solid ramen place. If you're in London and want some authentic ramen, this is the spot!

Hands down, one of the best ramen eggs I have ever had in my life. The yolk had a great consistency, not too runny, not overcooked.The ramen they serve are the thinner ones, so if you're a fan of thicker chewy ramen, you might not like this place. I had their Chashu ramen, and it came with 4 slices of chashu which was great. Overall, I have absolutely no complains about this place. Although the queue gets rather long during peak hours, I think it was worth the wait.

Good ramen - excellent ingredients, fresh condiments (esp. freshly grated garlic when we went) which you can add as you wish, and they master their yolky eggs to perfection. We found that the broth maybe lacked a little bit of flavor - but that's probably because we are used to more soja-y or miso-y flavors in France (and most ramen shops propose different broth flavors, which you choose from when ordering your ramen). 
Note that it is a bit expensive: £10.50 for the most basic version, £13 for the version with more pork of better quality, £2 for an egg, plus 10% service charge - free tap water though.

If Yelp would let us post just one word, then that is what I would do....scrumptious!  I have tried other Ramen spots in London, and no one can compare to Kanada-Ya (all their locations).  The flavor of their broth, their perfect noodles (my entire family prefers the hard noodle), the sauces, fried chicken, beer...all amazingly tastey.  We have tried every one of their ramen offerings and not one of them disappointed.  Typing this now I am actually salivating...I just may have to run over there for lunch today.

I finally built up the patience to get in the Que for this place.... For over a year now I've had my eye on it waiting for the hype to die down and a chance to have the famous ramen without the infamous pre-que!.. but today I realised it was never going to happen and I'd have to que like the rest of the world. In fairness it wasn't that long a wait (maybe 20mins)
Once inside you see the reason for the line.... It's really small. Comfortable but small. To maximise the seating, you will probably have to share a table. If your a group of 3-4 be prepared for a longer wait and bigger groups..... At your own peril!!!
The Ramen... This is what it's all about! The standard product is as good as the reviews make it out great broth, good noodles (choose how they are cooked) and great additional ingredients. Make sure you read what comes as standard though as I didn't and it meant I missed out on the egg (in most other places this comes as standard) I couldn't be bothered to order it after the ramen arrived . Btw, it comes out quick!! We also had a side of carage chicken, not the best but ok.
The service is economicical, but you won't be in there long enough to have any complaints... You may line up longer than you spend inside. They also also add 10% service on to the bill.
The food is good, the place is nice and the price is reasonable in comparison.... But damn, I hate quing!
Delicious ramen. Nothing fancy, just amazing ingredients prepared well. Dropped by after a long day and a big bowl and cold beer perfectly hit the spot.
Spicy uzu ramen was amazing! Truffle is a little overwhelming for the pork broth.  I prefer the OG pork broth.  Our favorite ramen spot in London.

Oooh I do like it when a ramen-plan comes together!!
Kanada-Ya has been advertising in Japanese newspapers for aaages, so I had the soft opening on my calendar for weeks (and my colleagues and I have been drooling at their twitter feed's pictures of perfect Tonkotsu and eggs...) Today was the soft opening, and although it wasn't perfect, it was still pretty damn good.
The Goooooood:
- The soup is rich, thick Tonkotsu and is really, really tasty. I thought this was one of the best Tonkotsu soups I've tried in London. 
- The spicy miso paste was also good. One portion was enough to spice up both of our bowls. Seriously yum.
- You can add extra noodles if you run out and are still hungry.
- The service was really friendly and sweet, despite the madness of people queuing around the block.
The saaaaad:
- Tonkotsu was the only option today. I'm not sure if they'll add more broths later, if not, don't bring veggy friends or non-pork-eating friends.
- Even though there was only one broth on the menu they ran out of looooads of options. I was planning to have an egg and the black garlic sauce, but they ran out before 7pm. Boo.
- They gave us the option of hard or soft ramen. We chose hard, but our ramen were pretty normal (not particularly al dente.) They weren't bad, but they weren't "hard". 
- Hopefully they'll improve the ordering system, as we had to ask for our spicy miso twice, and it took aaages for drinks to appear. We'd finished half our ramen before drinks and miso arrived. Doh!
I think I'll have to come back once they have opened properly to see if it gets even better. For now (as the soup was sooooo good) I'd give them 4 stars for flavour and 2 stars for service.
* It's 50% off during the soft opening, so do go and try it!
* Get there early before they run out of everything!!

We've been dying to try Kanada-Ya, but wasn't about to wait in a queue.  We decided to give Monday at 2:15 PM a try and we were lucky to beat the lunch rush and walk right in!
Food: We both ordered the original ramen (one order with egg) with our noodles "regular".  They ask you how you would like your noodles cooked which is awesome.  We added two original onigiris as well to our order.  The ramen broth was so flavourful and just down right delicious with the perfect noodles.  The onigiris were simple and perfect.
Drinks: We ordered one diet coke and one Japanese lemonade which is their version of sprite.
Price: 29.40 GBP for two people.
Ambiance: The restaurant is very small, but bright and cosy in a good way.   
Service: The service was efficient and very friendly.
Would I go back?  Definitely!  This is my new favourite ramen house in London.  Sorry Bone Daddies and Shoryu, there's a new kid in town.

This is the absolute best ramen I've ever had by far.  The broth is so rich - full of flavor alone. I always ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and add black garlic oil and an extra egg. I'm a huge ramen lover and I've never had a tamago (seasoned egg) as good as Kanada-Ya's. The noodles are firm just how they should be and the pork is very tender. I sometimes get Karaage (fried chicken) as a side and the Elderflower drink as my beverage. The chicken is so juicy and is perfectly seasoned. I'm from California and wish I could go back to London just to eat here again!

So... Most people will rate Kanada-Ya with 5 stars.
I would too. I honestly think this was the best ramen I had since I was in Japan. Better than my favourite Bone Daddies.
So why am I giving it 3 stars?
Well, when you go to Wagamama (yes yes it's a chain but it's a consistent and popular one) you get options for different meat in the ramen, and vegetarian options and such.
When you go to Bone Daddie's you also get these options, and you also have gluten free noodles if you so desire or require.
When you go to Kanada-Ya you spend ages queuing but all you can have is pork ramen. There isn't even a vegetarian option. Now this doesn't hugely bother me, but it does mean that I simply cannot go to this place when I am with a significant proportion of my friends who do not eat pork.
The friend who introduced me to this place told me that ramen is only supposed to come in pork varieties. But I guess she hasn't actually been to Japan, or she'd know this just isn't true.
So yeah, if you want a pork based Ramen, you cannot beat this place. It is awesome. But if you don't want pork, go somewhere else. I recommend Bone Daddies.

One of my favourite ramen place in London! What can I say about the ramen... AMAZING! The broth.. AMAZINGLY GOOD! Can I also add that the broth was properly done?! Not one of those lousy broth where you get watered down nonsense soup made with stock cubes -roll eyes-. The broth made in kanada-ya is made from proper pork bones and meat! Took away one star for long waiting time and the slightly expensive price tag for a bowl of ramen (but still so worth it, but what can I say, I'm not that rich!) 
Kanada-Ya, it's about time you renovate and expand your eatery? Yes please?! Kanada-Ya, you should, you really should.

There are a few things I am obsessed about, and Ramen is definitely one of them. 
I have been obsessed with Tonkotsu ramen since trying it at Bone Daddies 2 years ago, and fed off it in Japan last year. 
And truthfully, the battle for best Tonkotsu in London is VERY TIGHT between Bone Daddies and Kanada-ya - and based on my latest experience with both... I'm leaning more towards Kanada-ya. YES, yes. It was THAT good. 
The problem with the West End is that the cool and funky places are booked up like crazy, so it's always a challenge having an impromptu meal before enjoying a good show.
Don't let yourself be put off by the queue in front of Kanada-ya - and expect one, there will always be one. The venue is tiny, but the the turnaround is pretty quick and you won't have to wait too long (plus, as I said: worth it) 
As I mentioned, the venue is tiny and built in typical Japanese fashion. It's not made for you to come and spend hours with friends chatting, it's made for you to come, sit your bum and eat delicious ramen. The menu is very short, meaning you get served amazing food in a record time. 
Don't be too shy, you'll probably be sitting on a communal table with other people enjoying their deliciousness. 
And now the food. For those I've lost, Tonkotsu is a creamy pork broth based ramen. And broth is what makes the ramen. And that brother was out of this world. I added the garlic sauce as an extra (which really worked) and extra egg - soft boiled eggs are a classic, you can't have a ramen without one. Trust me. 
Price-wise, perfect value. You will be paying less than £15 per person for a meal and drink. 
Soo... What are you waiting for? (Also, please let me come with you?)

Best ramen in London. Period. Pork with a side of pork with added pork and a topping of pork fat. But in a good way. Add perfect noodles, an egg and those lovely wood eat mushrooms and there's your great value satisfying dinner.
This is the original location, there's always a queue but I feel like it hasn't been quite as bad since they opened the new Leicester Square location. The new location is a better place for groups or if you want to linger with friends, but this location is perfect for the crowded noodle bar feeling, I love it

Better tasting than Bone Daddies but really expensive for what you get. And the seating wasn't as comfortable or as inviting as Bone Daddies. And there was no super awesome cocktail menu either.
First impressions were great - 98% Japanese diners. Felt like I was in Tokyo again.
One neat aspect of this 24-seater restaurant is the way they handle their queue of customers. There are two benches outside of the restaurant, positioned end-to-end to create one long bench. If you see people sitting on the bench, then there is a queue, so follow these guidelines to join and "work" the queue: People seated on the bench closest to the door are at the front of the queue and people seated furthest away from the door are at the end of queue. As people from the front of the queue are seated in the restaurant, everyone on the bench slides down toward the door. Don't bother asking the hostess for available tables, just get in the queue.
Secondary impressions were good - diners seemed to be enjoying themselves slurping their bowls and such.
Tertiary impressions were just OK - I found £11.50 for a bowl of Moyashi Ramen a bit too expensive. On a good day, the bowl was worth £8. Why? The lack of pork. There were three small and thin slices, possibly an ounce in total weight. A shame, really.
The broth was good and the noodles were cooked perfectly (forgo ordering Kaedama (an extra portion of noodles) as you likely won't need any. I found there to be too many noodles in my bowl for my liking. 
There were a few condiments on the table, none of which included fresh garlic which was a huge disappointment. I've never eaten ramen without fresh garlic and loads of it.
Service was prompt and attentive, our server even kindly provided me with a fork so I didn't have to whip out my BYOF as I did whilst eating my way through Japan.
Overall, just OK ramen that overpriced.

Best ramen in London. 
Garlic topping + extra bamboo make your ramen even more tasty.
30 mins queuing time expected.
This is probably one of the best places for ramen in London. Worth every penny. Also, be aware that there usually is a line, reservations are not an option.

Was here during a rainy sunday, hence we only had to wait for 10 minutes for a dinner table for two. It was cosy and warm inside. Smell was incredible. Ordered their tonkotsu ramen and sour plum sushi. Note that the eggs come separately from the ramen. This was the first time i see my ramen served in very thick broth. It tasted really good and my meal was completed with the freshness of sour plum sushi. Definitely one of the best ramen spots in london.

This is my absolute go to place for a ramen in London. I almost think this place does not need another 5 star review. I feel that a lot of people already know how good the ramen in this place is. The ramen is excellent. I eat this ramen slow as to enjoy it longer. When I do this, when my bowl is empty, I'm a very happy customer.

Best ramen I had so far (comparing to the London region). I would be rated it among the top ramen places in  Egg was cook to perfection, the chashu was excellent. Right amount of fat and meat. Broth was tasty and rich (with the roasted garlic). The noodles are cooked to your liking. I would give it a 5 star, but there is always room for improvement. Also, I haven't had all the ramen places around the area yet.
Tried the original ramen.

Yes you have to queue and the space is small but quite simply this is the best bowl of ramen noodles in London. 
The menu is small (which I consider a sign of a good restaurant).
They have some benches out the front too which is a nice touch when you get towards the front of the line.

I came by on a weeknight at around 5:30 pm, and our group grabbed the last open table. When we got the menu I was surprised at how small it was, even though they had all the "essentials." I ended up going for the original, and I absolutely LOVED it. This was by far the best ramen I've ever had - the fact that it's the only ramen bowl I've ever completely finished is a testament to that. The noodles were the perfect thickness (thin, which is my personal preference), the toppings/pork were great, and the soup was absolutely phenomenal in its richness and flavor. I will definitely be back.
The only downside is that the place is extremely small - I can see why people before me said there was a queue - and so it feels a bit cramped...but honestly the ramen makes it all totally worth it.

Definitely worth the queue - best broth I've ever had. 
Cool space - mostly communal tables but they're quite wide so it's not awkward at all with other parties being seated next to you. Quick and professional service and a fantastic bowl of ramen - served with thin noodles. Great value will definitely be back.

The egg wins my heart so rich and flavourful. The pork broth was lovely milky, thick and hearty. Charsu pork is a bit too tender for me though. As the broth is extremely hot, you need to quickly finish the noodles before they become too soft. Everything is great but one thing there's a queue all day everyday here.

What a line up!
Very good ramen that's served quickly and piping hot. Perfect. 
Deliciously broth that's extremely rich. 
No sake here. Only Japanese beers.

This place has the bast ramen I've ever tried! I got the ramen with the spicy pork on top (sorry I can't remember the name) for just the right amount of spice once I mixed it all in. The sliced pork on top was the absolute best pork I've had ok ramen. It was so sweet and tasty, like it had been marinated for a long time. I'm weird about meat on ramen, so this is a huge win for me. Actually, I liked ALL the toppings. I ordered the noodles hard, which kept them nice and firm, as it takes me awhile to eat ramen. I also got the chicken karaage, which was AMAZING!! There was a bit of a line when I arrived, but I was seated within about 10 min and had my food 1 min after I ordered. This place is so much better than Bone Daddies, which was definitely a 2-3 star for taste, atmosphere, and service.

Yes, I gave into the hype and stood in line for Kanda-Ya. In attempt to be strategic, I went for a late lunch around 14:00. Even staving off my interest and hunger, I did wait around 15 -20 minutes. I will give the staff credit; they treated seating like a competitive game of Tetris. Eating solo? Don't expect to sit at your own table. In fact, you are likely to end up at a four top with a group of three. Who doesn't love communal dining? 
Who cares, let's get on to the food!
* Sake Onigiri - I know, I know, I was there for the Ramen. It was late, I was hungry! It was a moment of weakness. I would describe it as light on salmon. Luckily, I really (really, really) like rice.  My recommendation, wait for the Ramen. 
* Original Ramen - I thought the fairest way to judge the restaurant was to order 
the OG:
Let's break it down:
o Noodle -The portions were plentiful and the noodles seemed freshly made.  The most genius part is you select the level of al dente that you would like your noodles cooked to.  If you don't like your noodles, that's on you. 
o Broth - Rich and velvety. I like the noodles better, but perhaps you are catching  on to my love affair with empty carbs.
o Pork - Dee-lish! The pork was thinly cut. I find that often thinly cut pork dries out. Not here. The meat was nicely marbled with fat and super moist.
o Overall - Super delicious
* Moyashi Ramen + Egg - My companion was fancier and went for the Moyashi Ramen plus an egg.  From what I can tell, the difference between the Moyashi Ramen and the Original Ramen is blanched beansprouts. To me no person would spend an additional £1 for beansprouts; I stood corrected.  
o The egg - My companion was adamant that the egg is the most important part. This egg was apparently very good. I quote "perhaps even better than Bone Daddy's". She did not offer to share, which could be interpreted as rude.
* Spicy Miso - oh wait... they ran out! I am convinced that a spicy sauce would have taken the broth over the top. 
* Black garlic sauce - it was good, but you know it was no spicy Miso!

Kanada-Ya is hands down one of the best ramen places ever. The first time I walked by, a breeze carried the scent of freshly made noodles (yes that floury, doughy smell like freshly baked bread, except for noodles) right to me, and I knew that I had to go for a bowl of ramen.
I always get the original ramen for around £11. The broth was one of the richest broths I've ever tasted! It tasted like they melted down those pork bones and made it into soup. You can choose the firmness of the noodles, I usually go for the recommended option. The chashu on top is very tender and I like all the other veggies they put on top too. They have this green spicy pickled veggie thing on the side for free and I like to add a spoonful to my ramen for a spicy kick. Sometimes, I split an extra order of noodles with a friend when I finish my noodles but there's still broth left. 
The chicken karaage is also quite good. It was £6 and they give you around 6 big pieces. It's pretty standard so while it was really good, it's nothing extraordinary compared to other places. 
My only complaint is that there's always ALWAYS a line when I pass by (up to 2 hours one time) and there's only around a dozen seats in the restaurant. But that how you know it's good right?

Visited here after a few drinks in the pub a few doors down with friends who had been before. The restaurant is small, and there was a queue but the wait was not long and we had chance to look at the menu while waiting so it was not an issue at all. 
I had the original ramen (without fungus, I am a mushroom-phobe and they were happy to oblige) with the recommended "hard" noodles. The broth was delicious, noodles tasty and I would certainly eat here again if in the area. It's a reasonably cheap, no frills place.

Good grief, or yoi kanashimi, since we're talking ramen. Some Yelpers comments are out of line IMO. That said, I'm giving them a 4 for London (If we were in Japan I'd give them a 3). London is an expensive place to run a shop (and yes!, more expensive than in Tokyo IMO) so £10 for a bowl of ramen is sadly reasonable around here.   
Understand: Kanada-Ya makes Hakata ramen. This is a style that is pork based, has a milky white colour, and is full of delicious, yummy, lip-sticking collagen and fat. And remember, fat does not make you fat, carbs and sugar do. So if you're worried about your waistline why are you even thinking about going out for noodles?
 
Know: Kanada-Ya are specialists at what they do. So no, they don't have a gluten-free vegan ramen and they don't have a bar making green tea lychee 'tinis. If you want that go to Bone Daddies or some silly place like that. 
I should add that I'm really appreciative of a specialist and focused ramen place opening up in London that has the discipline and confidence in their cooking to just do one thing really well, instead of trying to offer 20-different mediocre dishes (ahem, Shoryu somewhat, or that London ramen atrocity known as Bento Ramen). Kudos to Kanada-Ya for focus. I hope this becomes more common here.
/// So the Ramen...
The Overall Bowl and Broth: It's good. It's not my personal favourite style, but it's a decent bowl. Overall I think it lacks punch, but again, they have their style and they are working hard at it. I'm going to experiment with some topping combinations next time and see what I can do to fix this.
 
Noodles: Mine were perfectly cooked to medium. Just like I asked.
Egg: Again, perfectly done. Not as good as Shoryu, but the eggs there are sublime- as good or better than many I've had in Japan.
Charshu: Was adequate. I prefer it saltier, but the texture and fat were very good.
Overall: This place is a welcome addition to London and will force a lot of people to step up their Ramen game. They will also keep Ippudo - who is about to open across the street - on their toes. While the service was a bit spotty, I'm willing to overlook this for now and chalk it up to them being new.

Kanada-Ya is definitely a ramen place worth the wait! There is always a line for it, since the venue is quite small, but the Chashu Men Ramen is amazing. I ordered it with a Hanjuku Egg that was very well prepared as well. The ramen broth is a perfect level of saltiness and savoriness. I usually feel like ramen broth leaves me very thirsty, but this broth was not overdone at all. Additionally, the Hanjuku Egg was very well made in the sense that the yolk was not too dry or too runny. I would definitely suggest this place to any ramen lover!
ADVICE: There will be a line! Bring a coat because the line is outdoors. There will be a coat rack inside where you can hang up your coat when you're eating. Additionally, be prepared to share a table with someone. The venue is very small so you will end up sharing a table with a stranger.

Good broth, exquisite chashu pork, decent toppings but the egg isn't a "wow" like Ippudo's (also the nori leaf has seen better days). Correct noodle hardness. The atmosphere is a bit hole-in-the-wall but it's okay for eat and go situations.

Unpretentious ramen, right across the street from the big 'I'. 
Went for lunch on a weekday and had to queue outside for about 10 minutes before I was able to sit down. There menu is extremely simple. Three choices: original, with bean sprouts, and with pork collar instead of pork belly. Really, they could have done with one menu selection and just had the bean sprouts and pork collar as add-ons. After you choose your ramen you can choose the firmness of the noodles. I ordered mine firm and added an onsen egg. I also ordered a plain onigiri.
First, forget the onigiri. The rice is good, but the onigiri itself is forgettable. If you're still hungry after your ramen, just get kaedama and order more noodles.
The noodles and broth were both excellent. Noodles had a nice, firm bite and the broth was creamy and frothy, without being overly gelatinous. I really appreciated the 5 thick slices of chasiu. Some other London ramen eateries seem to give one or two paper thin slices of chasiu. 
This is the type of ramen restaurant that you go to, eat your food, and get out. Very different experience from other London ramen eateries, but also a very nice change.

I ate at Ippudo and saw the que across the street.  After eating at Ippudo decided to check this place out.  
Went in there with a full stomach and yet I finished my bowl of ramen.  The boil egg was perfect, not too runny or hard.  The broth was Awesome.  
I loved the small cozy vibe.  And the food.  This is going to be my go to place whenever I am in town.

Always wondered about this place as there is forever a line outside of the door, waiting. Deterred by the line, I never even attempted to find out what type of restaurant that was. That was until one day my Japanese friend invited me to check out a great ramen place. When I research the restaurant online, I realized that we were going to that line outside the door restaurant. By then, I was really looking forward to checking it out, because Ippudo, another great ramen place, is right next door and this ramen shop can still maintain such strong following, they must be doing something right! 
I got to the restaurant around 1pm and, of course, there was a line outside. Luckily the line moved relatively fast, and within 15 minutes, we got our seat. This is a great place if you have just one or two people going, any size larger than that, you probably should forget about it. The inside of the restaurant is very tiny, and even with very efficient use of space, the whole restaurant can seat about 20 people. No wonder there is always a line outside. 
The menu is extremely simple: ramen plus choices of toppings and rice balls. I kind of like it. I always have trouble ordering my food when I have too many choices. Here it is simple, order your ramen and how do you like it cooked and add any extra toppings. Go crazy and order a rice ball if you are hungry. I ordered original ramen with Hanjuku eggs. The food came very quickly and, man, that was a good bowl of ramen. The broth was rich and flavorful but not greasy and the ramen was cooked al dente. I swallowed the whole bowl in record time. I felt that I spent more time waiting for my seat than actually eating! However, it is definitely worth the wait.

As a huge ramen enthusiast and broth snob, it is with great honour that I bestow best ramen ever to Kanada-Ya not in Japan. The broth is very well balanced, not too salty, black sesame spice has a great kick. Their service is also very fast, a great quick lunch during the work week. I dream of you..
Yup. you can taste the 18 hours pork bone broth. I had the Chashu-Men I think it is better than the Original.
Good ramen, though slightly fatty for me. Intimate environment and good service! Suitable for group of two. Next time I'll try different hardness for the ramen!

(7.26.15) I've never been to Japan. But I've had ramen in SoCal, NorCal, NYC, and the midwest. Enter London. Kanada-Ya has THE BEST ramen I've ever had. It's telling when Ippudo across the street is EMPTY (this wouldn't happen in NYC!) and there's a line out the door here. It was such a treat on the gloomy evenings in Bloomsbury. Can't wait to go back!

Is a in between 3.5 and 4 start.
I have been there three times now.  They are less busy now compare to newly opening time. The menu is quite simple because they only have a few option which make it simple.  I had tongkatsu once and cha Siew twice. 
When you order you get to order the noodle texture and i like mine regular. The best part of the noodle for me is their egg. Some noodle does not come with egg but you can add the egg with extra £1. Once you finish the noodle you can order extra noodle to add into your remaining soup to eat. I tried it twice now but I felt that it is not as nice. Once the soup get cold you will find that the soup is quite salty and oily.

As a ramen junkie, I've been searching for good bowls of ramen everywhere I go. I had heard amazing things about Kanada-Ya, and many claim that it's the best ramen in London, so naturally, I had to go! Also because I'm a huge fan of tonkotsu broths.
When I got there (around 1 PM on a Monday), there was a short queue, but nowhere near the legends that I'd heard of. After a friendly conversation with my fellow line waiters, I was seated in the restaurant.
To start out, I orderd an ume nigiri. For my main, I ordered the chashu-men with the mayu (black garlic oil) and hanjuku egg. They let you choose the firmness of the noodles; I chose hard because I like my ramen a tad undercooked (al dente?). They use the traditional thin straight noodles, which pairs well with tonkotsu.
The ume nigiri was exactly what I expected, the sourness of the pickled plum perked up my palate and made me excited for the meal to come.
They had some pickled kimchi-esque cabbage and ginger for you to just add to your dishes, as well as a toasted sesame seed grinder (which I of course used, generously).
The ramen came out pretty quickly and looked great. The broth was very good; one of the best tonkotsu broths I've had anywhere, not just London. The mayu was exactly what the broth needed to elevate it to the next level. The egg was a beautiful golden orange, and the slight sweetness of the marinated egg white was great in the savory and rich pork broth. The chashu was tender and melted away, though I would have preferred a slightly thicker cut, with more of a sear.
Overall, Kanada-Ya has one of the strongest tonkotsu broths outside of Hakata for sure, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who loves ramen who is in London. I hope they bring it to NYC soon!

Before I even write anything, I am not going back there again. I have read some good reviews on Ipoudo and I'm hoping that their ramen is just as nice, because the service at kanada ya is absolutely ridiculous.
It was a Wednesday night at around 8:30pm. We queued for over 30 minutes which was fine. However, just as we thought the next table available would be ours, suddenly came two people that was at the Back of the queue and just sat down. We asked what was going on and as I was expecting the Guy to tell those two to get back in the queue, he simply said "sorry there will be a table soon anyway." 
fuming, I ordered my ramen just to find out that they literally have nothing left. No egg, no salmon o nigiri. could the two people that pushed in have taken my last egg?probably.

I love noodles and have been eating them at least twice a week, more so in Japan (at least 4-5 a week).  So I have been looking forward to Kanada-Ya's opening.  Sadly I was totally disappointed with their Ramen.  
We ordered one Moyashi and one Chashu Ramens.  Their Tonkotsu soup was simmered for 18 hours according to their menu and tasted justifiably so; however it simply lacked depth.  It just tasted congealing pork fat/bones with soya sauce and nothing else much.  Adding lots of black pepper did not help.  Good Tonkotsu soup should have different layers of flavours.  The thin noddle was cloggy/starchy; it should have been boiled in a much larger pot and shaken vigorously to remove as much starchy water as possible.  I didn't see the point of Kikurage (Woodear Fungus) as it only gave texture but was bland.  The only good bit was Chashu in Chashu Men; they (Collar) were leaner than those (Belly) used in other two types of Ramen and tasted as good as you get in Japan.
The menu was limited to three types of Tonkotsu Ramen and Rice Balls (Onigiri) and they were way too expensive.  Why the prices of Ramen are so high in London?  You can get very decent ones for around £4-5 in Japan and the quality you find in London does not justify the price tag.  Even in Paris, you can get nicer Ramen for around 7-8 Euros.
Very disappointing.

I'm probably going to write exactly what everyone has already said but here goes...
Amazing ramen! The broth is creamy, flavoursome and rich. The pork was tender and delicious. And the hanjuku egg - wow. Perfection! I ordered an extra egg because it was too good to just have one.
I also ordered the salmon onigiri but would give them a miss next time and go straight for the ramen. They're not bad but it's about the ramen here. 
This little ramen bar gets filled up very quickly and the line forms before it opens so prepare for a wait.
Best ramen I've had in London!!! Seriously. Ramen lovers you must try out this place if you haven't. IT'S GOOD. Enough said just go for it.

Wowzas. Was this place worth the wait.
Even on a bank holiday monday there was a wait. As one of the first to arrive at around 12.20 there was still a 40 min wait, but it was damn worth it. Even though staring through the window at all the delicious ramen was tough!
The place is tiny. I think I counted around 20-25 seats. Two staff and two cooks.
Which was nice as the place had a warm cosy feel to it that would be very nice during the winter months.
I was going to order the standard ramen (there is not a lot of choice here) but my friend pointed out that they do a special which was detailed on the table. So I ordered the Gekikira Ramen, an "18 hour pork bone broth, spicy tan tan style minced pork, charshu belly pork, beansprouts, kikurage, negi" I have no idea what the last two were but it was damn delicious.
Service was quick. And the portions were Good. My previous favourite ramen place Shoryu was always excellent and had you full to bursting. However recently they've cut down on the portion sizes and a super stingy with the toppings.
Not so here, despite being a little cheaper than Shoryu (minus miso egg which isn't included by default, but a topping) they are quite generous with the meat. I got as much charshu pork belly as I normally get in my Shoryu bowl (note that's pork collar however, a bit more expensive) but I also get here a massive portion of spicy minced pork. Additionally from the orders of the pork collar I saw drifting around whilst Shoryu normally gives you 2-3 really thin slices, here they decorate your whole bowl in the stuff, so you get around 5-6 decently sliced pieces. 
The broth I haven't mentioned yet is excellent too. It tastes a lot cleaner and clearer than shoryu. Admittedly Shoryu is slightly more flavourful but oh well you can't have everything. Everything else, in terms of ingredients, quality and quantity are spot on.
Whilst there we also tried the sour plum onigiri. I didn't really like this much but more personal preference than anything. It was presented very nicely and was a decently sized portion. 
The only real improvement I can say is that they REALLY need another location as just thinking of the inevitable queue is making me sad.

The broth is TO DIE FOR. Like I want to die by drowning in this rich milky broth please. As grim as that sounds- that's the most amazing way to go.
Hazel, Iz and I actually popped in here after drinks because we thought drinks and desserts first because ramen is always almost packed and we'd try out luck at ippudo. It didn't work. 9.30 and still an hour and half wait. So we popped over to kanada ya instead for a ten minute wait.
Loved that they offer different textures of noodles! I go for hard and springy (LOL- im talking about bed shopping, take your mind out the gutter) and garlic. And it's so simple and kanada just do it so well. The service was great, especially for hazel's dietary requirements. They were so accommodating! 
Take me back here to bathe in broth,
Please!

Easily my favourite ramen place in London . It's tha place I go to when I want a taste of home.
The ramen is great and the broth is marvellous.
My favourite ramen here is the gekikara-men, since I'm a lover of spice. Best part is they don't hold back and adjust the flavour because of its location in the UK.

A friend suggested Kanada-Ya for dinner after work on one of the hottest days of the year (23 degrees in London!)... not exactly ramen weather but perfect for waiting in a queue! I have always wanted to try it ever since it opened in the fall last year, when I got the invite to the 50% off soft opening but couldn't make it. I have however dined at its rival Ippudo across the street, which is a much more upscale, modern building with a bar area to wait and a cell phone texting service to let you know when your table is ready. By contrast, Kanada-Ya is a lot more like an authentic hole-in-the-wall.  We arrived around 7 PM and took our place in the queue, as the restaurant does not take reservations and it only seats about 25 people inside. There is a nice wooden bench to sit on, and the staff bring out menus for you to look at. The queue also moves fairly fast; there were 5-6 people in front of us to start, and we had our seats inside within 20 minutes.
